definition: cause to feel shame
details: To abase something or someone is to humiliate them — no, more than just humiliate them. If you abase another person you are bringing them low, humbling them in a mean, base manner. Not nice at all.
examples: Why do you need to abase and demean me?
His spokesman Seumas Milne flew to Russia in 2014 to abase himself before Putin and tried to spread conspiracy theories about the Salisbury chemical attack.
And yet when he says, “I am from outer space,” some of you actually shut your eyes, abase your intellects, and believe!
How dare McCain say I am a naïve egotist with a sympathy for autocrats who abjectly abased myself before a tyrant and failed to defend American values?

definition: frivolous banter
details: Stiff corporate types don't tend to be too fond of badinage, or playful conversation, during important meetings, but sometimes a witty joke about the manager's ugly tie is just the right thing to lighten the mood.
examples: Whether she helps or hinders her argument by citing the dream-centric badinage of the Rarámuri tribe of northwestern Mexico is debatable.
So disordered were my nerves from their romping badinage that I did not mark this question was addressed to me.
Also set to be big: silent spas, where you haven’t even got the friendly badinage of your manicurist to distract you from your lack of reception.
You’ll find beatings, shootouts, car crashes, awkward analogies and a measure of buddy badinage in “Bright,” but true enchantment is in short supply.

definition: a clique that seeks power usually through intrigue
details: A cabal is a secret plot, or a small group of people who create such a plot. Some conspiracy theories are based on the idea that governments worldwide are in the hands of a powerful cabal.
examples: Their belief in ideas like “white genocide”, “demographic replacement”, or the influence of a shadowy cabal of “cultural Marxists” leads them to violent action.
Any time a show winds its way into “and there’s a secret cabal!” territory, things get a little iffy, as shows like “Alias” or “Chuck” or “Scandal” demonstrate.

The site's traffic appears to be tanking, which Farah, according to Roig-Franzia, blames on "a supposed cabal of powerful technology companies that he believes are suppressing traffic to WND and other conservative sites."
But the story of the conniving cabal of “Social Media Masters” should not be underestimated either.

definition: a platform raised above the surrounding level
details: A speaker stands on a dais, or a platform, when giving a presentation. If you were speaking at the Coffee Lovers of America's conference, you'd step onto the dais so the audience could see you over their enormous cups o' joe.
examples: “Be determined,” he tells them, pacing a small dais.
As he rose from the dais, Beal flashed a hint of exasperation about the question and mumbled under his breath that “y’all trying to get me in trouble.”
The final image of Zion Williamson wearing a Duke uniform was a sequence of dejection, an 18-year-old plodding off a dais and away from the proverbial and literal spotlight for a while.
“Nobody hates me,” Kentucky’s freshman guard said, seeming to shrink into his microphone on the dais at the team’s media availability.

definition: characterized by a firm, humorless belief in one's opinions
details: If you are earnest, it means you are serious about something. Your parents might not want you to drop out of school to follow some fly-by-night dream, but if you're earnest about wanting a career in show biz, they'll support you.
examples: Now, as the 2019 legislative session begins there in earnest, it’s clear that the ascendant progressives who control both chambers are intent on increasing taxes.
He then served as ambassador to the United Nations before returning to Israel to enter politics in earnest.
I don't want to preach or be earnest in books, especially for young readers.
The chancellor also shared the joke with others nearby, including summit chair Donald Tusk, before talks got started in earnest.

definition: cleverly amusing in tone
details: If someone is being facetious they’re being playful with an edge. A knock-knock joke isn’t facetious, but if you call it the most advanced form of comedy, you’re probably being facetious.
examples: Paul’s video is entirely facetious, but the underlying parallels between his journey into flat earth conspiracy theories and the way conspiracies spread on YouTube isn’t.
Keep up the naps, books and bubble baths, by all means — you are an inspiration, and I am not being facetious — at your usual pace except for one day a week.
Bevin added that he was “being only slightly facetious.”
Bevin added that he’s “being only slightly facetious.”

definition: a persistently annoying person
details: A gadfly is an irritating person, a nuisance who will often ask too many questions or lob lots of criticisms in order to get his or her way.
examples: The conservative media gadfly was spiking the football after Mueller’s probe was wrapped without an indictment against him.
Weld is nearing gadfly status — if he is not already there.

While often viewed as a pesky left-wing gadfly, he is also known to reach across the aisle, working on legislation with Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Senator John McCain of Arizona, both Republicans.

Rather, it is the new jurisdiction that would be created by returning the residential portions of the District to Maryland, a process known as “retrocession,” conceived by third-generation Washingtonian and policy gadfly David Krucoff.

definition: the act of dwelling in or living permanently in a place
details: Habitation is the state of living somewhere. When an area has no human habitation, it means that no people live there.
examples: Though these fossils are the oldest in the Philippines, evidence for habitation is even older; 700,000 years ago, ancient butchers on Luzon carved up a rhinoceros with stone tools.
Many residents are living in damaged homes or trailers unfit for human habitation.

Faced with a flood of homeless people living in cars near the beach, San Diego officials said Monday they will pass a new version of the city’s vehicle habitation law, which banned living in vehicles.

Sprinkled across Northwest Arkansas and the rest of the state - some would suggest a better description might be “littered” - are living quarters that would never rise to being called suitable for human habitation.

definition: someone who attacks cherished ideas or institutions
details: Are you always challenging the establishment? Or provoking popular thought by attacking traditions and institutions? Then you're definitely an iconoclast.
examples: Think earthy young iconoclasts inventing wild new forms of self-expression.
Her slim, eclectic volume relates how California was a beacon for all manner of health-conscious reformers, iconoclasts, and quacks, long before the days of the hippies.
She looked at Shrake, smiled and said, “Just call him an iconoclast.”

From the start, he was an iconoclast, committed to using everyday materials and found artifacts, blurring the lines between sculpture and painting, between reproduction and individual creation, between objects and artworks.

definition: talk in a noisy, excited, or declamatory manner
details: When someone starts to jabber, they start talking on and on about this or that, or that or this, in an excited, sometimes incoherent way. Jabber is a close cousin to blabber.
examples: The man trailed him, “jabbering in my ear,” Mr. Parker recalled in an interview, as he walked for blocks, trying to put distance between the harasser and his family.
Yet, as I got closer, I heard him jabbering away in seemingly native French to his female companion.
Jailed in the White House, hounded by investigations and jabbering himself in circles, he decided to insert himself into the Fox News coverage of New Year’s Eve.
His image alternates with a jabbering, era-appropriate collage: Muhammad Ali boxing, Billy Graham preaching, an ad for Mounds.

definition: demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
details: If you have a keen interest in something, you are really, really into it. Keen is an adjective that describes something that is intense, sharp, or focused.
examples: Medievalists across Europe, said to be keen to view the returned works, will be able to do so from Thursday.
What is her advice to other early career researchers who are keen to develop coding expertise?
You see, an oft-repeated phrase at PEP, the Parental Encouragement Program, is: “Children are poor interpreters yet keen observers.”
And then, all of a sudden, Ridley decided he was not so keen to dwell on the past after all.

definition: any piece of work that is undertaken or attempted
details: Although the word labor seems to suggest tough, physical work that makes you sweat, any type of work, whether physical or mental, can be considered labor.
examples: Falcon Age opens with your character, a young woman named Ara, in a prison labor camp.
And in a move heralded as a preliminary win by workers and labor advocates, McDonald’s recently announced it would no longer support lobbying efforts to oppose minimum-wage increases.
The Apartheid system of labor relations basically exempted industries that employed black workers from statutory collective bargaining, while making strikes illegal.
White House officials declined to answer questions about Trump’s use of undocumented labor, and ICE did not respond to requests for comment this week.

definition: a crafty and involved plot to achieve your ends
details: When a James Bond villain comes up with a plan to destroy the world, he doesn’t use a simple plan. No, he uses a machination — a complex plot that relies on numerous elements coming together to work.
examples: The grain of his voice and his folky sense of melody still hold together all of the songs’ odd machinations.
Shame on the Democratic-controlled House for allowing misuse of oversight authority, misapplication of statute, and such embarrassing political machinations.
The cloak and dagger machinations of spies and traitors is explored through files transferred from MI5.
If they lose, we’ll look to the manager — his moves, his demeanor, his command of the room, his public face, his private machinations.

definition: give a detailed account of
details: When you tell a story or describe something out loud, you narrate. You might hire a well-known actor to narrate your documentary film about circus elephants.
examples: The stories, narrated nightly by the Persian noblewoman Scheherazade to King Shahryar to delay her impending death, are humorous, replete with danger and derring-do.
It is narrated, in an unstable fusion of the third- and first-person, by “Karen,” a character who plays a thankless supporting role in the first part.
Thus Wright allows little direct sunlight on the narrating “I,” though she offers a series of pastoral snapshots from her childhood in the Ozarks — memories of growing into the soul of a poet.
The book was recognized at once as a classic, combining extraordinary breadth with what Gibbon calls “the art of narrating.”

definition: stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
details: Obdurate is a formal word meaning stubborn. If you want to major in English, but your parents are obdurate that you should go premed, they might go so far as to threaten not to pay your tuition.
examples: “He was a foolish choice in a lot of ways too, because President Obama was unable to recognize just how obdurate Republicans would be,” Stern says.

Yes, Atlético Madrid, for so long regarded as soccer’s most obdurate, unyielding opponent, the sport’s great immovable object, collapsed into itself, Diego Simeone’s players succumbing to their fate with barely a whimper.
They are both excellent, making it clear that their different responses to their servitude — awakening rebellion in his case, obdurate resignation in hers — are cut from the same suffocating cloth.
“Stocky and obdurate, Mr. Finney spits with aggression, walks with impatience and indicates that laws exist to be broken,” Ms. Sayre wrote.

definition: opposed to war
details: A person who opposes the use of war or violence to settle a dispute is called a pacifist. If you are a pacifist, you talk through your differences with others instead of fighting.
examples: That response is understandable but anathema to these pacifists, particularly Salome’s sister, Ona, an otherworldly young woman ignored and dismissed for her strange personality.
Actually, Prof Sharkey is much more of a pacifist - and leads the campaign to ban killer robots, something he thinks is a far more pressing ethical issue in modern-day robotics.
A pacifist, he declared himself a conscientious objector and was consigned for about a year to the psychiatric ward of a Boston naval hospital.
A chop-socky action sequence built around a would-be pacifist was undeniably funny.

definition: swallow hurriedly or greedily or in one draught
details: To quaff is to gulp. You’re in a desert; you haven’t had water in days; you’re wicked thirsty. Then you find an oasis! You lean over and quaff the water.
examples: Tea, by contrast, is esteemed for its palatability and, like wine, is known for several order-of-magnitude differences in cost per quaff, based on variation in quality.
“It was a good day to hedge,” Radford says while quaffing a beer and celebrating his victory.
Some visitors to Venice daydream in rocking gondolas; some sit in their favorite campiello and quaff spritzes all afternoon.
The recipes in his book are a mix of classically French quaffs and those interlopers that arrived during the era.

definition: complain bitterly
details: The verb rail means to criticize severely. When you rail against increased taxes at a town meeting, you speak openly and loudly about how wrong the increase is and point out the problems it will cause.
examples: He railed about what he saw as unfair news coverage, submitting a complaint to a British press-standards inquiry.
Trump is feuding with the island’s Democratic officials and railed against aid to Puerto Rico at a closed-door lunch with Senate Republicans last month.
On Late Night, Seth Meyers railed against the hypocrisy of Republicans supporting Trump’s border edicts.
Once in office, Mr. Trump railed against “leakers” who relayed damaging information about his former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, and other turmoil within his administration.

definition: destroy property or hinder normal operations
details: Sabotage isn't very nice: It's when you ruin or disrupt something by messing up a part of it on purpose. Loosening the blades on your competitor's ice skates would definitely be considered sabotage.
examples: If Republicans were hoping to sabotage the Judiciary Committee’s hearing, they got what they wanted.
Cleveland again played without star forward Kevin Love, whose season was sabotaged early by a toe injury that required surgery and altered everything for the Cavs.
On Friday, the editorial page of the Financial Times said that the nominations of Moore and Cain “surely qualify as sabotage.”
“Politicians in Cairo called for sabotaging the dam. Media outlets in both countries compared the two sides’ military strength in anticipation of hostilities.”

definition: implied by or inferred from actions or statements
details: Something tacit is implied or understood without question. Holding hands might be a tacit acknowledgment that a boy and girl are dating.
examples: If he’s not, the precedent set would be so immensely damaging as to provide a tacit endorsement of the imperial presidency by the House speaker.
Sissi’s second White House visit was aimed at strengthening military and counterterrorism ties and securing at least tacit U.S. backing for his planned remake of the Egyptian constitution.
“Blinded by its greed, Boeing haphazardly rushed the 737 MAX 8 to market, with the knowledge and tacit approval of the United States Federal Aviation Administration,” the lawsuit says.

According to Barr’s letter, Mueller determined that what was needed to establish “coordination” was an “agreement — tacit or express — between the Trump Campaign and the Russian government on election interference.”

definition: lying beyond what is openly revealed or avowed
details: An ulterior interest, argument, or revelation is one you try to keep hidden, like your ulterior motive for weeding your grandmother's garden is to have a conversation with your crush — and Grandma's neighbor — who happens to be outside, too.
examples: As an article in Sunday’s Mirror reported, Jim Stephens, director of maintenance operations and modernization for the Altoona authority, suggested the possibility of an ulterior HUD motive for implementing the change.
Moreover, “what lies beneath such a view is a notion that is itself antisemitic: that Jews do not act sincerely, but always with an ulterior motive or hidden agenda.”
And that ulterior motive often goes back to Israel—“They’re just trying to defend Israel.”
“Our children were used as pawns for an ulterior leftist agenda,” she said.

definition: leave behind empty; move out of
details: If someone asks you to vacate the room, you'd better pack up your things and go. When you vacate something, you leave it behind, usually empty.
examples: Some tenants of Philadelphia’s Jewelers Row say they were told in the notices that arrived this week that they must vacate by May 31.
"I'm not leaving the BBC, I'm just vacating the news desk," the presenter said.
Last year, after 27 years in prison and countless appeals, his conviction was vacated and he was finally released.
Welts said the Warriors worked on that deal for two years, intent on maintaining a presence in Oakland even as they vacated Oracle Arena.

definition: pause or hold back in uncertainty or unwillingness
details: You might think of a waffle as a grid-patterned pancake-like food that's tasty with syrup, and you'd be right. But the word is also a verb that means to avoid making a definitive decision.
examples: Are the waffles in here just the leftover bits of Waffle Crisp?
Charles Garrison, a mortgage officer in Florida, decided to try the keto diet, including food like waffles made with almond flour.
They sit down with their breakfasts, waffles all around.
Another problem is that one of the surveys waffled on what to call vapes — switching from e-cigarettes early on to electronic vapor products in the latter years of the survey.

definition: a free man who cultivates his own land
details: A yeoman was a farmer who owned and worked his own land — not to be confused with "yo, man!"
examples: The Coast Guard says Hooker enlisted in the Coast Guard Women’s Reserve in 1945 and rose to the rank of yeoman second class before her discharge in 1946.
For example, it compares Lenin’s demonization of kulaks, or yeoman farmers, to Ms. Warren’s critiques of the behavior of some large corporations.
Most were yeoman farmers and loggers, but the Coleman ancestors owned slaves.
A small number of yeoman property owners vs a sea of peasants, with the nobility pulling the strings to keep things in check.

definition: a feeling of strong eagerness
details: Zeal is dedication or enthusiasm for something. If you have zeal, you're willing, energized, and motivated.
examples: The dispute centers on the Trump administration’s allegations that China steals technology and coerces U.S. companies to hand over trade secrets — all part of Beijing’s zeal to overtake U.S. technological dominance.
Herself a descendant of Danish immigrants, Nielsen not only implemented Trump’s anti-immigrant agenda—she defended it with zeal.
Full of third party zeal, the Libertarian Party is planning its 2020 convention.
The best way to combat marauders from Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State and elsewhere is with the zeal they themselves use.

definition: become less in amount or intensity
details: Something that abates becomes fewer or less intense. Your enthusiasm for skiing might abate after falling off a ski lift and getting a mouthful of snow.
examples: “Symptoms appear to abate over time,” the manual explains, while noting that “some individuals may prefer to resume medication indefinitely.”
Like other Centcom leaders before him, he steps down at a moment when the militant threat, while seemingly abated, remains unvanquished and political objectives elusive.
And even if it did, the Green New Deal would not actually provide any “climate insurance” because it would do absolutely nothing to abate temperature increases or slow the rise of sea levels.
Abdul Majid Khan, who coordinates aid related to food security and agriculture for the U.N., said a plan is in place to assist families who return home as the drought abates.

definition: deadly or sinister
details: Baleful means the foreshadowing of tragic or evil events. If no one's listening in class and your teacher reprimands you with a baleful glance, expect a pop quiz.
examples: Too many writers imbue cancers with baleful intent and strategy, and it is disappointing to see Kinch do the same.
Here is a masculinity not of muscular exertion but baleful inaction.
The graveyard, which sits at the end of a bus route less than an hour from Madrid, lacks the baleful scale of Franco’s current resting place.
That extended staring in stillness, with baleful or at least somber faces, is something they’ve done many times before in this 80-minute work, usually in silence.

definition: having an unpleasant sound
details: The adjective cacophonous describes loud, harsh sounds, like the cacophonous racket your brother and his band mates make while trying to learn how to play their instruments.
examples: Second, he never wore his hair in long blond straggles, like a stoner Messiah; that, however, is the style favored by Moondog, as an accompaniment to his cacophonous shirts and his silver Ugg boots.
New York’s colors are like the city’s architecture: random, cacophonous, equal parts ego and vision, ornaments for a city that throbs in black and white.
Its parents eventually showed; the female was absolutely cacophonous.
Those critics understand the way Goff’s offensive teammates felt in the cacophonous huddle in New Orleans.

definition: marked by up-to-dateness in dress and manners
details: A neatly and stylishly dressed man can be described as dapper. If you like to wear a well-made fedora, you appreciate clothes. Place a brightly colored feather in the brim and you’re dapper.
examples: “Coach always looked dapper, incredibly well-dressed,” he said.
In previews this month, she looked slim as a match, dapper in a tuxedo and gleaming shoes.
For more than being a great raconteur, the dapper Ferencz benefits from a career trajectory that is as much the result of happenstance as careful planning.
There was a compelling duality in these trends: the soft power of Valentine’s colors and the harder lines of dapper suiting.

definition: listen without the speaker's knowledge
details: When you eavesdrop, you secretly listen in on someone's conversation. A little girl might eavesdrop on her parents in an attempt to find out what she's getting for her birthday.
examples: Have you heard that paranoid tale about how Google, Facebook and other tech giants are actually eavesdropping on you through your phone all the time to deliver targeted ads?
A Secret Service agent testified at the hearing to say that she was not carrying any lock-picking or eavesdropping gear.
I don’t mean to eavesdrop, but I haven’t heard Mom’s voice in normal conversation for so long I can’t help it.

The New York Times reported last year that the president displayed a “casual approach to electronic security” through his use of unsecured mobile phones, despite warnings his conversations were regularly eavesdropped by Russia and China.

definition: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth
details: If someone does something easily, or shows ease, it is described as facile in a good way, but if someone takes the easy way out and shows a lack of thought or care, it is facile in a bad way.
examples: Vidal-Naquet sells this facile notion by keeping his protagonist a borderline cipher — even-tempered, accommodating, seemingly at peace with drifting.
The commission says “such facile comparisons, used in order to demean opponents and gain political capital, should be actively avoided.”
The film “disarms any facile analysis or easy judgment of its characters,” A. O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times.
The point may be facile, but when the Republican opponent happens to be a former reality TV star now ensconced in the Oval Office, “Betomania” is not to be sniffed at.

definition: take exception to
details: Gainsay, a verb, means "contradict" or "speak out against." When you challenge authority, you gainsay, as in teachers don't like it when unruly students gainsay them.
examples: Will Republican elected officials gainsay Mr. Trump or opt for studious inaction as the nation potentially lurches toward constitutional crisis and banana-republic governance?
Crime waves are often linked to economic downturns, but this hypothesis is gainsaid by counterexamples, such as the relatively low crime rates during the 1930s depression and the 2008–2010 recession.
He spoke with an earnestness that it was hard to gainsay.
When others spoke they seemed harsh and uncouth by contrast; and if they gainsaid the voice, anger was kindled in the hearts of those under the spell.

definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
details: Hackneyed is a word for language that doesn't pack a punch since it's overused and trite. "Roses are red, violets are..." — enough already?! That's hackneyed stuff.
examples: The problem is that Rep. Omar hasn’t mentioned those policies in making her hackneyed anti-Semitic statements.
Having seen only the trailer for Leaving Neverland, whatever confessional justice was intended by its two informants is compromised by its director’s hackneyed, tabloid true-crime approach.
Trump’s careful tending to the hackneyed Monopoly Man caricatures seems to prove that the voter’s quest for authenticity is in fact easily satisfied by flat caricature.
This misty trinity of New Age exhortations — besides being hackneyed — does a disservice to women who don’t wish to or can’t attain them.

definition: characterized by attack on established beliefs
details: The word iconoclastic is an adjective referring to a breaking of established rules or destruction of accepted beliefs. It might refer to an artist with an unorthodox style, or an iconoclastic attack, either physical or verbal, on a religious doctrine or image.
examples: “I personally can’t think of any other more iconoclastic rock ‘n’ roll style icon.
An iconoclastic pied piper, Mr. Feiglin, 56, is pledging to upend the customs and tax system by introducing a flat tax and gradually eliminating import duties and quotas.

Reactions among Brazilians focused largely on the symbolism of the visit, with Bolsonaro supporters calling it a vindication for the iconoclastic leader and critics cringing to see him so cozy with Trump.
Punk, in its original form, was nothing if not iconoclastic.

definition: technical terminology characteristic of a particular subject
details: Jargon usually means the specialized language used by people in the same work or profession. Internet advertising jargon includes the terms "click throughs" and "page views."
examples: There was also talk of “brand identity” and a “refreshed logo,” the kind of marketing jargon that all teams use when they hope fans will buy items with the new look.
And the school abandoned jargon in favor of clear language about student aid and core requirements.
“This is not educating the ‘whole child,’” said parent Andrea Radosevich, using the school district’s jargon that indicates the emotional development of kids is just as important as academics.
Ms. Corman may hate the word “journeys” but her script is not free of self-help jargon.

definition: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
details: When you start a fire burning, you can say you kindle the fire. Knowing how to kindle a campfire is an important survival skill. It can help keep you warm at night, and keep you from eating cold beans for dinner.
examples: Recently, I was thinking about this iconic but fading brand, my memories kindled by a family vacation we’re planning to Maine for later this summer.
Although kindled by partisanship, the Mueller myth reflected the embers of faith in the strength of political institutions to overcome the flaws of our political culture.
He said his imagination was particularly kindled by the relationship between man and machine in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey.”
Late last year, Trump issued an initial order for a significant troop reduction there, but senior officials persuaded him to hold off on that move while diplomats seek to kindle peace talks.

definition: brief and to the point
details: Laconic is an adjective that describes a style of speaking or writing that uses only a few words, often to express complex thoughts and ideas. A more laconic way to write that last sentence might be this: laconic means brief.
examples: She encouraged him, and with a new focus on composition, he cultivated a distinctively laconic style purged of excess and meticulously designed from meaningful gestures.
Just to underscore this point: Barr offers two paragraphs of his own “principal conclusions,” and just two or three laconic sentences of Mueller’s conclusions.
The psychiatrist was both laconic and somehow heedless in his dealings with the paranormal.
Despite the book’s laconic compactness, Enia manages to fuse into it a fully realized personal narrative: that of a beloved uncle lost and a reticent father finally understood.

definition: an unaccompanied partsong for several voices
details: A madrigal is a specific kind of song, one that you won't often hear on the radio. The madrigal developed in 16th-century Italy and is sung in musical counterpoint, by several singers at once.
examples: The vocal ensemble Roomful of Teeth realized these different musical styles — Baroque madrigal, Appalachian folk song, Manhattan Transfer-style close harmony, buzzing rock anthem — with ease through amplification.
She is shadowed by a quartet of look-alikes in candy-colored coats, who form a kind of madrigal ensemble, singing in cool tones without vibrato.
I directed a madrigal choir and for some of our concerts we rented Renaissance Faire-esque dresses.
It was also enjoyed in chamber concerts at Queen Elizabeth I’s court, in madrigal recitals, religious gatherings and in informal settings and street performances.

definition: marked by up-to-dateness in dress and manners
details: Natty means current in style, both of dress and manners. A natty dresser is someone who is very stylish and has a snappy attitude. He may even be wearing a natty fedora.
examples: That’s the urge being translated with such sublime grace by those five natty men on the stage, Platonic ideals of stepping high and looking fine.
But now everybody gets to see his natty outfits.
A man who took pride in his natty clothes like custom suits with wide pinstripes and broad lapels, Mr. Stone published an annual “best dressed” column in The Daily Caller, the conservative website.
She doffs her cap at Sulzberger, with his natty suspenders, but dismisses younger reporters at places like Vice as notable mainly for being “impossibly hip, with interesting hair.”

definition: the goal intended to be attained
details: An objective is something you plan to achieve. A military objective is the overall plan for a mission. The objective for a bake sale is to raise money. If your objective is to learn a new word, you have succeeded.
examples: Aid, the author of the N.S.A. history, suggests that ThinThread’s privacy protections interfered with top officials’ secret objective—to pick American targets by name.
“In Venezuela, there is a need to separate political and humanitarian objectives,” Mr. Lowcock said.
“In forensic science, we use our science to be objective, to find answers from the evidence,” Sudkamp said.
“In Venezuela, there is a need to separate political and humanitarian objectives. Humanitarian assistance must be delivered on the basis of need alone,” Lowcock said.

definition: ease the anger, agitation, or strong emotion of
details: If you are bringing peace or calm to a state of unrest, you are pacifying the situation. Just think of the transformation a squalling baby undergoes when a pacifier is placed within his mouth, and you will remember the power of the verb to pacify.
examples: Egypt brokered an unofficial deal last week to pacify the frontier ahead of elections in exchange for efforts to mitigate Gaza’s acute economic crisis.
It’s salutatory to watch her corral her rebellious Democratic brood with committee treats and pacifying timeouts.

Identifying a qualified candidate — a person with extensive banking and management experience, the credibility to pacify regulators and the skill to shepherd a company with 260,000 restive employees — will be a challenge.
They needed to compete against the humiliation, not try to pacify it.

definition: a soft wet area of low-lying land that sinks underfoot
details: A quagmire is a dangerous place, like the muddy shoreline of a pond. Because it's so hard to climb out of a quagmire, the word has also come to also mean any difficult or sticky situation you find yourself in.
examples: It’s a quagmire in the same way that the U.S. is in a quagmire in Afghanistan, or how the U.S. was in Vietnam.
O’Rourke avoided talking about Aipac altogether, and sidestepped the politically deadly quagmire of what it means for Israel to be a Jewish state.

Rather than mire ourselves in the bureaucratic quagmire that reparations for our historic wrongs entail, we must address economic and social inequality through investments in education, job training, public health and housing.
His first reaction is to plead for a transfer away from this quagmire.

definition: especially fine or decorative clothing
details: Raiment is an old-fashioned word for clothing, particularly fancy clothing, like ladies who always wore their best raiment when calling on friends.
examples: Just in time for coat weather, two local companies are draping Shakespeare plays in new raiment.
He needed to shed the raiment of moderation and don the Republican conservative cloth coat.
“My mother’s, madam. She was a woman of fashion and exquisite raiment.”
As tall as trolls they were, twelve feet or more in height; their strong bodies, stout as young trees, seemed to be clad with raiment or with hide of close-fitting grey and brown.

definition: the ability to understand and discriminate between relations
details: If you are wise and prone to evaluating information before making a decision, you possess sagacity, the trait of solid judgment and intelligent choices. And if that is indeed the case, then good for you! We need more sound thinkers.
examples: For years, golf fans knew Eddie Pepperell more for his inquisitiveness, sagacity and humor rather than anything he accomplished inside the ropes.
There was, in this performance, not even a hint of the sagacity one expects from a potential Supreme Court Justice.
Aridjis exudes a mixture of sagacity, strength and charm; his energy for a man two years short of 80 is infectious.
As a wealthy and experienced investor, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross was expected to bring polish and sagacity to his job in the Trump cabinet.

definition: having a sense of what is considerate in dealing with others
details: If you are tactful, you have a knack for saying the right thing at the right time. A tactful person is appropriate and sensitive, never rude or careless.
examples: “You need to be tactful, though,” the company notes in a blog post on how to properly send a text-therapy gift card.
The dancers were told: “Be on time, be tactful, be creative, be funky, be yourself.”
There was some more chatter about the pronunciation, which Antetokounmpo brought to a close with a tactful “Just call me Superman.”
When presenting your new boundary be simple, direct and tactful.

definition: free of artificiality; sincere and genuine
details: When bad weather or a mean aunt or some other force takes over and you still don't change, you're unaffected. If your party was unaffected by the rain and Aunt Emma's no-fun attitude, then everyone probably had a good time.
examples: Other disputed territories, including the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem remain unaffected, the company said.
If the long-term divorce rate in Scotland was unaffected by reforms to the law, the reasons people were giving for divorce did change.
The island was sold in 1954 for £150,000 to the Landmark Trust and is kept as a "tranquil and unaffected place".
The level of recidivism seems unaffected by a more moderate penal regimen.

definition: be undecided about something
details: Vacillate means to waver back and forth, unable to decide. You might vacillate between ordering waffles and pancakes at your favorite diner — it’s hard to pick just one when both are so tasty!
examples: Face to face with his collection of bosses in the room, Servais didn’t vacillate.
This – like Mueller's vacillating conclusion about whether President Trump obstructed justice – split the baby in half.
American movies vacillate endlessly between the worship of lawmen and the romance of outlaws, but few are as dogmatically one-sided as this one.
For the Love of Spock vacillates between exploring Spock and telling Leonard Nimoy’s story.

definition: be driven or carried along, as by the air
details: When your grandmother cooks her famous spaghetti sauce, many wonderful smells may waft from the kitchen. In other words, the air will gently carry this familiar aroma throughout the house.
examples: He settles in as the calming fragrance of cedar wafts from the vent.
Soon the smell of macaroni and cheese wafts up to me and carries me downstairs by the nose.
Feeling nauseated because there’s a stale smell wafting through the cabin?
Uncles in aprons start up the grills, and delicious smells waft through.

definition: give or supply
details: Yield has two meanings that seem quite different: "an amount" or "to give way." The yield of the recipe was twelve brownies. To avoid being tripped, Mary was forced to yield to the children on her way to the brownie plate.
examples: Rising bond yields, which allow banks to charge higher interest on loans, helped lift the sector.
Banks were getting some help early Thursday from rising bond yields, which allows them to earn more income on bonds they hold and also to charge higher interest rates on loans.
“She’s a filmmaker, but the process of that residency yielded new ideas. It was generative,” Stevens said.
U.S. stock index futures pared gains slightly after the data while Treasury yields rose.

definition: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
details: The hamburger zealot was so fanatical about his burgers that he camped outside his favorite fast-food joint for hours every morning, waiting for it to open. And he would never put mustard on them, only ketchup.
examples: But, to form a government only with Zionists, he’d need not only Labor and Meretz but also some combination of rightist parties, including some of the ultra-Orthodox and rightist zealots whom he’s been running against.
Look at Labour peer Andrew Adonis, transformed from measured technocrat into tub-thumping remain zealot.

I’m Vaccinating My Child the Natural Way — With Measles With anti-vaccination zealots in the news for hijacking various social platforms, I appreciated Justine Cotter’s satirical view in McSweeney’s: Measles is the original measles vaccine.
Pryce was genuinely shocked by fans’ reaction to his religious zealot character.

definition: give up, such as power, as of monarchs and emperors
details: Sometimes someone in power might decide to give up that power and step down from his or her position. When they do that, they abdicate their authority, giving up all duties and perks of the job.
examples: The 85-year-old emperor is abdicating on April 30 and handing the Chrysanthemum throne to his elder son, Crown Prince Naruhito, the next day.
He became crown prince at 15, in 1961, and was crowned Brunei’s 29th sultan in 1968, the year after his father abdicated.
Leaving this inescapable assessment to Barr, the special counsel abdicated on the main question he was appointed to decide.
The Japanese government on Monday officially unveiled the name of the imperial era set to begin on May 1, the day after the current emperor, Akihito, abdicates.

definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
details: If something is boring and unoriginal, it's banal. Banal things are dull as dishwater.
examples: But it may be better understood as what Rovelli called “a glimpse of reality, a little less blurred than our blurred and banal everyday view of it.”
"It's one of the banal facts of the internet."
Knafo himself is too shrewd a detective, too wise about human nobility and human failings, to spend his time pondering the banal question of heroism versus villainy.
If this were a Saturday Night Live sketch, the joke would be that a banal situation sparked an elaborately-produced musical, complete with choreography and costumes, a la “Bodega Bathroom.”

definition: very thin especially from disease or hunger or cold
details: Cadaverous means looking corpse-like, from being sick or too skinny, like an aging rock star or a Halloween ghoul.
examples: My favourite comment is that I look “calm and in charge” while my least favourite is that I look like Judge Roban from French detective series Spiral, a cadaverously miserable mop-headed man in his 70s.
At last a tall, cadaverous woman in a white smock entered the room from an inner door.
A first wave of cadaverous firms are seeking rebirth under a bankruptcy code adopted in December 2016.
In 1847, he hypothesized that puerperal fever was spread by doctors carrying “cadaverous particles” from the deadhouse to the obstetrics ward at Vienna’s General Hospital.

definition: cause to lose courage
details: Daunt means to frighten or scare off. The Cowardly Lion's efforts to daunt Dorothy, the Scarecrow, and the Tin Man were less than successful.
examples: To capture a direct image of a supermassive black hole was a daunting technological challenge.

The Israeli prime minister was facing a daunting set of political circumstances, with indictments on corruption charges pending and a stronger-than-expected opponent in Benny Gantz, the former Israel Defense Forces chief of staff.
Re-creating the Lestrange vault proved to be an especially daunting task.
But just because it’s daunting doesn’t mean it’s not the job of government.

definition: fall away or decline
details: When something ebbs, it is declining, falling, or flowing away. The best time to look for sea creatures in tidal pools is when the tide is on the ebb — meaning it has receded from the shore.
examples: From there it moved into U.K. indie and New York indie, and continued to ebb and flow.
It’s an of-the-moment lineup, following decades of the ebb and flow in music, popular and otherwise.
We are not at all thinking about the campus in terms of special exhibitions space and collections space in the sense that those things ebb and flow with time.
After an unexpectedly weak February — just 20,000 new jobs were initially reported — concerns arose that the remarkable wave of hiring might be ebbing.

definition: make easier
details: To facilitate means to make something easier. If your best friend is very shy, you could facilitate her efforts to meet new people.
examples: President Donald Trump agreed in talks in Washington that a top-down approach led by leaders is essential to facilitate further progress in nuclear talks, Chung Eui-yong, the South Korean national security adviser, told reporters.
Baumann said Sotheby’s always sought to clarify the provenance of objects it was asked to sell, and to facilitate their return where appropriate.
The report said that rental companies like Airbnb allowed the settlements to be more profitable and sustainable, which facilitates Israel’s “unlawful transfer of its citizens to the settlements.”
It merely existed to facilitate and sustain a mood, which in turn might enable a task: studying, folding laundry, making spreadsheets, idly browsing the Internet.

definition: a strong wind moving 45-90 knots
details: If there’s a gale coming your way, you better hold onto your new hat and your little dog, Toto, too, because this is an extremely strong wind.
examples: The gale of laughter that ends “Beat the Devil” does recall “Sierra Madre,” but this time the joke was on Huston.
Wonderful though it is to see him with a white kitten, in homage to Anita Ekberg in “La Dolce Vita,” it is less enchanting to be subjected to his gales of forced laughter.
The gales will move into the eastern Carpentaria and northern Barkly districts and north-west Gulf country on Saturday morning.
The $3.6-billion project helped facilitate links with Crimea, which previously depended on a ferry crossing that was often interrupted by gales.

definition: wrangle, as over a price or terms of an agreement
details: If you want a great deal on a used TV, then you can try to haggle with the sellers to see if they’ll bring the price down. To haggle is to negotiate or argue over something, usually a price.
examples: If the two leaders decide to haggle in person over any final details, a third-country venue is more likely.
But while negotiators in Managua haggle over that and other thorny issues with little progress, many exiles are struggling.
But online pricing remains scant for funeral services, putting bereaved and vulnerable people at a financial disadvantage because they’re unlikely to haggle over costs.
Ms Hitchins said customers who were unhappy should haggle for a better deal from their existing supplier or switch to a new one to cut their broadband bill.

definition: an orientation that characterizes the thinking of a group
details: An ideology is a set of opinions or beliefs of a group or an individual. Very often ideology refers to a set of political beliefs or a set of ideas that characterize a particular culture.
examples: But at multiple points throughout the book, people told me quite literally that they were willing to die in support of a particular ideology.
He is certainly an ideologue, but his ideology seems born of a pugilist glee in offending liberal sensibilities.
“Over those eons, we emerged on Earth along with our myths, differentiated cultures, ideologies, languages and varied beliefs,” she says.
And Lieberman, though personally estranged from Netanyahu, is ideologically congenial with him—if ideology is the right word for seeing Arab Israelis best approached by intimidation.

definition: an airplane powered by gas turbines
details: A jet is an airplane that can rapidly travel long distances. To jet is the act of getting somewhere quickly, by jet or any other way, as in, "Do you see what time it is? We better jet!"
examples: The lawyer is also accused of embezzling millions of dollars from other clients, using the money to purchase a private jet, finance his coffee business and pay for his own legal and personal expenses.
That night, Valero executives flew Conners and his wife, Malory, in their corporate jet to Augusta, where he took a day to decompress before resuming practice on Tuesday.
Pasqualetti studies control theory, a branch of engineering that uses sensors and feedback to guide the behavior of a system, whether that's an electrical grid or a fighter jet.
Twenty-eight minutes after taking off with three other F-35s from Misawa air base in Aomori prefecture on a night training flight, the jet vanished from military radar at about 7:27 p.m.

definition: a special way of doing something
details: If you have a knack for doing something, you do it well. You may have a knack for baking cakes or a knack for cracking jokes. These things come easy to you.
examples: The bar itself, between the ashtrays and the drinks, is crammed with Mario knick knacks and ephemera; Piranha plant lamps loom above.
His major label debut, “Baby on Baby,” is a 31-minute breeze exhibiting his charm, sense of humor and, when necessary, knack for intimidation.
This knack for making friends in the most unlikely places resonates long after you turn the last page.
Lost in the science is his knack for being a good closer.

definition: someone who takes more time than necessary
details: Hey pokey! Yeah you, Mr. Slow Pants. Quit your dawdling! This is no time to be a laggard, or someone who's always lagging behind.
examples: America, the purported world leader, is clearly the world laggard on this issue.
Jakarta’s first subway is the latest of many infrastructure improvements nationwide that it is hoped will help the giant but laggard nation catch up with its neighbors.
While the US is, in so many ways, an environmental laggard compared to Europe, air quality is a glaring exception.
The line is the latest in infrastructure improvements nationwide that officials hope will help this giant but laggard nation catch up with its neighbors.

definition: offensively self-assured or exercising unwarranted power
details: A person who is magisterial can be distinguished and grand, or possibly just conceited and bossy. You will learn a lot if you listen to a magisterial presentation of early American history.
examples: Here is Harry Hansen’s view, from his magisterial history, The Civil War:
For Everfair, the titular African nation of Nisi Shawl’s magisterial 2017 novel rewriting the history of the Belgian Congo, the author created an entire country and its institutions from scratch.

Part of Wilson’s mission in his magisterial 10-play cycle chronicling the African American experience in the 20th century was to fulfill James Baldwin’s call for a “profound articulation of the black tradition.”
Victimization was not the theme of Brown’s magisterial work, or any part of his understanding of American Indian potential.

definition: make ineffective by counterbalancing the effect of
details: If something neutralizes the effect of something else, then you can say the effect is negated. Hanging a disco ball from your living room ceiling negates the sleek modern effect created by the contemporary furniture.
examples: Evers angered the bill’s Republican authors in March when he issued an executive order requiring all state agencies to remove “mental retardation” from their regulations, largely negating the need for the bill.
A Jarrett Culver basket was waved off on a charge call with just over eight minutes to play, negating for the moment Texas Tech’s bid to cut Virginia’s lead to six.
Those more complex realities do not negate the potential for contentious politics in 2020.
Evers angered the bill’s Republican authors in March when he issued an executive order requiring all state agencies to remove “mental retardation” from their regulations, negating the bill’s effect.

definition: abusive, malicious, and condemnatory language
details: If you are on the receiving end of obloquy, then society has turned against you and you are in a state of disgrace. Poor Hester Prynne who was forced to wear a red "A" on her chest for "adultery" knows all about obloquy.
examples: Sandmann’s lawyers argue that the Washington Post’s statements were defamatory per se because they were “libelous on their face” and subjected him to “public hatred, contempt, scorn, obloquy, and shame.”
Western intellectuals deserve their usual share of the obloquy.
Not content with his role in that obloquy, he now seems determined to shame his state by clinging to office.
As a result, she became an unwilling media figure and victim who, long after her father’s conviction and imprisonment, was subjected to obloquy and harassment.

definition: acceptable to the taste or mind
details: Something that is palatable is acceptable to one’s sense of taste—literally or figuratively. If it's palatable, then you can put up with it — whether it's leftovers or a mediocre made-for-TV movie.
examples: In the late 1970s, especially, they struggled to find a parish that didn’t compromise Catholic teaching for the sake of making it more palatable.
Your resentment about the passport, like so much of the discussion, is illogical, even if it does neatly sum up one less palatable side-effect of the current impasse.
I thought about why our grief seemingly wasn’t palatable.
But there is no guarantee any would be more palatable to a majority of lawmakers.

definition: draw back, as with fear or pain
details: Smaller than the chicken and not as well known as the pigeon, quail is like the often-overlooked middle child of the ground-dwelling bird family. Quail can also mean to cringe in fear or pain. So if you are a quail, you might quail at the thought of quail-hunting season.
examples: There is a restaurant on Broad Street that serves quail bisque and pork belly rillette.
Crackling fried baby quail, glazed with miso, honey and yuzu juice, lounges on grits fired up with Thai chile in a red pepper relish: fusion at its finest.
Red-headed quail with black and white speckles leaped from the brush too quickly to be identified or photographed.

The fires also help restore and maintain vital habitat for wildlife, including bobwhite quail and other grassland birds, wild turkeys, white-tailed deer, gopher tortoises and red-cockaded woodpeckers.

definition: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
details: Ladies, the rakish fellow you met last night with the suave dance moves, smoothly rehearsed lines, and your number listed as “Goddess #14” in his phone is fine for a flirt, but probably isn’t meet-the-parents material.
examples: In Chile, Santiago’s rakish sailor brother is the port city of Valparaíso, with its handsome looks, edgy creativity and whiff of salt-air decay.
As a collective, she and her friends organize a gendered revolt against their rakish colleagues.
Tom Cruise’s career suggests that these operations are entirely possible, as does every other movie about rakish charmers facing hopeless odds.
There were grungy slip dresses, bulky padded motorcycle leathers, rakish jumbles of denim and tartan, florals and leopard print.

definition: a mentor in spiritual and philosophical topics
details: Use the word sage for someone or something wise and judicious. Thanks to the sage advice of your friend, you didn't write your teacher an angry e-mail!
examples: Constitution sat on the dining-room table, near bundles of white sage.
Over the weekend, the congresswoman announced that she was getting involved in a community garden and asked her followers for some “sage words of advice”.
Places treated would include big-game winter range, sage grouse habitat and areas intentionally burned and thinned to reduce the risk of wildfire.
As a woman on the internet, my feeds are frequently stirred by the actions of digital mystics — astrologers, tarot readers, sage smudgers, crystal outfitters and generally witchy women.

definition: a plan for attaining a particular goal
details: Tactic is another word for a maneuver or method. If begging doesn't convince your parents to raise your allowance, you might want to try a different tactic—like doing all your chores without being asked.
examples: Al-Bashir seeks help from the Janjaweed militias, whose brutal tactics terrorize people in the region and displace more than 2 million people.
And of course, media lightweights use the same tactics.
Supporters say the bill, which permits police to use lethal force only when there is no reasonable alternative, would save lives by obliging officers to employ de-escalation tactics.
He was motivated partly by the financial difficulties of the tabloid business, but also by his distaste for the Enquirer’s tactics.

definition: everyone being of one mind
details: When there is unanimity, everyone agrees. When it comes to opinion, unanimity is the opposite of disagreement.
examples: It is clear that there is not unanimity among Trump’s advisers.
EU leaders meeting in Brussels on Wednesday must decide by unanimity on any further delay.
Schiff invoked the Republican committee members’ unanimity to tie them all into an across-the-board apologia for Trump.

In written testimony submitted to the General Assembly’s Public Health Committee, the society says “unanimity within the physician community on the physician’s role during the transition from life to death no longer exists.”

definition: an unexpected and inexplicable change in something
details: A vagary is an unexpected and unpredictable change, and the word is usually used in the plural. You might know from experience that the vagaries of winter weather make planning a vacation in February a risky proposition.
examples: Though many passionate golfers dream their whole lives of attending just one Masters, the vagaries of corporate entertaining mean some less-deserving folk slip through.
Nonetheless, Mr. Sterling took full responsibility for the mistakes and said the DOC was working to eliminate the vagaries that precipitated them.
She met researchers transforming understanding, rickshaw drivers in the firing line and policy experts struggling with the vagaries of regulation in the United States and China.
There's a reason why you'll hear the phrase "the vagaries of match play" about 2,834 times throughout the TV coverage.

definition: do without or cease to hold or adhere to
details: To waive is to give up one's right to do something. If you waive your right to help name your family's new puppy, you can't complain if he ends up being called "Mr. Tinkerbell Sweetheart Lovey-Face."
examples: He was waived after serving a two-game suspension to start last season for violating the league’s policy on performance enhancers.
Congress wrested three major farming states from the BJP in state polls in December by promising to waive the outstanding loans of distressed farmers.
Yet, did the president waive his privacy rights when he called for the public revelation of the full Mueller report?
That would require lawmakers to waive parliamentary procedures.

definition: the point above the observer directly opposite the nadir
details: Zenith means the high point — it comes from astronomy, where it describes the highest point in an arc traveled by a star or a planet or another celestial body. The sun reaches its zenith when it is as high in the sky as it is going to go on that day.
examples: In some ways, this was zombie thinking at its formalist zenith – never underestimate the tendency of the middle class’s need to be a herd of independent minds.
California Supreme reached its zenith at the 2016 Peach Jam, a summertime showcase for the best travel basketball teams and players in the country.
At its zenith four years ago, the Islamic State ruled a chunk of territory the size of Britain and controlled the lives of up to 12 million people.
This was Odeon at its zenith and its signature styles became well known.

definition: markedly different from an accepted norm
details: Use the adjective aberrant to describe unusual conduct. Sitting in a bathtub and singing show tunes all day long might be considered aberrant behavior.
examples: Other companies devised programmes that would perform automated searches of Uighurs’ internet activity and then compare the data it gleaned to school, job, banking, medical and biometric records, looking for predictors of aberrant behaviour.
Vesting power in athletes to reform sports is not historically aberrant.
The silver foil brick was an aberrant addition to our Tom Thumb shopping cart.
“The reason we think it went down is these cells were detecting aberrant tau and self-regulating to lower Rhes levels as a means to activate autophagy and remove the aberrant proteins,” Kosik says.

definition: discuss lightly
details: Bandy is a verb that means to toss many ideas around without focusing on just one. If you've ever brainstormed, you know what this is like — you bandy about different ideas until you find one that works.
examples: One idea Bates is bandying around is deepening the ponds and stocking them with fish.
The term “socialism” is now increasingly bandied about by pundits, scholars and presidential candidates.

The press also plays into the right’s hands by abusively bandying about the word “socialism” to describe progressive policies of universal health care, tuition free public universities, and higher taxation on the wealthy.
Ideas like banning women from the workplace are bandied around casually in these communities.

definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering
details: To cajole someone is to persuade them by using insincere compliments or promises. If you say "Please, pretty-please, I'll be your best friend," when asking for a stick of gum, you are cajoling the gum holder.
examples: For the better part of five years we’ve bribed him with an iPad, cajoled him into opening his mouth, and put the spoon against his lips.
The spectre of the malevolent Tempe appears in the room cajoling her sister to recall their family’s terrible history while the son still lives.
Then May must cajole dozens of zealous, ideologically driven, hardcore Brexiteers in her own Conservative Party to do the same.

May spent the weekend twisting arms and cajoling rebels in her party, as well as her governing allies in the Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland, to get enough votes to cross the finish line.

definition: an insufficient quantity or number
details: If there is a dearth of something, there is not enough of it. A dearth of cupcakes is unfortunate, but a dearth of nutritious food is a serious problem.
examples: Most headlines tend to highlight the experiences of young, white or Western victims — partly because of a dearth of public data on any violent experiences of women of color who travel alone.
Government already suffers from a dearth of qualified computer scientists, and the more advanced technology becomes, the more difficult it is to evaluate.
For students who belong to the Black Student Union, that includes addressing the dearth of black students in advanced classes and school discipline that disproportionately punishes black students.
On the other hand, many other Americans felt there was no justification for appointing a special counsel, citing the dearth of evidence and the existence of other options provided under Sec.

definition: joyously unrestrained
details: More than chipper, more than happy, more than delighted is ebullient — meaning bubbling over with joy and delight.
examples: The ebullient mood was a marked departure from nearly two years ago, when a white nationalist rally descended into violence and chaos and left one woman dead.
They are fit, they are well fed, they sport a sunny and ebullient blush.
To the tens of thousands of fans who follow her on social media, she is a consistently positive, ebullient personality with a touch of sass.
It features Madonna, Haris and De Lory singing together with ebullient energy.

definition: a dissenting clique
details: Fractions are smaller parts of whole numbers: one-quarter, one-tenth, one-half, and a faction is a smaller portion of a larger group that breaks away from it. A faction might take a fraction of the people from a large group and start a new group.
examples: Libya is on the brink of an all-out civil war that threatens to upend years of diplomatic efforts to reconcile two rival armed political factions.
But analysts say it is more likely that a collapse of law and order would be prompted by the rivalries between different factions within the security establishment, not the actions of the protesters.
That was the same as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud party did, though smaller right-wing factions tilted the election sharply to the incumbent.

Representatives of a religious ultranationalist faction inspired by the banned Kahanist movement, branded a terrorist organization by the U.S. for an agenda that includes forced expulsion of Palestinians, merged with a religious settler party.

definition: make false by mutilation or addition
details: When you garble something, you warp or distort it, making it hard to understand. Talking with marbles in your mouth is one sure way of garbling your speech.
examples: Indeed, when flicking through the text, it’s not hard to find garbled and incoherent sentences.
Zeppelin’s list reads like something you’d find in an izakaya overseas but frequently eats like a document that got garbled in translation.
It was like a garbled transmission from a starship in distress.
Yet, the social tragedy of the practice and the politics of hate is matched by the absurdity of its avatars, as in Van Der Weyden’s garbled philosophical misadventures with language.

definition: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquility
details: An old man watching his grandchildren play might look back fondly on his halcyon days, remembering the peaceful, happy time of his youth.
examples: But these are no longer the halcyon early days of the internet.
He recalled a halcyon youth of waking at dawn and returning home at dusk.
The Cup may not mean what it did; its halcyon days may be gone.
I wasn’t involved in the video shoot, but the fun and snowball fighting really captures the atmosphere of that halcyon period.

definition: a behavioral attribute peculiar to an individual
details: If a person has an idiosyncrasy, he or she has a little quirk, or a funny behavior, that makes him or her different. If you only say goodbye in French, never in English, that would be an idiosyncrasy.
examples: They were taking part in an idiosyncrasy of the Australian economic system.
The chapter about the idiosyncrasies and hidden frailties of judges is particularly eye-opening.
It's a sentiment shared by tour officials, implementing a round-robin format in 2015, in part, to reduce some of the idiosyncrasies of match play.

Gerald Shuster, who teaches political communication and presidential rhetoric at the University of Pittsburgh, said of O’Rourke’s arms, “If they become too distracting, any idiosyncrasy perceived by the audience is a negative.”

definition: be compatible, similar, or consistent
details: To jibe with someone is to agree with them. Jibe can also mean “be compatible with or similar to.” If two people jibe, they get along quite well.
examples: Introduced by a player from Europe and made popular by a player from South America, the Eurostep jibes with the NBA’s conscious attempts to portray itself as a global game.
The feedback Daniels got about Woodward from Dodgers executives, coaches and former players was favorable and jibed with Young’s assessment.
Kelton responded to Summers’ jibe with a Twitter video clip from the U.S.
To my mind, his art jibes with America’s chief contribution to philosophy, the pragmatism of Charles Sanders Peirce, William James, and John Dewey.

definition: a person of noble birth trained to arms and chivalry
details: Traditionally the noun knight means someone born of the nobility and trained to fight, usually in heavy metal armor. As a verb, if a king decides to knight you, that means the king wants to make you into a knight.
examples: He instead focused on constructing the fanciful Neuschwanstein Castle just up the hill, decorated with themes of brave knights, fair maidens and scenes from Wagnerian operas.
President Trump really puts the “err” in knight errant.
"Maintaining the status quo in terms of the Crusaders name along with the current imagery of knights on horseback is, in our view, no longer tenable," he said.
“Maintaining the status quo in terms of the Crusaders name along with the current imagery of knights on horseback is, in our view, no longer tenable,” he said.

definition: a surgical knife with a pointed double-edged blade
details: The noun lancet describes a small, double-edged surgical knife used to make incisions.
examples: They poked holes in the skull and copiously drained blood with leeches or lancets—a practice that remained a medical mainstay through the late 19th century.
But then you notice the lancet windows of the city’s Victorian-gothic cathedral, and the British street names: Chancery Lane, Bristol Avenue, Fenwick Street.
Police say the Ayden Middle School student found a diabetes lancet and poked several students.
It’s in the center of a colorful swirl of stars and orbits that span three lancet windows, offering a meditation on the heavens and man’s place in the cosmos.

definition: nobility and generosity of spirit
details: Magnanimous behavior is noble, generous, or unselfish, and to exhibit magnanimity is to be this way. He showed great magnanimity in not pressing charges when I drove his car into the pond. "Accidents happen my friend," he said, and patted me on the back.
examples: It does mean that, in the present, we should treat our fellow human beings with greater magnanimity than we often are prone to do.
This might sound like a call for magnanimity, but it is just as much an appeal to self-interest.
NPR repaid the president’s magnanimity with a phony fact check, where they insisted that the number of women in Congress was "almost entirely because of Democrats -- not Trump’s party."
Biss is a virtuoso pianist who performs with a haunted magnanimity that demands as close a vantage point as possible.

definition: any new participant in some activity
details: A neophyte is someone who's brand new at something. You're a neophyte the first time you pick up a guitar and start learning to play.
examples: And as a neophyte party, how it will legislate is difficult to predict.
President Trump is a political neophyte, and as such he gets into trouble.
That’s what happens to neophytes who don’t realize just how toxic the political environment in this country is.

This helped explain why Carnegie Mellon’s first-year classes were starkly divided between the sizable number of men who were already confident in basic programming concepts and the women who were frequently complete neophytes.

definition: not clearly understood or expressed
details: If something is obscure, it's vague and hard to see. Be careful if you're driving in heavy rain — the painted lines can be obscure.
examples: The Senate on Wednesday killed a similar bill because the House added an amendment involving the state’s obscure ruling making process.
The project helped highlight obscure artwork and decipher some theological aspects of the second-floor room, built above what Jewish tradition says is the burial site of King David.
Indian trade representatives regularly use obscure legal precedents to stop the Geneva-based body from doing its job, he says, even trying to block rulings on entirely unrelated matters.
Equally troubling are the Justice Department’s warnings about ADOC’s record- keeping, which obscures how bad things are.

definition: suitable for or like a large and stately residence
details: Knowing that the adjective palatial is derived from the same Latin word as palace gives you a good sense of its meaning: magnificent, reminiscent of a home fit for a king.
examples: She grew up in Northern California near the 128-acre Hearst Castle estate, where her father, Camille, served as construction supervisor for newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst’s palatial home.

This “Sleeping Beauty” is a good fit for the Eisenhower Theater stage with its visual richness, its draped and layered costumes in subtle pastels and soaring, palatial sets from Salt Lake City’s Ballet West.
The city is dotted with Hindu temples, and tourists flock to see the palatial Sikh gurdwaras — but of the vibrant Muslim community that once lived here, there is little trace.
Cardinal O’Malley moved into a small rectory, eschewing and later selling the palatial official residence.

definition: meeting the proper standards and requirements for a task
details: Qualified means something depends on another action occurring. If your friend receives a qualified offer on her house, that means something else has to happen — like a bank approving the loan — before it's sold.
examples: It was their best record since 2005-06 — the last time they qualified for the playoffs.
That was the Kings’ best record since 2005-06 - the last time they qualified for the playoffs.
The justices struggled with which jobs qualified as expressive, and they essentially decided not to decide.
Bling, 19, who qualified for the Masters with a runner-up finish in the U.S.

definition: have or develop complicating consequences
details: The verb ramify describes something that branches off or spreads, like the new subway lines that ramify across your city and reach even the neighborhoods farthest from the center.
examples: This is an instance of synesthesia, when experiences ramify through more than one of our senses.
Single-cell anatomical analysis reveals that each arm of the LPLC2 cross-shaped primary dendrites ramifies in one of these layers and extends along that layer’s preferred motion direction.
The root causes, McGlade said, basically boil down to two major systemic occurrences with multiple ramifying consequences: a changing climate and an intense trend toward greater urbanization.
Because it is possible to think of the Internet itself, in all its incomprehensible vastness, as an exponentially ramifying network of commentary and metacommentary.

definition: conspicuous, prominent, or important
details: If something stands out in a very obvious way, it can be called salient. It's time to find new friends if the differences between you and your current friends are becoming more and more salient.
examples: Married for a decade, the two are perfectly in step on every track, filling the space between one another with Trent’s gravelly voice and Heart’s coarse, yet salient vocals.
But our thirst for punishment is equally politically salient.
Third, it appealed to political elites who are unified by fears of foreign influence, and by the erosion of American institutions and norms, than by other issues more salient for voters as a whole.
Despite the sculptures’ abstract qualities, Ms. Baum said that the work offers a salient commentary on our current moment.

definition: of superficial relevance if any
details: Tangential refers to something that's not part of the whole. If you make a comment that is tangential to the story you're telling, it's a digression. The story could still be understood without it.
examples: Indeed, the investigation was not about some tangential issue.
They shouldn’t be fishing expeditions for tangential, unrelated matters.
Then there’s the astounding view that anti-Zionism bears only a tangential relationship to anti-Semitism.
The Jeff Bezos blog publication may seem tangential to Twitter’s operation, but I think it underlines the substantial influence and growing instrumental importance of the platform.

definition: not arrogant
details: The word unassuming means modest, lacking in arrogance, pleasant, or polite. You'll find that some of the most unassuming people are actually the most interesting and powerful of all. They're just decent enough not to display it all the time.
examples: A tall, angular, fair-skinned man in a wool pullover cap, he’s the sort of friendly, unassuming guy you might meet hiking the canyons of the Hollywood Hills.
When you open the box, you’re greeted by a stack of unassuming cardboard sheets and bag filled with elastic bands and stickers.
The channel’s description was gentle, unassuming: “We hope you enjoy these chill lofi hip hop tunes while studying / chilling / working,” it read.
As a song, “Old Town Road” is an unassuming experiment—the product of a kid messing around with the limited tools at his disposal.

definition: unproductive of success
details: If you spend all day admiring yourself in reflective surfaces — mirrors, pools of water, the backs of spoons — people may think you are conceited or vain.
examples: They burst into Aamir's home wearing balaclavas and screeching and stabbed him in the hallway - his parents fought the attackers in vain as they tried to save their son.
Her parents OK’d the death, though her mother later regretted it and tried in vain to save her daughter.
Pilots of each plane tried in vain to regain control.
Pilots of each plane struggled in vain to regain control over the automated system.

definition: move or cause to move in a sinuous or circular course
details: The verb wander describes something that has lost track. If you're watching a boring movie, your mind might begin to wander. If you don't have a clear goal, you could wander too — meaning you drift aimlessly.
examples: Binge-watch horror trailers and you’ll notice a thrum of sinister music and sound effects, a shadowed and claustrophobic screen-space, random innocents wandering into tense situations, and the cruel smiles or blank masks of monstrous villains.
A conversation with Burnett, 71, easily wanders from musical particulars to philosophical speculations and back.
We see nothing ambiguous about impeding folks from wandering around Montgomery sporting “For Sale” signs.

Monte’s memories recur throughout, but without a free play of memory; his mind neither wanders nor explores nor slips—it corresponds, as if his unconscious were a writers’ room that winks with portentous irony.

definition: a slight wind
details: Besides being the name of Babar's monkey friend in the much-beloved picture books about the elephant Babar, a zephyr is a gentle breeze.
examples: I much enjoyed the Warriors’ first championship team, as it played a brand of basketball that was fresh and beautiful and cut across the sky like a zephyr.
He's five feet nine, about as heavy as a zephyr, and he spends every match getting clobbered by opposing centerbacks.
The forecast for all four of the tournament’s rounds is fine and mild, with a moderate breeze on Thursday tapering off to a light zephyr on Sunday.
And it distilled the myriad shifts and reversals that were wafting through the Beverly Hilton ballroom like encouraging zephyrs, with the dust not soon to settle.

definition: a state or condition markedly different from the norm
details: An aberration is something strange that rarely occurs. An example of an aberration is when the temperature hits 90 degrees in January — it's nice and warm, but it's really strange.
examples: “Intersex people are a part of the fabric of our state’s diversity to be celebrated, rather than an aberration to be corrected,” the bill says.
Even some “good liberals” who consider Trump a horrible aberration don’t acknowledge that he’s only the most prominent carrier and casualty of the larger disease that’s been devouring civil society.
Those performances weren't aberrations, as Els finds himself just two shots off the lead at this week's European Tour event in Malaysia after opening rounds of 68 and 70.
The book argued that the centuries-long history of slavery wasn’t an aberration but a central fact in the creation of the modern world.

definition: something causing misery or death
details: The noun bane refers to anything that is a cause of harm, ruin, or death. But we often use it for things that aren't that bad, just feel like it. You might say mosquitoes are the bane of your existence.
examples: As a high school English teacher, grading is the bane of my existence.
“The bane of our existence as pitchers is the injury,” he said.
