After thousands of dollars are added up for every semester of college, one of the most stressful afterthoughts is the bane of every student’s existence: usually heavy, often useless and always overpriced textbooks.
One of the attorneys returning to her office at the Department of Justice said shutdowns keep everyone from doing their best work — the bane of the kind of achievers we want in government.

definition: emotionally hardened
details: A callous person is insensitive or emotionally hardened. If you laugh at your little sister while she's trying to show you her poetry, you're being callous.
examples: “But the funds do not deliver the ultimate good to the public: the release of the truth through discovery and the release of records documenting the Church’s coverup and callous disregard for children.”
She also apologized for previously being “callous” about immigration, meaning that she used to be mindful of the political center before she started ranting about abolishing ICE.
It’s important to celebrate the fact there was no loss of life, but it seems a bit callous to rejoice in the misfortune of others.
‘Seeing one’s work reproduced without consent is a fear of any illustrator, but seeing it attached to such a callous message is a real nightmare,’ Waszul told The Washington Post.”

definition: a sound defeat
details: Use debacle to refer to a fiasco, disaster, or great failure. If several dogs run onto the field during the big baseball game, tripping players and chewing up the bases, you can call the whole event a debacle.
examples: Impressed by what he heard, and with his injured knee healed, Rodgers was eager to get to Green Bay to start fostering that relationship and to shake off the sting of last season’s 6-9-1 debacle.
The run-up to the second debacle emerged in the 1990s.
The Arlington schools’ track record does not reassure, given the Ashlawn debacle and the opacity with which this policy is being developed.
The debacle raises questions about whether firms should set up such bodies.

definition: selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas
details: She listens to hip-hop, Gregorian chant, and folk music from the '60s. He's been seen wearing a handmade tuxedo jacket over a thrift-store flannel shirt. They both have eclectic tastes.
examples: Paramount promised a year of “eclectic” movies for theater owners.
The dozens of games released over 2018 are an eclectic bunch.
He said he approached casting the show as if he were putting together a dinner party with a wildly eclectic guest list.
More than 150 local artists and collectors rent booths in the eclectic shop, which goes all-out in supporting local creativity.

definition: dissenting with the majority opinion
details: A factious group is one that breaks away, or wants to. It’s often used in politics, where people separate into smaller like-minded groups. The Confederacy was factious — they wanted out of the Union, but we know how that turned out.
examples: Those backing a shorter respite for Britain said it would keep up the pressure on the factious House of Commons to ratify the stalled EU exit deal.
Queen Elizabeth in January sent a delicately coded message to Britain’s factious political class over Brexit, urging lawmakers to seek common ground and grasp the big picture to resolve the crisis.

Elegantly shot and edited, the movie closely tracks the new factory’s growing pains, which turn increasingly factious as the company’s management practices clash with the expectations of American workers accustomed to hard-won labor rights.
Lincoln also warned that “a nation which endures factious domestic division is exposed to disrespect abroad, and one party, if not both, is sure sooner or later to invoke foreign intervention.”

definition: tastelessly showy
details: Use the adjective garish to describe something that is overly vivid, bright, showy, and in bad taste — like the DJ's garish outfit that is a flashback to the disco era.
examples: The visually garish, dynamic worlds Burton created earlier in his career often supported that storytelling perfectly, when rendered with a mix of tangible, practical sets and makeup enhanced with computer-generated effects.
It did not look like the team that lost a garish West Coast Conference final to Saint Mary’s, 60-47.
At the time, he tweeted in response to the article, titled “The Great Sadness of Ben Affleck,” saying: “@NewYorker I’m doing just fine. Thick skin bolstered by garish tattoos.”
“This ghoulish, grisly, and garish proposed law would codify abortion — at any stage, right through the day before birth — as a fundamental human right,” said Mr. Zupan in a Manchester Journal op-ed.

definition: exhibiting or restored to vigorous good health
details: If you're hale, you’re strong and in good health. Think "hale and hearty," the well-known phrase to describe someone who can lift a piano or work ten hours in a field without blinking an eye.
examples: From the Anglo-Saxon “hale,” meaning “whole,” true health brings self-evident harmony to your body, from tip to toe.
The retired general, the inn, snowy, snowy Vermont—John fell into a lull, all this East Coast hale and heartiness, everyone in ruddy good health.
Immigration allowed for a constant gene flow, which kept the troop hale, hearty and healthy.
He is almost two decades older, but — up to the point at which the book begins — hale.

definition: the worship of idols or images that are not God
details: Idolatry means the worship of images as if they were gods. Many religions prohibit idolatry, some even to the extent of forbidding any representational objects in houses of worship.
examples: In it, Mr. Cahn likens Mr. Trump to the biblical king Jehu, who led the ancient nation of Israel away from idolatry.

Saudi Arabia’s strictly conservative religious ideology regards any reverence for pre-Islamic sites as idolatry, leading to the destruction or neglect of artifacts and architecture from the pre-Islamic and early Islamic eras.
There’s something almost sad about seeing this kind of idolatry articulated so clearly.
Our thing did seem a bit like idolatry when you put it that way.

definition: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
details: You know that teacher who always has a goofy smile on his face and a bad pun for the kids? He's got a jocund personality, meaning he's merry and cheerful.
examples: That last part is a bit of cheek for effect, deleted quickly by a green cursor, a taste of the jocund energy that informs this six-part limited series.
The happy and jocund faces of children, whom you looked upon complacently a month or two ago, will laugh away, you are tolerably sure, the disposition to low spirits and pale brandy.
Hither flock the jocund burgesses, and dance to the sound of harp and viol.
On the Common, jocund morning, fresh green of turf and tree, sweet breath of the earth; sunshine, bird-song, youth, ...

definition: a small natural hill
details: A knoll is a small hill or mound of earth, which makes a shady knoll a perfect spot for a summer picnic.
examples: But the remaining dozen or so Marines were stranded after a second helicopter was hit by enemy fire and crashed en route to the knoll.
The photographer chose to centre the project on the area in which she grew up; Burrow Hill, a grassy knoll formed on a rocky sandstone deposit on the edge of the Somerset Levels.
Looming over the San Gabriel Valley city, the walled and gated mansion sits on a private knoll of just over 2.5 acres.
They caught on a knoll on a vertical section of north-facing cliff, stranding them in a precarious position.

definition: lacking spirit or liveliness
details: Describe a slow-moving river or a weak breeze or a listless manner with the slightly poetic adjective, languid.
examples: The ball’s trajectory was languid and dreamy, like a gull gliding on an ocean breeze.
The key to Eazi’s success: a laid-back, languid delivery that guides listeners through his sweltering grooves.
With an athlete’s languid energy, Sacks led me to one end of the room, where we regarded “Amnesty” from afar before walking toward it.
It fit with Todbaum’s languid complacency, his stated preference for using what he called “available materials,” his way of throwing money at any situation.

definition: more than half of the votes in an election
details: Majority means “most of,” or the biggest part. Does the majority of what owls eat — mice, rats, squirrels, moles — sound appetizing to you? If not, you’re probably in the majority of people.
examples: The referrals stem from the investigation conducted by the House Intelligence Committee when Republicans held the House majority.
The majority of people with measles this year in the U.S. were not vaccinated, according to the U.S.
Amazon generates a large majority of its sales in the U.S., and it’s somewhat surprising that Amazon’s online sales aren’t growing that much faster than the e-commerce category.

The paper discovered Theranos’ technology was not all it was cracked up to be, allegedly using routine blood-testing equipment for the vast majority of tests rather than the revolutionary technology Theranos touted.

definition: disturb, especially by minor irritations
details: If you know what a nettle is—it's a plant with stinging hairs—then you'll have no trouble remembering the verb nettle: it means to annoy, bother, irritate, or bedevil.
examples: But cream sauce muffled the tortellini’s vivid nettle pesto, and the agnolotti were mired in a dull brown sauce the menu described as parmesan “brodo.”
Native Americans used the sturdy fronds to wrap and protect food during cooking, and eased the pain of nettle stings with the powdery spores.
The question nettled Ms. Ocasio-Cortez, who presents herself as a working-class champion against the corrupting influence of money in politics.
Hundreds of maroon sea nettle jellyfish drifted under the boat, and dolphin pods followed our wake.

definition: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
details: If you disapprove of the overly submissive way someone is acting — like the teacher's pet or a celebrity's assistant — call them by the formal adjective obsequious.
examples: Its distinguishing features included a hazy provenance; an obsequious, uninformative text; a lazily organized catalog of songs; and an unaccountable focus on an unknown performer.
After all, Alexander Hamilton worried in the very first of the Federalist Papers about those who would pay “obsequious court to the people; commencing demagogues, and ending tyrants.”
He delivered flattery in the ostentatiously obsequious register that Trump prefers.
I wasn’t recommending fawning, obsequious flattery; rather, recognizing and acknowledging things about your manager that you genuinely appreciate.

definition: a sudden numbing dread
details: A pall was originally a coffin’s cloak. Now pall usually means that an event or situation is — literally or figuratively — covered in gloom, like disappointing news that casts a pall on your day.
examples: While the typically loud racetrack cheering returned in later races, there was a pall over the place as everyone tried to adjust.
Mr. Kraft spent much of his time palling around with Meek Mill’s son and his son’s half brother.
The wonders of Wonder Park are dampened by the pall of grief that the protagonist is experiencing, while the wacky amusement park antics prevent the story from going especially deep.
It is an extremely narrow and unvaried technique, like the Evita-style arm-raises that also recur, and the excitement of it quickly palls.

definition: overcome or allay
details: Meaning to suppress or overcome, quell is what you have to do with nerves before a big test and fears before going skydiving.
examples: Zielke subsequently met seven employees on the 47th floor of the bank’s Frankfurt tower to quell concerns and explain his stance.
The organization’s statement – which wrongly suggested Inuit share the same beliefs as indigenous communities in the south of the country – did little to quell frustrations.
It was a masterclass, with West Ham utterly unable to quell his threat wherever he secured possession on the pitch.
Three pitchers were then used in the eighth inning before Jansen jogged to the mound to quell the Dodgers’ anxiety.

definition: an embankment built around a space for defensive purposes
details: If you are building a sand castle and want it to be extra realistic, don’t forget the rampart. This protective wall may not keep the ocean away, but it might intimidate a few hostile hermit crabs.
examples: Dozens of buses are parked sideways around the perimeter, forming makeshift ramparts.
You’ll need multiple visits to do justice to this park’s 77,000 feet of saltwater shoreline, three freshwater lakes and 38 miles of hiking trails traversing, old-growth forest and rocky ramparts.
“Nobody else is exactly storming the ramparts of the White House demanding you hire them for the toughest job in world politics,” the British television host wrote in the Daily Mail.

The Italian flagship store of Tod’s is embraced by concrete shadows echoing the trees that line Omotesandō; next door, the menswear shop Hugo Boss looks like a towering-yet-friendly asymmetrical castle rampart.

definition: promoting health
details: Salubrious is a fancy way to describe something that’s good for you or is generally favorable to mind or body, but it need not be limited to describing healthy foods or liquids.
examples: Political leaders evoke distant quarrels to revive memories of more salubrious and magnificent days.
This overlooks many less salubrious elements of that relationship.
Ferrante fans are more likely to flock to the more salubrious areas of this complex yet fascinating southern Italian city that feature in the novels.
Another issue we highlighted is that less salubrious aspects of change accompanied eras of rapid progress.

definition: leave slowly and hesitantly
details: To tarry is to linger and take your time leaving. If you really like going to Sally’s Diner for dessert, you might tarry over coffee and end up leaving after they’ve closed the kitchen.
examples: But despite his best efforts, the pipes spout tarry filth, the walls secrete viscous goo, and marbles seemingly appear spontaneously around closets and stairs.
And with another season over and another very soon to begin, it would be best if tennis’s leaders did not tarry, either.
But he never went far enough, just toggled between boroughs, and at some point he’d tarried, put down roots.
“Yes,” said Sister McCandless, “that sure is a praying man. I tell you, it ain’t every shepherd tarries before the Lord for his flock like Father James does.”

definition: surpassing the ordinary or normal
details: If something is uncanny, it is so mysterious, strange, or unfamiliar that it seems supernatural. If you hear strange music echoing through your attic, you might refer to it as positively uncanny.
examples: The moment is startling, akin to the uncanny rise of crippled congregants moved by the Spirit.
He also displays an uncanny sense of how time works, zooming past entire years with no warning, much like years tend to do.
Cloak and Dagger — leading very different lives, both trying to keep a low profile while honing their uncanny powers.
This level of production is not only rare; it borders on uncanny.

definition: lacking significance or liveliness or spirit or zest
details: Reserve the adjective vapid for the airhead in your office who brings nothing to the table, except maybe the doughnuts. Vapid is an adjective to describe someone or something that is dull or uninspiring.
examples: To his critics, Schnabel was synonymous with the decade’s excess, yuppie culture and penchant for vapid self-aggrandising.
The article said the film is as vapid and sexist as the band was.
Rieff found America’s therapeutic culture vapid, but it’s also open-minded and even egalitarian.
The overscaled hallways and caverns increase the sense of alienation: The characters are as vapid as the hotel that symbolizes the colonial regime.

definition: unprovoked or without motive or justification
details: Wanton describes something excessive, uncontrolled and sometimes even cruel. The principal sees a food fight as a wanton act of vandalism done with wanton disregard for the rules, but the kids might just see it as fun.
examples: Jail records show he’s held on murder, arson, wanton endangerment and public intoxication charges.
Laurel County jail records show Brock is held on murder, arson, wanton endangerment and public intoxication charges.
Allen is also charged with wanton endangerment, burglary, receiving stolen property, criminal mischief, fleeing or evading police and criminal trespassing.
The Durango Herald reports Mark Franklin is scheduled to be tried in Utah’s Carbon County on charges of trespassing and wanton destruction of livestock.

definition: assist or encourage, usually in some wrongdoing
details: To abet is to help someone do something, usually something wrong. If you were the lookout while your older sister swiped cookies from the cookie jar, you abetted her mischief.
examples: She said voter suppression was too often abetted by the “complicity” of political candidates, including the losers.
The report concludes that racism exists at UCT, “abetted by poor management systems” which “discriminate on a racial basis”.
Two uncles are accused of aiding and abetting the abuse.
It said identifying individuals involved would “aid and abet the regime in Pyongyang”.

definition: send away from a place of residence, as for punishment
details: To banish is to get rid of. Think very carefully before you banish someone from your group. Someday, you may want that person around again.
examples: In 2017, following the deadly white nationalist demonstrations in Charlottesville, Va., tech giants began banishing extremist groups and individuals espousing white supremacist views and support for violence.
In 2017, following the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, tech giants began banishing extremist groups and individuals espousing white supremacist views and support for violence.
In 2017, following the deadly demonstrations in Charlottesville, Virginia, tech giants began banishing extremist groups and individuals espousing white supremacist views and support for violence.
If you cross a line, you will be banished.

definition: the quality of affording easy familiarity and sociability
details: Camaraderie is a spirit of good friendship and loyalty among members of a group. You might not like your job, but still enjoy the camaraderie of the people you work with.
examples: Where are the films and series about women experiencing that special, complicated competitive camaraderie of team play?
Seeking camaraderie, he and a group of others formed a “book club” that served as a de facto liberal sub-caucus, which infuriated senior Democratic leaders.
The class also provides a camaraderie that may be nearly as essential as the exercise.
One hopes this is the start of a trend, where coaches at top programs throw games against McNeese State and Incarnate Word in order to build camaraderie.

definition: corrupt morally or by intemperance or sensuality
details: To debase something is to make it corrupt or impure. If your lemonade stand sells “pure lemonade,” you’d insist on using real lemons instead of a mix; using a mix would debase your product.
examples: Mapplethorpe both exalted and debased the black models who posed for him, an artistic relationship that should invite reassessment for its uneven power dynamic.
In this account, writing is already a kind of adaptation, in which inner experience is translated into a commodity form, alienated and debased.
Many of these purchases reproduce deep histories of racism and violence that debase and dehumanize Afro-Cubans and more generally, Black people.
But to hear that this same man finds time—between shooting his money to Mars—to send lurid, thrillingly debased texts to his paramour, Lauren Sanchez?

definition: a formal or authoritative proclamation
details: If your mom orders you to clean your room, that's an order. If the king asks you to do it, that's an edict — an official order from some higher up.
examples: On Late Night, Seth Meyers railed against the hypocrisy of Republicans supporting Trump’s border edicts.
The chancellor is convinced to pass an edict.

The Obama administration’s guidance drew wide-ranging criticism, including from college administrators, as arbitrary edicts that pressured colleges to conduct quasi-legal processes with a presumed outcome in favor of victims.
Following their mother’s edict, they worked hard and secured places together to Stanford, and then Harvard.

definition: not produced by natural forces; artificial or fake
details: If you create a "diamond" out of plastic, then you’ve created a factitious diamond, meaning that it’s a phony.
examples: There is even a pathological manifestation of the condition called “factitious victimisation”, of which Munchausen syndrome is an extreme version.

Instead, she explained that Munchausen syndrome by proxy – classified under “factitious disorder imposed on another” in the latest American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders – doesn’t always, or even usually, involve poison.
I hadn't known what factitious meant, so I looked it up in the dictionary.

“Frustrated opponents of the president are grasping at straws and factitious rumors to advance their own political agenda rather than the interests of the country,” Mr. Sensenbrenner said in an emailed statement.

definition: full of trivial conversation
details: A garrulous person just won’t stop talking (and talking, and talking, and talking...).
examples: Media narratives coalesced around words like “quirky,” “anachronistic,” “effusive,” “undisciplined,” “garrulous,” and “folksy.”
These conflicts are embodied by the series’ central figure, Gomez, a garrulous former cop, now private investigator, who calls himself “a punisher of the wicked … a bringer of justice for the good.”
This creature is not molded from earth, however, but from the body parts of people killed in post-invasion Iraq, scavenged by a garrulous junk dealer.
The duo are opposites: one experienced, the other a novice; one garrulous, the other taciturn; one eating freeze-dried food in his tent, the other eager to meet the locals.

definition: proceeding in a fragmentary, hesitant, or ineffective way
details: The adjective halting is used to describe something that is fragmentary or prone to interruptions. If you are overcome with emotion at your wedding, you may choke out your vows in a halting voice. If you're afraid you might trip, take halting steps.
examples: The Jockeys’ Guild’s agreeing to halting the experiment is not open-ended.
Allowances were raised again two years later in a new government, halting the rise in numbers of employed Haredi, Regev said.
This week, a federal judge issued an injunction halting a program requiring Central Americans to wait in Mexico as their asylum cases are adjudicated.
Last week, however, a judge ruled against the order, temporarily halting it.

definition: cause to start burning
details: Ignite is a verb that means to start heat or a flame. Trying to ignite a match inside a dark fireworks factory is a really bad idea — one that can get you blown sky high.
examples: The spacecraft will ignite its main engine again, slowing itself down from 3,700 miles per hour to zero.
That leaves thousands of homes at risk from the next inferno across California, their wood-shake shingles waiting to ignite.
Her first album Horses was released at the end of 1975, a full five months before the first Ramones album, but it ignited the punk explosion more in personality than musicality.
“There’s just a different brand of history there, and it does ignite the industry,” he said.

definition: make one's way by pushing or shoving
details: The verb jostle describes being bumped and pushed in a horde of people — or doing the bumping, like those at a concert who jostle their way to the front, and the people jostled out of their spots when the newcomers arrive.
examples: But Blue is more like a human in a crowded subway car: jostle it, and it’ll move aside.
Now they are too big, and my sleep is seriously suffering — I am constantly jostled by them all night, and I just don't sleep.
Her crew of political cut-throats, chancers and deadbeats jostle for position, tidying her messes, somehow making everything worse in the process.

definition: a small storeroom for storing foods or wines

definition: a person who is unsatisfied or disgusted
details: A malcontent is someone who's always dissatisfied. The guy at the restaurant who sends back the steak because it's too rare, then sends it back a second time complaining that it's not rare enough — he's a malcontent.

definition: someone who rejects all theories of morality
details: If you reject all moral beliefs and take the view that life has no meaning, you could be called a nihilist.

definition: lacking in insight or discernment
details: The adjective obtuse is good for describing someone slow on the uptake: "Don't be so obtuse: get with the program!"
examples: These obtuse and high-handed governmental removals almost never concluded so peaceably.

definition: beat rapidly
details: When you watch scary movies, do you ever feel your heart palpitate? This means it beats quickly.

definition: being quiet or still or inactive
details: The adjective quiescent means "being quiet and still," like the quiescent moments lying in a hammock on a beautiful summer Sunday.
examples: Large public works programs and free loans to young people, financed by the country’s oil and gas wealth, kept citizens content and quiescent.

definition: a variety of different things or activities
details: The word range refers to a variety of things or to an area in which something operates. The store offers the living room set in a range of colors. What's the range of that remote-controlled airplane?

definition: fill to satisfaction
details: If you just can't get enough popcorn, even the jumbo tub at the movie theater may not be enough to satiate, or satisfy, your desire.

definition: a characteristic state of feeling
details: Temper can refer to a tendency to become unreasonably angry. If you’re not sure whether you have a temper, ask your friends — but don’t get mad if you dislike what they have to say.
examples: Tesla Inc. and Panasonic Corp. are tempering expansion plans for the battery gigafactory into which they’ve plugged billions in the last few years, deepening concerns about demand for the carmaker’s electric vehicles.

definition: excessive but superficial compliments with affected charm
details: Unction is a specially-prepared substance meant to bless or heal — the use of special oils in a religious ceremony or the medicine you might put on your chest if you are congested.
examples: They were still looking at him with consternation and unbelief when the minister rose and introduced him in rich, rolling tones whose very unction served to increase the visitor's insignificance.

definition: profoundly honored
details: To be venerable is to be admired and respected because of your status or age. You become venerable by achieving great things or just by living long enough.
examples: The German village of Oberammergau is as commercial as it is cute — busy with tour groups and the venerable shops of the town’s famous woodcarvers.

definition: marked by keen caution and watchful prudence
details: Describe yourself as wary if you don't quite trust someone or something and want to proceed with caution. Be wary of risky things like wild mushrooms and Internet deals!

definition: most unfortunate or miserable

definition: moderate or restrain; lessen the force of

definition: openly straightforward and direct without secretiveness

definition: a downward slope or bend

definition: excessively self-indulgent, affected, or decadent

definition: undeveloped but potentially useful

definition: bring into existence

definition: annoy continually or chronically

definition: make free from confusion or ambiguity

definition: having or exerting a malignant influence

definition: insignificantly small; a matter of form only

definition: do away with

definition: a short moral story

definition: make jokes or witty remarks

definition: wandering freely
details: If you're driving in the country and have to stop the car to let a bunch of cows slowly cross the road, you'll be sitting there for a while admiring a herd of ranging, or freely wandering, cattle.

definition: witty language used to convey insults or scorn

definition: draw out a discussion or process in order to gain time
details: The verb temporize describes stalling in order to gain time in the hopes of avoiding or preventing something. Your class might temporize so your teacher won't have time to give the pop quiz you all think she's going to give.

definition: enter upon an activity or enterprise
details: When you undertake a task or challenge, you attempt to accomplish it. If you want to undertake a verbal challenge right now, try saying “sushi chef” ten times quickly without messing up.

definition: regard with feelings of respect and reverence
details: To venerate is to worship, adore, be in awe of. You probably don't venerate your teacher or boss; however, you may act like you do!
examples: Cardinal Timothy Dolan, the archbishop of New York, is to lead a Sunday procession venerating the heart of St. John Vianney, who was a priest in the southern French town of Ars, outside Lyon.

definition: pause or hold back in uncertainty or unwillingness
details: To waver is to move back and forth, like when you waver, one minute thinking you'll stay home, planning to go meet your friends the next, until you finally make your decision.

definition: formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief

examples: People who are otherwise deemed sceptical abjure their reason and believe in miracles.

definition: cheap showy jewelry or ornament

definition: showing self-interest and shrewdness in dealing with others
details: If you're a canny investor, you know how to spend money to make money — that is, you're prudent, farsighted, and capable of protecting your own interests, particularly in matters of finance or business.
examples: He’s admired by many as a canny political operative, but unreservedly trusted by few.

definition: propriety in manners and conduct
details: Decorum is proper and polite behavior. If you let out a big belch at a fancy dinner party, you're not showing much decorum.
examples: “We encourage our patrons to exhibit proper decorum,” said Ridley.

definition: capacity or power to produce a desired result
details: The degree to which a method or medicine brings about a specific result is its efficacy. You might not like to eat it, but you can't question the efficacy of broccoli as a health benefit.
examples: The bureaucratic quantification of public administration goes far beyond an attempt at discerning efficacy.

definition: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way

definition: a coming into being
details: When you talk about the genesis of something, you're talking about where it began. The genesis of hip-hop music was the party scene in New York City’s South Bronx in the 1970s.

definition: speed up the progress of; facilitate
details: The verb hasten means to move at a high speed. If you hasten to your room, no one will know that you came in late.

definition: widely known and esteemed
details: Something that's Illustrious is well known or famous, leaving a trail of glory in its wake. An illustrious career, for example, is full of impressive achievements and celebrated contributions to society.

definition: extend out or project in space
details: When something juts, it extends outward. Your nose juts out from your face, just as your ears jut from your head. If you’re feeling determined, you might jut out your chin.
examples: Among the simpler subjects are European cafes, a staircase that juts into the Adriatic and children playing hide-and-seek in a classical garden.

definition: freedom from normal restraints in conduct
details: Use the word latitude to describe how much freedom you have in making choices. For example, if a teacher gives you latitude in writing your paper, you might get to choose the topic and how many sources to include.
examples: It obscured Mars's atmosphere and temporarily forced the spacecraft to focus its search for methane on high elevations and latitudes.

definition: feeling a need to see others suffer
details: Malice is the intention to cause harm. If someone feels malice toward you, look out! They've got bad intentions.
examples: Public figures must show that the publication operated with a “reckless disregard” for the truth and with “actual malice,” and there are few examples of successful suits by politicians.
She uses her power over and over again to try to protect Dorian and herself from racist state trooper Officer Lasky, played with chilling malice by Billions’ Glenn Fleshler.
Voluntary manslaughter is defined legally as taking the life of another person in the heat of passion, without malice.
In court, they said the hoarding was a result of "mental illness", not malice or treason.

definition: marked by casual unconcern or indifference
details: If your friend is acting cool, unconcerned or in an indifferent manner, call him nonchalant — like when he saunters by a group of whispering, giggling girls and just nods and says, "Hey."
examples: Would Smith prefer interviewers to be casually dismissive or nonchalant?
Their soft-shoe was recklessly slow, a nonchalant tightrope walk of graceful control and rhythmic exactitude.They toured with the big bands of Cab Calloway and Count Basie.
One took him just a few steps to his left, and he glided under it before making a nonchalant catch by his hip.
Striving for a nonchalant vibe in official campaign emails is not a Trump innovation.

definition: block passage through
details: Occlude means to obstruct, as with an opening. You hear this a lot in a medical context. Heart surgeons are looking for occlusions in blood vessels––things that occlude the flow of blood.
examples: And yet yesterday’s good deeds remain good even if today’s bad ones occlude them.
The scene Friday was far more occluded than the media hullabaloo on Sept. 9, 1998, when two dark vans pulled up to Capitol Hill with 36 boxes containing Ken Starr’s report on presidential chicanery.
Fragmented by design, the book’s structure heightens the immediacy of its testimony but often occludes its inquiry into wider issues.
I find this earlier novel more satisfactory as an act of storytelling than Family Lexicon, where the narrator occludes her own experience.

definition: a perfect embodiment of a concept
details: Paragon applies to someone who is a model of perfection in some quality or trait. We link paragon with other words that follow it, such as "paragon of virtue" or "paragon of patience."
examples: A stickler for the rule of law, he respected the judges in Jerusalem and the rights of Israel’s Arab minority, and was a paragon of modesty.
Or that she would invoke former secretary of state Hillary Clinton as a paragon of dutiful defense work.
Unlike the Spanish-style haciendas, the Italianate villas, or faux Tudor mansions that populated this neighborhood of film stars, crowds were there to see this paragon of modernism.
You hold up Rockefeller Center as a paragon of city planning - are the tenants there not high-end restaurants, multi-national Fortune 500 companies and luxury retail?

definition: make resentful or angry
details: Rankle is a cranky-sounding verb that means to eat away at or aggravate to the point of causing anger. If you want to rankle a cat, try splashing it with water and then putting it in the bathtub.
examples: Mr. Trump’s decision on the Golan Heights rankled Egyptian officials, as did his earlier order to move the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
They always punch up, never down, which rankles the powerful and puts the team more or less permanently on the verge of insubordination.
While the Astros batted in the seventh, Cole was still rankled while pacing back and forth in the dugout.
In all the back-and-forth, there is one particular point that really rankles me.

definition: infuse or fill completely
details: The verb saturate means to cause something to be fully soaked to the point where it can't take on anything else. A heavy rainstorm can saturate the ground, leaving puddles on the lawn because no more water can be absorbed.
examples: Let’s focus on one of the most vexing dietary issues: saturated fat.
But the label notes a high amount of saturated fat.
But the exchange with reporters was otherwise so saturated with falsity and misdirection that the actual state of play was left in doubt.
Atlas reads the work himself, and his voice — that of the bookman, rather than professional narrator — is saturated with feeling.

definition: based on sound reasoning or evidence
details: If your teacher says your position on the benefits of abolishing homework is not tenable, she means it is not based in fact. To be tenable is to be evidence-based and well-founded.
examples: "Maintaining the status quo in terms of the Crusaders name along with the current imagery of knights on horseback is, in our view, no longer tenable," he said.
“Maintaining the status quo in terms of the Crusaders name along with the current imagery of knights on horseback is, in our view, no longer tenable,” he said.
“It’s also a recognition that the position to fight minimum wage increases tooth and nail that the company clung to for so long is no longer tenable.”

Meanwhile, the chaos, confusion and contradictions of Parliament’s efforts to find a tenable Brexit policy must seriously undermine confidence in Britain’s political system and its ability to attract future investors, domestic and foreign.

definition: any piece of work that is attempted
details: Painting a house is a serious undertaking––it looks simple but involves a lot of preparation and hard work. An undertaking is a job or a task you commit to. The word also can mean the profession of funeral management.
examples: “This is at the Ford Theatre, so my sense is that his audience is also expanding. He’s a force of nature, this is a huge undertaking for him.”
Still, it’s fairly obvious it’s a prodigious undertaking.
Launching an infrastructure investment program is the kind of big bipartisan undertaking that seems all but impossible in times like these.
This culminated in her dismissal as "being incapable of undertaking the duties of her post", while Smith continued in his role.

definition: easily excused or forgiven
details: Some crimes are unforgivable. Others are venial — venial crimes and sins are excusable. They're not a big deal.
examples: Father Byrnes went on to discuss the difference between mortal and venial sins.
And when they do, the framework they’re working through suggests that they might be committing a venial sin by putting trees above people.
In the grand scheme of electoral politics, however, these are pretty venial trespasses.
Sins were divided into three grades – original, venial and mortal.

definition: increase in phase
details: The verb wax is most often found in the company of its opposite, "wane." To wax is to grow larger or increase, whereas wane means to grow smaller or decrease.
examples: Remove all the wax from your ears with the Q-Tip Drill Bit.
At a precise spot on the common, Williams and his famous witness buried the hare, which was sealed in wax and placed in a ceramic case to evade metal detectors.
I light two and we use those to tag team the rest, racing to finish before the wax drips.
The bad news is I was so shocked I morphed into a wax museum exhibit of myself.

definition: sharply disagreeable, unpleasant, or harsh
details: What does an obnoxious person have in common with sandpaper? Both are abrasive. Anything that grates or irritates — physically or metaphorically — can be described using this adjective.
examples: As his profile rose, his abrasive remarks drew increasingly intense criticism in the national media.
The contents of my Prose smell fine—less abrasive than the drugstore stuff, vaguely floral, like an expensive perfume, but muted.

Before, Westa said, she saw liberals as opponents who forced “a lot of abrasive conversations” whenever she set up a table on campus to promote Young Americans for Freedom, a conservative group she helps lead.
The comic and tragic are in this staging cut from the same abrasive cloth, with crowd scenes that quickly turn threatening and characters who lurk moodily on the edges.

definition: resembling or befitting an angel or saint
details: That blissful grin on your face? It could be described as beatific, meaning it projects a peaceful sense of joy.
examples: “I imagined long, silent afternoons in spotless rooms, typing clean lines of prose while the baby napped beatifically in a sunbeam,” she recalls.
In his TV series, he’s indulged his squishy side, a little in “Extras,” and a lot in the maudlin “Derek,” in which he played a beatific, childlike nursing-home worker.
Another woman sprouts multiple legs that dance gaily as she smiles beatifically.
The documentary “Woodstock,” released in 1970 and edited in part by a young Martin Scorsese, won an Academy Award for its beatific crowd shots of the swaying, fringed counterculture.

definition: a collection of books accepted as holy scripture
details: Canon (one “n”) refers to a collection of rules or texts that are considered to be authoritative. Shakespeare and Chaucer are part of the canon of Western literature, so you might read their work in an English class.
examples: Those who are less familiar with the Hellboy canon might be overwhelmed, as this all hurtles at a relentless, unforgiving pace.

As Rodney Fopp wrote, Marcuse’s argument “was trenchantly criticized because it was anti‐democratic and defied the academic canon of value neutrality. Yet his argument is attracting renewed interest in the 21st century.”
“Le Corsaire” fairly bursts with virtuosic showpieces and spirited good times, but it’s also the most inane work in the classical canon.
Amid impassioned debates about the canon and its exclusion of historically marginalized voices, his remarkably individual and intricately crafted musical voice is long overdue for discovery.

definition: a legally binding command or decision
details: Look carefully! A decree isn't something you get when you graduate. That one little letter change makes it something else altogether: a legally binding command or the announcement of such a thing.
examples: Last year, then President Michel Temer decreed a federal intervention in Rio de Janeiro that put the army in charge of security.
District Judge James Bredar said the consent decree agreement to reform Baltimore’s beleaguered force will withstand any “drama and trauma” in city leadership.
The new rules will include a minimum timeframe of six months from petition stage to decree absolute - the legal document that ends a marriage.

On Friday, Trump called for Congress to “get rid of the whole asylum system” and get rid of immigration judges, and criticized a long-standing federal court decree mandating certain standards of care for migrant children.

definition: a foul-smelling outflow or vapor
details: Effluvium is a smelly gas, vapor, or an exhalation. You wouldn't want to breathe in the effluvium from a cargo ship or you might become ill. Stick to sailing.
examples: That’s important to keep in mind in an era that finds America wading hip deep in a cascading tide of bovine effluvium.
They quoted Shakespeare and used words like “effluvium” in everyday speech.
Note the drain in the floor: By intermission, stagehands will be hosing away the blood and effluvia.
After a while, it becomes easy to wave off even the most pestilent and dangerous effluvia as just more of the same old routine debris.

definition: imagine; conceive of; see in one's mind
details: Fancy can be an adjective, noun, or a verb. As an adjective, it’s the opposite of plain. The noun names something that isn’t real. When someone likes or wants something, the verb can be used: “I fancy a cup of tea.” Doesn’t that sound fancy?
examples: The greens will be as slick as ever, mind, thanks to Augusta’s fancy SubAir drainage system.

In an age of screens and keyboarding, when kids hardly learn cursive anymore, fountain pens — along with their old-timey accoutrements like blotters, bottled ink and fancy nibs — are making a comeback.
Before the season, the Astros and Yankees both fancied themselves World Series contenders.
She even wrote the airport a letter "on fancy paper and everything", giving her address and asking them to send more planes past her house.

definition: elegance by virtue of fineness of manner and expression
details: Anyone can be nice. Many people have good manners. But gentility is that rare kind of graciousness that is handed down from one elegant generation to the next.
examples: The teenager who sewed her own skirts with babysitting money grew into a woman with no schooling, and little interest, in Southern glamour or gentility.
Marlin Fitzwater, who was the late president’s White House press secretary, said the ceremony “will show a quality of gentility and kindness that he was noted for.”
Our town is a lovely mix of old Florida Gulf-side hamlet and Deep South gentility, blue-collar redneck ethos, military town and artist colony.
He emerged as a symbol of racial pride, crossing Tin Pan Alley gentility with street patois, and sometimes singing directly about black frustrations.

definition: having or showing arrogant superiority
details: Someone who is haughty is arrogant and full of pride. When you're haughty, you have a big attitude and act like you're better than other people.
examples: Right from the start of negotiations we insisted on playing it the haughty way.
Here she is on a young white woman in Zambia: “She seemed both weak and imperious, helpless yet haughty. In a word: British.”
So, in the interest of balance, here is some of what Egdes claimed in an overnight email, prefacing it with the haughty: “There will be no further comments on this matter.”
Her people don’t talk so much as they exclaim “with a contemptuous sneer” or “a loud, haughty cry of derision.”

definition: take in liquids
details: Imbibe is a fancy word for "drink." If you need to imbibe ten cups of coffee just to get out of the house, you might have a caffeine problem.
examples: Sweat bees, also known as Halictidae, are attracted to sweat and sometimes land on people to imbibe perspiration.
For middle school student Han Dong-jae, eating greasy barbecued pork belly on a smoggy day is a life lesson imbibed from his mother.
As anyone with a friend or relative who suffers from substance abuse knows all too well, the addict’s reasons for imbibing their drug of choice are often multitudinous and frequently hurtful.
This translates beautifully to her late night series, where Busy and guests imbibe cocktails and visit and giggle unapologetically.

definition: praise, glorify, or honor
details: To laud someone means to praise them extravagantly — usually in a very public manner. A music critic might laud a new song by calling it the best summer anthem ever created.
examples: Democrats took their time to laud Bank of America and Citigroup's decision not to finance gun manufacturing companies, while Republicans took their turns to lambaste them.
Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, held his own event, speaking to members of the Guard and their families, and lauding their role in “defending the country and the revolution.”

Some circles lauded her — The Guardian named “Chris” album of the year, Time picked “Girlfriend” as song of 2018 — but in France some undermined her, even for a matter as insignificant as her cropped hair.
The bill’s sponsor, Republican Sen. Jim Davis, lauded the tribe for bringing jobs to an otherwise distressed portion of western North Carolina.

definition: someone shirking duty by feigning illness or incapacity
details: Have you ever pretended to be sick or hurt to get out of taking a test or doing a chore? Then you, my dear, are a malingerer, and should be ashamed of yourself. Shape up!
examples: In other words, if one believes that people with low credit scores are moochers and malingerers.
Until this point, soldiers bearing psychic wounds tended to be dismissed by the military as cowards and malingerers.
Having recently visited upstate Buffalo, I stopped at two different Starbucks and saw the same thing: radically redesigned cafes that clearly sent a message to laptop malingerers.
Spotting a malingerer often requires extended observation, suspicion that a patient may be feigning illness, and collaboration across multiple providers.

definition: a person of no influence
details: The noun nonentity refers to a person of no significance or importance. If you are a member of a sports team, but spend all your time sitting on the bench watching the rest of the team play, you will probably feel like a nonentity.
examples: Earlier in her career, though, as a prosecutor and then as state attorney general, she was a nonentity on the issue.
“McCarthy’s like a nonentity, and McConnell — God knows what motivates him,” he said.
In “Breaking Bad,” Walter White went from ineffectual nonentity to super-competent tough guy and moral monster, and millions of us couldn’t look away.
“He is totally a nonentity,” one senior Democratic aide said.

definition: state of disgrace resulting from detestable behavior
details: That shivery feeling of disgust and hatred that you get when you see something senseless and horrible is called odium.
examples: As a counterbalance, then, we begin with that everfresh and exciting odium: the author’s formal introduction.
Congress is a hemorrhaging gash right now, bleeding odium and hostility…..
Of those who rely on the metaphysical, their arguments are usually strongly imbued with prejudice, and even odium, and, as such, are beyond the pale of scientific criticism.
The invidious utterance or person invites odium more openly.

definition: equipment consisting of miscellaneous articles
details: Having lunch in the park might require you to first gather together a lot of picnic paraphernalia, such as blankets, coolers, Frisbees, and other miscellaneous items that are relevant to that activity.
examples: Root was charged with seven counts of possession with intent to deliver a controlled substance, possession of drug paraphernalia, tampering with physical evidence and operating a motor vehicle while privilege was suspended or revoked.
The same penalties will apply to possession of drug paraphernalia.
Academic Ben Wagner says tech’s enthusiasm for ethics paraphernalia is just “ethics washing,” a strategy to avoid government regulation.
Katie Walter pleaded guilty to felony theft and possessing drug paraphernalia.

definition: feeling great delight and interest
details: To be rapt is to be carried away, caught up, or otherwise engrossed in something. If a performer is really good or particularly mesmerizing, the audience will be totally rapt.
examples: Clutching 35 pages of personal statement, she began to read to a rapt courtroom.
Before a rapt gathering of investors, Bill McGlashan was holding forth on his favorite subject: “impact investing,” which aims to generate lofty social, as well as financial, returns.
Although I was ordinarily a loud and antsy child, I sat silent and rapt in the audience for more than two hours.
At the end of a cocktail party, a crowd of people would sit rapt at Tomkins’s feet.

definition: bitter or scornful
details: Medieval alchemists ascribed to the planet Saturn a gloomy and slow character. When people are called saturnine, it means they are like the planet — gloomy, mean, scowling. Not exactly the life of the party.
examples: It is not easy to kick off a new era with the requisite upbeat mood when the saturnine sight of a near-vacant arena evokes the apathy caused by past disappointments.
Lilli Palmer is a saturnine icon in the Marlene Dietrich mold.
The elfin Mr. Keating, the saturnine Mr. Ruddy and the radiant Ms. Street all move persuasively between fragility and strength.
Pat and Steve, moving across the Golden Gate Bridge, bought a hilltop plot that looked onto the marshes and the saturnine eastern face of Mt.

definition: stubbornly unyielding
details: Use tenacious to mean "not easily letting go or giving up," like a clingy child who has a tenacious grip on his mother's hand.
examples: Tony's teams are known for their tenacious defense, but putting Nantz on the spot like that was a brilliant offensive attack.

In the pediatric ward, a one-month-old baby, Blessing Karanja, was fighting a worrisome blood infection, and elsewhere in the hospital, Grace Mutiga, 65, a retired nurse, was back again with a tenacious respiratory infection.
The lead changed hands 26 times between the Irish and the Huskies, almost mirroring the earlier semifinal, in which Baylor barely escaped a tenacious Oregon team.
John Johnson is a courageous and tenacious man pursuing the truth about the violent history in his southwestern Virginia county.

definition: completely acceptable; not open to reproach
details: If something is unexceptionable, don't bother trying to find something wrong with it — you won't. Your unexceptionable character makes you the perfect candidate to run for public office, but if you run, people will be looking for things to criticize.
examples: The purpose, seemingly unexceptionable — and in fact not objected to by many — was “teaching, fostering and perpetuating the ideals, principles and spirit of Americanism.”

Pro-Trump diehards – when they’re not giving Don Jr softball interviews – are insisting that Trump’s campaign-season meeting with a Russian lawyer is unexceptionable, and the media storm around it is proof of a witch-hunt.
Likewise, that tone should vary without clashing and be euphonious without being soporific is pretty unexceptionable advice.
Many novel verbs that set purists’ teeth on edge become unexceptionable to their grown children.

definition: proceed somewhere despite the risk of possible dangers
details: A venture is a risky undertaking. If your latest venture is a dog food store, you hope there are some hungry dogs around. Also, to venture is to go somewhere possibly dangerous, like if you venture out into a snowstorm.
examples: A Balfour Beatty spokeswoman said the company is making significant investments to improve its military housing ventures and “working closely with the Department of the Army and West Point Garrison Command.”
Its cost of $100m is a fraction of what would normally be spent on a venture like this.
Either way, I ventured, both friends and foes of the president would find substance for debate.
The venture was announced on Wednesday by Augusta National chairman Fred Ridley.

definition: wait in hiding to attack
details: When you waylay someone, you stop them from doing what they were going to do, either by using violence or some other tactic.
examples: E.D.T. on Saturday, the New York City Wireless Network, or NYCWiN, went dark, waylaying numerous city tasks and functions, including the collection and transmission of information from some Police Department license plate readers.
She then waylaid the judges with a pink Champagne cake with rose buttercream and a raspberry jam to win episode three.
Griffin’s attempt to rejoin the Sun last year was waylaid by injury.
Like the Manhattan store, many will be outside immigrant enclaves, waylaying diners with limited knowledge of Filipino food.

definition: run away, often taking something or somebody along
details: Abscond is to escape, often taking something along. As a kid, you may have absconded from your lemonade stand — with the coffee can of cash in hand, and your bewildered sister still filling cups for your customers.
examples: He also admitted absconding before his manslaughter trial.
He absconded from Britain to Somalia during a trial in 2009, in which he was accused of attempting to travel to Afghanistan for terrorism.
After absconding with Closs to his family's cabin in sparsely populated Gordon, he held her for 88 days until she managed to break free and flag down help.
Why shouldn’t be and his old Special-Forces pals help others by taking Lorea down and then help themselves by absconding with all that cash?

definition: influence by slyness
details: To beguile is to entertain and convince by flattery. Someone who beguiles is tricky and often charming, like when a smooth-talking friend tries to beguile you into giving them your allowance.
examples: With considerable grace and beguiling modesty, the movie frames its subject as one of Christ’s most discerning followers and a crucial witness to his ministry, death and resurrection.
Whatever the strengths and weaknesses of this “Master and Margarita,” Bulgakov’s beguiling, confounding story shines through it.
Danielle Trussoni, in her horror roundup, calls it a “beguiling” and “wildly entertaining story that grabs you on Page 1 and drags you into its dark world kicking and screaming.”
Barbara Kiser’s pick of the top five science books to read this week includes fighting for air, mathematical mayhem, and beguiling bats.

definition: insincere talk about religion or morals
details: Cant is language repeated so often and so mechanically that it's essentially empty of meaning. Cant can also mean the specialized jargon of a particular group — like the "cant of piracy" (e.g., Ahoy! Lubber! Arrr!).
examples: The fairway cants to the right and plays to a kidney-shaped green that cants from front to back.
Denver Nuggets guard Gary Harris asked, “So coaches cant yell at players now?”
"I was 'oh my God, It's really high, I cant get down - I'm really scared."
Once it was a heavily forested course with canted fairways hampered by just a single fairway bunker.

definition: reason from the general to the particular
details: To deduce is to figure something out based on what you already know. When you see a person crying, it's easy to deduce that the person is sad. Unless they're happy, of course. Sometimes happy people cry.
examples: The image is a spectacular confirmation of black holes’ existence, first deduced from Albert Einstein’s general theory of relativity nearly 100 years ago.
The Saudi source says there is a note in the transcript that says Khashoggi was given an injection, which apparently was deduced from the audio.
Can we therefore deduce that Slovakia don’t run very much?
A wide-ranging study looked at users of a popular food delivery app in 197 cities, to deduce how they decided from which restaurant to order.

definition: audacious behavior that you have no right to
details: If you rudely behave as if you have a right to something that you have no right to, you're committing effrontery. When a couple stroll into a crowded restaurant, demand the best table, and threaten the staff unless they're seated right away, that's effrontery.
examples: He was picking people at random now in his fury, punishing innocent people for the dead man’s effrontery.
Order him off your porch, scolding him for such effrontery?
Reports should not gloss over his blatant racism and effrontery under the guise of bravery, adventure or — worse yet — faith.
The sheer effrontery of the interview, like the effrontery of this attack, sends a message: We don’t care what any of you think.

definition: a gaudy outward display
details: Fanfare is a loud, proud burst of something to get attention. If you open up a carpet store with one of those sky-sweeping lights, lots of balloons, and a brass band, you’re doing it with great fanfare.
examples: When people use the word “fanfare” to describe celebrations, they usually mean it metaphorically.
He hired football coach Mike Leach to much fanfare in 2012 and embarked on a stadium renovation and construction of a football operations building at a total cost of $130 million.
Indeed, with all the fanfare at the outset, tax practitioners began to worry on behalf of their clientele.
She enters the church quickly and without fanfare.

definition: the most powerful members of a society
details: The gentry are the powerful members of society. In the United Kingdom, where there are still kings and queens and dukes and duchesses, the gentry are the people who rank just below the nobility.
examples: She was known among the New York art and party gentry as Anna Delvey, who introduced herself as a German heiress with a $60 million fortune.
Without that arrival, there is no landed Virginia gentry: no Washington, Jefferson or Madison.
The long, snooty shadow of St. Moritz’s old winter gentry is still discernible in the remaining private clubs — sporting associations by origin — that are key to social life here.

It was mid-November in a private room upstairs at the Monocle, the longtime haunt of Capitol Hill's gentry, where signed photos of aged congressmen line the walls like movie-star headshots in a Hollywood dry cleaner.

definition: in a hasty and foolhardy manner
details: Headlong describes something done headfirst, rashly, or really quickly. If you’re the star batter on your baseball team, it’s expected that you'll make a headlong dive for the base.
examples: And of course, like so many neo-cons, Boot fell headlong into the Russia conspiracy nuttiness for more than two excruciating years.
So we need to leave them no choice and drag them headlong into the future, like a recalcitrant goat at the end of a rope.
The challenger spun around in surprise, and Pax charged him headlong.
As Apple dives headlong into the services business, it’s exactly the kind of angle it needs.

definition: lock up or confine, in or as in a jail
details: When you immure someone or something, you put it behind a wall, as in a jail or some other kind of confining space.
examples: She spoke wistfully of freedom, but she was effectively immured.
But it also sounds, marvelously, like a geographical location in which a character from a Paul Bowles novel might be immured.
They escorted me to a room immured among poor houses.
I mean, all you need to acknowledge in order to embrace this epiphany is how solidly immured in the wilderness Democrats are at all levels of our governance from president down to local dog-catcher.

definition: an association of sports teams that organizes matches
details: The two meanings of league are quite different — either it’s a group or federation joined for a common purpose (say, your bowling league or the League of Nations) or it’s a rough measurement of about three miles, usually at sea.
examples: And when they were ready to sign the papers to establish the league, they leaned on the hood of the car to finish up.
Gray grew up a Reds fan and attended his first major league game at Great American.
Congress passed a limited cutout that was signed into law in 1998, making the employment of major league players subject to antitrust law.

definition: easily influenced
details: A malleable personality is capable of being changed or trained, and a malleable metal is able to be pounded or pressed into various shapes. It's easier to learn when you're young and malleable.
examples: "Free will is an illusion. People are much more suggestible than they think. All of our perceptions are very malleable," says Dr Kuhn.
According to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, cadmium is a malleable metal found in zinc and used in batteries.
Somebody should explain that facts and truth are to Trump what golf scores and crowd sizes are—“feelings”—malleable and negotiable, flitting this way and that like a car-lot balloon man.
How do you convince them you’re white – a racial category that was still new and, they hoped, malleable – like them?

definition: be a mystery or bewildering to
details: To nonplus is to baffle or confuse someone to the point that they have nothing to say. Something weird and mysterious can nonplus you, like a play that is performed entirely by chickens.
examples: Going on the reactions of the babies online, most are startled or nonplussed.
If you’re nonplused about whether the markets’ recent behavior is a bellwether of a looming economic slowdown, prepare for more mixed signals.
I was nonplussed by some of the nomenclature in the Dec. 3 front-page article “Trade terrain forever changed” regarding U.S.-China trade relations.
When he first screened a rough cut last year, “I was completely nonplused by it,” he said.

definition: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
details: Though officious sounds like official, it means being annoyingly eager to do more than is required. "The officious lunch lady made everyone's food choices her business, and made nasty comments when students chose cookies over carrots."
examples: The top scam now involves an officious caller claiming to be from the IRS and demanding payment of back taxes - now.
Her writing should be allowed to develop naturally, he said, without the officious influence of New York types.
The opening national anthem, belted by the Oakland Interfaith Gospel Choir to the tune of clanging tambourines, was more spiritual than officious.
There are those who circled wagons around Serena Williams after her churlish reaction, again, to overly officious umpiring at the U.S.

definition: dried out by heat or excessive exposure to sunlight
details: Something parched is excessively dry and hot, in extreme need of water, like a desert, a neglected plant, or your throat after a five-kilometer run.
examples: When I met her last year in Hemet, Calif., nearly 90 parched miles east of Los Angeles, her ranch-style home was trimmed in red Christmas lights.
Air tankers dropped fire retardant on the parched land to halt the inferno.
His throat was parched and his tongue swollen and thick.
The answer is: nothing is stopping them except their own parched, self-serving notion of leadership as maximizing profits and shareholder value.

definition: of high moral or intellectual value
details: Use the adjective rarefied to describe things that are so stylish, smart, or moral that they seem elevated above the ordinary, like the rarefied conversation of brilliant scholars.
examples: He became the second player after Jack Nicklaus to complete three legs of the slam before the age of 24, rarefied company to be sure.
Even a field as rarefied as celestial mechanics benefited from slavery.
There are only two businesses headquartered here that fit that rarefied description.
Other companies cater to jet-setters more interested in the rarefied heights of a country’s cuisine than in the nitty-gritty of its inhabitants’ lives.

definition: a learned person
details: You know that girl in your school with a GPA over 100? She is a savant in the making. A savant is someone over-the-top smart, a scholar. It might take a savant only five minutes to do an entire math test.
examples: Bennett, a coaching savant since starting his career with consecutive 26-win seasons at lowborn hoops outpost Washington State, just achieved the ultimate validation.
And so I became known as a blackjack savant.”
If you’re what media savants call an “efferent reader,” looking for the efficient take-away, his approach will drive you bonkers.
That school represents Sampson at his purest: a blue-collar, optimistic, resolute basketball savant.

definition: very thin in gauge or diameter
details: If something is tenuous it's thin, either literally or metaphorically. If you try to learn a complicated mathematical concept by cramming for 45 minutes, you will have a tenuous grasp of that concept, at best.
examples: But Roger Christian, the British director and set designer who won an Academy Award for his production design on Star Wars, believes any link would be "tenuous" at best.
As Toby’s grasp on reality becomes more tenuous, Driver becomes more manic and less composed.
We accept that people need education, job training, mental-health support and substance abuse classes, but support for the arts is tenuous.
In New Mexico, along the Navajo’s eastern border, two plants and two mines face a tenuous future.

definition: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable
details: Unfaltering means unwavering, not changing. As an adult, you might thank your mother for her unfaltering support of your education, never letting you skip a night of homework. Now, not so much.
examples: It is also an interpretation that seems propelled by an unfaltering inner confidence.
It’s been 26 years since the St. Louis course hosted a major, when an unfaltering Nick Price won the PGA in 1992, and 53 years since Gary Player won his one and only U.S.
Underlying them all was his unfaltering optimism in the inevitability and righteousness of his cause — the end of white supremacy and democratic self-rule for the black African majority.
“Now,” the preacher says, his smile unfaltering, “Let us pray.”

definition: habitually speaking the truth
details: Someone who is veracious speaks the truth — like your brutally honest friend who always lets you know what she thinks about your outfits, your hairstyle, your lasagna recipe, and your taste in movies.
examples: “All American Made” is a soulful and veracious snapshot of the times we’re living in.
So often when the American plays, tennis becomes a very simple equation: if she gets into her veracious groove she triumphs.
For too long this film renders a portrait of a feminist artist in clown paint, though Tomlin hangs in with a veracious, multidimensional performance.
Oyster’s an obvious option for veracious readers, or those of us living in 300 sq ft studios.

definition: face and withstand with courage
details: Weather is the atmospheric conditions, including the temperature, wind, snow, rain, or anything else happening outside. People tend to talk about the weather when they can't think of anything else to talk about.
examples: To me it was a perfect place to set “Abby’s” because San Diego to me is just, ocean breeze and everything is calm and the weather is always exactly the same.
A "bomb cyclone" is a weather phenomenon that entails a rapid drop in air pressure and a storm strengthening explosively.
AUGUSTA, Ga.— On the first day of the Masters, the weather is absolutely perfect—the way it’s supposed to be.
“Some people like the rustic effect of a weathered, worn look,” she said, “but if you want your furniture to last without cracking, then you should treat it like you would a marble countertop.”

definition: refrain from doing, consuming, or partaking in something
details: If you abstain from something, you restrain yourself from consuming it. People usually abstain from things that are considered vices — like eating French fries every day for lunch.
examples: Does the structure of college students' brains interact with the structure of their social networks to influence their ability to abstain from alcohol?
To succeed, a handful of Conservative MPs or lawmakers from the allied Democratic Unionist Party, would need to either abstain or vote with the opposition to topple the government.
Almost 100 Tory MPs voted against the prime minister’s decision to ask for a three-month extension to article 50 and another 80 abstained, underlining the loss of control over her party.
The U.K. may also be asked to accept constraints on its drawn-out membership, such as abstaining on key votes.

definition: annoy persistently
details: Beleaguer means to pester or badger with persistence. A babysitter might find annoying the children who beleaguer her with requests for candy, cookies, games, and piggyback rides all at the same time.
examples: While interim president Guaido works to bring much needed humanitarian assistance to beleaguered Venezuelans, Maduro continues to rob them of the nation’s natural resources, shipping them to Cuba.
District Judge James Bredar said the consent decree agreement to reform Baltimore’s beleaguered force will withstand any “drama and trauma” in city leadership.
About a year ago, Donald Trump seemed a little more agitated than usual, and it led the beleaguered president to create a new conspiracy theory.

In a strategy detailed to Reuters for the first time, top security officials said they plan to isolate gang bosses, ramp up surveillance, build more lockups and deploy federal forces to beleaguered state prison systems.

definition: a major division of a long poem
details: Long books have chapters. Long poems do, too. But a chapter in a long poem is called a canto.
examples: Lawrence Brownlee is among the most celebrated bel canto tenors alive.
Bel canto, I realize, is a little bit like a drug: Descriptions tend to sound either clinical or loopily subjective.
Once a bel canto specialist, he’s the rare tenor with both Rossini’s and Verdi’s very different versions of “Otello” in his repertory.

One piece discussed bel canto singing before touching on Plato and Aristotle, then examined the 18th-century German poet and philosopher Friedrich Schiller and ended with a commentary on the grain trade.

definition: an option that is selected automatically
details: As a setting, a default is automatic. You weren't sure why your new TV kept returning to the factory defaults until you realized you were sitting on the remote.
examples: In this latest version, engagement icons don’t appear by default.
This is simply a superb camera in its default state.
Noble denied the allegations but subsequently defaulted and sold many of its assets as profits collapsed.

Dubbed “quick removal,” the new default setting keeps external storage devices ready to be pulled “at any time,” according to Microsoft Windows support, as long as users aren’t actively saving files to it.

definition: the quality of being bright and sending out rays of light
details: Your future's so bright, you've got to wear shades. Really, it's giving off blinding, radiant rays of light — what some people would call effulgence.
examples: Balls of apparently sentient effulgence prowl intersections like terrestrial comets.
While the word “radiant” is rightly used of many ballet dancers, Ms. Nuñez’s kind of effulgence combines sunniness and heart to a rare degree.
With that word the heat seemed to increase till it became a threatening weight and the lagoon attacked them with a blinding effulgence.
She sat holding it in her hand, while the music penetrated her whole being like an effulgence, wanning and brightening the dark places of her soul.

definition: proceed, get along, or succeed
details: It's not fair that fare means three unrelated things. As a verb, it means to proceed or get along, as in "Fare thee well." As a noun, it can refer to the cost of travel ("Train fare is ten dollars") or to food ("Tatertots are typical cafeteria fare").
examples: We got an early look at this version of Firefox late last year, and it seemed to fare well on an ARM laptop with a dozen tabs open.
How do partisan pages fare across the social network?
The 20-year-old company says the transatlantic market suffers from poor competition and high fares, especially in the premium category.
The left fared poorly in the election, as did the Labor Party, once practically synonymous with the state of Israel.

definition: have the idea for
details: It's unclear just how long it took for the idea for the website to gestate. Did he think of it right away, or did it take months for him to come up with the idea?
examples: But we paid homage to his literary genes by reading thousands of books to our gestating bookworm.
Yet Welles was in steady pursuit of a daring conceit: a film as much improvised as scripted, reflecting the circumstances in which it gestated, a heightened version of Hollywood reality.
Seahorse males famously get pregnant, gestating their progeny in a brood pouch for about 24 days.
Indeed, an edgy blog post by two other academics discussed the hypothetical alternative of farming organs in brainless humans that are gestated in external artificial “wombs.”

definition: forward movement
details: Headway is what you achieve when you move forward or make progress. When you're rowing a boat on a very windy day, it can be hard to make any headway.
examples: After a crisis that ranged from the streets to the state’s psychiatric hospital, lawmakers are finally making some headway on a plan that should move the system forward in a compassionate and budget-conscious way.

“We are making headway in a lot of areas. That includes enforcement, that includes IP theft, that includes forced technology transfers, ownership, cyberspace, commodities and all the rest of it,” Kudlow said.
Futures were supported earlier on hopes that Beijing and Washington were making headway to resolve their trade dispute.
Talks between the two economic powerhouses made good headway last week in Beijing, Kudlow told reporters at an event hosted by the Christian Science Monitor.

definition: not subject or susceptible to change or variation
details: If you can't change it, it's immutable. There are many things in life that are immutable; these unchangeable things include death, taxes, and the laws of physics.
examples: But all of this sort of fanciful notion that there is a constitutional mandate for nine justices and that is immutable, that’s all kind of mythmaking.
“Sexual orientation is not immutable to the same extent as race,” he wrote.
Teenagers are, in effect, hunting for causes to care about and latching onto immutable ideas about themselves—I am this kind of person, or I am someone who believes in that.
But by embracing the ideology of “gender identity,” it treats womanhood as a mutable feeling rather than an immutable fact.

definition: deficient in alertness or activity
details: When you feel lethargic, you're sluggish or lacking energy. Being sleepy or hungry can make anyone lethargic.
examples: It’s a hard argument to counter considering the lethargic pace of the Brexit negotiations until a deadline focused the mind.
Sparks, who got the nod after Andersen made 28 saves in Monday’s victory, struggled on Carolina’s opener in the first for the lethargic Leafs.
A combination of lethargic defense and errant shooting did the 76ers in, particularly early.
Responding help found him “to be lethargic and unresponsive in his patrol vehicle,” according to the news release.

definition: reveal its presence or make an appearance
details: Choose the verb manifest when someone shows something for everyone to notice. You might manifest your dislike of school food by stirring it around into a big pile of slop on your tray.
examples: Interestingly, the symptoms her son experienced manifested after two seizure episodes.
An innovation that hopefully manifests in fans' ultimate viewing desire: clips of Jim Nantz rehearsing his weekend intros and victory calls.
There are rarely unobstructed views of Big Cat; the ones that manifest result in elbows, nudges, the dissolution of boundaries.
Conditions that are caused by dominantly inherited mutations, however, require only one mutated copy of a gene to manifest.

definition: patent medicine whose efficacy is questionable
details: Though you try many medicines that claim to cure your cold, none of them work. They turn out to be nostrums, or ineffective drugs.
examples: It showed up in operating rooms as an anesthetic, was used as a key ingredient in innumerable nostrums and beverages—one of which evolved into Coca-Cola—and became a go-to stimulant for recreational users.
