Traditional conservative nostrums of tax cuts for the best-off and business-friendly deregulation were not answering the needs of less affluent Republicans.
The Mondale defeat exposed how broken was the party — captive of special interests, of New Deal nostrums discredited a generation earlier, of regional and generational tension.

A strong selling point of the proposal is that, unlike the nostrums currently being served up by Trump and the Democratic left, the New Center’s compromise actually corresponds to a broad spectrum of public opinion.

definition: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
details: If something looks or sounds ominous, be careful: a threat or an unpleasant event is at hand. If you see an ominous frown on your boss's face, you're in trouble!
examples: At night in the summer, Aimee Costa, who lives on a hill above the elementary school, sometimes keeps her window open, the better to hear ominous sounds.
This was an ominous sign for Walker, and he was quick to tout the centers in his campaign, attending the announcements and following them up with local ads.
It seems ominous at first, a warning of the great deluge of images made possible by cellphone cameras and digital photography.
Monday's practice round was cut short due to severe weather, and the forecasts for Tuesday and the weekend are also ominous.

definition: functional equality
details: All things being equal, parity means, basically, equality. It’s used in finance, physics, math, and even sports. When people talk about parity in a football league, for example, they mean the teams are evenly matched. Go, evenly matched team, go!
examples: But the defense spending levels are a sore spot for liberals, who want Democrats to use their new majority to advocate a tougher line that would bring defense and domestic spending to dollar-for-dollar parity.
According to IWPR, at the current glacial pace of progress, it will not be until 2059 for women to reach the promised land of pay parity.
Tech companies founded by men rarely achieve gender parity in their workforce and don’t get anywhere close in leadership, according to a new analysis of 13,000 firms by recruiter Stellares.
Although she is comfortable with her “Thrones” salary, Turner is committed to improving gender parity on her projects moving forward.

definition: approve and express assent, responsibility, or obligation
details: To ratify a treaty or contract is to officially approve it by signing or voting for it. You and your brothers and sisters might devise a plan for a family vacation to Disney World, but it would need to be ratified by your parents.
examples: It still must be ratified by the union’s members.

“At the same time, as if signaling his willingness to work with the world community, Mr. Putin confirmed that Russia is in the process of ratifying the 2015 Paris Climate Accord,” the journalist wrote.
Cubans overwhelmingly ratified the new constitution in a February referendum after a year of debate, updating its 1976 Soviet-era Magna Carta.
A shareholder vote to ratify boards’ actions features prominently at every German AGM.

definition: a particular taste or smell, especially an appealing one
details: Whether it’s a feeling of joy or a piece of pecan pie — when you savor something, you enjoy it to the fullest.
examples: Biking through Bavarian fields, I savor that moment when the setting sun warms up all the colors and the newly cut hay fills the air with a sweet and fertile humidity.
Behind those doors sat Bradley Beal, undoubtedly savoring his space in team lore.
So when the well finally runs dry for one of them, I think it's OK to savor the moment.
His return Thursday provided moments to savor, and hinted at what 2019 might hold.

definition: the geographical area under the jurisdiction of a state
details: A certain area that's owned or under the control of someone is called a territory. Countries defend their territories during wars and dogs mark their territory in the yard by peeing on it.
examples: The territory is controversial, even among Lebanese themselves.
But “The Invisible Light” veers into stranger territory.
Informed that Bryant hoisted 50 shots that night, Nowitzki conceded that he very likely wouldn’t reach that territory, but promised to “let it fly.”
In January, Airbnb expanded that policy to other regions with an announcement that it would also remove listings in South Ossetia and Abkhazia, disputed territories in the Caucasus.

definition: lacking grace in movement or posture
details: Ungainly is the opposite of graceful, convenient, or easy. A clumsy dancer boogies in an ungainly or awkward fashion.
examples: While the film ended being a smash at the box office, it was also an overlong, ungainly, and nigh unwatchable mess, roundly savaged by audiences and critics alike.
This musical cut-and-shut of astral grunge and 6Music indie may seem an ungainly chimera, but it is part of a broader trend.
At several points last season, Gronk appeared greatly reduced, slow and ungainly in heavy pads—a bionic man, leaking oil.
Just the usual petty vengeance that’s been all but normalized by this ungainly and incompetent crackpot.

definition: using or containing too many words
details: If you're verbose, you use far more words than you need to. A verbose book report goes on and on and is packed with long, complicated words that aren't at all necessary.
examples: Conversely, Kikuchi was honest and direct, if not verbose, about everything in his answers.
"The environment is at a turning point. We don't need verbose documents, we need concrete commitments."

But the famously verbose Clinton does dive deep into policy and offers advice on how to appeal to the same economic anxiety that drove some white, working-class voters to side with Trump over his wife.
Suddenly, the room is even more crowded, as we are joined by a verbose businessman who speaks faster than anybody I’ve ever met.

definition: be oppressive or burdensome
details: To weigh is all about judging; you could be seeing how heavy something is or if it is a good choice. You could weigh the tomatoes you're buying or weigh your options when applying to college.
examples: They said she weighed about 165 pounds, down from 200 last year.
Wisenberg, a Fox News contributor, also weighed in on President Trump's comments that the Muller investigation into him was "an attempted coup" and an "attempted takedown of a president."

Johnson also weighed in on the escalating crisis on the southern border, and said that “by any measure” it was a crisis that risked overwhelming border patrol and the humanitarian effort on the border.
Her daughter was born at 31 ½ weeks weighing less than 2 ½ pounds.

definition: marked by temperance in indulgence
details: Reserve abstemious for someone who exercises restraint, especially with regard to alcohol. A rock musician may sing about enjoying wine and women, but in his private life he may be abstemious.
examples: Disdainful of democracy and famously abstemious — he reportedly wore the same exercise shorts for 17 years — Lee led a one-party state that enforced strict notions of public behavior.
This bright picture of Australian food — packed with fresh and local produce, invitingly global in its flavors, health-conscious but not abstemious — is relatively new.
This cheerful acceptance of the bottle may strike more abstemious American readers as another very “British” element.
Many of the more abstemious outfits are at the Cloisters, which we all agreed is the strongest section of the show.

definition: be in contradiction with
details: To belie means to contradict. If you are 93 but look like you are 53, then your young looks belie your age.
examples: The April 4 Metro article “Blooms belie crisis at Tidal Basin” highlighted the need for more to be done to protect our beloved cherry trees and Tidal Basin area.
The whimsical name for her work — “bubbling” — belies its prickly technicalities.
The relative simplicity of the apps belies the years it took hospitals to build in not only patient-friendly features but also secure ones.
They kept a sign on the wall pronouncing that “Reading Rots the Mind,” which belied, in the trademark irreverence of both scientists, their dazzling work in pushing the frontiers of their profession.

definition: large in the amount that can be contained
details: When something is really big and holds a lot it is capacious, like a woman's capacious purse that is so big, people mistake it for a piece of luggage.
examples: Time and again a close election leads to hand-wringing about the need for Electoral College reform; time and again, politicians and parties respond to the college’s incentives, and more capacious and unifying majorities are born.
The thread starts sensibly enough, with a reminder that Mueller’s mandate was capacious, and his office’s work is not over.
Poems like Ms. Romo’s point to new myths, just as capacious and fragile as the actual West, despite its tortured history.
Stacked in a corner a capacious gallery at Blum & Poe, the futons form a mountain one must climb to see the images.

definition: courteous regard for people's feelings
details: Sure you wear ripped jeans to school every day, but you don't wear them to your grandmother's house out of deference to her. When you show deference to someone, you make a gesture of respect.
examples: They were given public deference and titles of courtesy because they were white.
Democratic candidates are desperate to brand themselves as true champions of the people, free of corporate interests and deference to big money.
Republican lawmakers were muted in their criticism of the measure in deference to Busch, who led the chamber for 13 years.
Many of those taking the stage at CinemaCon made sure to pay deference to movie theaters, which are enduring despite competition from Netflix and other streaming services.

definition: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible
details: Something that is egregious stands out, but not in a good way — it means "really bad or offensive." If you make an egregious error during a championship soccer match, your coach might bench you for the rest of the game.
examples: “The murder of Till was so egregious, and it connected Johnson’s home base of Chicago to what was going on in the South in such a powerful way,” Nishikawa said.
Like many black women, I push through egregious infractions based on my skin tone.

U.K. watchdogs would gain unprecedented powers to issue fines and other punishments against social media sites if they don’t swiftly remove the most egregious posts, photos and videos from public view.

If approved by Parliament, U.K. watchdogs would gain unprecedented powers to issue fines and other punishments when social media sites don’t swiftly remove the most egregious posts, photos or videos from public view.

definition: come to understand
details: To fathom something is to understand it thoroughly, and is usually used in the negative, as in "I can't fathom why he doesn't want to go along with us."
examples: It is cultural neglect on a scale we can’t quite fathom.
But I couldn’t fathom dessert; we’d bought apple fritters a few days before when I was still pregnant.
I couldn’t fathom what was so hard to understand about this!
“It’s hard to put into words, especially to people of my generation. Wilt was untouchable. And for someone to be in that context, it’s hard to fathom,” Stotts said.

definition: laugh at with contempt and derision
details: "Loser! Bonehead!" the kids shouted, tossing those words and other gibes at the people who offered themselves up to the annual humiliation of the harvest-fest dunk-tank. A gibe is an insulting comment. To gibe is to insult.
examples: She added that she agreed with President Trump’s gibe that “Paris is no longer Paris.”
Warren answers Trump’s taunts of “Pocahontas” with gibes in return.
His evil genius was in plumbing the depths of that id and liberating the latent bias there through his bigot-baiting gibes at Mexicans, Muslims and others.
Ronald Reagan’s 1986 statement still invokes chuckles on the right and some nostalgia for the general good nature of his gibes.

definition: someone motivated by desires for sensual pleasures
details: Your parents might want to visit the museum while you want to hike in the forest, but your brother, the hedonist, just wants to lounge by the hotel pool and eat cake. A hedonist values sensual pleasure above all else.
examples: James Franco played him as a through-and-through hedonist who only hustles hard in order to live large.
The tortilla, which eats like a glutton’s last meal request, calls to the hedonist; recipients get a tin of roe and a tray of uni, splashed with soy sauce, to play with.
All of us, with the exception of hedonists, nihilists and goldfish, are in favor of planning for the future.

Former hedonists or over-sharers at house parties try to set aside their worries – huge credit-card repayments, a toddler who insists on calling them by their first name – by slugging shots of this Mexican mind-wipe.

definition: make worse or less effective
details: If you make bad decisions in the morning after drinking coffee, you might conclude that caffeine tends to impair your judgment. When you impair something, you damage it or make it work poorly.
examples: A spokesman for Attorney General Steve Marshall said the changes would impair efforts to enforce key provisions of existing ethics laws.
He was arrested again later that year for impaired driving.
The justices also cited the clause in the state constitution stating that pension benefits “shall not be diminished or impaired.”
Standard toxicology tests are pending, but investigators don’t think Brown was impaired.

definition: an embankment built to prevent a river from overflowing
details: A levee is an embankment, like a dam, constructed to prevent the overflow of a body of water. It can also mean a formal reception. How do these two words relate? Read on...
examples: There were 50 levee breaks along the Missouri River during March flooding, the U.S.
Most of the closed roads are along the swollen Mississippi River and in the northwest part of the state, where the Missouri River breached numerous levees last month.

Customs and Border Protection said it was about to begin construction as early as Thursday on approximately 13 miles of levee construction in the Rio Grande Valley using funds that were allocated in 2018.
Beginning Thursday, the city is adding protection at five additional locations around the city, including clay levees and 4-foot-tall sandbags.

definition: a clear appearance
details: A manifestation is the public display of emotion or feeling, or something theoretical made real.
examples: The shoppers sifted through racks of “Harry Potter” plush dolls, “Riverdale” sweaters and “Kiki’s Delivery Service” jewelry, seeking the perfect physical manifestation of their — or their child’s — fandom.
The wall is a physical manifestation of global white supremacy ideology.
Modelling HFpEF is challenging because of the complex interplay of many contributing factors and the plethora of clinical manifestations of the disease.
Can two political movements with such different manifestations really be called part of the same phenomenon?

definition: a general inclusive concept
details: If you have a notion that you can swim across the ocean, you are probably wrong. A notion is an idea, often vague and sometimes fanciful.
examples: Huge themes are explored, including the plight of the underclass, the notion of inherent criminality, the force of justice and the role of citizens.
Outside Sudan, it’s perhaps easier to get caught up in the romantic notion of revolution and one’s place in it.
Some people eat here with only a vague notion of eating South Asian cooking.
The notion of Mickelson winning a fourth green jacket is romantic.

definition: infinitely wise
details: To be omniscient is to know everything. This often refers to a special power of God.
examples: “Remember the impossible eventfulness of time, transformation and emotion packed like gunpowder into the barrel,” its omniscient narrator exhorts the reader.
A girl needed to preserve some mystery, even from her omniscient Dadi.
The omniscient strangeness imparted by this latest adventure in viewpoint is perfectly suited to conveying the reality of an immortal being.
In a time when so much is left to chaos and shrugs and incompetence, the show offers the comforting illusion that some omniscient force is in control of what happens.

definition: narrowly restricted in outlook or scope
details: If an issue or a matter is parochial, it is trivial or only concerns a local area. Likewise, a person with a parochial mentality is narrow-minded, or not open to new ideas.
examples: After getting a degree in education, he returned home and taught in public and parochial schools.
Norton would like to allow the 1,500 low-income children who attend private and parochial schools using public funds to complete their education but stop new enrollments.
In the end, the effort in New Jersey was also sunk by more parochial political reasons.
They framed the vote around both lofty constitutional principles and parochial home-district matters.

definition: the doctrine that reason is the basis for regulating conduct
details: Rationalism is a doctrine that prioritizes reason over emotion. If you're scared of the dark and convinced there's a monster in your closet, your parents will beg you to be rational, and rely on what you know (empty closet) instead of what your fear (monster!).
examples: Optimism does not need to be in conflict with rationalism.
But this “bravado rationalism,” with its aloof dismissiveness and bullying imperiousness, only serves to inflame the problem it purports to solve.
He wrote of “a conscious rationalism” in conflict with his own feelings and experience.
Aristotle’s brand of rationalism is reductive and absolute.

definition: a sheath for a sword or dagger or bayonet
details: A scabbard is a sheath for a sword, dagger, or other type of knife. Some cooks wear their French knives in a scabbard so they'll be ready to chop no matter where they are in the kitchen.
examples: Someone found a scabbard for it, which raises all kinds of questions.
A waiter entered the room carrying eight alarming-looking knives, sheathed in wooden scabbards decorated with mother-of-pearl inlays.
On it he hung a short sword in a battered black-leather scabbard.
There were more sounds: footsteps crunching through the undergrowth, groaning, the rattling of sword scabbards and gun holsters.

definition: brief and to the point
details: Terse means brief, or using very few words. If your teacher tells you to make your writing in your essay style terse and to the point, he's saying use as few words as you can and be simple and clear.
examples: When he was arrested in 1941, London sent a cable expressing condolences and ending with a terse question: “Who is taking over?”
The terse statement by Xinhua on Saturday did not say where or when further discussions will happen.
In a terse press release titled “Harley Franco Terminated from Harley Marine Services,” the privately held company said its board of directors was announcing that Franco is no longer CEO.
Mr. Barr’s terse explanation of his own reasoning — his deputy, Rod J. Rosenstein, concurred, he said — emphasized the difficulty in proving Mr. Trump’s intentions.

definition: beyond doubt or reproach
details: Unimpeachable describes someone or something that is totally, completely, without any doubt, innocent and good, like an unimpeachable role model who avoids bad influences and sketchy situations.
examples: And whatever its value as sociopolitical commentary, its status as revered satire is unimpeachable.
They touch on affirmative action, impostor syndrome, being told they were unworthy of their spots, and the need to be unimpeachable in every way, even to this day.
In its simplicity, its directness, its willingness to seem naïve, Schneidermann finds it hauntingly unimpeachable.
How much of a scientific consensus, how many unimpeachable experts and how exquisitely rational an argument must you present?

definition: being truly so called; real or genuine
details: When something is veritable it is true, or at least feels that way. "The trees and lights turned the campus into a veritable wonderland" means that the campus seemed to be transformed into a true wonderland (if there is such a thing).
examples: It was middling compared with her rivals’ hauls, but a veritable bonanza when viewed through the lens of what were exceedingly low expectations.
She falls under the spell of this “veritable flea market” from across the Atlantic: “a way of feeling less alone.”
The letter was sent to a veritable who's-who of Trump opponents, including Reps.
He remains a fan favorite, the veritable face of the franchise.

definition: a raised mark on the skin
details: If someone hits you hard with a thin stick, your skin might rise up in a welt. Ouch. A welt is a swollen bruise.
examples: Today’s whip is shorter, wider and softer than those used in the past, when some horses exited races with welts and bruises.
“They were injured to the extent that welts appeared and blood was drawn,” according to Zeheralis’s prepared testimony, which was shared with The Washington Post.
“It hurt really bad,” said the woman, who said she was left with bruises, welts and bleeding cuts that took almost two weeks to heal.
Indiana elementary school teachers participating in an active shooter training drill said they were shot with plastic pellets which left them with bruises and welts.

definition: existing only in the mind
details: Use the adjective abstract for something that is not a material object or is general and not based on specific examples.
examples: This nonsense is not harmless, not trivial, not abstract.
As the process proceeds, the matrix representation of higher-level features becomes somewhat abstract, so it is not necessarily possible to peer into a deep network and identify, for example, an eye.

Sexton’s book reads as a series of TED talks, addressed to people who are interested in thinking about college in lofty, abstract terms—a matter of civilization rather than the immediate needs of citizens.

This will be possible only if we anchor the exertion not simply in abstract ethics but also in respect for existing international human rights law and fundamental freedoms — and that is the key point.

definition: cause to be confused emotionally
details: To bemuse is to confuse or puzzle. You could bemuse your teacher by writing an essay as a series of haikus, but don’t. Usually a bemused teacher is not a happy one.
examples: Despite all its success as a beautiful theory of the building blocks of the universe, quantum mechanics still leaves even those of us physicists who work with it daily both frustrated and bemused.
Far from the first time, the world—friends, foes, and bemused or appalled observers—must be wondering: WTF?!
Exeter magistrates heard Coles was "amused and bemused" by the investigation saying it was "only a goldfish".
I was disheartened by constant throwing away of dough – what was wrong with the last lot? – and bemused by the random suggestions I found on the web.

definition: surrender under agreed conditions
details: To capitulate means to give in to something. If your parents refuse to raise your allowance, you might try to argue until they capitulate. Good luck!
examples: It is described as “an inspiring homage and handbook for the rebellious everywoman who refuses to capitulate”.
In 2011, he capitulated horribly over the closing nine tournament holes from a dominant position.
When Congress would not agree to provisions for a border wall, Trump shut down the government but ultimately capitulated to House Democrats led by Speaker Nancy Pelosi.
“I still think I'm good enough to compete and win and be one of the better players in the world,” Donald said, obviously not ready to capitulate.

definition: a hostile challenge
details: Stand up when the powers that be order you to sit down, and you've given a fine example of defiance. It happens when someone or a group of someones openly flouts or challenges authority.
examples: For Democrats and their allies in the labor movement, the effort to abolish the agency and redistribute its functions is a power play in defiance of Congress.

So much defiance of the Supreme Court will entail, fourth, a new law, which already exists in various drafts, allowing the Knesset to override Supreme Court verdicts on constitutional matters by a simple majority vote.
“It’s a bit of defiance – it’s like walking into a room full of vicars and shouting something rude.”
The Chinese and Russians are jointly propping up Nicolás Maduro’s dictatorship in Venezuela in open defiance of warnings from American leaders.

definition: marked by complexity and richness of detail
details: Use the adjective elaborate when you want to describe how something is very detailed or especially complicated, like a devilish prank planned out weeks in advance.
examples: But unless you or someone in your family is a serious craftsman, most people don’t need something so elaborate taking up so much space.
Officials did not elaborate on what exactly the "object" was that the aircraft struck while in the air.
He did not elaborate on the betrayal claim.
He did not elaborate on his relationship with the woman, but said she and her son live at the home with him.

definition: devoid of intelligence
details: Fatuous means lacking intelligence. When your mother outlaws calling your brother stupid, use fatuous instead.
examples: They found the question silly if not fatuous—the music wasn’t really for liking, in the traditional sense.
Mr. Sisto’s Caesar, confident and fatuous, doesn’t suggest his ambition or its lack.
But it's especially clear that this is a fatuous argument in cases of possible impeachment.
All you needed at the beginning was a small group of geeks; and there was no need for the kind of initial massive initial funding that the fatuous dotcoms absorbed.

definition: prepare oneself for action or a confrontation
details: "Gird your loins and prepare for battle!" Okay, no one says "gird your loins" anymore (which basically means "tighten your pants"), but gird is still used as a verb to mean "get ready for a dangerous situation."
examples: That’s not to say, though, that there’s no party circuit to gird for — plenty of the weekend’s traditional fetes are still on.
Copenhagen is girding itself for the impact of climate change, too.
Top Democrats reacted swiftly to reports that Trump was seeking more money for the wall, reflecting how they are girding for the fight and betting that public sentiment is on their side.
The powerful military is girding against eventual chaos, while protesters in the North African nation are relishing the notion of an Algeria reborn.

definition: pay close attention to
details: Heed is an old word, meaning to listen to and follow. It can also be used as a noun: "Take heed of my instructions, little boy," said the old bearded man. "My potion will only work for the one who wears the ring."
examples: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Pay heed to the following, those attending the Masters this week.
Time to heed the advice of the American Academy of Pediatrics: Eliminate all non-medical childhood vaccine exemptions.
Entrepreneurs will learn to do things government’s way instead of heeding the market.
But Haftar, a military strongman who critics describe as the new Muammar Gaddafi, paid them little heed, said the sources who spoke on condition the ambassadors were not identified.

definition: transmit, as knowledge or a skill
details: Let me impart a little bit of knowledge to you about the word impart. It means to pass on, transmit, or bestow. If you share this with your study partner, you are imparting your new wisdom.
examples: Philip also prefers the flavor and texture that butter imparts.
Corbyn was happy to oblige, imparting tips on using lavender or comfrey to attract bees.
Williams thoroughly imparts Verdon’s internalized damage, which feeds a kind of disproportionate delusion about the limelight.
At the hospital where she works as a nurse, Ms. Ridley imparts breathing exercises she learned at CorePower to anxious patients, watching as their heart rates slow.

definition: a relative position or degree of value in a graded group
details: A level is a position in a scale. Attaining a high level of unemployment is depressing, but getting to a high level on a video game is exciting.
examples: The lack of cohesion is one reason for the lack of accomplishment at the working level.
The report also says tougher state and federal rules for vehicle emissions and planned retirements of coal-fired power plants will lower nitrogen levels.
And even after the drought ended, isoprene levels didn’t immediately rebound.
The device also features a 3″ speaker for robust audio production and ten unique, non-looping sound programs, each with their own richness levels.

definition: having unnatural behavioral attributes
details: If someone calls you mannered, it's really not a compliment. It means that the way you act seems artificial or exaggerated. Chill out.
examples: There would be something a bit more kind of mannered or slightly harder to find.
With mythologically named characters sometimes voicing their stage directions and inner narration, the plays seemed mannered, and the productions felt groomed to slickness.
Carell is a charming, maddening enigma, mawkish and mannered but always, somehow, a magnet for empathy.
But they are no more perfect or well mannered than you are!

definition: despite anything to the contrary
details: Notwithstanding means "in spite of something." Your boasts about having memorized the entire textbook and bribing the teacher with apples notwithstanding, you still managed to fail the final exam with flying colors.
examples: When fairness is wrongly taken away from us, justice steps in -- at least most of the time, the Smollett-kind-of-cases notwithstanding.
Of course, seeking asylum in this country is by definition legal, unilateral declarations from the executive notwithstanding.
It is wrong to include the term “regrets” in the headline of a discussion of affirmative action, journalistic balance notwithstanding.
As a decision in one of those earlier cases made clear, “parties negotiate and even resolve their disputes quite often notwithstanding the pendency of a court case.”

definition: burdensome or difficult to endure
details: If one teacher gives you three hours of homework a night, that's rough. But if all of your teachers do it, that makes the task of completing your homework an onerous one, to say the least. If something is onerous, it is very difficult to deal with or do.
examples: The EU’s executive Commission said last month in a strategy report that China was a “systemic rival” which preserves its domestic markets for national champions while placing “onerous requirements” on EU companies doing business there.
Similarly, tapping into the View’s live stream takes an onerous 15 to 20 seconds, sometimes even longer, which means I’ve often missed whatever activity or person caused a push alert to hit my phone.
There is abundant precedent for attorneys general to act honorably and forcefully in onerous political situations.
Monitoring the spread of misinformation is an onerous task.

definition: avoid or try to avoid fulfilling, answering, or performing
details: Sword fighters thrust and parry. To thrust is to try to stab, and to parry is to avoid getting stabbed by blocking a thrust. Though it comes from fencing, parry is also handy in dodgeball and awkward conversations
examples: First among equals at this are Ms. LaVoy and Mr. Brannon, who seem to carry the incipient knowledge of social change in their exquisitely modulated parries and retreats.

Candidates on both the left and right will lift a page from the early 20th century election playbook, when Standard Oil was depicted as an octopus, dexterous enough to parry Republicans and Democrats.
On “Morning Joe,” she parried questions about a possible presidential run.
During a marathon set of hearings that lasted more than four hours, Mr. Mnuchin parried multiple questions about how he would handle a request for the president’s taxes.

definition: praise enthusiastically
details: If you rave about a book you just read, you're telling people you think it's great, or you're giving it a rave review.
examples: The Chemical Brothers were borrowing ideas from rave and rock culture.
While Roberts' plan faced initial pushback from membership, the course opened in the fall of '58 to rave reviews.
I’ve raved in the past about Google’s Night Sight, which is — was — truly a revolutionary step forward for nighttime photography.
The new fish is now raised by most delta farmers, who rave about its hardiness and how fast it grows.

definition: relative magnitude
details: A scale is a series that climbs up or down. Think of scaling, or climbing, a mountain; a musical scale: do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti-do; or a scale you weigh yourself on––it counts up the pounds one after another after another.
examples: It will also look at existing efforts on a global scale and new science currently being developed.
Last year, this happened at scale when lots of artists signed up to SoundCloud’s new self-monetization agreement and accepted the terms without reading the deal.
Large scale Russian military action in Venezuela is unlikely, given the distance between the two countries and Moscow’s capabilities.
We need political leaders to pilot our economy through a period of rapid economic transformation, on a grand scale unseen since the Second World War.

definition: a person who makes a will
details: When you make your last will and testament, you are the testator, and if the will is written and witnessed according to the law of the land, your estate will be divided in the way you, the testator, requested.
examples: It would therefore place itself in the "armchair" of the testator and consider the circumstances that surrounded them when they made their will, to assist arriving at their intention.
Other convents are mentioned once only and in some cases a testator leaves legacies to nuns by name, without mentioning where they are professed.
In some places the notary drawing a will in the absence of the priest was excommunicated and the body of the testator was refused Christian burial.

It ascribes to bishops the power to punish the authors and the printers of forbidden books, to interdict notaries, change the directions of testators, and apply the revenues of hospitals to other uses.

definition: not diminished or moderated in intensity or severity
details: The adjective unmitigated describes something that is undiminished, unqualified, or absolute. If your new recipe for chocolate cupcakes is met by enthusiastic cheers, you can assume you have an unmitigated success on your hands.
examples: "We're facing an unprecedented unmitigated crisis on the southwest border," said former chief of the Border Patrol and current acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Ron Vitiello.

The US and Mexico trade about $1.7bn in goods daily, according to the US Chamber of Commerce, which said closing the border would be “an unmitigated economic debacle” that would threaten 5m American jobs.
Chamber of Commerce, which said closing the border would be "an unmitigated economic debacle" that would threaten 5 million American jobs.
She often tells me she needs to beat cancer because it would be an unmitigated disaster, particularly in the personal hygiene department, if she left our boys in my care alone.

definition: able to move freely in all directions
details: To describe a person or thing that can adapt to do many things or serve many functions, consider the adjective versatile.
examples: Together, these newfound species show that human evolution was highly versatile, as groups adapted to unfamiliar conditions around the world.
It is fine by itself and versatile with a variety of foods.
The Italian’s game is so versatile as to suit any venue.
With an available boost of electric power, e-bikes offer a versatile alternative for both commuter and leisure uses.

definition: a confused multitude of things
details: Use the noun welter to describe an enormous, messy pile, like the jumble of papers, coffee mugs, pens, and food wrappers on the desk of the messiest person in the office.
examples: We live in a vast welter of data — and it is riddled with gender bias.

The high emotional temperature of the performances can’t quite disguise the mechanical nature of the story — it’s at once over-plotted and flimsy, a welter of reversals and revelations that don’t so much resolve as collapse.
A purported narrative of student life in a state university … The intended contrast between the fraternity and nonfraternity men is lost in a general welter of meanness and vulgarity.
He manages the welter of voices, keeping one separate from the other, and beautifully captures the irony that underpins much of the story.

definition: present in great quantity
details: On Halloween, you can find candy in abundant supply. Use abundant to describe something that exists in large amounts that are more than what's needed.
examples: But opportunities were still more abundant in the U.S.
The benefits in terms of noise, air quality and open space are abundant.
Many miners began to hide or flee to places with friendlier laws or abundant electricity, including the United States.
There is abundant evidence of Boswell’s habit of abusing girls, many of them orphans and desperate for sixpence.

definition: perplexed by many conflicting situations or statements
details: If you're bemused, you're muddled or preoccupied. It happens when you're lost in thought, dazed, or overwhelmed (say, on the first day of high school).
examples: Despite all its success as a beautiful theory of the building blocks of the universe, quantum mechanics still leaves even those of us physicists who work with it daily both frustrated and bemused.
Far from the first time, the world—friends, foes, and bemused or appalled observers—must be wondering: WTF?!
Exeter magistrates heard Coles was "amused and bemused" by the investigation saying it was "only a goldfish".
I was disheartened by constant throwing away of dough – what was wrong with the last lot? – and bemused by the random suggestions I found on the web.

definition: a sudden desire
details: On a whim, he sold everything and left the city for the beautiful wilderness of Alaska, but his act of caprice felt a lot less whimsical when he realized how freezing cold Alaska is.
examples: Philharmonic, was an intense solo introduction for Koh’s confident playing; “Kinski Paganini” deconstructed a Paganini caprice until all that was left was a handful of dry glittering bits, like salt crystals.

Enlightenment France was not Soviet Russia; sources of power were dispersed through the caprices of patronage and the existence of an aristocracy wealthy enough to be, within limits, independent of the King.
Both ANT and Chronicles of Turkmenistan say the black-car ban is also down to presidential caprice.
There is a bit of the Old Testament in his caprice, something pagan in his appetite.

definition: bear the expenses of
details: If your mother says she will defray the cost of your next move, say thank you. She means she will take on some of the expenses for you.
examples: He helps defray the expenses by mounting fossils, doing reconstructions, and casting and selling replicas for museums, private collectors, and other clients.
Top lawmakers are pushing for a reprise of three prior deals to use spending cuts or new revenues and prop up additional spending rather than defray deficits that are again approaching $1 trillion.
The developer is using federal and state historic tax credits to help defray some of the costs associated with the renovations.
The contest may be a potentially lucrative lark for some, but a woman in the Arctic Circle city of Severomorsk wants the prize in order to defray the costs of surgery for her son.

definition: a mournful poem; a lament for the dead
details: An elegy is a sad poem, usually written to praise and express sorrow for someone who is dead. Although a speech at a funeral is a eulogy, you might later compose an elegy to someone you have loved and lost to the grave.
examples: Those frail, hopelessly mortal melodies, clinging on with dignified tenacity, became powerful allegorical elegies for both the horror and the enduring humanity of 9/11.
In 1996, Dr. Walker won the Pulitzer Prize for “Lilacs,” a commission from the Boston Symphony Orchestra that set portions of Walt Whitman’s Lincoln elegy “When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d.”
The poem is an elegy for Baker’s mother, but there’s something in it for everyone to grieve.
“You’re the Man” is one of the best singles of his career, a track that found him working in a drastically different mode than the meditative elegies of What’s Going On.

definition: attempting to win favor by flattery
details: Use fawning to describe someone who's over the top in the flattery department. Like a fawning admirer who just won't stop complimenting your looks, showering you with gifts and otherwise kissing the ground you walk on.
examples: As we saw from their fawning, elementary and sometimes inane questions during those hearings, few members of Congress understand the technology that they are tasked with regulating.
But filmmakers are not only fawning over the incumbent government.

Indian opposition parties are attempting to delay the release of what is widely seen as a fawning new biopic about Narendra Modi that is scheduled for release days before the start of national elections.
So they sent fawning congratulatory tweets, posted generic blog posts to Medium and name-dropped their deals on one of a dozen interchangeable V.C. podcasts.

definition: the central meaning or theme of a speech or literary work
details: When you need a quick summary of the essentials, rather than the whole story or a thorough explanation, you're looking for the gist.
examples: If that doesn’t exactly inspire “Game of Thrones”-level anticipation, well, you’re starting to get the gist of this conflict.
But the gist is this: Fasten your seatbelts; it’s going to be a bumpy night.
At best he probably recollects the gist of what was said, then uses his artistic skills and knowledge of the people involved to create a scene that sharpens what he only vaguely recalls.
He didn’t speak any Vietnamese, but he guessed the gist of what they were asking.

definition: displaying superhuman strength or power
details: Things that take great strength — like throwing a boulder or finishing math homework — are sometimes called herculean in honor of the Greek god Hercules.
examples: "This was a Herculean task," explained National Science Foundation Director Dr. France Cordova, during the press conference, noting that the Event Horizon Telescope's findings transform and enhance our understanding of Black Holes.
The sets and effects of the play are even more herculean considering North Bergen high school is one of the most underfunded schools in the entire state of New Jersey.
Morrison’s ambition was to show how “the Herculean effort to forget would be threatened by memory desperate to stay alive”.
He also proved his promise by defeating an in-form Nadal on clay—a Herculean task, perhaps the toughest test in tennis.

definition: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
details: Someone who doesn't seem to react — who is always "taking a pass" in the conversation of life can be described as impassive.
examples: The second silver-medalist—the surgeon—adopted a chin-up, impassive look, the same stoic face he wore on the golf course.
Zhong appeared impassive as the jury foreperson read the verdict, which found him guilty on five counts.
When Campbell was convicted by a unanimous jury verdict last month he did not show a flicker of emotion and remained impassive in the dock.
Asked whether he would support the measure that requires presidential candidates to disclose tax returns, Mr. McConnell remained impassive: “We’ll be happy to look at it.”

definition: a manner lacking seriousness
details: Joking that your dead grandmother "never looked better" could inject some levity, or frivolity, into her funeral, but your relatives might find your joke inappropriate to the occasion.
examples: And, like any commentator worth his salt, Spieth sprinkled in some levity with his recollections.
He did try add a little levity to his denial, however.
But that balances the levity and the heart.
That even raised a moment of levity in court.

definition: free from slavery or servitude
details: To manumit is to set free, or to release a slave from slavery. During slavery in the United States, it was rare for a slave owner to manumit his slaves.
examples: If they were faithful and hardworking, the master would set them free, manumit them, when he died.

When, finding slavery unprofitable, the northern States passed laws for gradual emancipation, but few obtained their freedom, the majority of them being shipped South and sold, so that but few, comparatively, were manumitted.
He quoted a decision of Judge Gaston, of North Carolina, that free negroes born in that state were citizens of the state and that slaves manumitted there became citizens by the fact of manumission.

Let liberal means be provided for removing far away those unfortunate beings amongst us whom we denominate free blacks, together with those slaves who shall be voluntarily manumitted for the purpose of removal.

definition: an extended fictional work in prose
details: If something is so new and original that it's never been seen, used or even thought of before, call it novel. The noun novel describes a book-length work of fiction.
examples: Boyle’s excellent new novel, “Outside Looking In,” presents his latest fictional exploration of how people drive, and are driven by, their environment.
I slouch against the back cushion, my legs propped up in front of me, and I consume story collections and novels, memoirs and biographies.

When Ellis was in his twenties, he published three novels—“Less Than Zero,” “The Rules of Attraction,” and “American Psycho”—that are considered some of the most biting and lasting satires of Ronald Reagan’s America.
One idea is that some novel physics prevents black holes from forming.

definition: the beginning or early stages
details: When something is at its onset, it's at the beginning, just getting started, and it's often something that's not so pleasant. The onset of hurricane season is probably not the best time to visit the beach.
examples: As for Oyelowo’s onset standoffishness, that melted away on the last day of shooting in Cannes.
Like Ellie, the actor Michael J Fox was diagnosed with young onset Parkinson's at the age of 29, and he's still acting occasionally in his late 50s.
Such brain benefits may be protective against the onset of dementia, she said.
The Standard & Poor’s 500 index was slightly lower from the onset of trading, and if it stays down, it would be the index’s first loss in eight trading days.

definition: excessively unwilling to spend
details: A parsimonious person is unwilling to spend a lot of money. You know those people who count up every penny when it's time to split a restaurant bill? You can call them parsimonious. Or cheap.
examples: Flush with this correlation, the authors declared that blaming monarch loss on practices involving herbicide-tolerant crops was “neither parsimonious nor well supported by data.”
But Van Wagenen speaks the management palaver of choice this parsimonious winter.

The club took the players’ dissatisfaction seriously and were quick to dismiss Henry, even though his hefty severance package of between €10 and €15m is a departure from their previously parsimonious ways.
Meanwhile, he says, “we are taking a parsimonious view” that they are in fact feathers.

definition: disentangle
details: Ravel is an interesting verb, in that it can mean both "tangle" and "untangle." So if you work to ravel yarn into a neat ball, your cat may come along and try to ravel it again.
examples: First, dreams knit up the ravelled sleeve of care by allowing us to process unhappy or traumatic experiences.
In early August, in a reactionary attempt to ravel it back up again, the Republicans held their convention in Miami and nominated Richard Nixon and Spiro Agnew.
Olakunde narrates always with looks of the greatest solemnity, but raveled deep in his demeanor is his joy in telling these tales, and to an audience so delighted with his testimony.
Like our friend sleep, soup knits up the raveled sleeve of care; like a favorite sweater, soup warms and reassures.

definition: deficient in quantity or number compared with the demand
details: If something is scarce, there isn't much of it around. Crops are scarce after a long drought, or you might find babysitters scarce if your kids are a nightmare to watch.
examples: Why push people to where jobs are relatively scarce? asked Benn Steil, an economist at the Council on Foreign Relations, a nonpartisan think tank.
Complex algorithms and vast databases were supposed to revolutionize crime fighting, making policing more efficient as number-crunching computers helped to position scarce resources.
Water is scarce and Taiz is some 100 kilometers from the coast.
“If you prevail — well, you’re devoting scarce resources of your department toward that effort, are you not, attorney general?” the Pennsylvania Democrat pressed.

definition: a well-substantiated explanation of some aspect of the world
details: When you have a theory, you have a set of beliefs or principles that might not be proven yet. Does anyone have a good theory for where missing socks go when you do laundry?
examples: Sen. Angus King, Maine independent, cited the “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it,” theory to press for changes to Mr. Trump’s far-reaching plans.
All of this is to say that Amazon, in theory, is competing for a greater share of the total retail market than it was even a few years ago.
Barr faced a massive backlash from Democrats for his testimony, with critics accusing him of feeding conspiracy theories.
When asked about the controversy surrounding Barr’s remarks, a person familiar with his thinking denied that he was trying to fuel conspiracy theories or play to the conservative base.

definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is proper
details: Something that is inappropriate or unacceptable behavior is unseemly. It's a gentler, somewhat nicer word for "inappropriate" than its synonyms, the "in" words: "indecent, indecorous, indelicate, inelegant, inept" — well, you get the idea.
examples: Countless clips document “Messi magic,” a playing style of almost unseemly brilliance.
You devour your piece in one unseemly breath, nearly smashing it into your mouth to avoid spillage.
No one walked the line of treating music’s unseemly elements as a cake-and-eat-it-too irony riot like Blender magazine.

White House Counsel Pat A. Cipollone said demanding to pry into diplomatic talks goes beyond the powers of Congress — and called it particularly unseemly when being done “for partisan political purposes.”

definition: an indication that something has been present
details: A vestige is a trace or reminder of something that has disappeared or is disappearing. A lump of snow with a carrot in it might be the vestige of a snowman.
examples: Lower incomes, worse health outcomes and the higher rates of incarceration currently experienced by the black community are highlighted as vestiges of this history.

Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, introducing the bill in January, said that “the impact of slavery and its vestiges continues to affect African Americans and indeed all Americans in communities throughout our nation.”
Another vestige of minority power is going by the boards.
All are made in-house and are on display in the deli counter, a vestige of the restaurant’s former life as The Market Hall.

definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering
details: To wheedle is to sweet talk, or flatter someone in the hopes of getting something in return. You might try to wheedle a meter maid into not giving you a parking ticket. Good luck with that.
examples: It’s a fascinating vignette, but we never learn her real name, or what happened to her, or how she wheedled those secrets from Nazi submariners, or how useful her intel proved to Alliance and MI6.
At 16, he wheedled his way onto the staff of a local newspaper.
My wife finds traditional Southern food to be soft and starchy, and will not cook it, especially after I am no longer around to wheedle and cajole.
In one exchange caught on tape by the New York Police Department, Mr. Weinstein tries to wheedle an actress into his room and explains that he is “used to” groping women.

definition: lie adjacent to another or share a boundary
details: When something borders something else, it is said to abut it. The term is often used in real estate to refer to a lot line. Wouldn’t it be nice to have your back yard abut a forest preserve or park?
examples: But for now, the city is only requiring homeowners’ associations to implement a “vegetation management” plan and install fire-resistant fencing around properties that abut open space areas, Rodriguez said.
One part of the plan imagines moving a lobby to the third floor of an occupied apartment building because the covered highway would abut the current entrance.
Questions also remain abut his net worth, tax profile and past financial dealings.
Then, there are some 2.2 million homes in the wild-land-urban interface where houses and businesses abut foothills, forests or other open land.

definition: doing or producing good
details: Beneficent is the type of act that helps others. If you're a beneficent person, you probably spend a lot of your time volunteering at soup kitchens or homeless shelters, helping people who are less fortunate than you are.
examples: Half a century later, by contrast, the modernist architect Le Corbusier saw the indoor environments he designed as beneficent bubbles of man-made weather, shielded from the smog-choked city outside.
There, wrote one of the founders, Ernest B. Gaston, these pioneers would build “a city set upon a hill, shedding its beneficent light to all the world.”
A woman on the assembly line looks on beneficently as boxes charge diagonally across the composition.
A huge billboard showed Xi gazing beneficently beside Papua New Guinea’s leader.

definition: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
details: Capricious is an adjective to describe a person or thing that's impulsive and unpredictable, like a bride who suddenly leaves her groom standing at the wedding altar.
examples: But in the days that followed, parents from a private Waldorf school filed a lawsuit that called the ban “arbitrary” and “capricious.”
Civil rights lawyer Michael Sussman called the order “arbitrary and capricious.”
Thorsen made his ruling after some parents from a private Waldorf school filed a suit calling the action “arbitrary, capricious” and “an unprecedented ‘declaration of a local emergency.’
District Court of New Mexico, calling the state standard “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not supported by substantial evidence.”

definition: skillful in physical movements; especially of the hands
details: Deft means "showing cleverness and skill in handling things." What you want to see in football or basketball is some deft handling of the ball.
examples: Add this deft chip to the growing collection of all-world par saves in golf this year.
Ahrens is a deft lyricist but some song lines are cloyingly obvious.
At the core of the action was Elizabeth Burke, who tore up the stage in a deft and impassioned solo.
Federer improvised and covered the corners impressively, slashing forehand and backhand winners and hitting deft, precise volleys.

definition: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
details: When you elicit, you're bringing out a response of some sort. A good comedian elicits a lot of laughs.
examples: “Oh, my goodness,” replied Dr. Van Doren, eliciting a laugh from the audience.
That was followed by a rare slam dunk that elicited howls from the crowd and a big smile across Nowitzki’s face.
The programs are expressly designed to elicit claimants’ accounts of particular acts of abuse.
Mr. Fish’s version isn’t the first “Oklahoma!” to elicit the shadows from within the play’s sunshine.

definition: exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style
details: Felicitous describes something that's pleasantly apt or fitting. Felicitous words you write on your friend's birthday card are the ones that perfectly suit the occasion and make her happy when she reads them.
examples: For a hint of what those of us outside the golden circle of overachievement are missing, Chabon obligingly taxonomizes the merits of felicitous forewords.
I am not sure that we need the term "beanball" or that it's the most felicitous metaphor, but if people find it a useful heuristic for that point, so much the better.
First developed in the seventeenth century by the Italians—their clear, open vowels suited it perfectly—bel canto does a number of felicitous things at once.
Morrison’s felicitous art bursts off each page with a pop of energy.

definition: having only superficial plausibility
details: A hiring manager might think you're being glib, or slick and insincere, if you say you've led a successful multinational corporation when you were actually in charge of flipping burgers for a fast-food restaurant chain.
examples: He says this with no trace of glib, because—in spite of the panorama that lies before him—he holds it as true.

Her story moved quickly from social media to the press and television, where sympathy for the problems that street cleaners faced over the severe winter was mixed with exasperation at their employer's glib responses.
If their butts are not clean, I apologize for being glib.
"The thing is, there are cameras everywhere. So I guess, to be glib about it, unfortunately for him, there were cameras everywhere but nobody punched anybody," Baldwin said.

definition: the abode of a recluse
details: Your summer cabin deep in the woods where you go to think about how funny life is sometimes? If you want to sound fancy, it could be called a hermitage, a dwelling removed from civilization.
examples: The hermitage at base camp, the glasses of brandy— That’s the past.
The monk described Doug as an “exceptional soul” and his hermitage as “the real thing.”
The site of Chapelle Dom Hue contains the ruins of what excavators believe is a religious retreat, or hermitage, which de Jersey said dates back to the 14th century.
Each year, more than 100 brotherhoods travel to the hermitage at El Rocío from all over Andalucía.

definition: be a hindrance or obstacle to
details: To impede something is to delay or block its progress or movement. Carrying six heavy bags will impede your progress if you're trying to walk across town in a hurry.
examples: This rule is unlikely to lead to many redactions in the part of the Mueller report dealing with whether Trump committed the crime of obstruction of justice with actions aimed at impeding the inquiry.

That approach, along with threats to close the border, narrow asylum criteria and create artificial bottlenecks to impede asylum seekers from legally entering the country, is doomed — legally, constitutionally and practically.
The shift in enforcement efforts is overwhelming legal checkpoints and impeding the free flow of goods and services, in some cases increasing wait times about fivefold.
We see nothing ambiguous about impeding folks from wandering around Montgomery sporting “For Sale” signs.

definition: having political views favoring reform and progress
details: A liberal is someone on the left wing of politics — the opposite of a conservative. Also, a liberal attitude toward anything means more tolerance for change.
examples: "As an American and a New Yorker I couldn’t be more offended by this bullsh*t, but of course Chuck Schumer, Nancy Pelosi and their band of liberal clowns will do nothing," he continued.
Jack Balkin, a liberal law professor at Yale, agrees that the increase in leak prosecutions is part of a larger transformation.
“Well it’s liberal arts education and - it’s a bachelor,” Kerry said.
I am just trying to understand why liberal opposition to Trump bothers you so much.

definition: raid and rove in search of booty
details: As a verb maraud means to rove about the countryside looking for goods to steal and in general, to make mayhem and trouble. The Gilbert and Sullivan opera "The Pirates of Penzance" is about a band of marauding pirates, the daughters of Major-General Stanley, and a big misunderstanding.
examples: Rival warlords were battling for control of the British Isles, and against marauding Viking forces.
Entertainment media—and media consumed for entertainment—were wringing these marauding hornballs for every scummy detail.
Officials in the Arkhangelsk region, where the archipelago lies, on Saturday declared a state of emergency because of the marauding mammals.
Large swathes of north-west Africa are now vulnerable to attack by marauding jihadists.

definition: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
details: Use nuance to refer to a very small difference in color, meaning, or feeling. What makes singers brilliant is not how loud they can sing a note, but how many nuances they can evoke through their approach.
examples: Cities are complex organisms, with many nuances and constantly moving parts.
No nuance, no comic relief, no sympathy, no social content, no gradual build-up and sudden release of tension, not much story – just jolts of fear-making.

When dealing in different languages, there are countless more nuances, like regional slang and dialects, that may not been accounted for during the development process for that language’s Alexa support.
But, from the late 70s, the grape’s swell of success led to a generation of mass-produced, one-note New World wines that increasingly lacked the nuance of their Old World counterparts.

definition: come down on or keep down by unjust use of one's authority
details: When you oppress someone, you use your authority to keep them down. If you oppress people long enough, they might decide to fight back and then decide to oppress YOU.
examples: Even the Times mentions Pompeo’s support for the rights of Muslims oppressed by certain Asian nations such as China and Myanmar.
Could the real problem be greedy capitalists taking advantage of a situation with limited competition and overcharging for products while they oppress the working class in their spare time?
Nerds are often oppressed in life, but on Broadway they’re the ruling class.
Why can’t this be just another ploy by the rich and powerful to keep us oppressed?

definition: being or affecting only a segment
details: If you describe something as partial, you're usually saying it's just part of the whole, or incomplete. Say someone asks how you started your band and you say, "I bought a guitar." That would be a partial answer, at best.
examples: October 2017 - U.S. announces partial lifting of long-standing sanctions against Sudan, citing progress by Khartoum in fighting terrorism and its commitment not to pursue arms deals with North Korea.
They issued a partial dissent when the court turned down an appeal brought by a football coach who said he was fired for leading prayers on the field after games.
Poverty and limited access to care offer only partial explanations.
It urged demonstrators to remain at the sit-in to ensure there was no "partial or false solution".

definition: extremely conservative or resistant to change
details: Reactionary describes people on the far right politically. Reactionaries are extremely conservative and oppose reform or change.
examples: Susan Wilkins, chair of the Unfair School Taxes Committee, described the district’s process as reactionary and said they caused the capacity issues in the first place.

In the past, the argument was often made that the religious establishment or the more conservative, reactionary elements of society would not tolerate women driving or a mixed-gender environment in the workforce.
In fact, they lie on the reactionary right, in the counter-Enlightenment of the late 18th century.
Despite Zelenskiy’s success in unifying almost all the regions of this polarised country, he is unlikely to be able to move Ukraine away from reactionary nationalism.

definition: a small and inadequate amount
details: If there is a cupcake scarcity in your kitchen, there are hardly any cupcakes around, and you're not sure that any will be appearing any time soon.
examples: Instead, he was using concerns about environmental scarcity to justify racial discrimination.
Such specialist physicians require extensive training and particular equipment, and their scarcity in many regions of the world often forces people to travel long distances for an eye examination.
But it also seemed to remark on the immediate surroundings, the atmosphere of scarcity that drove people away in the first place.
The scarcity of workers is driving up wages.

definition: the state of being under the control of another person
details: When you're in thrall to someone, you are under their control in some way. If you're being held as a hostage, you're in thrall to your captor.
examples: General Hifter’s opponents, in turn, bash him as a tyrant in thrall of Mr. el-Sisi, and say he aspires to be a strongman like the nation’s former dictator, Col.
One quibble is that the book’s thesis, that literature is boringly in thrall to Aristotle, is a bit of a straw man.
She was under the thrall of sovereign gurus, he said, “people who kind of strutted back and forth on the stage with an answer for everything.”
“Wines from the US still hold diners in thrall, making up 38.4 percent of the Most Popular bottlings,” the magazine said.

definition: unpleasant to look at
details: Unsightly is a gentler way of saying ugly. Often something that is described as unsightly sticks out like a sore thumb in an otherwise attractive environment.
examples: The result was an unsightly season debut last Sunday against the Arizona Diamondbacks.
The next week, the Chargers’ season ended in dramatic and unsightly fashion against the Patriots, who opened a 35-7 halftime lead en route to a 41-28 win.
If I trim off the top of the panels, I fear the top panels will be unsightly.
By the 1790s, the unsightly clutter of graves in the center of town led to establishment of the New Haven City Burying Ground, known as Grove Street Cemetery.

definition: a gown worn by the clergy
details: A vestment is a garment worn at special ceremonies by a clergy member. For example, a priest would wear a vestment in church, but out in the community, he would wear a shirt and pants.
examples: There is a symbolic passing of the baton here, or at least of the vestments.

Though the Bible readings through this period warn against performing dourness for the sake of impressing people with your piety, the church itself goes stark: rough, burlaplike vestments instead of shiny finery; no “alleluias.”

“I ask forgiveness of God, of the wider community and our own Catholic community,” Archbishop Blair said, standing before the packed church in flowing vestments and the red-rose skull cap worn by bishops.
His DNA was later found to match salvia on the back of the vestment worn by Canon White on 7 July last year.

definition: make keen or more acute
details: To whet is to sharpen. You could whet a knife's blade with a whetting stone, or you could whet your appetite by having some Doritos.
examples: His interest in politics was whetted in 1982 when he was a driver for Robert Pascal, an unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor.
It’s so good to finally see MLB bring the game to Europe and, unlike the NFL, we’ve actually got one of the most heated rivalries in sports to whet our appetites with.
The way it works in TV now is they send you two or three episodes to get your appetite whetted.
She advised her son to enrol on a course in hotel and catering operations, which whetted his appetite for a career in the hospitality industry.

definition: so deep as to be immeasurable
details: If you want to say something is really, really bad — then call it abysmal. If one person shows up to your party, well then that is an abysmal turnout. The 1958 Ford Edsel? An abysmal failure.
examples: Maryland missed seven of its 23 free throws and suffered through an abysmal shooting performance in the first half, shooting just 28.6 percent from the field.
“The numbers are abysmal; we knew that,” Williams, who is black, told the Times.
“The numbers are abysmal, we knew that,” said Mr. Williams, who is black.
After a 335-yard drive, Rory hits an absolutely abysmal wedge into the fifth green, and it’s time to honor our shared Irish heritage with a Guinness.

definition: showing or motivated by sympathy and understanding
details: Choose the adjective benevolent for someone who does good deeds or shows goodwill. If your teacher collects homework with a benevolent smile, she's hoping that you've done a good job.
examples: Though I fancy the idea of contrasting block-by-block urban combat with helping different communities to flourish, the benevolent side of the game is not very engaging.
Peele is pretty sure the first episode he saw was “To Serve Man,” from 1962, in which humans discover that the titular text of a seemingly benevolent alien race is actually a cookbook.
His biggest moneymakers often repeated the formula of, as he put it: “Taking something which is considered benevolent and turning it into some kind of monstrosity.”
This particular novel is about a multigenerational journey to an Earth-like moon in another galaxy, narrated in part by a benevolent all-knowing spaceship.

definition: tending to find and call attention to faults
details: If someone tends to be hypercritical and find fault with everything, you can describe that person as captious. Try not to be described as a captious person yourself, however. No one likes a carping individual!
examples: “I wish you’d learn to put the caps back on things properly when you’re finished using them,” she said in a tone she fully meant to sound captious.
Still, readers shouldn’t be overly captious about this diverting, light entertainment.
From Tennessee to Birmingham, their captious free-for-all Suggests that I am riding on the Squabash Cannonball.
The captious, however, might complain that Levi’s autobiographical writings are somewhat repetitive, his essays a bit dry and his fantasy fiction rather labored.

definition: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity
details: Deign means to reluctantly agree to do something you consider beneath you. When threatened with the loss of her fortune, an heiress might deign to get a job, but she might look down her nose at the people she'd have to work with.
examples: And while God is busy at his peephole—as he deigns us with his disapproval—as he lumbers about his empty kingdom like some overfed colonial governor—as God sleeps late, we will win.
But Ali is a bad communicator, and one lesson the movie deigns to teach her is to listen more carefully.
When the film won two Golden Globes earlier this month, no one deigned — or dared — to mention Singer’s name from the stage.
George didn’t even deign to meet with the Lakers about a return to his home state after years of hopeful speculation by Lakers fans and Magic Johnson, who wanted to team James with George.

definition: omission or suppression of parts of words or sentences
details: An ellipsis is punctuation that is used to show where words have been left out. The ellipsis is usually formed by three periods (four if the ellipsis comes at the end of a sentence).
examples: More often than not the real stories are transpiring in the silences, in the margins and ellipses that another filmmaker might be inclined to fill in.
A chapter in the story that should read, "The Trump-Russia Scandal: The End" is instead punctuated by question marks or an ellipsis.
The Patriots commemorated the anniversary by securing another championship against the same franchise, in a similar way, for a title that represents not a bookend so much as an ellipsis.
It will at first orbit Earth in expanding ellipses and, about two months later, cross into the moon’s orbit.

definition: characterized by intense emotion
details: Use fervent to describe a person or thing that shows very strong feelings or enthusiasm. If you have a fervent desire to become an actress, you'll stop at nothing to realize your dream.
examples: The Basij is made mostly up of volunteers who are fervent believers in the ideology of the Islamic Republic.
The faith's highest leadership group, known as the First Presidency, made the decision after "fervent, united prayer to understand the will of the Lord on these matters," the statement said.
A million people walking in peaceful protest, declaring their fervent wish to remain in Europe.
That wrongheaded assumption was severely weakened in the D.C. area by Reed’s fervent attacks on it.

definition: look angry or sullen as if to signal disapproval
details: If you see someone glower at you, you might consider glowering back, but no one likes an angry staring contest. To glower is not only to stare, it's to stare angrily, as if you're going to throttle someone.
examples: She glowers at me, quickly pulling her face mask back over her mouth before Barb notices.
Remember when it was the Death Star, monopolistically glowering over technopolis and threatening to cut off the air supply of competitors and regulators alike?
Henry glowered at the pastor but remained silent.
I tried to glower at Sohrab, but it was impossible, because he was squinting again and I ended up laughing instead.

definition: make or shape as with an axe
details: If you're a lumberjack, the word hew is nothing new. You hew things every day with one swift swing of the axe, chopping and shaping wood.
examples: Beyond machetes, the cafe’s wide-ranging menu hews closely to the foods that Jose Villegas grew up eating in Mexico City, and his devotion to home-style Mexican cooking is broadcast loud and clear on the menu.
All four of the initial episodes parallel specific earlier episodes, and the closer they hew to the originals, the weaker they are.
And it hews closely to the main views of most intelligence agencies, particularly the CIA.
The commission also hewed closely to Handy’s definition of a “marketplace platform” and “marketplace contractor,” terms of art for “company” and “worker.”

definition: cause to move forward with force
details: Impel means to force to move forward. A person sleep walking might move as if impelled by a force beyond their control. Loneliness might impel you to talk to someone you don't know.
examples: Malpaso’s stylistic essence is the reverse — movement linked to and impelled by the musical accompaniment.
The legislation establishes liability only if the property owner “with a degree of conscious decision-making, impelled the conduct of said third party.”
The experience impelled her to find a way of prompting parents to record video messages for their children.
The emergency for Mr. Trump is purely political, impelled by expectations inflated by his campaign promises to build a border wall and force Mexico to pay.

definition: a dissolute person
details: If you drink a lot, eat a lot, and live a wild and unrestrained life, you might be called a libertine.
examples: Araki’s libertines are fun to follow as they romp and revolve, but what happens to them seems a little too shallow, too prolonged and too low-stakes.
In “Talking Pupils,” a notorious libertine is blinded for making unwanted advances, only to discover that tiny beings live inside his eyes.
But a share of what ails this series from the get-go is its frenzied emphasis on Mo’s unregulated libertine lifestyle, amorality and his quest to break new records in the realm of excess.
She was both a libertine and fitfully conservative.

definition: bite and grind with the teeth
details: To masticate is to chew your food or to bite and grind stuff with your teeth.
examples: “So you want to stay here with us for a spell?” said Jacquel, masticating the slice of the girl’s heart.
He smears the masticated leaf all over Haye’s body, and then packs it with mossy soil.
Below, the best centrifugal juicers, masticating and cold-press juicers, and citrus presses determined by the hard-nosed reviewers on Amazon.
Now he needs to expel a masticated remnant.

definition: a state of extreme dishonor
details: If you go against or oppose what's good, you might earn opprobrium — the opposite of getting attention for something good. Bad behavior leads to opprobrium. If you throw a soft drink off the theater balcony, the opprobrium might keep you from getting dates to the movies.
examples: Messi’s name attracted a little opprobrium, too: not quite the howling chorus reserved for his teammates, but not too far-off.
Bashir earned international opprobrium for his generous hospitality towards violent extremists such as Osama bin Laden and Carlos the Jackal in the 1990s.
A frosty reception at Anfield may be unavoidable since his departure, but he attracts opprobrium elsewhere, too.
Even at its most persuasive, the opprobrium — which became more aggressive as the campaign season accelerated — felt disproportionate to the film’s humble intent.

definition: a predisposition to like something
details: Partiality is the habit of favoring something — taking its part. If your parents always seem to let your little sister off the hook while you get grounded, you could accuse them of partiality in their parenting. They favor your sister over you.
examples: The IRS already recognizes the risk of partiality—or at least, the appearance of partiality—in its examination of the president’s taxes.
Television stations in both countries were accused of sensationalism and partiality.
The three-judge panel found in his favor, saying Bitney’s actions created a substantial risk of bias resulting in the appearance of partiality.
“True justice must be completely just without even a hint of partiality, lack of integrity, or impropriety,” Tucker wrote in his opinion issued late on Thursday.

definition: the act of correcting again
details: If you have to make changes to something, you make a readjustment. You make readjustments all the time — like when you lower the bike seat for your little sister or set your clock forward for daylight saving time.
examples: “This legislation will remove existing barriers to care for National Guardsmen and Reservists by allowing them to access readjustment counseling at VA Medical Centers and through VA mental health services.”
She clearly thinks I am insane, pointedly ignoring my furtive readjustments when Theresa shifts around as I sing.
Even the simple process of attending a day’s worth of screenings demands a continual cycle of adjustment and readjustment, of leaping from unknown to unknown.
It is important to keep in mind that the projected path for your semester will need continuous readjustment.

definition: an elaborate and systematic plan of action
