details: A scheme is an elaborate plan or plot. It's going to take a really solid scheme, probably involving teleportation or some sort of temporary cloning, to make an appearance at both parties at once.
examples: The three are accused of taking part of a multi-million-dollar public corruption scheme that involved elected officials in Arkansas and Missouri.
The Trump family used a fraudulent scheme to avoid taxes on hundreds of millions of dollars President Trump and his siblings inherited from their father, according to a Times investigation.
The aim of this scheme, the indictment says, was to leak government secrets to an unnamed newspaper reporter, who is identifiable as Siobhan Gorman, of the Baltimore Sun.

Ms McGeough-Adams is one of 52,000 members of the pension scheme - technically the 1974 Midland Bank defined benefit pension scheme - whose company pensions will be reduced when they reach state retirement age.

definition: thin and tattered with age
details: Those jeans you wear every day that have holes in the knees and thin patches in the rear? They're threadbare. Threadbare means thin from overuse.
examples: But cabinet discipline is now so threadbare that it starts to become interesting.
Long gone are the days when minor leaguers subsisted on peanut butter and jelly sandwiches with threadbare coaching staffs to guide them.
Languishing in the threadbare luxury of a dying empire, Hassan and Fatima find refuge in stories and in each other’s company, freed from the claims of desire and ownership.
That’s what Bravo is hoping for as it seeks to revive the threadbare reality competition.

definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is proper
details: The adjective untoward describes something offensive or inappropriate, like the rumors of untoward behavior that can shatter a Hollywood icon's reputation.
examples: Mr. Carone said there was nothing untoward in his financial support of the mayor.
Usually there would be nothing untoward about this – but eight of the flats were still occupied.
“All I’m thinking is, if anything untoward happens today …”
Bharara said Trump did not say anything "untoward" and did not ask him to do anything inappropriate.

definition: disturb, especially by minor irritations
details: If something vexes you, it brings you trouble or difficulty. In other words, it annoys, worries, distresses, irritates, bothers, or puzzles you.
examples: Let’s focus on one of the most vexing dietary issues: saturated fat.
James Atlas’s heartfelt memoir of his vexed friendship with Philip Roth is available exclusively in audiobook form.
“I was trying to produce through someone else’s eyes and ears — someone who’s not here,” he said with vexed intensity, while sitting at his control board.

Another challenge ahead for Ms. Lightfoot: the scandal-prone police department and persistently high homicide rate, both of which damaged the city’s reputation and vexed Mr. Emanuel through eight years in office.

definition: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
details: Whimsical means full of or characterized by whims, which are odd ideas that usually occur to you very suddenly. If you decide at the last minute to fly to Europe, you could say you went there on a whim.
examples: In rooms filled with giant hanging moons, plastic sausages and mechanized light displays, their messages range from the whimsical to the political to the deeply personal.
In its early years, flight was utterly whimsical.

In a speech on the Senate floor on Tuesday, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, lamented the “chaos” in the White House stemming from the president’s “whimsical, erratic” behavior.
The whimsical name for her work — “bubbling” — belies its prickly technicalities.

definition: yield to another's wish or opinion
details: If you accede, it means you agree with someone or give in to his or her wish. The word is often used in a political context — the Queen acceded to the Prince's demands for more territory, a larger army, and funnier jesters.
examples: At the same time, Mrs. May faces a convulsion in her own party if she accedes to Labour’s demands, with hard-line pro-Brexit Conservative lawmakers threatening new attempts to oust her.
Malaysia this year backtracked on acceding to a U.N. treaty against racial discrimination after a massive Muslim rally.
Malaysia earlier this year backtracked on acceding to a U.N. treaty against racial discrimination following a massive Muslim rally.

definition: lacking enlightenment or knowledge or culture
details: Being called benighted is much like being called naive. It means lacking in knowledge or understanding—the kind you might have if you were older or more sophisticated.
examples: Is he a benighted fool embarking on a quixotic quest, or a devoted son fulfilling a religious obligation?
In a democratic republic, our legislators are as benighted or enlightened as our voters.

And while the show’s dialogue, especially, is defined by broad vulgarity, beneath that surface is an experiment in skewering a benighted milieu without indulging in the very things that made it appalling.
Could it be that we are too selfish, too benighted, too lacking in courage?

definition: one of a group of prominent bishops in the Sacred College
details: A cardinal is a bright red songbird, and the word also refers to the bird's crimson color. In Catholicism, a cardinal is a high-ranking bishop. In math, you use cardinal numbers to count. A cardinal rule is one that is central and should not be broken.
examples: More important, they and their writers understood the cardinal rule of television: It is all about the characters.
The charge sheet includes statements from 83 witnesses, including a cardinal, three bishops, 11 priests and 25 nuns, the group said in its statement.
He knelt repeatedly with a cardinal and a barrister, praying for protection of the students and protesters.
Gregory is one of eight black bishops in the United States, and this position puts him that much closer to becoming a cardinal.

definition: harmful to living things
details: If something is deleterious, it does harm or makes things worse. Smoking has obvious deleterious effects on your health, not to mention your social life.
examples: The lobsters, however, also ate the hair on the hide, with deleterious effects — prompting Maine’s Marine Resources Committee to ban “hairy bait” in 2006.
She knew firsthand the deleterious effects of that lack of demand.
Countless authors and academics and politicians warn about the deleterious effects of screens and social media.
Only after being pushed to be more specific did Williams cite her unhappiness with the president’s “approach to tariffs” and its potentially deleterious impact on Montana’s wheat farmers.

definition: escape, either physically or mentally
details: Elude means "evade or escape," like the way you might elude the other kids during a game of hide-and-seek. This word can also mean "to be hard to understand." No matter how hard you try, the finer points of quantum physics might elude you.
examples: Being at Coachella meant the band was finally facing the kind of massive, appreciative crowd that eluded them in the U.S. before breaking up in 1993.
SACRAMENTO, Calif. – California prosecutors say they will seek the death penalty if they convict the man suspected of being a notorious California serial killer who eluded capture for decades.
In Bennett’s case, the son brought home the championship that eluded the father.
The Champions League is the one major honor to elude City in the 11 years since Abu Dhabi investment transformed the club.

definition: feelings of great warmth and intensity
details: Use fervor to describe an intensity of emotion or expression. Fans of the Los Angeles Dodgers show so much fervor that they "bleed Dodger blue."
examples: It was the most aggressive show of force between the two nuclear-armed rivals in decades, and the renewed national fervor caused by the tension was good for Modi’s polls.
When I was in that office, I sat instead at my desktop computer and wrote with the fervor of a woman with two children under the age of 3 and a part-time babysitter.
District Court in Eastern Kentucky accused the Post of being driven by anti-Trump fervor in its reporting on the incident.
Add to that equation his life’s passion — he was an offensive lineman for Miami in the early 1990s, then got into coaching — and the fervor level goes to 11.

definition: stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick
details: A goad is a pointy stick or other instrument used to prod something along. To goad is to poke something with that pointy stick. Either way, the pointiness is really essential for making things leap into action.
examples: Mr. Sanders’s refusal to release his full tax returns was a relatively minor issue in the 2016 Democratic primaries, when Hillary Clinton goaded him to be more transparent.
The shooter, who professed affection for divisive online memes and sowing social discord, stated that his intent was to gin up division and goad different factions into attacking one another.
They were victims of a leftwing mob — led by Democrats and goaded on by willing accomplices in the mainstream media.
Watch in slow motion as Democrats, goaded by the media, conspire to reelect President Trump:

definition: the period of greatest prosperity or productivity
details: A heyday is a peak of popularity or success. If you hear someone say "Hey! Back in the day, I was the best boxer in the city! No one could beat me!" he might be remembering his heyday as a fighter.
examples: Far from its heyday in Israel's pioneering age, Israel's left now appears doomed, as Yohanan Plesner from Israel's Democracy Institute said, "to represent a mere niche."
“They remind me of the Dallas Cowboys in their heyday,” said Burke, who won a Stanley Cup as general manager of the Anaheim Ducks in 2007.
The heyday of Brutalism, from the 1950s to the 1970s, coincided with the process of decolonisation in Africa.
In the midcentury heyday of the Broadway musical, Bob Fosse was one of theater’s most celebrated choreographers.

definition: close in time; about to occur
details: If something is impending, it is about to happen. If you hear thunder in the distance, you might go inside to escape the impending storm.
examples: The importance of maintaining secrecy about the impending raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound was likely on Obama’s mind.
The stories, narrated nightly by the Persian noblewoman Scheherazade to King Shahryar to delay her impending death, are humorous, replete with danger and derring-do.
Society needs to stop producing carbon emissions if it is to tackle the impending climate crisis.

Bissell first briefed Nixon, the GOP nominee, in March 1960 about the agency’s covert Cuba operations—including use of “goon squads” paid to undermine Castro’s supporters—but with no mention of impending assassination attempts.

definition: the words of an opera or musical play
details: In opera, the libretto is the words or lyrics, as distinct from the music. Mozart composed the music to his operas, but the librettos were written by someone else.
examples: Perhaps more so than the translation of the libretto, Shaw and Isomura point to the ethnically accurate casting of this production as its most transformative –– and challenging –– element.

For the piece, co-commissioned by the National Geographic Society, Auerbach traveled to the north and spent extensive time with the Inuit peoples, learning the language and writing the libretto herself.
These horrors aren’t imagined; Mr. Sellars assembled the libretto from historical texts, including journals, poems and folk song lyrics of the time.
As he approached 70, Mr. Previn turned to opera, writing “A Streetcar Named Desire” to a libretto by Philip Littell based on the Tennessee Williams play.

definition: come into being; become reality
details: When you materialize, you show up suddenly after being missing, unborn, or unseen. Think of Harry Potter removing his invisibility cloak. He materializes.
examples: After the sanctions never materialized, economic adviser Larry Kudlow said she got “ahead of the curve” and suggested she was confused.
If you can’t wait for that future to materialize, the P30 Pro is already here and, for a brief moment in time, it owns the title of the most capable mobile camera on the planet.
The charge never materializes as he shoots 71.
One example of such an entanglement was the proposal to build a Trump tower in Moscow, a deal potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars that never materialized.

definition: rich and superior in quality
details: Opulent is a word that you will hear a lot around rich people looking to show off. "Remember the opulent buffet at Carrie’s sweet sixteen? Sixteen chocolate cakes iced in gold leaf!"
examples: Imagine that the White House, instead of a fortress, were an opulent country club.
It was golden and crisp and tasted of stone fruit and flowers and, beneath that, something heavier and riper and more opulent.

liver or meat or fowl finely minced or ground and variously
                                    seasoned

details: Emboss means to carve with a design. A silver tray might be embossed with your initials and wedding date. You might give your teacher a plaque with "World's Best Teacher" embossed under their name.
examples: Inside the case was Ford’s signed letter of apology on embossed White House stationery.
His was dark leather with the logo embossed on it—much nicer than my canvas-and-polyester one.
Leather embossed in a crocodile design for handbags offered a glossy shine.
The album’s packaging features embossed line-work images showing a hand reaching skyward on the front and a range of smaller pictures, also embossed, surrounding the track list on the back.

definition: a long narrow depression in a surface
details: A long fine crack in the surface of something is called a fissure. If you see a fissure in the ice on a frozen lake, you'll want to take off your skates and head back to the car.
examples: If so, the United States should be working to deepen fissures within the Iranian elite, rather than pushing different factions toward the Revolutionary Guard.
In practice, social fissures within American society are to be exploded for the political and personal gain of Trump, his allies and the global kleptocrats.
“And there’s a heart shape here in the center, but it’s got little fissures in it.”

The fissure widens when she becomes romantically involved with Steven, a handsome and charismatic young pastor who preaches to a raucous congregation in an old movie theater, prowling the aisles “like a panther.”

definition: work hard to come to terms with or deal with something
details: When you wrestle with something — literally or figuratively — you grapple with it, or try to overcome it.
examples: As Californians grapple with that 13.3 percent income tax – and some leaner-than-usual refunds this year due to the recent federal tax overhaul – lawmakers in Sacramento are looking at a range of other revenue sources.
But the 41-year-old community relations manager for a public library still grapples with the care she received — the doctors who talked over her and rolled their eyes when she asked questions.
Admittedly, that “good start” was delayed somewhat as company grappled with some unwelcome publicity over a major personnel change.
Alongside his competitors, he’ll also grapple with a new fifth hole on the course.

definition: all of the same or similar kind or nature
details: If a group of things are homogeneous, they're all the same or similar, like a room full of identically dressed Elvis impersonators.
examples: And it is playing into the growing global conflict between old-style national identities, imagined as homogeneous and fixed, and a world that no longer aligns with them.
This only further illustrates the problem with racially homogeneous communities in America created by both explicit and covert modes of segregation.
The strains in many Western yogurt brands are chosen to produce milder-tasting, more homogeneous curds.
And, like the smaller and more homogeneous group before it, this academy stayed true to its inexplicable, and frankly unforgivable, “no Oscar for Glenn Close” rule.

definition: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
details: An impervious surface is one that can't be penetrated. The word is often followed by "to," as in "His steely personality made him impervious to jokes about his awful haircut."
examples: The Candida auris fungus is deadly, impervious to major antifungal medications — and on the move.
The team then transferred their feces via colonoscopy to three patients with the same kind of cancer whose tumors seemed impervious to PD-1 drugs.
But the bad news for Democrats is that, beyond a certain point, Trump is impervious to negative campaigning.
The conspiracy hawks seem totally impervious to shame or reason.

definition: a deposit of valuable ore
details: If you work in a mine and you find a stripe of gold that seems to stretch on forever, you’ve found a lode of gold — a supply vein of ore. You’re also rich.
examples: In a paper to be published Monday, a team of paleontologists at the University of Kansas say they found a “mother lode of exquisitely preserved animal and fish fossils” in what is now North Dakota.
By spring 1996 I’d seen 24 of the 37 possible paintings; then I hit the mother lode, going to a Vermeer retrospective at the Mauritshuis in The Hague, which was displaying 23 works.
You hope only that this young man walked away with a mother lode from the league without shame.
He took a peek into the bag—whoa—a fly mother lode!

definition: given to lying
details: A mendacious person is one who tells lies habitually and intentionally. Don't get stuck at the water cooler or bus stop next to someone you consider mendacious!
examples: Some of course were more mendacious than others.
But even by his usual mendacious standards, his latest lie was a doozy.
He described the president as “mendacious” and “incompetent” and predicted he would not win reelection.
We feed off of a mythology of whiteness and white supremacy, a mythology that is completely mendacious and entails vast historical distortion and historical amnesia.

definition: move or swing from side to side regularly
details: On a hot day, you’ll be happy to have a fan that can oscillate, meaning it moves back and forth in a steady motion.
examples: First, when the BEC was set to oscillate back and forth in the harmonic trap, the oscillation frequency changed when the lithium gas was present.
Air traffic controllers in Ethiopia also said they saw the oscillating trajectory before the plane crashed on March 10.
Marine sediments suggest that, before about one million years ago, the climate oscillated in 40,000-year cycles.
The sound is like a low frequency hum of a propeller driven airplane that oscillates between a louder and a softer hum.

definition: relating to the study of diseases
details: If something is caused by a physical or mental disease, it is pathological. Someone with a pathological compulsion for cleanliness might scrub the floors for hours every night.
examples: “It’s a weird, pathological thing. I also think the intelligence community coöpted Obama, because he’s rather naïve about national security. He’s accepted the fear and secrecy. We’re in a scary space in this country.”
Certainly, I agree with you that there's a pathological construction of whiteness which is not doing anybody any favors and we've been living with this thing for centuries.
And there is growing awareness of how our dependence on smartphones is becoming pathological, an addiction that scatters attention and fritters away our relationship to real things and real people.

New Zealand's privacy commissioner slammed Facebook as "morally bankrupt pathological liars" as the fallout from the Christchurch mosque attacks, which were livestreamed and spread virally, continued.

definition: withdrawn from society; seeking solitude
details: The adjective reclusive describes a desire for seclusion or privacy. A reclusive movie star is the one tabloid photographers dream of capturing on film.
examples: Mr. Pompeo said recently that the U.S. will keep in place its policy of maximum “economic pressure” on North Korea until the reclusive nation agrees to fully and permanently dismantle its nuclear and missile programs.
“I became reclusive for a bit,” she wrote.
“I used to be reclusive, burdened by lots of frights. I was alive but I was in limbo. Now I'm more present in myself.”
Price also said at the time that both Day and Caswell were “reclusive” and their home was in “very, very poor shape.”

definition: marked by care and persistent effort
details: A sedulous person is someone who works hard and doesn't give up easily. If you make repeated and sedulous attempts to fix a leaky pipe and it only makes things worse, it might be time to go online and find the number of a plumber.
examples: As their hatred for Trump and his policies grew, they became more sedulous in propagating fictitious stories.
In his own right he remains one of jazz’s more sedulous bandleaders, and later this year, he’ll release a new album with his Captain Black Big Band.
Even in the most amicable of arrangements, when all the ostensible needs are met, and everyone is healthy and clear-headed, it's nearly impossible to harness the sedulous nuances of adoption.
And that, following an assessment of his sedulous performance over the years, the distributor was promoting Mr. Dalai to manage the College Street branch.

definition: marked by repeated turns and bends
details: Tortuous means twisting or complicated. "James Bond drove up a mountain road that was tortuous in its twists and turns. He had to stop the evil madman's plan for world domination, a plan so tortuous that even 007 himself could not understand it."
examples: In European capitals there was weariness and exasperation with Britain’s tortuous Brexit divorce after 46 years of membership.
That’s not to say that “Outside Looking In” is one long buzzkill, but it is a farce laced with tragedy: the story of a good man’s increasingly tortuous moral gymnastics.
After more than two years of tortuous discussions about the minutiae of the separation, EU leaders are weary of London’s failure to agree its own divorce and patience is wearing thin.
The tortuous issue was further complicated when Trump moved the U.S.

definition: seize and take control without authority
details: If you take over your neighbor's backyard and claim his in-ground swimming pool as your own, you might seize control of, or usurp his yard, but he'll probably call the cops on you.
examples: “Trump’s end run around Congress clearly usurped their appropriation authority. His so-called emergency declaration presents a critical constitutional question.”
From there, Coach K usurped Calipari as the top choice for players who needed a quick stop between high school and the NBA draft green room.
The Bears usurped perennial power Connecticut as the team to beat - for the time being, anyway - by knocking off the then-top-ranked Huskies 68-57 on Jan. 3.
The Bears usurped perennial power Connecticut as the team to beat — for the time being, anyway — by knocking off the then-top-ranked Huskies 68-57 on Jan. 3.

definition: someone who is dazzlingly skilled in any field
details: A virtuoso is an incredibly talented musician. You can also be a virtuoso in non-musical fields.
examples: Bahni Turpin delivers the general narrative in a warm confident voice and is, in dialogue, a virtuoso of accents and manner.
Each is a phenomenal virtuoso with the necessary technique to burn and the bravery to then burn it.

We heard a virtuoso performance of Bach’s Goldberg Variations II by pianist Bruce Murray, followed by innovative interpretations of pieces written for cello, played on acoustic guitar and a specially made cello banjo.
It’s the sound of a true virtuoso and a towering figure in American art, and it’s awfully hard to hear it with dry eyes.

definition: an established custom
details: A wont is a custom or habit, like my wont to drink at least ten cups of coffee a day. (In this particular example, some people might call my wont an addiction.)
examples: Although he did not specify which products would be affected, he added: "That isn't to say there won't be food on the shelves and things people wont be able to buy."
That doesn’t meant they don’t need carbs – they do – but they don’t do as well with grains as they do with high-carbohydrate vegetables, while complex carbs are wont to pass through them completely.
If experience is any guide, spies are not wont to emote.
The NCAA, as is its wont, appointed a commission headed by former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to study the matter, with predictable results.

definition: harsh or corrosive in tone
details: If you say something acerbic, or harshly bitter, to someone, it can leave a bitter taste in your own mouth that lingers, and the acerbic, or acidic, words can eat away at the person on the receiving end too.
examples: But she noted acerbically that “in retrospect these dynamics were artificial and were valued more by myself than Nathaniel”.
Last week, Trump struck back against Powell by saying he’ll nominate Stephen Moore, a supply-side polemicist and acerbic critic of the Fed, to join its board.
But he was probably best known for helping to spearhead the study of popular fiction in the classroom, and for his frequent — and frequently acerbic — reviews and essays on contemporary literature.
Gayle Green’s brilliant and acerbic 2008 book Insomniac describes not only her exploration of sleep research but also her many less than successful attempts at treatments and therapies.

definition: be a signal for or a symptom of
details: A dark sky full of clouds might betoken a thunderstorm. In other words, the clouds indicate or point to the fact that a thunderstorm is on its way.
examples: But it doesn’t betoken a path to profitability, in part because the improvement reflected an intensified squeeze on drivers.
M Hollande, however, wonders if it doesn’t betoken a certain chilliness.
The circular patterning also betokens a geometry repeated around official Washington: the Oval Office, the Rotunda, the dome of the Jefferson Memorial.
Banks employ armies of people in back offices, looking for discrepancies that may betoken fraud or honest error.

definition: meet to select a candidate or promote a policy
details: The noun caucus is a closed meeting of members from the same political party. The Iowa caucuses get a lot of attention during the presidential primary season.
examples: California will be the largest of the 12 states scheduled to vote on March 3, 2020, directly after the early voting primary and caucus states of Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina.
“Hopefully everybody understands now that the best success for a united caucus is for us to be consulted and be at the table.”
But would he support the former Texas congressman in next year’s Iowa caucuses?
“Hopefully, everyone understands that the best chance of success for a united caucus is for us to be consulted and to be at the table.”

definition: lower someone's spirits; make downhearted
details: If something demoralizes you, it makes you feel bad or hopeless. When your soccer team was trounced by the last-place team in the league, the loss seemed to demoralize everyone, from players to coaches to fans.
examples: To avoid demoralizing troops, flights carrying the containers to America took place at night.
Many who joined the revolutions of 2011 are dead, imprisoned or demoralized.
Personnel problems also plague the State Department despite Mr. Pompeo’s vow to revive its “swagger” after Mr. Tillerson’s often demoralizing time in office.
Zidane received an ovation from the crowd when his name was announced before the match, and there was an upbeat atmosphere again following demoralizing home losses.

definition: force into some kind of situation or course of action
details: To embroil is to drag someone into a mess. If you're embroiled, you're in deep. Being embroiled is far worse, far messier, and generally far more long-term, than simply being "involved" with something. Nothing good can come of being embroiled.
examples: The two countries are also embroiled in a long-running trade dispute.
Here we are, embroiled, as a nation, in what many in the art world regard as a pretty desperate political situation.
Now, Google leadership tends to face substantial collective action around any hot-button topic the company finds itself embroiled in.
The case also threatens to embroil an unidentified official who prosecutors described as speaking to Causey several times on Lindberg’s behalf.

definition: occurring in spells and often abruptly
details: An adjective that sounds a little like what it means, fitful means stopping and starting, on-again off-again, switching suddenly. I had a fitful night's sleep: I woke up several times throughout the night.
examples: His sense of smell returned, and whenever he woke from a fitful doze, he sniffed for Bristle and Runt to reassure himself that they were still alive.

The prisoner release is the first of five agenda items negotiators plan to tackle after several fitful weeks of meetings to establish ground rules for talks on resolving Nicaragua's political divisions.

The prisoner release is the first of five agenda items negotiators plan to tackle after several fitful weeks of meetings to establish ground rules for talks on resolving Nicaragua’s political divisions.
After a night of fitful sleep on the ground, Scruggs woke up with an eerie premonition he was going to be shot in the back.

definition: costing nothing
details: When there’s a concert you want to go to and your best friend gets tickets and takes you gratis, be grateful: that means you’re going for free.
examples: All the guest actors are giving their time gratis.
But the park left the main gates open and let cars stream in gratis, as there are no government employees to charge the typical $30-a-car entrance fee.
Plus, I’d heard a rumor that the airlines serve Champagne, gratis, to their New Year’s Eve guests.
Early missteps at Little Beast seem to be service-related, though all were promptly corrected with a gratis drink or appetizer — something I witnessed at other tables as well as my own.

definition: influence by slyness
details: To hoodwink someone means to trick or mislead them. Beware of fake ATMs that try to hoodwink you into giving over your bank card and your code, only to keep them both and steal all your money.
examples: The secret government organization, tasked with tracking extraterrestrials, gets hoodwinked by the evil Decepticons Shatter and Dropkick to find Bumblebee.
All this maneuvering, however, needs to understood strictly as theater, meant to hoodwink voters into thinking that Trump wants to save their health care.
To the extent it is mistaken for actual news, the people who are hoodwinked tend to lean conservative.
The irresistible power Jackson brought to his music is the same power he wielded to abuse children and hoodwink their families into letting him do so.

definition: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought
details: Someone impetuous acts too hastily or carelessly. Hotheaded, impulsive folks are impetuous.
examples: Now, you might be asking yourself: Didn’t we just get done with an extended news cycle related to Trump’s impetuous and legally dubious demands for some sort of border-related crackdown?
The entire event seemed intended, at least in part, to provoke an impetuous president who is quick to attack anyone who attacks him.
He is too grounded in family and faith to be too impetuous.
However, no one explains why he should risk his life for the impetuous, whiny heroine.

definition: of imposing height; especially standing out above others
details: Lofty is a good word for describing something that's high above the ground, or someone who acts like she's high above everyone else.
examples: Sexton’s book reads as a series of TED talks, addressed to people who are interested in thinking about college in lofty, abstract terms—a matter of civilization rather than the immediate needs of citizens.
He’s more accustomed to a private-sector process in which he barks orders from a lofty perch, at which point employees scramble to follow his instructions.
Over the years, those lofty ideals were corrupted, according to a history of the hospital prepared for the Garden Club of Virginia.
There would be lofty lectures on the Enlightenment and liberal democracy and integration.

definition: a pauper who lives by begging
details: People who live off begging can be called mendicants. However, you probably wouldn't call your kids mendicants, even though they beg you for stuff, because the word mendicant also implies extreme poverty.
examples: Subsidies are a naked transfer from taxpayers to corporate mendicants; they are also an indirect transfer to overseas consumers, who enjoy artificially depressed prices as a result of the handouts.
The Bibles were common among mendicant Franciscans of the time who took vows of poverty and renounced all worldly possessions.
He became a mendicant and began wandering India, and was “driven mad with mental agonies” over what he encountered: ritual, poverty, disease.
But what are the proper prerogatives of a mendicant legislature avidly seeking maximum leeway to repudiate debts?

definition: appearing as such but not necessarily so
details: When something is ostensible it appears to be the case but might not be. Research for a role is the ostensible reason for Nat's drinking. But I think it's because he just likes to drink.
examples: Becky, the ostensible "goddess" of Something She, never seems convincingly worth all the trouble she puts everyone in her path through.
Though the movie’s ostensible subject is the politics of race, Bissell seems to be more interested in questions of class.
But the ostensible political mastermind exists only when he’s treated like one.
One of the ostensible goals of this kind of maneuver is presenting a united partisan front—minimizing divisions on a matter within the Party to refocus attention elsewhere.

definition: characteristic of the nobility or aristocracy
details: That refined gentleman over there with the excellent manners, the elegant suit, and the beautiful home on Park Avenue? He’s a patrician, a member of the upper classes.
examples: His elevation to the top rank of pianists is due to his astonishing technical virtuosity, which marks his concerts with an aura of patrician athleticism that, in effect, sells his intellectual rigor.
If it disappeared, a patrician uncle insists, “the people who’d miss it most of all are the ones who are the most afraid of getting thrown into it.”
Waring, born in 1880, was a Charleston patrician whose ancestors were slaveholders and whose father was a Confederate soldier.
It called him “the epitome of B.D.E.” and praised his “patrician uprightness,” his “perfectly parted silver hair,” and his “pronounced jawline.”

definition: the reestablishment of cordial relations
details: Reconciliation is the act of getting two things to be compatible with one another. You might have a reconciliation with a former enemy, or your mom might call for a reconciliation between your spending habits and your diminishing bank account.
examples: It would also be an end-run around the filibuster that would create precedent for using reconciliation much more aggressively in the future.
In A Girl From Yamhill, though, there is no cheerful reconciliation and no ambiguity in the teacher’s meaning.
This limited sanctions relief would cost the U.S. very little and be a significant boost to Moon’s separate inter-Korean reconciliation initiative.
Salamé did little to hide his frustration at the fighting’s impact on his efforts to bring about political reconciliation.

definition: according with custom or propriety
details: You don't want to seem anything less than seemly, especially in the presence of the Queen. Only seemly behavior is allowed when she's around.
examples: The old librarian expressed this wish more often than was seemly, undaunted that the answer was always no.
It is more seemly to regard it as the last message to his fellow- creatures of a man who laboured with all his strength to propagate the noble truth - Love is of God.
For in those days every man who wore a black robe and consented to behave in seemly fashion in public, possessed the power of a tyrant.
But neither the one nor the other felt it seemly to show his emotions, so all Teplotaxl said was “Good-bye, Robert,” and all Robert said was “Bye.”

definition: a route all the way around a particular place or area
details: Use the noun tour to describe a route taken while sight-seeing or the act of experiencing a place, like a tour of Italy in which travelers tour museums and churches.
examples: A New York auction house announced Thursday that costumes, props and tour items from Disney Channel’s “Hannah Montana” will be auctioned off to raise money for charity.
I caught up with Cory, who now calls the Los Angeles area his home, via email as he was on tour for “Radicalized.”
The German village of Oberammergau is as commercial as it is cute — busy with tour groups and the venerable shops of the town’s famous woodcarvers.
More continental misery from the never knowingly cheerful Peter Hammill, who’s on tour in Germany and not enjoying it.

definition: without qualification
details: The adjective utter is often used as an intensifier to mean "total" — often with negative connotations (like "utter failure"). As a verb, the word has a totally unrelated meaning: to speak or to articulate a sound.
examples: The utter fluff of Comedy Central's "The Other Two" frankly provides a far more credible, and emotionally resonant, exploration of how the talent sausage gets made, and without dialogue that sounds like rejected song lyrics.
“Bleakness,” he says, “forms the constant theme of these images, a sense of emptiness and an utter lack of urbanity.”
He’d soon kick off his campaign with an 80-second video that uttered the words climate change or global warming a dozen times.
The phrase was uttered at the end of Buttigieg spending close to 1,000 words speaking on issues of race, diversity, and policing.

definition: the human face
details: Visage is a literary term for referring to someone's face or facial features. You may notice that some face creams use the word visage to try to sound fancier than they are.
examples: In the new film, Ellie uses the memory of Norma against Jud by conjuring the woman’s visage and similarly uses Rachel’s deeply repressed guilt over the childhood death of her own sister against her.
His visage is so consistent, so confident — and so unnerving.
But also, in a way, those empty visages parallel Welles’ need to disappear into his own roles with heavy makeup.
“By this will we be remembered,” he wrote in The New York Times, “a black gash of shame and sorrow, hacked into the national visage that is the Mall.”

definition: a mental representation of some haunting experience
details: If you have a vision of your grandfather just before he passes away, you have seen a wraith or a ghostly image. Wraith can also mean something thin, wispy, or ghost-like.
examples: Then he climbed the steps, silent as a wraith.

The tales boil down to the problem of balancing empathy with self-assertion—of both practicing kindness and expressing your own needs, and all while the people around you are behaving like wraiths or aliens.
Not a drifter, not a teen-ager, not a wraith from social services skulking into the woods to shoot up.
She writes that the recent swarm of “hauntings, haints and wraiths” might be read as a representation of traumatic memory, of “the past clamoring for redress.”

definition: the highest level or degree attainable
details: When something is at the very peak of perfection, reach for this noun from Greek: acme. A brilliant violinist might reach the acme of her career, but eventually she might become unstrung.
examples: To them, he is “Vincent” — the patron saint of psychic anguish, the acme of tortured genius.
Seventy years ago, Vespa was the acme of modern metropolitan living.
We tend to think of today as the acme of the sports company/player synergy, but the 1970s heralded the entry of the branded player in more ways than one.
But within the film’s logic, its 1999 is the Matrix, the delusion, the acme of all ideology.

definition: pledged to be married
details: Betrothed means "formally engaged." If you are betrothed, then, congratulations! As they say in the song, you’re going to the chapel — you’re going to get married.
examples: She was delighted to be betrothed to the king's son Prince Joffrey in season one, only to learn he was a vile monster.
She was delighted to be betrothed to the king’s son Prince Joffrey in season one, only to learn he was a vile monster.
By March I was Bill’s betrothed, sitting in the park across from the cathedral, listening to its tolling bells and nauseated without understanding why.
So is her betrothed, a guy with the unpromising name of Thorn.

definition: capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action
details: Use the adjective caustic to describe any chemical that is able to burn living tissue or other substances, or, figuratively, a statement that has a similarly burning effect. Caustic in this sense means harshly critical.
examples: On an Instagram account called Public Lands Hate You, the author adds caustic commentary to images of destruction or carelessness, such as a recent shot of a woman presenting a bouquet of recently un-earthed poppies.
Still, Boeing representatives faced caustic comments from some at the Wednesday session, said one of the people familiar with the discussions.
At the center of a program of caustic sounds two works from the late 1990s formed an oasis of radiant beauty.
Her native caustic, skeptical dryness and air of casual capability fit well here.

definition: attack the good name and reputation of someone
details: To denigrate is to say bad things — true or false — about a person or thing. Your reputation as a math whiz might be hurt if your jealous classmate manages to denigrate you, even though the accusations are unfounded.
examples: A US intelligence report in January 2017 said Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, directed a sophisticated influence campaign including cyber-attacks to denigrate the Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and support Donald Trump.

The episode poses an awkward dilemma for Biden’s Democratic rivals, who appeared loath to denigrate a popular party elder but were also keenly aware of the social climate in the wake of the #MeToo movement.
He denigrated the investigation, led by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, as an “illegal takedown that failed” and said those responsible for it should face scrutiny.
Consumers were expected to absorb the lesson that denigrating women wasn’t just smart, edgy, and hilarious—it was what free inquiry looked like.

definition: make corrections to
details: When you emend a piece of writing, you correct or revise it. If you are asked to emend a report, that just means you need to go through it and make revisions.
examples: In his 1897 novel, “An Antarctic Mystery,” he saw fit to emend Poe, rescuing Pym from the boiling sea only to kill him off on a lodestone mountain.
The Nicene Creed, formulated under Emperor Constantine in AD 325 and emended in AD 381, stated bluntly that Christ “was crucified under Pontius Pilate.”
Officials at the museum said in a release on Thursday that they are making the lists public "in the interests of transparency" and that the museum will "endeavor to emend the lists, step by step."
It’s rife with typos and misspellings and sprinkled with attempts at emending them.

definition: a rectangular piece of cloth of distinctive design
details: A flag is a piece of cloth that represents a country, group, or institution. If you're particularly proud of your Irish heritage, you might fly an Irish flag in your front yard.
examples: Taggart advocates removing the Confederate battle emblem from the Mississippi state flag, saying it’s divisive.
Gov. Tom Wolf on Thursday ordered the flags lowered through sunset Sunday.
Sometimes, that means private information such as bank details or full names, which employees are supposed to flag as critical data.
A few protesters waving Tibetan flags were also gathered outside of the zoo on Thursday.

definition: the force of attraction between all masses in the universe
details: In physics, gravity is the natural force that causes things to fall toward the earth. The noun gravity can also mean seriousness or solemnity.
examples: It may be caused by fluids shifting in the absence of gravity.
Clearly, the intelligence community hopes that the Drake case will send a message about the gravity of exposing government secrets.
So, information that falls into a black hole must ultimately escape the black hole, plausibly through some new and subtle delocalization related to the basic principles of quantum gravity.
General relativity, first described in 1915, explained gravity as a phenomenon created when matter warps the geometry of space and time.

definition: a moving crowd
details: Use the word horde to describe a large crowd: “A horde of people followed Newman as he left the airport in Helsinki.”
examples: And there seem to be more of them than ever, what with the subway’s decline and hordes of Uber cars and Amazon delivery trucks.
Now he was sitting among the hordes of fans, who exploded in to deafening cheers with every sunk basket and defensive rebound.

The measure represents Democrats’ effort to find the sweet spot between addressing a burgeoning humanitarian crisis and not lending credibility to Trump’s assertion that hordes of immigrants are invading the country.
When California exploded in a “super bloom” of flowers this spring, Instagram exploded with it, as hordes of selfie-taking tourists descended on the delicate florae.

definition: a force that makes something happen
details: An impetus is the force behind something, whether it's a boulder rolling down a hill or a person making a decision.
examples: The impetus for the essay, titled “The Church and the Scandal of Sexual Abuse”, was a summit of senior bishops that Francis held in February to discuss the crisis, he said.
The partial federal government shutdown in January and an expected drop in trading revenues provided additional impetus for analysts to cut first-quarter bank earnings estimates.
For Shaw, the impetus for this project was never an attempt to create a politically correct “Butterfly.”
So similar to Haniger, the Mariners aren’t really under any impetus to extend him beyond that first year of free agency.

definition: a segment of the trunk of a tree when stripped of branches
details: A log is the trunk of a tree minus the branches: logging is cutting down trees. A log is also a written record of something, and logging is keeping such a record.
examples: Manning went on to tell the court that in February 2010 she began talking through a secure online chat log to an individual with WikiLeaks going by the handle “Ox”.
“It took them two years to analyze the data,” added the former astronaut, who logged more than 570 hours in space.
They’re putting pen registers’ ”—logs of dialled phone numbers—“ ‘on everyone in the country!’
Jones was not listed under the inmate logs at the Green County jail Thursday morning.

definition: liable to sudden unpredictable change
details: Mercurial describes someone whose mood or behavior is changeable and unpredictable, or someone who is clever, lively, and quick. With a mercurial teacher, you never know where you stand.
examples: Nielsen is the latest person felled in the Trump administration's unprecedented churn of top staff and Cabinet officials, brought about by the president's mercurial management style, insistence on blind loyalty and rash policy announcements.
The opposition “opposes”, biding its time until the mercurial electoral system brings it back to power.
Would it shock anyone to learn that Roman begins to heal his own traumatic past through his work with the similarly mercurial Marquis?

definition: intended to attract notice and impress others
details: Reach for the adjective ostentatious when you want a flashy way to say — well, "flashy" or "showy."
examples: The poem remains a bravura performance, though not an ostentatious one; much like oysters, it is raw and briny and tender all at once—“and bowing not knowing to what.”
Its new inhabitants thought this sounded less ostentatious.
But Soviet elites’ wealth was always less ostentatious and flashy than that of American billionaires and celebrities, making things more equal in that way.
Yet one tester said the handle looked “ostentatious” and didn’t think it would fit with her other silverware.

definition: treat condescendingly
details: If you patronize a business, you shop there regularly. But if someone patronizes you, it's not so pleasant — they talk to you as if you were inferior or not very intelligent.
examples: Mike Carpenter, who served on the National Security Council in the Obama years, added: “When foreign powers patronize the president’s businesses it creates an enormous national security risk.”
The movie is only halfway skeptical of her patronizing attitude and very literal limousine liberalism.

definition: difficult to penetrate
details: It's rather difficult to penetrate the meaning of recondite. Fitting, because it's an adjective that basically means hard for the average mind to understand.
examples: I knew in advance from his recondite Instagram account that a friend I challenged, the filmmaker Amos Poe, would produce surprises.
“It is the book where he turns the corner from being an entertainer to doing more recondite things,” Smith says.
He travels the world to see recondite species.
“The Noh is unquestionably one of the great arts of the world,” the poet Ezra Pound wrote in 1916, “and it is quite possibly one of the most recondite.”

definition: be in an agitated emotional state
details: If a liquid seethes, it is boiling, but if it's a person who's seething, watch out! He or she is really angry!
examples: “We are still wired to only be able to process knowing about 150 people in our brains,” he seethed.
Lots of politicians seethe about the news media, but not many channel their frustrations through lawsuits.

definition: advertise in strongly positive terms
details: To tout means to praise, boast, or brag about. If you like to tout your skill as a skier, you tell people you can go down expert-level hills.
examples: The other document, which touted the success of Turbulence, was officially declassified in July, 2010, three months after Drake was indicted.

The paper discovered Theranos’ technology was not all it was cracked up to be, allegedly using routine blood-testing equipment for the vast majority of tests rather than the revolutionary technology Theranos touted.

Warren touted that she raised $1.4 million in the final week of the first quarter of fundraising, which ended on March 31.

definition: having the sticky properties of an adhesive
details: The adjective viscid is used to describe something that is sticky or a thick, slow-moving liquid. If you bake bread and you get flour all over your counters, clean it up carefully because adding water can turn the flour into a viscid paste, and then you'll really have a mess!
examples: But he also plays trombone, piano and electronics — and he’s just as interested in exploring slow, viscid harmony, or music that verges on silence.
This fight between the old and the new is at the viscid, romantic heart of Chazelle’s gooey, seductive film.
Pollinia 2, of coarse grains united by an elastic web, each attached at base by a stalk to a viscid gland.
An extremely adhesive viscid substance, usually made of the middle bark of the holly, by boiling, fermenting, and cleansing it.

definition: quarrel noisily, angrily, or disruptively
details: To wrangle is to take part in a long, angry, intense argument, especially over an issue with lots of details. You can also wrangle, or herd, a bunch of cows. Politicians and lawyers frequently wrangle, no cows necessary.
examples: The two sides wrangled even over routine procedural matters.

After yanking the man onto the ground, the lawman punched him several times in his back and shoulders as other officers wrangled the suspect onto his stomach and into handcuffs, according to law enforcement reports.
Others said Mr. Erdogan knew the risks to the economy if there were a wrangle over the election or a protracted dispute.
That, and his legal wrangles, would surely catch up with him eventually.

definition: agree or express agreement
details: To acquiesce is to agree to something or to give in. If your kid sister is refusing to hand over the television remote, you hope she acquiesces before your favorite show comes on.
examples: But more than anything, they accused Democratic leaders of acquiescing to their party’s most liberal voices.

definition: a partiality preventing objective consideration of an issue
details: Use the noun bias to mean a preference for one thing over another, especially an unfair one.
examples: And, we argue, announcing pronouns may enable gender bias and discrimination.
Women in science face unconscious bias, leading to discrimination in hiring and salary.

He recounted the importance of arriving in Oxford with few scientific biases, and leaving with the conviction that seeing the double helix model one chilly April morning would be a defining moment in his life.

definition: given to haughty disregard of others
details: Someone who is cavalier has a dismissive attitude and regards other people as inferior. If you think you know more than your teacher and never bother doing homework, your parents might complain that you are cavalier about your studies.
examples: “That decision not only contravenes Congress’s clear intent, but does so with cavalier indifference to the impacts it would unleash on the health care system.”
The Post went into depth, rehashing famous stories about Trump’s infamously cavalier relationship with the truth.
Superhero comics declare that the stated intent not to kill is important, even for people who are entirely cavalier about applying lethal force.
He displayed an "utterly dangerous and cavalier attitude", Teesside Crown Court heard.

definition: the outcome of a complex sequence of events
details: You know that part of every movie after the big action scene, where things get explained, and the characters tie up loose ends? That's called the denouement, or the showing of how the plot eventually turns out.
examples: The denouement of the early '90s recession was signed divorce papers.
Charles Grant, director of the Center for European Reform in London, spent the past few days watching this endless second-act drama — all buildup, no denouement — from Brussels.
But the denouement is one hell of a black eye for the press.
Has there ever been a romantic comedy with a more melancholy denouement?

definition: come out into view, as from concealment
details: To emerge means to come out into view or come forth. You might hope to emerge from an epic perming session looking like a beauty queen, but chances are it will just look like you got electrocuted.
examples: A year later, Assange emerged as a thorn in Ecuador's side again.
A year later, Assange emerged as a thorn in Ecuador’s side again.
In emerging markets, equities declined and were poised to snap their longest streak of gains in more than one year.
He was at the forefront of the 1975 Asilomar meeting to discuss the appropriate use of emerging abilities to alter DNA, was a key proponent of the Human Genome Project, and much more.

definition: thrash about
details: To flail means to wave around wildly. If you are stranded on a deserted island and you see a ship in the distance, it’s a good idea to flail your arms in the air to get the captain’s attention.
examples: When he flails his arms, she says “quiet hands”.
Watching him flail at the sliders thrown by Yankees lefty James Paxton, missing some of them by seemingly three feet, was painful and difficult to stomach.
But soon, it seemed like a sleight of hand, all of it -- or maybe just hand flailing.

definition: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
details: If you know someone who's outgoing, sociable, and fond of the company of others, you might want to call her gregarious.
examples: Noisy and gregarious, its flight is fast and direct and it walks and runs confidently.

definition: loud confused noise from many sources
details: Hubbub is a fun, rhyming word for an uproar, a brouhaha, or another crazy situation that has gone completely higgledy-piggledy.
examples: But in the 1970s, amid the hubbub of the demolition of an adjacent shipyard, the outdoor stones disappeared.

definition: unrighteousness by virtue of lacking respect for a god
details: Impiety is a disrespect for the sacred. For example, visitors are advised not to wear shorts or tank tops when touring certain churches and cathedrals in Europe, because doing so is viewed as impiety by those who worship there.
examples: At this shocking impiety, the tumult died away.
Sexual and moral boundaries will be transgressed; every shirt sleeve will be a crusty shirt sleeve, every piety an impiety, every angel a grievous angel.

definition: the property of having lived for a considerable time
details: Something with longevity has the ability to last for a long time. While tortoises are not known for their quickness, their longevity is amazing. Just ask the Hare.
examples: But there are a few reasons why this battery monster is less expensive than the G7, which just exhibits standard get-you-through-the-workday longevity.

Just contribute to the longevity and culture that sustained this city for years,’ ” Turner said.

definition: any admirable or beneficial attribute
details: Merit means "worthiness or excellence." If you receive a certificate of merit in school, you are being recognized for doing a good job. As a verb, merit means "deserve." Your certificate might merit a prominent place on your bulletin board!
examples: The news last month that only seven black students were offered seats at Stuyvesant High School, New York City’s most selective public high school, incited a national uproar about merit, race and class in education.

definition: noticeably or extremely unconventional or unusual
details: If something is outlandish it's bizarre or unfamiliar, far outside the boundaries of expected or normal behavior. Driving around the city in a golf cart and eating spaghetti with pineapple sauce are both examples of outlandish behavior.
examples: But black holes are a far more outlandish concept than an orbiting projectile.

definition: an insufficient quantity or number
details: The word paucity means not enough of something. If you've got a paucity of good cheer, for example, you'd better cheer up!
examples: And former FBI attorney Lisa Page admitted to Congress that the investigation was opened with a “paucity” of evidence.

definition: something or someone turned to for assistance or security
details: Recourse is a source of help. If you're failing trigonometry in spite of studying until your brain hurts, you may have no recourse but to hire a tutor.

definition: an outward appearance that is deliberately misleading
details: Semblance is all about illusion. Cramming all of your dirty clothes into the closet gives the semblance, or false appearance, that you've done your laundry — but the stench might give you away.
examples: Being distractible — allowing incessant beeps, flashes and trills to shatter any semblance of concentration — contributes to a strained lifestyle, she said.

definition: a system of body parts that serves some specialized purpose
details: A tract is a large, open piece of land — like that tract of farmland you bought when you decided your dream in life was to raise llamas. Tract is also a word for a short pamphlet or booklet, like that tract you recently read entitled "The Care and Feeding of Llamas."
examples: These analyses found that there was not enough evidence to support probiotics’ impact on preterm labor, Crohn’s disease, urinary tract infections, and more.

definition: having a relatively high resistance to flow
details: Viscous means sticky, gluey and syrupy. So if something is viscous, you usually don't want to stick your fingers in it — that goes for boogers and maple syrup alike.
examples: But despite his best efforts, the pipes spout tarry filth, the walls secrete viscous goo, and marbles seemingly appear spontaneously around closets and stairs.

definition: cause to happen or to occur as a consequence
details: To wreak is to cause something to happen, usually with a terrible consequence. You can make mischief, cause problems, or inflict pain, but to wreak damage suggests a deeper level of destruction.
examples: Instead, Le Pen wants to team up with other European far-right nationalists and wreak havoc inside the bloc.

definition: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
details: To acquit someone is to clear them of charges. Acquitting also has to do with how you carry or present yourself.
examples: A Cook County judge acquitted three other officers in January of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and official misconduct charges in the case.

definition: irritable as if suffering from indigestion
details: If an unpleasant meal has left you feeling grumpy and looking green, you're bilious in several senses of the word. This adjective can mean both "troubled by indigestion" and "irritable," and it can also be used to suggest a sickly green shade.
examples: In Peckham, a formerly gritty area of the city now filled with microbreweries and artisanal butchers, clients favor bold colors like Radicchio, a dark red, or Studio Green, a bilious black.

definition: relinquish possession or control over
details: To cede is to give up or surrender land, position, or authority. "She reluctantly ceded the coveted position as the baby of the family to her brother when he was born. She would not, however, cede her bedroom to him."
examples: The argument was that Gramm-Rudman-Hollings ceded spending authority to the executive branch.

definition: permitting little if any light to pass through
details: When woods are dense, the trees grow close together. When fog is dense, you can't see through it. And if someone calls you dense, they think nothing can get into your thick skull.
examples: Then, they ask questions about the features of the network: Is it a sparse web or a dense jungle of connections?

Using the mass of the sun, Michell calculated that if it were 500 times as dense, light itself would be unable to escape its surface.

definition: a medicine that induces nausea and vomiting
details: An emetic is a medicine or potion that makes you vomit, which you might be given if you've taken poison or some other harmful substance.
examples: “Because the emetic toxin is preformed in food and is not inactivated by heat treatment, it is important to prevent B. cereus growth and its cereulide production during storage.”

On Wednesday, British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was “emetic” - vomit-inducing - that Putin is rejoicing over hosting the World Cup soccer tournament this summer.

definition: a natural talent
details: Use the word flair to refer to someone’s knack or natural talent for something. Someone might have a flair for throwing fantastic parties, or a flair for solving complex math problems.
examples: Young settled in and proved to be both durable and dynamic with a flair for clutch, game-winning shots.
“But Ted Baker is a company worth more than half a billion pounds, it’s not solely reliant on the flair of just one man.”

Though known for depicting San Francisco’s counterculture of the 1960s and ’70s with surrealistic flair, you’ll find one of his greatest legacies on three bookcases in the basement of Vancouver’s Clark County Historical Museum.

definition: complain
details: The word gripe, as both noun and verb, refers to a minor complaint. Why gripe about the size of the portions when the food is so awful?
examples: A gripe for retailers is that selling on Amazon loses the direct customer relationship they get from their own website or store.

These are somewhat minor gripes — and honestly, they may not even register as issues to some — but they are important to consider when paring down your options.

definition: marked by meekness or modesty; not arrogant or prideful
details: Humble means "modest; without an excess of pride." A person who brags about being humble may have too much pride in being humble to actually be humble.
examples: “He was a passionate man, a humble man, he was a go-do-your-job kind of man.”

definition: incapable of being appeased or pacified
details: An implacable person just can’t be appeased. If you really offended your best friend and tried every kind of apology but she refused to speak to you again, you could describe her as implacable.
examples: Of Rum’s three women, it is implacable Fareeda — enforcer of norms, keeper of secrets — whose voice proves the most revelatory.

But rather than use the nearly three-hour interview to challenge Musk on anything of substance, Rogan let him use the podcast to burnish the myth of his own implacable brilliance.

definition: full of trivial conversation
details: A loquacious person talks a lot, often about stuff that only they think is interesting. You can also call them chatty or gabby, but either way, they're loquacious.
examples: “I can’t say with any confidence what will happen, and, in that respect, I think I’m frankly not in a minority,” said the loquacious keeper of order.

definition: striking change in appearance or character or circumstances
details: In Kafka's novel entitled Metamorphosis, a man wakes up to find he has turned into a cockroach. That kind of complete and startling change pretty much sums up the word.
examples: Her discomfort is caused by the cells of her body undergoing metamorphosis.
All recent work, all on the theme of metamorphosis.

definition: area relatively far from the center, as of a city or town
details: Some people like to live downtown. Others prefer the open spaces of the suburbs. But if you live in between the two, you are in the outskirts, the place where the city ends and the suburbs begin.
examples: Stalled for a fourth day in his drive to conquer Tripoli, General Hifter’s forces on Monday retreated on several fronts around the outskirts of the city.

definition: someone who educates young people
details: Pedagogue is another name for "teacher," but one who is strict, stiff or old-fashioned. The word comes from the Greek pedo for "child" and agogos for "leader." A pedagogue leads people by teaching.
examples: Neither zany entertainer nor earnest pedagogue, Rogers was instead a respectful mentor who promoted tolerance.
Stalin emerges as a murderous pedagogue, using violence to teach his people how to behave.

definition: returning to health after illness or debility
details: If it's on the mend, it's recovering. If you're getting better after being sick or injured, you can be described as recovering. When the unemployment numbers start looking up, you can refer to a recovering economy.
examples: Plains and Midwest, bringing fears of more flooding in areas still recovering from last month’s deluge.

definition: abounding in or given to pompous or aphoristic moralizing
details: If you speak in sententious phrases, your listeners are probably falling asleep, as your speech is pompous and pretentious, and full of moralistic babble.
examples: Meany’s sententious offerings were typically well-stocked with school and neighborhood history.

definition: easily managed
details: If your little brother quietly obeys your instructions and waits for you at the food court while you and your friends wander around the mall, he's probably a tractable child, meaning he's obedient, flexible, and responds well to directions.
examples: For a baby, there are structures underlying language that are tractable and learnable from the information available in the environment.

definition: make imperfect
details: As some sneaky five-year-olds know, crossing one’s fingers while making a promise is an effective way to vitiate, or destroy the validity of, an agreement.
examples: An egregious linguistic solecism vitiated the otherwise well-written and informative March 5 news article “Ben Carson to leave HUD at end of Trump’s term.”

definition: humorously sarcastic or mocking
details: A wry sense of humor is a sarcastic one. You were late for work, stepped into a mud puddle, and you forgot your lunch. If your co-worker asks how your morning is going, you can reply with a wry tone, "Perfectly perfect."
examples: Taylor’s 1986 memoir is the basis for the play, a wry, self-deprecating survey of the star’s life framed by her eternal struggle with weight gain, poor body image and fad dieting.

definition: marked by strong resentment or cynicism
details: Locked in a mean-spirited, bitter argument? That's an acrimonious situation that might result in fists flying unless you and your opponent can cool down.
examples: The tension and “animosity” between the justices was “palpable and unpleasant,” and it bled over into an acidic, acrimonious set of opinions.

definition: turn pale, as if in fear
details: To blanch is to turn pale, usually as the result of a physical or psychological shock. Nineteenth century literary heroines were frequently blanching — before they fainted, that is.
examples: I’ve always loved the combination of spinach and sesame — one of my favorite Japanese dishes is blanched spinach dressed with goma-ae, a toasted sesame sauce.
Once it is smooth, stir in the crisped bacon pieces, the blanched spinach and the cheese.
And specific proposals offered by progressives, whether free college or a wealth tax, cause some Democrats to blanch.
In testing, we used raw almonds per the original recipe; if you would rather not end up with bits of almond skin in your pesto, use whole blanched almonds or almond slivers.

definition: material consisting of seed coverings and pieces of stem
details: The proverbial phrase "separate the wheat from the chaff" may not be terribly meaningful to you — unless you happen to be a grain farmer. The chaff is the husk surrounding a seed, the part of the grain that is generally thrown away.
examples: How do you separate the wheat from the chaff?
“After we start planting, there’s no time for sugaring. You plant oats early and you get oats; you plant ’em late and you get nothing but chaff.”
He added, “It’s very difficult for people, no matter how well educated they are, to parse what’s the wheat and what’s the chaff on the internet.”

Sifting the wheat from the snake oil chaff, she considers acupuncture, chiropractic, energy medicine, several varieties of meditation and even faith healing, providing historical background and related scientific studies.

definition: force to leave an office
details: When you force someone in authority out of office — a politician, a king, or a cheerleading captain — you depose them.
examples: But as a party power broker, Shorten played a key role in deposing two prime ministers through internal government leadership ballots in the face of poor opinion polling during Labor's chaotic six years in office.

But as a party power broker, Shorten played a key role in deposing two prime ministers through internal government leadership ballots in the face of poor opinion polling during Labor’s chaotic six years in office.
For world powers including France, Italy and Britain, the general’s military campaign, the biggest in Libya since the 2011 uprising that deposed Gaddafi, represented a major setback.
Anglin, an Ohio native, said in an email to The Associated Press that he is unwilling to be deposed in the U.S. despite the judge’s decision.

definition: compensation received by virtue of holding an office
details: Not many workers think of their paychecks as emoluments, but they certainly could. Emolument is another word for the money you receive for working.
examples: The emoluments clause of the United States Constitution forbids presidents and other federal officials from accepting gifts from foreign governments without Congress’ permission.
There’s business fraud and violations of the Constitution's emoluments clause.
The emoluments clause forbids the president from accepting anything of value from foreign or state governments.
The so-called foreign emoluments clause was intended to curb presidents and other government officials from accepting gifts and benefits from foreign governments unless Congress consents.

definition: strip the skin off
details: Nasty word, flay. It means to peel or beat the skin of a person or animal, and not necessarily a dead one, either. Nowadays it more commonly means to criticize harshly someone or something, usually in public, leaving them raw and wounded.
examples: This double drama, centered on two women staying in a small-town hotel, is a quietly flaying story of childhood unhappiness and misunderstandings, of broken bonds and enduring fears.
But he was flayed again for the team’s shortcomings in the postseason.
Fathers flayed their arms, coaxing their toddlers to look into the camera.
It is neatly flayed to reveal yarn organs.

definition: shockingly repellent; inspiring horror
details: Grisly means disgusting and bloody, absolutely repulsive and horrible. There’s a wonderfully creepy movie about a man who suffers a grisly death at the hands of the grizzly bears he was studying.
examples: Human remains were removed from an Arkansas high school campus Tuesday after a student made the grisly discovery in the woods and contacted police.
A suspected rhino poacher met a grisly demise at Kruger National Park in South Africa last week.

A global outcry was sparked by Khashoggi’s grisly killing inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul in October by Saudi agents, in an operation directed by former top aides to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
“The Iliad glorifies courage and fighting prowess while simultaneously showing the grisly suffering inflicted on soldiers and civilians in war,” writes Hinds in an afterword.

definition: cause to feel shame
details: Humiliate means to make someone feel ashamed or stupid, often publicly. It would humiliate all but the most self-assured person to realize that everyone else in the room has noticed their fly is down.
examples: But when he tried to attack Kerry’s credibility during the testimony, he chose a bizarre and self-defeating line of attack — and only ended up humiliating himself.
It was just a humiliating and confusing place to be.
The article said pupils at the academy were hit, kicked, scratched until they bled, pulled by their hair and subjected to a stream of humiliating comments about their bodies.
The Daily Mail blames "inept" MPs for the "humiliating" prospect of "another year in limbo".

definition: suggested though not directly expressed
details: Use the adjective implicit when you mean that something is understood but not clearly stated. You might think you and your boyfriend might have an implicit understanding that you are going to get married, but it's probably better to talk it through.
examples: “At the heart of it, it really is about implicit bias in the medical health profession,” Harris said.
The only way to achieve this balance is to let the implicit learning system — responsible for quick, efficient and automatic responses — drive the car.
Judge Bronson James didn’t grant Williams a new trial, writing that his defense hadn’t presented any evidence that implicit racial bias motivated this particular jury.
Corporations dream of achieving that level of urgency in consumers, whether it’s explicit or implicit in their messaging.

definition: an awkward stupid person
details: A lout is a clumsy, awkward oaf. If you want to insult the person who just stepped on your toes and belched, say, "Watch where you're going, you lout!"
examples: The insidiousness of masculine entitlement is such that Fujino, an unpredictable lout, still plays the victim while she shoulders the bulk of domestic responsibilities, acting as both mother and father.

Mrs. Stevens often said that Ruth’s popular image as a vulgar, woman-chasing lout who packed away immense quantities of food and liquor, was nothing like the man she knew — except for the food, that is.
Where does that leave the 19-year-old lout who eventually learns to treat women with more respect?
Why, this lazy lout is perfectly vulnerable to a Muslim takeover!

definition: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
details: People who are meticulous can be pretty annoying, what with their extreme attention to detail. But if that person is, say, your surgeon or your accountant, you'll want them to be meticulous.
examples: The Vatican restorers were meticulous, even touching up centuries of graffiti on the frescoed walls.
Premium woolen fabrics are designed, cut, sewn and packaged by hand—a meticulous process that shows in each finished product.
They require meticulous care in the vineyard and winery.
Instead, they seek stability through meticulous hygiene and winemaking, scrupulous attention to detail and keeping the pH of the wine low enough to discourage unwanted microbiological life.

definition: having or showing arrogant superiority to
details: Overbearing means domineering. You might find it difficult to play the piano as your overbearing instructor criticizes every key you touch.
examples: The race attracts sponsors, although this year’s event seemed happily free from an overbearing commercial presence.
Strength, according to this paradox, is now viewed by some as overbearing, overly aggressive, abusive, egotistical, “micro-aggressive” and even misogynistic, hence the label "toxic masculinity."
Critics describe him as calculating and at times overbearing.
Adolescence is hard enough, but how are you supposed to handle trauma in the family when your parents are overwhelmed, absent, overbearing or just plain oblivious?

definition: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning
details: There's nothing wrong with focusing on the details, but someone who is pedantic makes a big display of knowing obscure facts and details.
examples: Gore was often onstage, pedantic as ever, but he was also speaking a language that was familiar to her.
And perhaps it’s pedantic to gripe about visitors wearing sunglasses at museums.
Our burgeoning Netflix-and-chill habit, however, somehow turned a pretty pedantic documentary about health and diet into a talker.
I get pedantic about the placement of the vocative comma in “God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen.”

definition: restore to good health or strength
details: To recuperate is to get something back that you have lost — could be good health, or money lost in a bad investment. When you recuperate, you heal and recover.
examples: “He falls, he recuperates, but then he goes on to the next battle.”
While she recuperated, the deadly disease returned two years later.
