definition: endowed with feeling and unstructured consciousness
details: Someone sentient is able to feel things, or sense them. Sentient usually occurs in phrases like "sentient beings" and "sentient creatures," making it clear that things that don’t have life don’t have feelings. Explain that to a pet rock.
examples: It's almost as if they were testing to see if Junior was even sentient.
These creatures don’t seem to be sentient and appear to exist only to kill and eat humans.
Even the relatively upbeat “Hang the DJ” imagines a future where dating apps create and torture sentient AIs to test them for compatibility.
It’s about a sentient mech coping with the loss of a beloved pilot, and running into a gang of rogue mechs in the wastelands of Canada.

definition: speak unfavorably about
details: To traduce is to badmouth someone or something. If you don't want people talking trash about you, then don't traduce them either — even if they started it.
examples: But do we sometimes traduce the truth for the sake of a bit of tartness and tang?
Others took further issue with the adaptation and its apparent traducing of Jane’s role in furthering Stephen’s life and work.
From this, the department began micromanaging institutions’ disciplinary practices in ways that traduce constitutional guarantees.
Think of Lucrezia Borgia, traduced by slander and gossip, and of Isabella d’Este, greedy for art.

definition: marked by harshly abusive criticism
details: Use the adjective vituperative to describe criticism that's so sharp it hurts. A vituperative review of a movie would make the director bitter for months.
examples: Broadway theatergoers who caught her Tony-winning performance last year in Edward Albee’s “Three Tall Women” will certainly recognize the vituperative dazzle.
In today’s vituperative climate, that’s a story no one wants to tell or hear.
The "vituperative" exchange between Mr Musk and Mr Unsworth took place during frantic attempts to rescue the 12 boys and their coach from deep within the partially flooded caves in July 2018.
The vituperative, emotional response to this study illustrates the doubt and anxiety that any conversation about human diets incites in the public realm.

definition: a rough and bitter manner
details: Acrimony is bitterness, or ill will. Acrimony is a spiteful word. It sounds bitter, like acid.
examples: The acrimony stems from a fiercely fought campaign and a sense among Sanders loyalists that party leaders privately favored Clinton.
“I refuse to buy into the idea that you need acrimony and tension to create great work,” he said.
The acrimony continues more than a year later.
The presidents and chancellors will be present; the acrimony will be absent.

definition: lacking stimulating characteristics; uninteresting
details: When you have a nasty cold and you’re very congested, food can taste unappealingly bland. That means dull, flavorless, or just plain “blah.”
examples: The bland tone of Barr's presentation will do a lot of the work, serving to conceal how the attorney general is dodging accountability and covering for the president with this argument.
I've talked to people who prefer to wear these bland, nondescript, work clothes rather than what they would wear when they're at home because it creates a separation.

The room is ringed with 14 identical shutters salvaged from the ticket booth at San Francisco’s Winterland arena and painted a bland blue-green.

definition: strong feelings of embarrassment
details: Chagrin is a noun that represents an emotion or feeling and it's an uncomfortable one. If you feel chagrin, it means that you are embarrassed or distressed as a result of a failure.
examples: Much to Munch’s chagrin, Vigeland was given a grand studio and park by the city of Oslo.
Once recovered, I realise to my chagrin that the ambivalence is still there.

definition: corrupt morally or by intemperance or sensuality
details: Use the verb deprave as a more dramatic synonym for corrupt: Some parents in the 1980s feared that heavy metal music would deprave their innocent children.
examples: The Democrat said the alleged arson was perpetrated by a "depraved individual", adding: "Hate is not a Louisiana value."
To approve the use of pentobarbital in Mr. Bucklew’s execution would be depraved indifference to a potentially horrifying death.

“These aren’t bots. These are real people. I’m like- for real you think we faked this? You think first responders did? What a depraved mind. Depraved.”

definition: understanding and entering into another's feelings
details: Use empathy if you're looking for a noun meaning "the ability to identify with another's feelings."
examples: What are the limits of empathy across the color line in America?

“Through that conversation, my understanding and empathy for them grew.”

definition: young bird that has just become capable of flying
details: A fledgling is a fuzzy baby bird just learning to fly, or someone (like a baby bird) who's brand new at doing something. Awww.
examples: When the fledgling European Coal and Steel Community launched in 1951, Britain was nowhere to be seen.
In the fall, the fledglings would be relocated for the winter and then released in suitable places in the spring.
There is a fledgling tech sector, helped along by the planned move of the United States Army’s Cyber Command headquarters from Virginia to nearby Fort Gordon.

definition: a small growth of trees without underbrush
details: A grove can be an orchard or a clump of trees that doesn't have much undergrowth and occupies a contained area, like an orange grove or a small shady grove of oak trees where you can have a picnic.
examples: I spotted Maddie and Lewis then, walking away quickly toward a grove of trees on the far right, under which was parked Lewis’s Range Rover.

definition: a small natural hill
details: You don't swing in a hummock, you climb one. A hummock is a hill, a mound, or a ridge.
examples: Finally, then, without a sound, looking like a colored shadow, the fox slipped from the hummock and was gone.
For those with no immediate job up the valley, beds were tundra hummocks a few hundred yards from the beach.
But a little of it goes a long way on an empty … rhymes with hummock.

definition: burst inward
details: When something implodes, it explodes inward — instead of outward. With extremely large buildings, it helps to implode them rather than explode them, because by falling inward they take up less space.
examples: The Hanoi talks imploded after North Korea demanded that all U.N.

definition: transparently clear; easily understandable
details: Something that's lucid is clear and understandable. Lucid writing is important in journalism, so that readers easily get the point of the article they're reading.
examples: Consultant neurologist Guy Leschziner specializes in sleep disorders: lucid dreaming, narcolepsy, insomnia, sleep paralysis and other conditions sparked by neurological, environmental, genetic and psychological factors.

definition: the courage to carry on
details: Mettle is the courage to carry on. If someone wants to "test your mettle," they want to see if you have the heart to follow through when the going gets tough.
examples: Jackson’s Lear, made of more ferocious mettle, wails to the bitter end.

definition: unrestrained, especially with regard to feelings
details: Overweening is a negative term meaning arrogant or excessive. People can be described as having overweening pride or overweening ambition. It's too much and not good.
examples: This finding is not about the potential “back doors,” nor about China’s overweening party-state, but is just as worrisome.

definition: transparently clear; easily understandable
details: A sentence that teaches a new vocabulary word should always be pellucid, that is, its style and meaning should be easily understandable so that you can derive the definition from the sentence.
examples: It contains prose and verse; polemic and introspection; remixed pop lyrics and pellucid memoir; straightforward narration and constellated word games.
Gass was one of the great prose stylists, and the writing here is typically smooth and pellucid, conjuring its effects by stealth and unflagging control.

It is little surprise, then, that the pellucid perfume trend is now back, but with a youthful twist.

definition: serving to bring to mind
details: When something is redolent of something, it makes you think of that thing by making a pretty strong impression on you. He had a shifty eye redolent of years of lying and petty crime.
examples: It is against this backdrop that Democrats are looking to a us-v-them style of politics redolent of the US agrarian revolts of the 1890s – the movement that spawned the word “populism” in the first place.

definition: a person employed to keep watch for some anticipated event
details: A sentinel is a guard, a lookout, a person keeping watch. It's often a soldier, but not always. If you're watching a pot, waiting for it to boil, you're standing sentinel over it — and incidentally, it won't boil until you leave.
examples: "The team tracked one of the sentinel males with the transmitter and found this massive female nearby," the park said on Facebook.

Now, research reveals these oddball cells serve as sentinels along the body's invasion routes, relying on their sensory capabilities to detect pathogens and allergens trying to infiltrate the body.
Tuft cells serve as sentinels along the body's invasion routes, relying on their sensory capabilities to detect pathogens and allergens that are inhaled or trying to infiltrate in other ways.

definition: the violation of a law or a duty or moral principle
details: A transgression is something that is against a command or law. Whether you are cheating on a test, or cheating on a spouse, you are committing transgressions that are not easily forgiven.
examples: “This transgression toward her and the public I will carry for the rest of my life,” she said of her daughter.
He expressed surprise and disappointment that the U.S. government continued to pursue him for decades-old transgressions, she said.

definition: conspicuously and offensively loud
details: Vociferous describes loudmouths, such as the vociferous mob at the soccer game.
examples: Russia and Belarus are allies with close political, economic and military ties, but they regularly engage in vociferous trade arguments.

definition: give an incentive for doing something
details: To actuate is to put into motion. The "act" in actuate can remind you of this word's meaning — to put into action. A lever might actuate a pump, or malice might actuate a crime.
examples: “When done effectively,” the report stated, “malware insertions will not be detected until actuated,” and, if they are finally found, they may be misdiagnosed as “a design flaw.”
Bao’s artificial nerves already do something similar, adding up mechanical signals and converting them into an actuating one.
"You need a cylinder of air in your back pocket and as you walk you get little 'phutts' of air as they actuate," said Rossiter.
The bill is mostly a list of grievances against ICE, and does little of the hard work of actuating revamping the agency.

definition: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
details: Something blatant is very obvious and offensive. Don't get caught in a blatant lie, because you won't be able to weasel your way out of it.
examples: The US Campaign for Palestinian Rights released a statement calling the decision “shameful” and “a blatant attempt to whitewash reality”.
And it would be a blatant way for the American people to get ripped off by their own legislature.
Trump, asked about what human rights groups call a blatant power grab in Egypt, said he was unaware of it.

If, as Democrats expect, Barr releases another "Mueller report" that is not actually the Mueller report, there's every sign that they plan to raise hell and work to break through the blatant cover-up.

definition: a natural or artificial enclosed space
details: A chamber is an enclosed space, often where a specific event usually takes place — such as a sleeping chamber or a torture chamber.
examples: But it died in the Senate after county lawmakers in that chamber said the bill would send the wrong message to residents.

definition: a destructive action
details: The horrors of war include depredation — the plundering and ransacking of the defeated and their homes, the terrible, unrestrained preying on the conquered. The word depredation entails all of the pain humans inflict upon each other.
examples: A “depredation” exclusion permits killing them in private areas from September through May, but they must be buried, composted, burned or put in a landfill that accepts them.

By reasserting its institutional prerogatives — by setting limits to the depredations and recklessness it will accept — the Republican Party would be acting to deter hijackers in the future.
This may manifest itself as crop and property damage, livestock depredation, human injury and death—and it poses a significant challenge to conservation.

definition: derived from experiment and observation rather than theory
details: If knowledge is empirical, it's based on observation rather than theory. To do an empirical study of donut shops, you'll need to visit every one you can find.
examples: Olsen published the orrery’s preliminary results—some 24 million years’ worth of empirical data—in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in January.

definition: elaborately or excessively ornamented
details: Something that's elaborate and full of extra flourishes is florid, whether it's your relatives' ornate decorating style or the way they talk, using a lot of unnecessarily long, complicated words.
examples: The orchestra does the heavy lifting in advancing the drama, including during many stretches of spoken dialogue, accompanied by a few solo instruments or a florid piano, or, at times, skittish symphonic bursts.

At certain points her diaries, teenage and florid, are made vivid through animated sequences.
One might expect a poet’s prose to be florid, or at least highly metaphorical.

definition: show submission or fear
details: To grovel is to beg like a hungry dog. You don't have to be a canine though; you might grovel for a better grade (please don't).
examples: It also kicked off a feud between Trump and Fox, in which Trump briefly boycotted the channel, hurting its ratings and forcing Ailes to grovel.

Praise the movie, but don’t grovel for awards — at least, not that openly.”

definition: move with or as if with a rushing sound
details: If you forcefully throw or fling something, you hurtle it. In a food fight, you may hurtle chocolate pudding across the room, but be prepared for someone to launch peas at you in retaliation. Duck!
examples: Those who are less familiar with the Hellboy canon might be overwhelmed, as this all hurtles at a relentless, unforgiving pace.
At a time when the Earth itself seems to be hurtling toward doom, the presence of genuine wonder and new life in the film carries a sliver of optimism.
More than half a billion years ago, our planet was a giant snowball hurtling through space.
“Being stuck in a metal bullet hurtling alongside other metal bullets at eighty miles per hour is not my idea of fun.”

definition: not marked by artful prudence
details: If you've ever put your foot in your mouth, you've probably said something impolitic. If you have made an impolitic statement, it was a politically unwise one.
examples: The first episode of the final season contains impolitic jokes about two fictional mass shootings.
Donald J. Trump’s highly personal management style as a businessman — impetuous, impolitic, sometimes immature — worked.

definition: a celebrity who is an inspiration to others
details: In scientific writing, Stephen J. Hawking is a luminary. People look up to this well-known scientist and author for his knowledge and insight.
examples: The book is a roll call of luminaries, including Galileo Galilei, Johannes Kepler, René Descartes and Pierre de Fermat.

definition: a miniature model of something
details: When you think of microcosm, picture your home town inside a snow globe. The teeny tiny city is a microcosm of the one you live in. It is that place in miniature.
examples: A microcosm of that is the tee shot on the par-3 sixth, particularly when the pin is located on the back right shelf.

definition: a strong liking
details: A penchant is a strong preference or tendency. If you have a penchant for pizza, you either eat it daily or wish you did.
examples: Ko’s ascent to the top of the Rolex Ranking coincides with her recent penchant for being at or near the top of the leaderboard.
Wolf Blitzer highlighted the senator’s penchant for “off-the-cuff comments”; Politico called him “a reliable fount of gaffes, awkward statements, and hyperbole.”
Li also studied the president’s quirks and habits — his penchant for fast food and television-watching habits — to develop Trump’s character.
The current president’s penchant for secrecy surrounding his finances is well documented.

definition: worthy of respect or honor
details: Redoubtable means honorable, maybe even intimidatingly so. If your grandmother worked tirelessly to raise four kids on her own and start her own taxi cab business and to this day, keeps all of her cabbies in line, she is without a doubt redoubtable.
examples: True, the investigation was, by many measures, a redoubtable success.
B. B. King’s autobiography, “Blues All Around Me,” a co-production with the redoubtable David Ritz, is a moving story and overlaps with Guy’s.
Her characters are redoubtable, flawed, honest, passionate, determined to hang on to the reins of life even as it gallops away from them.
When your book begins, the long-term future of even a newspaper as redoubtable as the New York Times looks, thanks to the internet, to be in doubt.

definition: the absence of mental stress or anxiety
details: The goal of meditation is to reach a state of serenity, when your mind is still and perfectly calm. Use serenity to mean the quality or state of being calm and peaceful.
examples: But—save your Amen Corner and 15th/16th homilies for someone else—it's the best place to find peace and serenity at Augusta National during Masters week.
Bennett described the serenity of those moments Sunday, recalling how picturesque the skies were that afternoon.
Hurricane Katrina was the original motivation for the principal piece in “Vortex,” the Boston artist’s exhibition at Spagnuolo Gallery, so the serenity is ironic.
The building, which is known by locals as 50UNP, also promises its residents “an extraordinary level of privacy, security and serenity”.

definition: lasting a very short time
details: Use the adjective transient to describe something that always changes or moves around. If your older brother is constantly moving from city to city, you can say he's transient.
examples: The state levies the transient accommodations and general excise taxes that the short-term rental operators must pay.
The state levies the transient accommodations and general excise taxes the short-term rental operators must pay.
Beaches and barrier islands are by nature transient.
The southern residents behave very differently from the transients, she said.

definition: liable to lead to sudden change or violence
details: Watch out when a situation becomes volatile — it is likely to change for the worse suddenly. If you and your best friend have a volatile relationship, you frequently fight and make up.
examples: California’s state revenues are notoriously volatile because they are heavily dependent on high-income earners through the nation’s highest marginal personal income tax rate of 13.3 percent.
The human body emits hundreds of volatile compounds.
Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core wholesale prices rose 0.3% in March and 2.4% compared with a year ago.
The Arkema plant became waterlogged and lost power needed to keep the volatile chemicals cooled after Hurricane Harvey dumped more than 50 inches of rain on the area in September 2017.

definition: extremely sharp or intense
details: Use the adjective acute for when you want to describe something as sharp or extremely serious.
examples: He said migration pressures would become more acute as temperatures continued to rise because more parts of the world would become uninhabitable.
It was a harrowing brush with a baffling problem: the high risk of dying as an expectant mother in America, a danger that is especially acute for black women like King.
However, the Confederation of British Industry is warning that a fresh start is needed to avoid more acute uncertainty in the run up to the new Oct.
So broadly targeting the prescription side only harms cancer patients, as well as other people with chronic and acute pain.

definition: affected by something that prevents growth or prosperity
details: Use the adjective blighted to describe something that has a condition that makes it weak or unable to grow, like a blighted lawn with more brown patches than green.
examples: The vibrant redcoat of a British bugler returning to blighted Manchester from the Battle of Waterloo is a rare blaze of color throughout much of Mike Leigh’s “Peterloo.”
Those first months were intense and electric, but blighted by loss.
The borough is in the process of clearing 21 blighted properties, which includes demolishing dilapidated structures.
But when O’Rourke was young, the city found itself in decline, with many downtown buildings vacant or blighted and an economy focused on low-wage labor.

definition: characterized by great caution
details: Being chary (pronounced CHAIR-ee) is being wary or cautious. If you lost two teeth in last year’s rugby season, you should be chary of signing up again this year.
examples: Experts with long experience in treating depression were encouraged by the news, but also chary.
But the administration, chary of appearing to politicize intelligence, refused to do so unless both congressional Republican leaders consented.
The chary locals are less forthcoming about the lingering horror of the mass shooting in which a young priest took the lives of five members of his elderly congregation.
But his personal experience made him chary, too.

definition: in deplorable condition
details: If something has been abandoned, you can call it derelict. Even if a person has abandoned his responsibilities, you can say that he is derelict in his duties. But don't call a lost child derelict — unless, of course, he has neglected his chores.
examples: Roberts, currently renovating the derelict fort that will become the the National Poo Museum’s permanent home this summer, takes an interesting view when asked if this is all a flash in the pan.
Three years ago, Stella Osunbor transformed a derelict English pub called The Bull into an African grocery, stocked by weekly flights from Lagos.
Despite its popularity, they couldn't extend the exhibition because work is now beginning to convert the derelict factory into flats.
Mayor George Flaggs Jr. Monday said the city will begin cracking down on vacant and derelict commercial buildings.

definition: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating
details: When you emulate someone, you imitate them, especially with the idea of matching their success.
examples: I try to emulate the tone of her voice.
He “considered these gruesome actions brave and he wanted to emulate them,” the government said.
Music was a constant in the family home, and she clearly remembers trying to emulate her father's guitar skills.
I studied them carefully and then failed in my attempts to emulate his writing style.

definition: a fleet of small craft
details: If you see a boy launch a flotilla of handmade sailboats on the far side of a pond, chances are his fleet of ships won't make it to your side of the pond.
examples: Shells, gas clouds, and flotillas of tanks—shattering, corroding, death.
Last year, a flotilla of 40 fishing boats set sail from northern Sri Lanka with a mission to seize back their island from navy occupation.
Sea Shepherd published a video Friday showing a flotilla of fast, small fishing boats swarming around its larger vessel, the Farley Mowat.

Just as Noble Energy was discovering the massive gas fields in Israeli and Cypriot waters, Cyprus in 2010 suddenly banned Turkish flotillas seeking to break the Israeli naval blockade of Gaza from using its shores.

definition: petty or reluctant in giving or spending
details: If you do something in a grudging manner (or grudgingly), you do it with reluctance. Doing homework, paying taxes, and saying sorry are all commonly done in a grudging manner.
examples: And found … no joy, very little laughter and only a grudging amount of hope.
With grudging permission from the developer, PMC Property Group, construction was halted whenever a backhoe turned up another body.
Approval was grudging; the critic Helen Vendler called him “a lesser Eliot” writing “elusive pallors”.
Gibney approaches his subjects with the air of an appalled moralist and, increasingly, a grudging connoisseur.

definition: the practice of cultivating the land or raising stock
details: Husbandry has nothing to do with being a husband, and a lot to do with being a farmer. If you cultivate the land or breed animals, you are practicing husbandry.
examples: The drop covered key farms in Shandong province, northern China’s biggest producer of hogs, according to a report published earlier this week on the website of the provincial husbandry and veterinary bureau.
“She was the perfect panda,” said Carmi Penny, the husbandry director at the zoo.

Pig facial recognition would be invaluable to precision livestock farming, an animal husbandry practice most common in European countries and China that uses tracking technologies to maximize efficiency.
“Their livestock sectors often suffer from poor husbandry which leads to more prevalence of disease and a greater reliance on the use of antibiotics,” he said.

definition: making persistent or urgent requests
details: Importunate means annoyingly persistent or relentless, like a cranky child's importunate demands for candy in line at the grocery store checkout.
examples: Most important, Mr. Green is his old self: arriving anywhere he wants around the beat, gliding or leaping, importunate and reassuring.
He publicly humiliated Theresa May and did his importunate best to force regime change in Westminster, before halfheartedly apologising.

For Thesiger and Lawrence, as for the Desert Fathers who founded Christian monasticism in third-century Egypt, the desert promised sanctuary not just from society but from the importunate, unclean body.
In between, he fielded several calls from Lugovoi, who was becoming increasingly importunate.

definition: softly bright or radiant
details: Luminous means full of or giving off light. During the winter holidays, with all their emphasis on light, you can see luminous displays of candles everywhere.
examples: The woman in the tiny white dress is a luminous beacon of beauty radiating from the stage to the audience.
This luminous tracing pad features three brightness settings to help you succeed at any type of project.
There was also the striking vision of Vafadari singing under a luminous sky as the malodorous smells of agricultural contaminants lingered in the air.
In the towering Music Room, marble floors and red curtains seem to lead toward a luminous ceiling by Venetian painter Tiepolo.

definition: a person's appearance, manner, or demeanor
details: Your mien is how you present yourself, the impression you make. It's best to keep a low profile but a dignified mien.
examples: After the wild success of “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” Child cultivated an apolitical mien.
And how many conservatives, with furrowed brows and studious miens, pretended to believe there was some reason to doubt that he was born in Hawaii?
There are shades of "Winter Light's" Gunnar Björnstrand in Ernst Toller: the grim resignation, the frosty mien, the difficulty mustering real faith or compassion.
In many ways last year was ghastly, With so much going downhill fastly, But let’s assume a hopeful mien Pertaining to two-oh-nineteen: May that famous arc of justice Bend a little faster.

definition: hanging loosely or bending downward
details: Walking a path with pendulous trees, the kind with hanging branches, is easier if you're five rather than seven feet tall.
examples: I colored in his hair, drew on ears and lips, but the nose got special attention—it was giant, pendulous, overpowering.
She pointed to a gnarled, ancient branch pendulous with fruit.
Big or small, pert or pendulous, one or two, a celebration of breasts is taking place across fashion and decor.
Draped in elaborate spangles, her body is uncorsetted, pendulous and haggard.

definition: a communal dining-hall, usually in a monastery
details: A fancy word for a dining hall, or a place for communal meals, is a refectory. It is usually used to describe a dining hall in a religious institution, like where monks eat together.
examples: There’s chili cooking on the refectory tables onstage, for the audience’s consumption at intermission.
The princess sees her responsibility as feeding hundreds of hungry people in her refectory every day and being supportive of increasingly isolated priests.
But that meant long services in the oratory rather than well-filled tables in the refectory.
One report on church-run residential schools said physical abuse took place in “classrooms, offices, cloakrooms, dormitories, showers, infirmaries, refectories, the bedrooms of staff members.”

definition: an instrument for measuring angular distance
details: A sextant is a tool for measuring the angles between heavenly bodies — the kind found in outer space. Used as a navigational tool out at sea, it helps determine a ship's longitude and latitude.
examples: The building itself is a stony colonial relic; inside its centuries-old confines, artifacts on display range from traditional costumes to sailors’ sextants.
Only radio communication is allowed; sextants are used for navigation.
The race involves solo sailors navigating with a sextant and paper maps, and communicating only occasionally with the outside world via short-wave radio.
Inside was a brass sextant, possibly a hundred years old.

definition: allowing light to pass through diffusely
details: A translucent material lets light pass through, but objects on the other side can't be seen clearly. Think Shrinky Dinks or stained glass.
examples: Stir in the onions; cook for about 8 minutes, until mostly translucent.
He was so small, so wrinkled and translucent, it was difficult to imagine he would ever resemble those other babies on the maternity ward.
In many places the calcite is fashioning stalagmites on the ground, glossy nubs that appear translucent white in the center.
And then the soft, translucent layers are allowed to move.

definition: marked by a ready flow of speech
details: Voluble describes someone who talks a lot, like your aunt who can’t stop telling you to cut your hair or a political candidate who makes twenty speeches on the day before the election.
examples: But she was as voluble as ever and filled with plans.
She was open and voluble that day, ruminative.
People who drink in moderation tend to be voluble, relaxed, literally sanguine and engaged.
When they met, Tennessee Williams was already Tennessee Williams, flush from the success of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” voluble and lit as if by klieg lights.

definition: a condensed but memorable saying embodying an important fact
details: An adage is a saying. Moms and dads love adages such as "early to bed, early to rise" and "an apple a day keeps the doctor away."
examples: “So you iterate off a design that’s 50 years old. The old adage is: If it’s not broke, don’t fix it.”

One of the oldest adages about college basketball is that guard play is the key to tournament success.

definition: frighten someone by pretending to be stronger than one is
details: Bluff can mean a high cliff, or it can describe a person who is abrupt in manner. The most common usage of bluff is as a verb meaning to pretend. If you bluff at cards, you are pretending to have a better hand than you do.
examples: "She refused to accept any jail time and thought the DA was bluffing. She was adamant she wouldn't do any jail time."
Brown notes that the founders of Kiev built the city on a bluff to repel invaders.
If Mexican leaders conclude Trump is bluffing, there will be little reason for them to change their behavior.
If this were the first time Trump bluffed badly and lost, it would be a milder embarrassment.

definition: censure severely
details: Chastise is a fancy word for telling someone that something they did was really bad. If you pick your nose, your mom will probably yell at you. If you pick your nose in front of the Queen of England, your mom will chastise you.
examples: Democrats involved in Congress’s investigations of Russia’s election interference quickly chastised Mr. Barr for using the term spying in a way that they believe feeds a right-wing conspiracy of F.B.I. wrongdoing.
Chief John Roberts harbors a deep resentment over the president's chastising of the judiciary.
In interviews, students and workers complained that superiors publicly chastised them for low scores.
But the employee said that Brownstein, the legal director, chastised her for her actions.

definition: treat or speak of with contempt
details: The verb deride means to show a low opinion of someone or something. The jerk would deride the other kids on the bus by calling them names or pulling their hair until the driver decided to de-ride him by kicking him off the bus.
examples: Even as Trump derides Democrats as “unhinged” and claims they are a party taken over by “socialists,” he pulls his punches with Pelosi.
On Wednesday, Trump fired back, deriding Ocasio-Cortez as a "young bartender, 29 years old," and mocking senior Democrats for being "petrified" of her political clout.
Last August, he derided President Trump as basically a "disgraced game show host."
It was derided at the time by Republicans as a “nuclear option.”

definition: attract
details: When you are enamored by something or someone, you love it. It attracts you. You might say that you're enamored with your new car, or enamored of the new kid in school.
examples: But Mr. Soborowicz was less enamored of the president and unsure if he would vote for him the next time.
Do you think that collectively the leaders and people who manage the leavers of society are no longer enamored of neoliberal economics?
The Detroit Lions apparently were enamored by the Rams’ rushing attack in 2018.
Thereafter, Roberts, who was deeply enamored of President Ronald Reagan, took a position as special assistant to William French Smith, Reagan’s attorney general.

definition: grow vigorously
details: A flourish is an extra touch — a trumpet's "ta-ta-da!" announcing a king's entrance, a fancy carving atop an otherwise utilitarian pillar, a wave of a flag or a cheerleader's pompom.
examples: At night, he would visit remote villages along the Kou Valley, north-west of the city of Bobo-Dioulasso, to capture flourishing music scenes.
The word most frequently used to describe the Justice Department’s findings was “scathing,” and for once this was no mere rhetorical flourish.
Lawmakers are eager to gather tax revenue from the state’s flourishing but mostly unpermitted vacation rental sector.
The lawmakers are eager to gather tax revenue from the state’s flourishing but mostly unpermitted vacation rental sector.

definition: a thin porridge
details: Gruel is a truly unpleasant food — weak and runny, consisting of oatmeal or cornmeal boiled in milk or water. It's the kind of "slop" prisoners and other inmates of institutions were historically forced to eat.
examples: Agriculture softened our ancestors’ diets with processed gruels, stews and yogurts, and this fare led to gradually shrinking lower jaws to produce today’s overcrowded mouths.”

Dairy products and other soft foods, such as gruel, porridge, soup and stews, helped shape our faces, the researchers claim, and allowed us to form the sounds “f” and “v”, known as labiodental fricatives.
For others, however, infuriated by Trump and his party, that message seems thin gruel.
The theme park is staffed entirely by “100 percent genuine farmstead girls,” who are paid in fake money, fed gruel and kept in a state of perennial nausea.

definition: extravagant exaggeration
details: Praising your favorite sports team is one thing, but if you call the team the most incredible group of humans ever to walk the earth, then you're going overboard and indulging in hyperbole.
examples: Wolf Blitzer highlighted the senator’s penchant for “off-the-cuff comments”; Politico called him “a reliable fount of gaffes, awkward statements, and hyperbole.”
The number of migrants now flooding the border is a genuine humanitarian crisis, but not one susceptible to solution by hyperbole and bluff.
Publicists are legendary for speaking in hyperbole, and I am no exception.
By all standards, measures and hyperbole, that is the record — the only record.

definition: set forth authoritatively as obligatory
details: Something that is imposed is usually unwelcome and unpleasant and is expected to be endured — like higher taxes or unwelcome guests.
examples: Trump spawned confusion last month when he appeared to lift sanctions imposed by his own administration that were intended to further isolate North Korea.
What’s more, the policy protecting Mexico from newly imposed tariffs on cars is already in effect.
It may not live up to the expectations imposed upon it.
Despite not explicitly naming the “hostile forces” that imposed sanctions, Kim is displaying a more hardened stance toward Washington than was recently in state media, analysts said.

definition: produced or growing in extreme abundance
details: You can use the adjective luxuriant to describe something really luxurious or full and lush. If you walk through a dense forest after it rains, it's really luxuriant with green plants overgrowing the paths.
examples: A wall of moist succulents on the facade was springing to luxuriant life, embedded in rosette-patterned tiles 3-D printed from chardonnay grape skins, sawdust and cement.
Before her, in overly luxuriant rows, was a host, so to speak, of golden pharmaceuticals, plus a few technically less indigenous whatnots.
The second year, the luxuriant blossoms unfold shortly after daffodils bloom, and then continue throughout the season.
In both films, luxuriant visuals were meant to function “as an extension or reflection of the consciousness of the main character,” he observed.

definition: affectedly dainty or refined
details: Mincing is an adjective that describes someone who is being especially dainty or refined. The voices of older women who speak as though they're young girls can be described as mincing.
examples: Fertile ground for forgiveness is sown as they humbly and unequivocally acknowledge past behaviors without mincing words.
Meanwhile, Guardian works on his liver dish, mincing pre-marinated lumps alongside bell peppers, purple onions and shredded carrots.
There’s no mincing words: we are entering into a dangerous new phase in the voting wars.
None of them — picking and chopping parsley, peeling and mincing garlic, browning pans of ground meat — were particularly difficult.

definition: a state of extreme poverty or destitution
details: Penury means extreme poverty to the point of homelessness and begging in the streets. Economic downturns, job loss, shopping sprees, and weekends at the high rollers' table in Vegas can lead to penury.
examples: The emergence of a strong El Nino triggered back-to-back droughts in 2014 and 2015, only for the fourth time in over a century, driving some Indian farmers to penury and suicide.
His passport was revoked, and he was blacklisted and, unable to perform, forced into penury.
An era of mass unemployment and penury would undeniably be a dark one - a fate best avoided.
His parents, after a lifetime of work, were reduced to penury: his father in a nursing home and his mother forced to accept meals from charity.

definition: show an image of
details: Something that reflects comes back to you. If you look in a mirror, you will see your reflected image. If you reflect on your past experiences, you look at them once again thoughtfully.
examples: Others say it reflects short-term incentives gone wrong and an out-of-touch board beholden to its CEO.
The Pinkerton National Detective Agency is a staple of Western fiction, reflecting its real role in the American Old West.
“I really wanted my dress to reflect my personality, thus the lilies and bright colors,” the teen told Fox 5.
—He experienced some chromosomal instability that might reflect radiation exposure in space.

definition: a broken piece of a brittle artifact
details: If you break a mirror, the thin sharp pieces you want to avoid are shards. A shard is simply a broken piece of metal, glass, stone, or pottery with sharp edges.
examples: Effectively, the telescopes work as if they were shards of one big dish.
Within the fury, he emphasized Schumann’s repetitive mottoes as obsessive shards that recurred like fenceposts in a nightmare landscape.
The shards get pieced back together into one legible image, only to explode.
The shards injured several people, and many were limping as they tried to find their way around police barricades.

definition: ornaments; embellishments to or characteristic signs of
details: Big house, shiny new car, a custom-made suit, an expensive watch, cool sunglasses... If you have these things, you have the trappings of success, which means you own things that give you the outward appearance of success.
examples: For Egypt’s leader, Mr. Trump offered only the trappings of an Oval Office welcome, though one with flashing cameras and looming boom mics.
Today, the power of the office is diminished, but the trappings remain: high ceilings, broad staircases, a grandfather clock that rings on the quarter-hour.
In the pictures, the aides are reveling in the trappings of power, projecting an entitlement bestowed by their proximity to Trump.
Culture at large sends a message that it’s bad to want social media popularity and the trappings thereof, but it’s not bad to want a cool job—that’s ambition, right?

definition: capable of being wounded or hurt
details: Use the adjective vulnerable to describe something or someone open to being physically or emotionally wounded, like a newborn chick or an overly sensitive teenager.
examples: Areas where there is more biodiversity – more sharks, more fish, more types of coral, more everything – are less vulnerable to change like global warming.
Look at Folsom, widely considered one of the most vulnerable places in greater Sacramento to fire.
California’s state-of-the-art building codes help protect homes from wildfire in the most vulnerable areas, experts say.
But while prosecutions are rare, activists said criminalising abortions leaves women vulnerable to unsafe surgical procedures and blackmail by partners.

definition: impervious to pleas, persuasion, requests, or reason
details: If you stubbornly refuse to change your mind about something, you are adamant about it.
examples: "She refused to accept any jail time and thought the DA was bluffing. She was adamant she wouldn't do any jail time."
"Meghan said she doesn’t want the men in suits. She was adamant that she wanted her own people. It did leave a few of us a little baffled," a source told The Daily Mail.
“After bringing Kashmir to the brink, the administration is adamant on ensuring collective punishment for Kashmiris.”
It’s worth noting that Cain is an adamant defender of the gold standard as well.

definition: act in an arrogant, overly self-assured, or conceited manner
details: If you tell the captain of the basketball team that you're going to beat him at a game of hoops even though you've never played, you're speaking with a lot of bluster or false confidence and bravado.
examples: So I think Democrats are in something of a conundrum because for all their bluster about Trump's vulnerability, they're the ones with a big problem.

Yet much of the current rhetoric about gun law nullification is “bluster, by and large,” Spitzer said, since he hasn’t yet seen these local officials getting into direct conflict with state or federal authorities.
Krikorian does not believe shutting down the border will be back on the agenda any time soon, given that Trump “made the bluster” and then retreated.
Li, who writes Cantonese operas and manages a Cantonese opera house, is certainly not the first to find art amid Trump’s improbable rise to power, his public bluster and prolific tweeting.

definition: marked by changeable fortune
details: The author who sells a million copies of her first book, four of the second, wins a prize for the third and dies at the ceremony has had a checkered career: it's got bright spots and dark ones, like a checkerboard.
examples: Both arms are raised into the air and the checkered flag is in his right hand.
He’s also wearing a big brace on his knee after tearing his ACL last month, not to mention a checkered past that includes a video from high school showing him punching a woman.
The NFL’s relationship with its female fan base is checkered, at best.
Cameras caught Chopra, 36, sporting a high-waist two-piece black bikini and a beige sunhat while Turner, 23, donned a yellow and black checkered one-piece swimsuit.

definition: a compound obtained from another compound
details: Alert: shifting parts of speech! As a noun, a derivative is kind of financial agreement or deal. As an adjective, though, derivative describes something that borrows heavily from something else that came before it.
examples: Marijuana and derivatives were sold to buyers who were not participants in the program, including out-of-state customers.
The alternatives, parathyroid hormone and a derivative, build bone but also break it down, limiting the therapeutic effect.
The survey also found foreign exchange ranked a distant fourth in terms of structured data by asset class with stocks, fixed income and derivatives the top three.
The bill approved by the Senate on a voice vote Tuesday calls for replacing the term and derivatives with “intellectual disability” in regulations governing the agencies.

definition: an enclosed territory that is culturally distinct
details: An enclave is a separate space or group within a larger one. Imagine an enclave as a cave carved out of a big mountain. All of the bears live in the cave or enclave, while the people live on the mountainside.
examples: “I do not care about the results of the Israeli elections,” said 41-year-old Mohammed Sultan, a teacher who lives in the enclave.
As home prices soar and rents rise, Inglewood is struggling to meet its goal of encouraging more investment while trying to preserve one of California’s last remaining African American enclaves.
As news of the college-admissions scandal broke, ripples of chatter emanated from wealthy enclaves of the United States.
Not only is it less active on social media, but it is also under-represented in the well-educated, urban enclaves where journalists roam.

definition: treat with contemptuous disregard
details: To flout is to scorn or show contempt for. "I flout the law and the concept of civilian safety by making a concerted effort to jaywalk every time I cross a street."
examples: Thorny issues include the flouting of EU competition rules, potential over-borrowing by some of the states, the quality of constructions, and security concerns over high-speed 5G network technology supplied by Chinese companies.
The daily barrage of lies, followed by gaslighting from his supporters is only upstaged by his flouting of decorum, undermining of institutions and the cruelty of his policies.
Nielsen’s alleged defiance of that demand to openly flout a court order appears to be another source of her heroic resistance work.
David Levine, who specializes in civil litigation and remedies at the University of California Hastings College of the Law, said property owners flout permit regulations all the time.

definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
details: If a job is grueling, that means it is really difficult. If a race is grueling, that means it is really difficult. If a trip to the dentist is grueling, that means you need to toughen up.
examples: Because she’s skipping the grueling 1,500 in Richmond, those events are intended to keep her workload up, preparing Ledecky for the grind that awaits her in South Korea.
It began as a grueling game until Texas Tech pulled ahead.
“Border Business: The human coyotes helping migrants survive Central America's grueling Darien Gap jungle,” went the bizarre article.
"It was grueling, definitely with the winds, the temperature today. Overall it was a long week, but I prevailed."

definition: a tentative insight that is not yet verified or tested
details: In science, a hypothesis is an idea or explanation that you then test through study and experimentation. Outside science, a theory or guess can also be called a hypothesis.
examples: Why was this hypothesis not the quest of McCarthy?
But his message was a good one, Bassett tells the class: Strive for the simplest hypothesis.
The idea became known as the ‘nocturnal bottleneck’ hypothesis.
But other concepts are more challenging; fewer Americans recognize a hypothesis or identify the main components of antacids.

definition: impressive in appearance
details: Imposing is an adjective reserved for those things that are impressive in the sense that they are large or serious, as in the US Capitol Building or even, say, a professional wrestler.
examples: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A bill imposing one of the most stringent abortion restrictions in the nation was signed into law in Ohio.
Safeguarding the future of the planet meant that governments may need to risk the wrath of voters by ending subsidies for fossil fuels and imposing carbon taxes.
Four weeks ago, Newsom, a Democrat, said he was imposing an indefinite moratorium on executions for any of the 737 inmates now on death row, the most of any state.
But Newsom’s reprieve lasts only so long as he is governor and does not prevent prosecutors from seeking nor judges and juries from imposing death sentences.

definition: infinitely or immeasurably small
details: Craftsmen can paint whole villages or detailed portraits of people on a grain of rice using minute, or tiny, paintbrushes. Often the works of art are so minute that you can only see them with a magnifying glass.
examples: The telegram reads: “Abraham Lincoln died this morning at 22 minutes after seven.”
About 90 minutes after the photographers got there, a convoy of three police vans arrived.
The plane departed from the Arizona airport after about 90 minutes.
The preliminary report on the disaster said the plane’s anti-stall system pushed the nose of the plane down less than two minutes into the flight because of a malfunctioning sensor.

definition: a laborer who is obliged to do menial work
details: Pity the poor peon. He exists at the very bottom of the food chain of servitude, beneath wage-slaves, underlings, drudges, or even minions. His boss doesn't even know he exists.
examples: As I said, though, those first few nights, it was clear my peon sack would not be multiplied.
This year he was one of two million people who applied for a few thousand low-level “peon” jobs in the state administration.
But Boss felt more like a peon when training camp opened.
“To the government, each of us is just another peon.”

definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
details: Imagine yourself pulling a dog who doesn't want to walk. The dog is refractory, or stubbornly resisting your authority.
examples: For many patients, first-line treatment buys little or no relief, and relapsed or refractory disease entails more-intensive treatment and a worse outlook.

It is approved to treat patients with advanced, refractory heart failure as a bridge to cardiac transplantation and as destination therapy in patients for whom subsequent transplantation is not planned.
One featured patients with refractory celiac disease type 2, the most severe form of celiac disease.
Chinese CAR-T cell trial impresses on the global stage, showing excellent results for relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma.

definition: a frozen dessert made primarily of fruit juice and sugar
details: Sherbet is a frozen dessert made of fruit juice and sugar. Though it looks like ice cream, sherbet is a little different since it's made with little or no milk or cream.
examples: The paintings are executed in candy and cupcake hues, and their titles invoke sherbet, doughnuts and marshmallows.
Werfel admitted, “I’m just guessing about the sherbet.”
From left to right: Maine seaweed with “frothy ocean broth” and tapioca pearls; the onion; parsnip cake with pear and cashew-milk sherbet; and the black-plum terrine.
She plied them with indulgent treats like cotton candy and rainbow sherbet.

definition: a step in walking or running
details: When you tread on the earth, you walk on it. The next time your pal thinks you have it too easy, you might ask him, “Why don’t you tread in my shoes for a day?”
examples: “I always want to tread delicately—and rightfully so—when it might be something treading on First Amendment rights,” he told me.
While that growth should entice any retailer, Chico’s is one of a growing number of clothing brands treading carefully.
A happy troubled soul just doing my best, trying not to tread on people’s toes in this mad mad world.
They hope for a future in Europe, to create a world of peace and reconciliation, to tread ever more softly on our planet.

definition: having or showing knowledge and skill and aptitude
details: Are you looking for another word to describe a person who is highly skilled, very proficient or expert at something? Try the adjective adept!
examples: You write fiction and you’re also a public advocate for tech, privacy and current cultural issues, and you’ve been adept your entire career in using the former to advance the latter.
He is impatient with those processes, but he isn’t very adept at them.
He saw lawmaking as a team effort, was adept in building consensus and mentored a new generation of political leaders that included women and minorities.
The Inuit approach also differs from that of performers in Mongolia and adjacent regions of China and Russia, where adepts produce high and low notes simultaneously.

definition: talk about oneself with excessive pride or self-regard
details: When you boast you are bragging about yourself and your accomplishments (or maybe those of your family), often to the boredom and annoyance of your audience.
examples: Still, Macron boasted afterward about his “responsibility” for the outcome.
The Masters boasts a litany of customs and rituals, arguably more than any institution in sports.

Morrison boasts that the conservative administration Prime Minister Howard led delivered 10 annual surplus budgets and paid off all federal government debt before the government changed at the 2007 election.
“We’ve already cut illegal immigration at the southern border by 61 percent,” he said in early 2017, one of many such boasts.

definition: the use of tricks to deceive someone
details: Have you ever gotten the sense that politicians or corporate leaders will say anything to turn public opinion their way? This tricky kind of deceit and manipulation is called chicanery.
examples: He described the decision last night as “abject surrender”, and said not holding a debate was “cowardice and chicanery”.
Tax experts say the principle of taxing forgiven loans is crucial to preventing chicanery.
Carter Wrenn, a longtime Republican consultant in North Carolina, said the allegations of chicanery created “a smell in the air and around the Republican Party.”
The boxer Oscar de la Hoya and musician Alice Cooper were also cited as celebrity witnesses to presidential fairway chicanery.

definition: formed or developed from something else; not original
details: When something is derived from something else, it is made from that. Ham is derived from pork, and the active ingredient in aspirin is derived from the bark of the willow tree.
examples: I find deep comfort in returning to her books, like touchstones, to understand what this region once was and where its spirit derived from.
The feeling of a disadvantage derived from Rooney’s absence, which left United without one of the most lethal players in the league.
That many affectionately called him “Coach” was derived from his earlier work as a high school teacher and coach but also from how he managed the fractious egos and shifting alliances of Annapolis.
“I don’t believe there is any reason to redact any material for the sole reason that it is derived from grand jury proceedings.”

definition: entry to another's property without right or permission
details: An encroachment is something that intrudes and has the power to influence whatever it encounters. Some might consider text messaging to be an encroachment of impersonal technology on true, heartfelt interactions.
examples: In that setting, Burnett speak-sings his way through free-associative songs that contain biblical allusions, echoes of the blues, tall tales, lovers’ plaints and warnings about disinformation, the cult of personality and the encroachments of technology.

In recognition of how important the jury-trial right is to our democracy, close to 200 years ago, the Supreme Court said that it would guard against “every encroachment upon it … with great jealousy.”
The 1980s is the reaction point, where, fueled by the conservative “Reagan revolution” white students start pushing back against this perceived encroachment.
Baker’s reports from the interior leave in all the encroachments that threaten it.

definition: hinder or prevent, as an effort, plan, or desire
details: You can serve as a foil to someone if you show them to be better than you by contrast. If you can't dance but your friend Lisa can, you can be a foil to Lisa's grace.
examples: Hard-right lawmakers in the House Freedom Caucus stuck together to complicate, and sometimes foil, GOP leaders’ plans to pass spending, health-care, agriculture and other bills they found too accommodating to Democrats.
From afar, she is the reserved, aloof foil to the colorful Grace Coddington, another Vogue editor.
The combination works to great effect; the sweetness of the mild, creamy beans is the perfect foil to the briny, chewy shrimp.
The best eggs are, of course, chocolate; strung in triumphant arches or filling bowls with pastel-coloured foil joy.

definition: innocent and free of deceit
details: If you are guileless, you are not a liar; you are innocent, and you might be a touch on the gullible side.
examples: It was this, I think, that felt like the oddest reversal of received wisdom: that whether Jackson was a lovable weirdo or something darker, he was essentially a guileless individual.
Harriet Lee is such a character, kind and sympathetic, but guileless in the ways of social competition.
With his sausage of a body, short legs and big personality, Burns the longhaired dachshund looks guileless in the ring.
As Charlotte the spider wrote of Wilbur, while the guileless pig dozed on his pile of manure, Stone was RADIANT.

definition: an uncalled-for burden
details: Imposition means you force something — usually an unwanted burden — on someone else. If your friends invite themselves over for dinner the night before your big test, that's an imposition because you'll have to cook instead of studying.
examples: Haley herself clashed with the White House last year when on television she previewed the administration’s planned imposition of a new round of sanctions on Russia.

What we are seeing from both Facebook and Google is an epic public relations push to become champions of regulation while avoiding the imposition of rules that would damage their operating profits too much.
Netanyahu continued, promising that if reelected, he plans on extending a “gradual imposition of Israeli sovereignty” over the entire territory.
HUD’s new thinking is not, in fact, an unfair imposition.

definition: someone who dislikes people in general
details: A misanthrope is a person who hates or mistrusts other people. Your great aunt Edna who lashes out at anyone who approaches, convinced they'll steal the jewelry she keeps in her handbag on her lap? A misanthrope indeed.
examples: In her favor: Critics loved this true story of two New York misanthropes who forged letters from literary figures, starring Melissa McCarthy and Richard E. Grant.
I don’t speak good English and, for the most part, I’m a misanthrope — I hate people.
Whether he is playing a lovelorn misanthrope in last year’s quirky indie “Wilson” or an intergalactic desperado in “Solo,” an innate likability, a folksy decency, shines through.
Freud was not only a misogynist but also a misanthrope.

definition: not allowing contradiction or refusal
details: Peremptory comments are like orders. If you say something in a peremptory manner, you want people to stop what they’re doing and do what you say. Peremptory comments put an end to a discussion, and that’s final!
examples: In addition to the four liberal justices, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. seemed inclined to toughen the rules limiting so-called peremptory jury challenges.
In the first four trials, held between 1997 and 2007, Mr. Evans used all 36 of his peremptory challenges — ones that do not require giving a reason — to strike black jurors from serving.
Prosecutors and defense attorneys also receive what are known as peremptory challenges.

Next month, the Supreme Court will consider whether Mr. Evans’s use of dozens of peremptory challenges — ones that do not require giving a reason — to exclude black prospective jurors violated the Constitution.

definition: overthrow by argument, evidence, or proof
details: The verb refute is to prove that something is wrong. When the kids you're babysitting swear they brushed their teeth, you can refute their claim by presenting the dry toothbrushes.
examples: After a panicked Jordan summons April to her high-rise apartment for help, April refutes the movie’s very premise: “But that’s for white people.”
Hatchell, through a lawyer, refuted the players various claims as largely a misunderstanding.
The new “Pet Sematary” movie proudly refutes this common sense, even as it follows a familiar chain of Hollywood logic.
The statement also contended that the claims would be refuted by the family’s response this week to the Massachusetts lawsuit.

definition: an action of an armed force that surrounds a fortified place
details: Your city is under siege if it is surrounded on all sides by an opposing force on attack. Think of a castle surrounded by a legion of armed knights.
examples: Abalone, corals, salmon and starfish: populations of these four marine animals are under siege from disease.
“He is under siege by congressional Democrats, and that is how he’s operating — under siege.”
“Utøya” is a dramatization of the 2011 terrorist attack on the eponymous Norwegian island and tracks the journey of a fictional protagonist from the moments just before the siege to its conclusion.
But — in a climate in which the press increasingly is under siege, especially from President Trump — these efforts send an unsubtle message.

definition: having keenness and forcefulness and penetration in thought
details: If you're trenchant, it means you think or say smart, sharply worded things that cut right to the heart of the matter. A trenchant observation is one that makes people scratch their chins thoughtfully, or wince with embarrassment for whomever you're talking about, or both.
examples: The multimedia scene is one of several trenchant sequences in the effective, if sometimes leisurely, 1st Stage production of “Columbinus,” the 2005 docudrama about the 1999 mass shooting at Columbine High School.
At first, your book seems like a portrayal of a very cool one, but by the ending pages, it’s developed into a sneaky but trenchant critique of urban planning and an exploration of terrorism.
Despite its big laughs and no-you-didn’t surprises, it builds a trenchant argument.
It was so trenchant that it drew a response from Justice Brett Kavanaugh, who wrote to assert that the “question before us is narrow” and compelled by a law “signed by President Clinton.”

definition: stick to firmly
details: If you don't want monkey droppings to adhere to the sole of your shoe, watch where you’re walking. Maybe if you'd adhere, or stick to, the zoo rules and stay on the walking path, you wouldn't have to worry about it.
examples: The nation, he said, would continue to adhere to all treaties and charters.
It is vital that we adhere to this distinction and not let Uncle Sam turn into Big Brother.
The catastrophic Great Chaos released upon the nation by Call Me Dave does not adhere to any rules.

Both Moore and Cain are perceived by economists and aides as likely adhering to Trump’s wishes should they join the Fed, even though the central bank is supposed to set rates free from political influence.

definition: full of rough and exuberant animal spirits
details: Boisterous is a word used to describe someone spirited, loud, and slightly out of control — like someone with a spring in their step and a song in their heart singing to strangers on the street.
examples: Commissioner Mallory Jones says some moviegoers would become “loud and boisterous.”
I was in England that week, watching demonstrators in the street: angry, boisterous, distressed, disconsolate, some waving the starred flag of the E.U., some draped in the Union Jack.
The King’s Court was no less full, no less boisterous than it was during its hero’s heyday.
We planned our wedding for a few days after Lulu was to be released from prison, a boisterous dinner in the nicest hall of the hotel where I worked.

definition: scold or reprimand severely or angrily
details: To chide someone is to ride them or get on their case, without really getting in their face.
examples: He lives with his two sisters and his mother, who often chide him to be more strict with the boys, but he can’t bring himself to tell them off.
They chided him over his interactions with the human resources official who investigated the Atlanta incident.
He is chided, moments later, for his intellectual arrogance.
Still, there were those who succeeded and some fans celebrated — and chided — their purchases on Twitter.

definition: catch sight of
details: If you spot something, you descry it. When you spy it, you descry it. It's a good verb to use when you catch a glimpse of a rare bird in the trees. Or when you finally spot Waldo in a "Where's Waldo?" book.
examples: The reader is similarly invited to descry herself in Chung’s story—to conceive of herself as a kindred spirit.
There it seemed to Frodo that he descried far off, floating as it were on a shadowy sea, the high dim tops and broken pinnacles of old towers forlorn and dark.
Police Chief Murphy Paul descried the footage as “shocking to the conscience,” even as he emphasized that it does not “tell the whole story of the investigation.”
Q: I’m seeing Intel processors descried as “4th generation” or “6th generation.”

definition: hold back, impede, or weigh down
details: To encumber is to weigh someone or something down with a physical or psychological burden. You may find yourself encumbered by a heavy backpack or with anxieties. Either way, it's a heavy load to bear!
examples: Jim Grogan, the deputy administrator and chief counsel at the Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission, said the law typically applies to attorneys who obfuscate and encumber the legal process by wasting the court’s time.

I imagine that many women, like Oortman and Clark, find their homes similarly encumbered by projected failures and lapses, by the presence of abusive partners and demanding children, by the oppressive need to keep up.

Virginia House Democrats, earlier this week, reiterated calls for Fairfax to resign, but said they “believe the law enforcement investigation should proceed encumbered and outside of the political arena.”
Neither production overcomes the repetitive didactism that encumbers both scripts, especially “Clock.”

definition: force onto another
details: Did your parents foist your baby sister on you when they went out? It means they forced her on you. Anything — a person or object or idea — can be foisted if it's done by force upon an unwilling party.
examples: The government imposed by the United Nations was foisted on Libyans at the behest of the Obama administration and its ill-advised and mistaken alliances.
The presumptuous foisting of significance upon the natural world is a less visible human trespass.
However, he is working for the bulk of this time and immediately foisted the responsibility and time commitment upon me without asking.
Miners say coal operators want to foist their obligations back to on the government.

definition: naive and easily deceived or tricked
details: If you are gullible, the joke is on you because you are easily fooled.
examples: Does it really matter if the rich and the gullible are drinking celery juice in the misguided belief it will change their life?
Critics say he is a ruthless authoritarian propped up by a gullible and guilty international community which failed to intervene to stop the genocide 25 years ago.
On their gotcha page, for anybody gullible enough to click it, Nike swears up and down that Finau will be wearing their new Snake Pack at Augusta, not this evergreen abomination.
Is anyone still gullible enough to believe anything on the first day of April?

definition: pretending to be another person
details: Imposture is the act of pretending to be someone else. Everyone knows the Elvis impersonator isn’t really Elvis himself, but your imposture as Elvis’s long-lost daughter might actually fool some people.
examples: Cercas believes this is because the entire Spanish nation was resolving its shameful complicity in fascist rule and Hitler friendship and forging its own imposture of resistance.
The most shocking thing about Flip’s imposture is how easy it seems, how natural he looks and sounds.
“Recall,” she would say to me, “that you are a prince”; and I began to doubt her reiterations and resent her impostures—the tales of orchid thrones and panther steeds.
It denounced the new rules as “shame, scandal, imposture,” even “treason,” while dismissing pasteurized milk camembert as “lifeless matter,” “pasteurized plaster” and “an ocean of mediocrity.”

definition: characterized by or indicative of lack of generosity
details: Miserly people are stingy with their money and not likely to be generous, like Ebenezer Scrooge himself.
examples: House Democrats today denounced the Trump budget blueprint for being too miserly while Senate Republicans mostly just ignored the matter.
It is a miserly conditional sympathy that is withdrawn the moment victims let us down.
The miserly move brought complaints from some parents who described it as “horrible” and “disgusting”.
Hall says it’s a question of being organised, not miserly.

definition: lasting an indefinitely long time
details: Perennial typically describes things that are permanent, constant, or repeated. If you fight with your parents every year over whether they really must invite your annoying cousins for Thanksgiving, you could call that a perennial conflict.
examples: The most popular pooch here is the Labrador Retriever, a perennial favorite in the Emerald City.
Inside the sprawling garden center, employees apologized to people struggling with heavy bags of mulch and armloads of perennials: All the carts were taken.
The question of human rights and values versus interests is a perennial problem and a perennial tension for America.
The perennial hand-wringing over baseball’s waning popularity and relevancy amid the hastening pace of American life, a tradition dating back more than a century, is not entirely without merit.

definition: a quick reply to a question or remark
details: A rejoinder usually means a witty comeback. If someone asks you a silly question like, "Are you painting?" when you are holding a paint can and a brush, your rejoinder could be, "No, I'm just doing my nails."
examples: But by the time I’d decided to rejoinder with a perfectly acceptable, “Pretty good, and you?” his back was already to me.
Uncowed by the majority’s rejoinder, Clement doubled down on her political critique.
Well, here is rejoinder question: Has CNN become "Resistance TV," where the president and by association, a huge lot of Americans who voted for him, are treated like evil Neanderthals?
On Sunday, Netflix issued its own sharp rejoinder on its Twitter account.

definition: smile affectedly or derisively
details: To simper means to smile in an artificial, coy or self-conscious way. If you hope to please someone by simpering, you may wind up annoying him or her.
examples: He couldn’t simper around these fools and still be what he was becoming for Naomi.
There were no simpering sycophants in the GHW Bush White House.
Her subdued performance is a welcome counterbalance to Emma’s audacious egomania and David’s simpering foolery.
She simpered and swished and ordered Harry about.

definition: an assembly to conduct judicial business
details: A tribunal is like a court. If you've done something wrong and you get caught it's likely you'll be brought before a tribunal, although not all tribunals are there to determine guilt.
examples: The ICC plans to investigate the actions of CIA operatives in secret detention centers in Afghanistan and in other nations that are members of the tribunal.
More than 35,000 equal pay claims were filed at tribunal in the last full year.
Texaco was released from liability through a settlement with Ecuador years earlier, the tribunal found.

In 2015, Russia vetoed a proposal by Malaysia, Australia, the Netherlands, Belgium and Ukraine for the United Nations Security Council to set up an international tribunal to prosecute those suspected of downing the aircraft.

definition: command solemnly
details: The verb adjure is a heavy-duty synonym of the word "ask," with more of a demanding tone. For example, you might have to adjure someone to tell the truth.
examples: Then another surprise: He adjured the name “Pius XIII” in favor of his father’s, John.
The punishment of Flattery the Friar, the Prioress and the other prelates follows; and the Sergeants proceed to divest her of her habit, gaily adjuring her: Cum on, my Ladie Priores.
Lord King, I adjure thee, open the gates, open thy heart.
If Adrienne would adjure her allegiance to the stage and banish all earthly thoughts, he would absolve her and would grant her the rite of Extreme Unction.

definition: support and strengthen
details: When you cheer up a friend who's feeling down, you bolster them. To bolster is to offer support or strengthen.
examples: Administration officials are counting on better trade deals, like its newly renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement, to help keep more industrial jobs at home and bolster wages.
To bolster its potential digital portfolio, Disney recently purchased film and TV assets from Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox and gained prized properties such as “Avatar.”
The episode links use a podcasts.apple.com URL instead of itunes.apple.com, which even further bolsters the iTunes rumors.
That show’s producers were also looking for a way to bolster the ratings of “Twenty One” when in walked Van Doren, a contestant with an intellectual pedigree and telegenic upper-crust looks.

definition: characterized by anger
details: Are you easy to tick off? Known to have a short fuse? Then, you could be described as choleric. Don't worry; it's not a disease related to cholera. Choleric just means you're testy and irritable.
examples: Yet for all her sorrow and self-pity Benjamin is rather pleased by her solitary nighttime self and the neurotic, “choleric” temperament from which she believes her insomnia springs.
If this all sounds like a choleric doctoral dissertation, that’s because it is, sort of.
Their emotionalism is in direct contrast with Barsoumian’s hurtling Hotspur, who hammers his lines for choleric emphasis.

He was also probably mentally ill, as so many people remark on his choleric, ill-tempered, jumpy, unpredictable personality — even those, like Cardinal del Monte, one of his earliest admirers and patrons, who wished him well.

definition: lacking vitality or spirit; lifeless
details: The verb desiccate means to dry out, dry up and dehydrate. It's helpful to desiccate weeds but certainly not crops.
examples: Stephen A. Smith loves nothing more than picking apart the desiccated carcass of a story.
Turner thought the 99th meridian, the place where the prairie meets the desiccated plains, as good a place as any to symbolically mark the frontier.
They proved the planet in ancient times was very different to the freezing, desiccated world we see today.
The prevailing ethic in New Hampshire is bitter envy of everything, a desiccated unwelcoming treatment of strangers unless, of course, there’s a nickel to be made.

definition: native to or confined to a certain region
details: If you want to underscore just how commonly found and present something is within a particular place, try the word endemic. The saguaro cactus is endemic, or native, to the American southwest — so watch out for its sharp spines when you're hiking in Arizona!
examples: “To the extent there were any issues at the F.B.I., I do not view it as a problem that is endemic to the F.B.I.,”
In many cases, measles outbreaks are traced to travelers from elsewhere in the world where the disease is still endemic.
Cholera is endemic in Mozambique, a hotspot in Africa along with parts of Congo, Nigeria, Ethiopia and Zimbabwe, and many people are familiar with purification tablets and other precautions.
Among them, endemic racism and inequality and a geographic and political divide every bit as raw as in the 1860s.

definition: try to stir up
details: Stand outside the school cafeteria passing out flyers with nutritional details on school food, and you may foment a revolution — foment means stirring up something undesirable, such as trouble.
examples: Treasury Department blocked ibn Ouf's assets along with two other Sudanese officials for their role in "fomenting violence and human rights abuses in Darfur."
Treasury Department blocked ibn Ouf’s assets along with two other Sudanese officials for their role in “fomenting violence and human rights abuses in Darfur.”
In a way, the means that we use to engage with each other are designed to foment conflict.
“When you’re trying to foment political change, you need pressure from below and divisions above.”

definition: vigorous and enthusiastic enjoyment
details: You can do many things with gusto, or hearty enthusiasm, whether it's eating a steak, playing table tennis, or cheering on your favorite team. Some people live their whole lives with gusto.
examples: But she praised the menu’s two largest and most expensive meat-a-paloozas with such gusto that it felt like professional negligence on my part not to heed her advice.
