His cheerleaders expressed themselves with gusto; he commanded a legion.
Unless he tells you that you’re “inadequate,” assume that you are not—his gusto is great proof that you’re doing everything right, even if you aren’t doing very much at all.
They seem less like agents driving a story than slaves to their respective character arcs, and though they are performed with gusto the actors are ill-served by clunky dialogue.

definition: not supplying something useful for the future
details: Someone who is improvident doesn't worry about the future — or plan wisely for it. If you spend all your money on video games even though you know you have to buy your mom a birthday present next week, you have made an improvident decision.
examples: It opines at length about the benefits if “children of improvident parents starve to death.”
This reluctance is often attributed to a Teutonic belief that Southern Europeans, and Greeks in particular, are lazy and improvident.
Indeed, he presents himself throughout Black Boy as a rebel, at odds with both his ailing mother, his faithless, improvident father and tyrannical “Granny”.
Then again, Mr. Ryan is making a similarly improvident bet on Mr. Trump.

definition: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
details: If you have misgivings about something, it means you're worried that it's not a good idea. Trying to fall asleep the night before a test, you might have misgivings about having studied so little.
examples: Shannon Boniface, regional supervisor for the Department of Children, Youth and Families, acknowledged some early misgivings about the whole-family model.
The opposition's spokesman on the attorney general portfolio, Mark Dreyfus, committed his center-left Labor Party to support the bill despite misgivings.
In New Hampshire, the party chairman harbored deep, if largely private, misgivings about her party’s nominee.
The opposition’s spokesman on the attorney-general portfolio, Mark Dreyfus, said the bill would be passed on Thursday with the opposition Labor Party’s support, despite misgivings.

definition: tending to betray
details: If someone accuses you of being perfidious, you should probably be offended — it means underhanded, treacherous, deceitful — even evil.
examples: The court found that the defendant “exploited the mood in Germany in a particularly perfidious way.”
Still, the palatial 1910 museum is a protected monument, and erasing all the fingerprints of the king and perfidious glorification of colonialism was never an option.
The desire not to allow Republicans to get away with such a perfidious and consequential court hijacking is understandable.

But what’s that, you say, about the beaver already being an official “symbol of the sovereignty of Canada” and even bearing a perfidious reference to that country in its scientific name, Castor canadensis?

definition: assign to a lower position
details: Relegate means assign to a lower position. If the quarterback of the football team stops making decent throws he might be relegated to the position of benchwarmer, while another kid is given the chance to play.
examples: According to Bourges, the only reasonable choice if Buffon was to stay would be to establish a clear hierarchy between the two goalkeepers, with the Italian relegated to a No. 2 role.
Drumbeats lurch and sputter amid eerie, amorphous electronic sounds; instruments like guitars or pianos are relegated to the far distance.
He relegated “Aladdin and the Enchanted Lamp” to an ancillary volume, The Supplemental Nights to the Thousand Nights and a Night.
It’s done a phenomenal job of relegating business deals from Nigerian princes and extremely wealthy widows to my Gmail spam box while making sure emails with legitimate offers still get to me.

definition: a job that involves minimal duties
details: If you have a cushy job — one that pays, but involves minimal work — then you have a sinecure. "Because he was the brother of the CEO, he was offered a sinecure in the company: he showed up each day and collected a pay check, but others actually did his work."
examples: If that sounds like an executive role, an honorary sinecure, it is not.
Global financial stability is worth a lot more than a sinecure.
Michael Flynn was never going to be one of those studious, intellectual military leaders who quote from Sun Tzu’s “Art of War” and settle into Ivy League sinecures after taking off the uniform.
This is no haphazard system, they report, but is run by a methodical apparatus devoted to collection, distributing stipends, sinecures and cash to those who help.

definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
details: When you want to indicate that something is silly or overused, you would call it trite. A love song with lyrics about holding hands in the sunshine? Totally trite.
examples: An open mind and the right connections may sound so simple and perhaps a bit trite, but they are arguably undervalued ingredients in effective collaborations.
A statement from the Southern Border Communities Coalition called Trump’s visit “trite political theater to extract more funds to fulfill his obsession with building deadly walls”.
But I was surprised that Gold and his accomplished set designer resorted to such a trite trope.
With all there is to potentially say about that, the show chooses a predictable and possibly trite way to wrap up the episode.

definition: scold or reprimand; take to task
details: To admonish is to scold. If you want to show someone you're not happy with his behavior, admonish him.
examples: But that sense of peace faded a few days after arriving when my older female relatives began admonishing my mother for “letting” my skin become “so dark”.
I admonish myself for being theatrical about something so mundane.
Nevertheless, the bureau admonished banks with high fees for not acting in the best financial interest of students.
That’s not to say he hasn’t seen fans get admonished, even his own relatives.

definition: run away
details: We love words that sound like what they mean, and bolt is no exception. It's a quick, sharp word that either means to move quickly or refers to a stroke of lightning, as in "lightning bolt."
examples: “If you use Photon, all you would do is just bring your suitcase-sized antenna and bolt it on.” he says.
I slammed the door shut, locked and bolted it, then ran upstairs, checking windows, pulling curtains back, looking inside cupboards.
He splutters, clears his throat and sits bolt upright.
Plus, Trotz — without the services of John Tavres, who bolted for Toronto this summer — helped the Islanders exceed expectations by a wide margin.

definition: the size of something as given by the distance around it
details: The distance around a circle is called the circumference, and although circumference is often used when talking about round things, it can mean a boundary of any shape that completely surrounds something.
examples: Dear Heloise: This memory clue helped my math students: There are three measurements for circle distances: radius, diameter and circumference.
It devotes a chapter to classical mathematician Archimedes, including his “heroic” calculations of π, the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter.
Not long after her arrival, she started calculating the most accurate value of pi, which is the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter.
Pi is the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter.

definition: a state in which all hope is lost or absent
details: Despair is the feeling of not having any hope left. If you completely forgot to study for your final exam in math, you might feel despair when your teacher passes out the test.
examples: While most folks look at the Crenshaw neighborhood where he grew up and see only gangs, bullets, and despair, Nipsey saw potential.
There were various points of despair that nobody saw happening that were bubbling beneath the surface.
Saying that truth aloud seemed to grant Shiv the space to move away from her despair.
One thing, however, is certain: “Game of Thrones” will keep dazzling with dragons and disgusting with gore, leaving us dangling between hope and despair, right up until the very end.

definition: furnish with a capital fund
details: To endow is to furnish, but not with furniture. If you've been endowed with something, it means you've been given a gift — most likely a gift that can't be returned or exchanged, like a sense of humor or athletic ability or trust.
examples: These provisions let charities remove donors’ names from buildings, endowed fellowships or scholarships or return donated funds following allegations of or convictions for immoral or illegal behavior.
The National Gallery is renowned for art but a horticultural team also endows the building with sweeping Instagrammable flower displays.
It wants the defendants to endow a fund to curb the epidemic.
There are few Mozart interpreters as sublime as the pianist Mitsuko Uchida, who endows nearly every note she plays with exquisite, crystalline import.

definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
details: If you decide you are going to scale Mt. Everest next weekend without any training or experience, that would be a foolhardy decision. Use the adjective foolhardy to describe someone who rushes into action without considering the consequences.
examples: To her peers, such a proposal sounds foolhardy or worse.
And so there is a certain satisfaction in seeing Denis venture into outer space, following a group of characters on a foolhardy if involuntary mission to stake their own small claim on the infinite.
Unfortunately, proceeding with massive highway expansion and a third bay bridge without determining their likely impact on climate change would be foolhardy.
But it would be foolhardy to do so at the expense of future generations’ well-being.

definition: blowing in puffs or short intermittent blasts
details: Gusty, the adjective, describes what the wind is like when leaves are swirling around in the air, garbage blowing all over city streets, and hats refusing to stay put.
examples: Meanwhile, gusty winds are expected Wednesday across much of northern Arizona.
Widespread gusty northerly winds will affect a widespread area of SW California today thru tonight.
The area and the rest of the Colorado’s southeastern corner are under a red flag warning because of gusty winds, low humidity and dry fuels.

DeWayne Johnson, a groundskeeper at a San Francisco Bay Area school district, sprayed large quantities of the product, sold under the brand name Roundup, from a 50-gallon tank attached to a truck during gusty winds.

definition: attribute or credit to
details: The verb impute can be used to blame someone for doing something bad, give credit for good work, or just tell it like it is, like when you impute your lateness to my not telling you where to meet me.
examples: “He is a victim of political persecution,” his spokesperson told the Antagonista site, and “repudiates the attempt to impute irregularities and crime where there are none”.
Yet the history of science is replete with natural phenomena like electricity and infectious disease that were once imputed to God simply because we didn’t understand them.
They would instead grow more likely to impute bad motives or pathologies to people on the right.
The U.S. government “is required to provide information as to the criminal charges that are imputed to Mr. Assange in full,” they reportedly wrote in the filing.

definition: a slight but appreciable amount
details: Mite is one of many words for a very small amount, like a bit and a jot. A mite is teeny-weeny and itty-bitty. It's not much at all.
examples: Rose bud mites transfer the rose rosette virus while feeding on the flower.
One is the final meal of a feather mite, a bloodsucking parasite that lives in the hollow quills, downy tufts, and outer layers of bird feathers.
Nematode worms and broad mites attacked the crops.
Scabies is an itchy infestation of the skin by a microscopic mite.

definition: hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough
details: Perfunctory means done as part of a routine or duty. If you give someone a gift and they look at it like it's roadkill and say nothing about it but a perfunctory "thank you," you might not be giving them another one anytime soon.
examples: It’s not unusual for issues between stakeholders to be decided before the meeting, making the public comment more perfunctory than persuasive.
For all of its foodie appeal, however, “Ramen Shop” is a wispily sentimental enterprise, full of perfunctory transitions, maudlin plot twists and awkward time shifts between past and present.
As of opening weekend, the complex production felt a bit hasty and perfunctory, but these flaws should disappear with repetition.
It felt more dutiful and perfunctory than anything, as if Phillies fans knew the media would be listening and took it upon themselves to uphold their own reputation.

definition: an abatement in intensity or degree
details: Remission refers to a stage of lesser intensity, when something subsides or improves. Remission is usually a good thing — like when your cancer is in remission, it means that it is manageable and not getting any worse.
examples: WBKO-TV in Bowling Green reports Molly Hughes went through five rounds of chemo, and her family recently learned she is in remission.
They say guidelines often assume the disease is in remission, but many patients now live for years with advanced cancer.
Guidelines on how cancer survivors should be monitored later in life often assume the disease is in remission rather than still being treated, they wrote.
Four months later, with the cancer in remission, he returned to the Texans and played in eight regular-season games and their playoff loss to the Indianapolis Colts.

definition: curved or curving in and out
details: Sinuous means winding or curvy. If you get lost on a sinuous mountain path, you'll need a compass or a GPS to figure out which direction leads back to camp.
examples: For millenniums, the Missouri was a wide, sinuous river.
Crude paintings dispersed throughout the show feature a variety of abstracted naked women in sinuous or jagged shapes rendered in bright, flat colors.
Over time, this visual slackness proves to be a sinuous strength.
History and the landscape are littered with examples of such obstructions, from medieval walled cities to the sinuous and fortified Great Wall of China.

definition: a group of three people responsible for civil authority
details: A triumvirate is a group of three people who share power. In America's early days, George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison were a triumvirate — three men whose leadership helped shape America.
examples: This taquería triumvirate is responsible for the popularity of red pastor.
That lineup would keep the top three positions of the current septuagenarian triumvirate — with none of the youthful sheen of the incoming class.

But after a closely watched, expensive battle, Democrats won eight Republican-held seats, giving their party decisive command of Albany’s triumvirate of power and positioning them to unleash a cascade of long-stymied progressive legislation.
NEW “This was more a “transparent triumvirate of electorates” from Nicaragua, Venezuela and Cuba,” said Christopher Sabatini, a Columbia University professor and expert on the region.

definition: make more attractive, as by adding ornament or color
details: To adorn is to dress something up by decorating it. You might adorn your poncho with fringe or your poodle's dog collar with rhinestones.
examples: The portrait, which once adorned Adolph Hitler’s Munich offices, disappeared at the end of World War Two.
The last of the Golden Week holidays, Children’s Day sees neighborhoods and cityscapes adorned with colorful koinobori carp streamers.
Mr. Robbins, whose creations adorned millions of American homes in their heyday, was a self-described “right guy at the right time in the right place.”
The trio, which date to the 10th and 11th centuries, are adorned with crosses and Celtic interlace patterns similar to the ones seen on the stones inside the church.”

definition: ostentatiously lofty in style
details: To be bombastic is to be full of hot air — like a politician who makes grand promises and doesn't deliver.
examples: Many Israelis shrugged at the bombastic pledge, dismissing it as eleventh-hour electioneering.
It ratchets down the headache-inducing, bombastic battles of the bots and within a coherent teen drama focuses on the robots interactions with humans and their human-like qualities.
Mr. Schnabel became known for his bombastic ego and not his big heart.
Known for his brash media persona, Avenatti was similarly bombastic when dealing with Nike’s attorneys.

definition: careful to consider potential consequences and avoid risk
details: If you are circumspect, you think carefully before doing or saying anything. A good quality in someone entrusted with responsibility, though sometimes boring in a friend.
examples: Because those senior officials contend Comey said too much about people who were not charged with crimes, they are now arguing internally for Barr to be more circumspect in public statements and releases of information.

Republicans contend that Barr is being transparent under Justice Department regulations adopted after former President Bill Clinton’s impeachment in the 1990s, which allow the attorney general to be circumspect in what he releases.
All of this liberates him to be more circumspect.

Guatemala, the source of much of the recent migration from the region, was particularly circumspect, with presidential spokesman Alfredo Brito saying simply that the official response was not to comment for the time being.

definition: destroy and strip of its possession
details: Despoil is to spoil, only worse. You may spoil a dinner party by being late, but we all despoil the earth with pollution and over-consumption.
examples: A new aluminum smelting plant threatens to despoil the landscape and the fresh Icelandic air.
The New World was seen as “simultaneously pristine and despoiled: empty and at the same time filled with primitives begging for deliverance.”
Huge corporations will be further empowered to despoil the earth for profits while workers are left more vulnerable.
Maduro is feeling the heat from within and without his despoiled country.

definition: give qualities or abilities to
details: You probably hope that your years of ballet classes will endue you with the ability to dance like Baryshnikov. In other words, you're dreaming that all of those arabesques and pirouettes will provide you with the dancing talent you wish for.
examples: He instead exalted the enduing friendship between the two countries and the alliance that twice helped saved France from German occupation.
All its phenomena, all its catastrophes, were read in a new light, were endued with a new significance, acquired a religious sanctity.
With amplest gifts endued, A being of flesh and blood.
It will need tact, discretion, and kindness of heart, and I trust I may be endued with the necessary qualifications to a much larger extent than I think I naturally possess.

definition: a delay in enforcing rights or claims or privileges
details: When a teacher says, "Bear with me for a moment," while he writes on the board, he is asking for the class's forbearance. He wants them to wait patiently during the delay.
examples: Some may find this movie unbearable; yet there’s a place for pictures that push us to the limits of forbearance.
Its stated central values are “truthfulness, compassion, and forbearance.”
Respond with warmheartedness, disarming your attacker with forbearance.
But the mood of proud forbearance—the lofty perspective on human hysteria—that some readers of “Stoner” find repellent is central to the novel’s appeal.

definition: without knowledge or intention
details: Inadvertently is an adverb that means "without knowledge or intent," like when you inadvertently take someone else's coat from the coatroom because it looks just like yours.
examples: On Feb. 25, a friend and Arlington Public Schools parent inadvertently discovered a meeting that evening of a working group charged with developing procedures to implement the district’s transgender/gender-nonconforming students policy.
Immigration advocates say Mexico might inadvertently be encouraging more caravans to form.
The bot inadvertently helped spread the senators’ information across Twitter, a process that prosecutors say Cosko aided by tweeting about his leaks.
A woman inadvertently rents a room to her daughter’s deranged nemesis in the new thriller “Nightmare Tenant.”

definition: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
details: Choose the verb mitigate when something lessens the unpleasantness of a situation. You can mitigate your parents' anger by telling them you were late to dinner because you were helping your elderly neighbor.
examples: “When an account violates the Twitter Rules, the system looks for linked accounts to mitigate things like ban evasion,” the spokesperson told us.
By that stage, though, Messi was in no mood to consider mitigating circumstances.
For example, the Bank of England is modelling the UK housing market and simulating the effects of policy measures aimed at mitigating financial risk.

“We can’t effectively mitigate the growing problem of antibiotic resistance without dealing with places like Kibera,” said Dr. Guy H. Palmer, a researcher at Washington State University who studies resistance in Africa.

definition: pass from physical life
details: Perish means to die, but it suggests a slow, gradual, nonviolent death. Starving to death is perishing. Getting hit by a bus is just plain getting killed.
examples: Most major characters shall perish, but I think Gendry will end up on the throne in the end – why else would such a non-character still be around?
Now a jury will decide if the death of a 21-year-old man who perished in the September 2017 blaze was a crime.
Kobani, where more than thirteen hundred Kurds perished, still ranks as the longest, deadliest, and most vicious battle with the Islamic State.
But when the researchers stimulated colitis or triggered other types of intestinal injury in mice lacking tuft cells, the animals quickly perished.

definition: tear or be torn violently
details: The verb rend means to tear with force or violence, or into many pieces. Your parents won't be happy if your new kitten decides to rend their brand new curtains with her tiny claws.
examples: It’s been 150 years since slavery ended in the United States, and the legacy still stains the national character, rends the national soul, and continues to unfairly stymie the progress of millions of Americans.
“Delicate Adonis is dying, Cytherea, what shall we do? Beat your breasts, maidens, and rend your tunics.”
“Stop this drift towards violence and hate, also rhetorical, that is starting to rend the fabric of Italian society,” Mr. Bonomi said, in remarks broadcast on television news and in press reports.
Her teeth rending flesh, the taste of it, the feeling of it between incisors and tongue and gums.

definition: someone who habitually doubts accepted beliefs
details: A skeptic is a person who doesn't believe something is true unless they see evidence. As a skeptic, you refuse to believe your sister saw a ghost — after all, she can't prove it.
examples: Add in small-town charm and a local literary pilgrimage site, and Vancouver skeptics will be changing their tune by the time the train pulls into the station.
Many of the vaccine skeptics cloak their rhetoric with scientific language, as did the speakers on the recent conference call.
“Who thought these cards would be a good idea lol” another skeptic moaned.
Some skeptics see it as mere window dressing by corporations more interested in profit than what’s in society’s best interests.

definition: a solemn pledge of fidelity
details: A troth is a serious promise to be faithful, such as a pledge people make about getting married. If you and your girlfriend announce your troth at a family dinner, then that means you better be serious about your relationship.
examples: The coronation scene, in which Elizabeth is anointed and pledges her troth to the nation and God, really moved me, though I’m still a confirmed anti-monarchist.

In the US, this trend is thought to contribute towards the growing divorce rate, but I say that you should never pledge your troth to someone before observing their attitude towards buying toilet roll.
One of those leaders who chose to plight his troth with Bernie Sanders is the former president of the NAACP, Ben Jealous.
The black brother is so brainwashed that he may even be repelled when he first hears the troth.

definition: quick or skillful or adept in action or thought
details: Someone who is adroit is clever and skillful. An adroit leader will be able to persuade people to go with his ideas. An adroit sculptor can turn a lump of clay into an object of great beauty.
examples: And despite profound cogitation and adroit personnel shuffling by the former Yankee manager, the Pirates won, 4-3.
One of the most technically adroit buildings to open along the High Line in New York City, the Shed is a public-facing amenity of the luxury Hudson Yards residential and retail development.
Rep. Hank Johnson, D-Ga., said Pelosi is adroit at being able to “adapt to the reality once that reality becomes clear to her.”
One of the staffers, more adroit than I was, agreed to fetch the director, though of course he never did.

definition: ill-mannered and coarse in behavior or appearance
details: If your cousin tells revolting jokes, belches, and smells like he spent the winter in a cave, he could be described as boorish — an adjective used for people with bad manners and a sloppy appearance.
examples: “I would not let anyone harass anyone in my restaurant,” she said, adding that she believed some of the actresses involved in the campaign lacked legitimacy to try to protect other women from boorish behavior.
This season, the N.C.A.A. put a renewed focus on bench decorum, hoping to clamp down on the boorish behavior of coaches — who might set an example for fans.
As I drank I became brash, boorish and shouty to compensate for how much I hated group socialising.
There is a sense among genteel Washington that partisanship is rude and boorish.

definition: one's overall condition in life
details: Circumstances are factors or conditions that play a part in determining an outcome. Given the current economic circumstances, a lot of good candidates just can't find jobs.
examples: Barry was not identified by name in the order, but the facts matched her circumstances.
An Oxford University college campus is in upheaval after a tutor was suspended under mysterious circumstances.
Police said inquiries were ongoing to establish the full circumstances, but the girl's death does not appear to be suspicious.
It is our broad policy in all circumstances, so it equally applies to Julian Assange, that he will not be extradited if he is going to face the death penalty.

definition: the place designated as the end, as of a race or journey
details: Destination can describe where you are going, like a traveler whose destination is Paris, or a place that is known for a particular purpose, such as a hip new music club that's a destination for fans of indie rock.
examples: Looking for the next world-class destination for top-tier dining in Los Angeles?

After opening in the summer and touting itself as the region’s premiere destination for Chinese fine dining, San Gabriel restaurant Opal abruptly announced in March that it would transition to group dining only.
The cartoon version of evolution, in which a hunched ape becomes a tall and jaunty biped, suggests a journey with a destination.
"I think it will be really good for Birmingham as a destination."

definition: unceasing
details: Many people have an enduring love for ice cream, that is, they have loved it for a long time and will continue to love it into the future. Enduring means long-lasting.
examples: The Spanish forward hasn’t fully met expectations after his much-anticipated return to the club where he thrived in the early 2010s, seeing more cards and enduring more injuries than scoring goals.
For Rebecca Wetten, scaling the heights of the Faculty of History is an enduring memory of her time in Cambridge.
He met with his new players for about 30 minutes Wednesday, telling them he needed to lean on them after enduring the emotional fallout of saying goodbye to his old players the previous day.

definition: cross a river where it's shallow
details: When you’re out hiking in the wilderness, you may have to ford a river if there’s no bridge. Roll up your pant legs because you'll have to wade through the water at a shallow point.
examples: Mr Law was first on the scene and saw the car reversing near the ford on Friday, before it was swept away.
One sent to her @dee_ford handle read: “You ruined my whole year.”
This would be like fording the Rhine to fight for Nazi Germany -- in March 1945.
The weeds they forded fell to dust about them.

definition: characterized by ardent emotion, intensity, or brilliance
details: When heated, coals become incandescent, which means that they glow red-hot. You could also describe a brilliant and moving novel as incandescent.
examples: The carbon-filament bulb, which he patented in 1880, enabled people to keep daytime activities running around the clock and cemented incandescent lighting as a cornerstone of modern life.
On “Say My Name,” the record’s emotional core, Wilde demands we remember victims of state-sanctioned police violence, and its hooks drip with soul music’s incandescent pain.
As it pierces through the billowing darkness, resembling a supernatural rage, the lightning’s incandescent flashes warn volcanologists far away that a potentially dangerous tower of ash is skyward.
One turns back to Gates’s best book, the incandescent memoir “Colored People,” with its evocation of Piedmont, West Virginia, in the nineteen-fifties and sixties.

definition: how something is done or how it happens
details: You can describe the specific style of doing something as your mode. If you're in vacation mode, for example, it might mean you say everything in a super-relaxed voice and spend all of your classes daydreaming.
examples: The PGA Tour relented on its phone ban in 2011, asking spectators to put the devices on silent mode so as not to distract players.
"She is very distraught and is in crisis mode," a source said specifically of Olivia Jade.
The same is true of the doodle mode, which is like a simplified Tilt Brush, letting you draw and paint in 3D space.
The software maker is adding dark mode to many of its popular apps, including Outlook for iOS and Outlook on the web.

definition: allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through
details: Something that is permeable can be passed through, especially by liquids or gases. "I wish I hadn't worn my permeable sweater to the picnic when the weatherman called for thunderstorms. The rain seeped right through the fabric, soaking me to the skin."
examples: There are few substantial barriers preventing people from accessing the range in places that aren’t along the Mexican border, making the territory permeable from many sides.

“I deeply miss those times when the border was a permeable line and the two cultures mixed in a natural and agreeable fashion,” she wrote in her bestselling 2013 “musical memoir” titled “Simple Dreams.”
But borders are permeable, and Africans who fall seriously ill may travel long distances to see the healer in their home villages, because they trust them.
From the New York and Providence mountain ranges, rain and snowmelt wend down through porous ground, skirting less permeable volcanic rock on its way.

definition: give an interpretation of
details: Render is a synonym of make — technically it means "cause to become." An illness might render you unable to walk, or a shocking site might render you speechless.
examples: Each church catered to an African American congregation in a rural setting, and each was rendered a charred disaster scene as a result of intense flames.
While the chicken skin renders to a golden brown crisp, I quickly blitz the raw salsa ingredients in a blender, adding some white wine for extra tartness.
One that renders a SolidWorks file in 10 minutes instead of 10 hours saves more than it costs.
They often featured flowers, birds and trees, or tradesmen at work and were rendered in an intentionally naive, shallow perspective.

definition: an ability that has been acquired by training
details: If you have an ability that required practice, training, or experience, you have a skill. His welding skill allowed him to create wonderful pieces of art out of metal plumbing pipes. He called his best work "Peace Pipes."
examples: “So it’s a real skill by our sonographer to talk people through that.”
But when he was asked if his skill set best fits a specific position on Wednesday, Bryant said, “Not necessarily, no. Just wherever coach Lake needs me, that’s where I’ll play.”
At the time, Boulder County district attorney Stan Garnett said police and prosecutors lacked the manpower and skill for such a case.
Ph.D.s teach students independent research skills.

definition: obstreperous and defiant aggressiveness
details: If you get into fights all of the time, you might be accused of truculence and sent for anger management classes. Truculence is showing a fierce kind of aggression.
examples: The girl, indignant, gathers up the clothes and stalks away; there’s a genuine truculence in her step.
History is clear that moments of high trade truculence, such as that pursued against Japan in the early 1990s, accomplished little while imposing substantial costs.

Though he opposes such measures, the fact that the House is moving towards Medicaid expansion represents a huge shift from the McAuliffe years, when the mere mention of the programme sparked truculence from Republicans.
The other is that the wall would be a waste of money as well as an unfortunate symbol of U.S. truculence.

definition: exaggerated flattery or praise
details: If you've ever been to a pop concert filled with screaming fans you've probably been exposed to adulation — praise so over-the-top it's almost embarrassing.
examples: Both of them were, in their own ways, addicted to the adulation of others, for their own reasons and because of their own wounds.
And Cillizza is far from alone in what sounds a bit like adulation.
And if not adulation, victory in a Big One at least resulted in the demand for many hundreds of autographs.
He basked in the adulation of his supporters at the Grand Rapids rally.

definition: a clear seasoned broth
details: Bouillon is a clear broth made by simmering meat, fish, or vegetables in water with herbs. A nice cup of bouillon will make you feel better if you have a cold or a stomachache.
examples: “But it’s also a flavor bomb. It tastes like you rubbed bouillon all over a steak.”

Peek into homes and restaurants in China, Poland, the Philippines, France and Australia, and you’ll probably find Maggi products — most often a seasoning sauce, bouillon cube, noodle or soup mix — on one of the shelves.
Shaya first poaches the cauliflower in a wine-heavy broth that reminds me of the court bouillon used for traditional French fish cookery, getting it tender and infusing it with flavor.
But even a bouillon cube will do in a pinch.

definition: avoid or try to avoid fulfilling, answering, or performing
details: To circumvent is to avoid. Someone who trains elephants but somehow gets out of picking up after them has found a way to circumvent the cleaning of the circus tent.
examples: Trump subsequently declared a national emergency to circumvent Congress; the House filed suit last week to prevent the move.

That afternoon, House Democrats filed a lawsuit challenging Trump’s national emergency declaration, which he invoked to circumvent Congress and to use military construction money to pay for the border wall.
There’s his refusal to fill cabinet posts, instead circumventing accountability by keeping a record number of people in acting positions.
He also orchestrated a scheme to circumvent the federal ban on foreign donations to inaugural committees.

definition: marked by lack of definite plan, purpose, or enthusiasm
details: If you lack a definite plan or purpose and flit from one thing to another, your actions are desultory. Some people call such desultory wanderings spontaneous. Others call it "being lost."
examples: But the hours of discussion that preceded the desultory procedural vote marked the most extensive examination of climate change on the Senate floor in years.
She dragged her feet down the jet bridge, holding my hand and staring at the floor desultorily, until we stepped into the terminal and she caught the scent of Subway.

The essentials: During practices, the girls on the high school soccer team the Wolves engage in desultory, often overlapping chatter on topics ranging from the atrocities of the Khmer Rouge to their menstrual cycles.
That progress screeched to a halt Wednesday night with a 101-69 loss at DePaul that earned a place of its own in the ledger of the season’s most desultory defeats.

definition: weaken mentally or morally
details: To enervate is to weaken, wear down, or even bum out. A three-hour lecture on the history of socks might thrill someone, it would enervate most people. So would a too-long soak in a hot tub. With your parents.
examples: But the effort to be everything to everyone is enervating, and no doubt exhausting.
Because the cornea is enervated, the prions, which prey on proteins found in neurons, may be reaching the surface via these tiny neural conduits.
But far from being enervating, this helps to carry Johnson’s narrative along, allowing it to flow like a river.
We prefer wines that are nimble and energetic, that refresh the palate rather than enervate.

definition: a person from whom you are descended
details: Your father, grandmother, and great grandfather are all your forebears. A forebear is an ancestor, or someone you are descended from.
examples: These are the forebears of the Google Petition Signers.
In other versions of this tale of megalomaniacal delusion, the subject believes himself to be president of the US, the country of his birth, or president of Turkey, land of his forebears.
It runs in my family: several forebears grappled with depression, too, and at least two tried to kill themselves decades ago.
The best way to honor our past is not to freeze its practices in place but to remember that our forebears were willing to undertake reform when reforms were required.

definition: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
details: Inchoate means just beginning to form. You can have an inchoate idea, like the earliest flickers of images for your masterpiece, or an inchoate feeling, like your inchoate sense of annoyance toward your sister's new talking parrot.
examples: I wondered if the archivist was right that I was a naïve girl with inchoate ideas.
This “arrested, inchoate form of mourning” keeps people locked in a state of inaction, she writes.
Like a lot of fools, I’d been propelled to this juncture by inchoate yearning.
In many stories, fumes of inchoate contempt practically waft off the screen.

definition: not large but sufficient in size or amount
details: A person is modest if he or she is very successful but does not call attention to this.
examples: A few of the future owners of NFL franchises instead sat on the running boards of the modest Hupmobile in Hay’s dealership.
Gover says a projected modest increase in passenger traffic means the airport will also need more parking spaces, a larger concourse and upgraded baggage handling systems.
Unlike in previous games during this modest streak, the Angels didn’t claw across runs in multiple innings.
Before a modest crowd, Mr. Castro denounced Mr. Trump’s anti-immigrant message in no uncertain terms, calling the president’s policies “downright stupid.”

definition: spread or diffuse through
details: When you live in a big city like New York, you know all too well how the smells of spices and cooking meats can permeate a hallway, easily passing through those thin apartment doors to make your mouth water.
examples: She said her grandfather’s legacy of experiential retail still permeates the Fred Segal brand.
The NHL long ago shed itself of the Stanley Cup dynasties that permeated its landscape from the 1940s onset of the Original Six era right on through the early 1990s.
More than anything else, violence is the centerpiece of Baltimore life, and its toll instills a daily sense of wariness that permeates the city.
The Burning Sun scandal shows that such predatory entitlement permeates even into the realm of elite K-pop stars.

definition: someone who rebels and becomes an outlaw
details: A renegade is a person who has deserted their cause or defied convention; they're rebels and sometimes outlaws, or even traitors.
examples: And although membership of a club isn't necessary to partake in this renegade pastime, it does appear there is a shadowy group dedicated to night climbing.
This is not the world of “Grit: The Power of Passion and Perseverance”; it is the world of small-press social critique and renegade voices.
There was no immediate reaction from Beijing, which views Taiwan as a renegade Chinese province.
On July 15, 2016, four days before Trump was nominated for president, renegade officers in the Turkish military attempted a coup against Erdogan.

definition: unpredictably excitable, especially of horses
details: If you're skittish, you're unpredictable and excitable. You've probably seen skittish horses in parades — the loud noises and crowds of people make them very nervous and jumpy.
examples: A skittish robot leads her through the same routine every day, which starts with a series of questions about compliance and ends with hard labor mining for minerals.
He’s a skittish reporter; more content to chat with taxi drivers than squeeze stories from his subjects.
But the budget process showed a distance remained between the party’s emboldened left wing, and the older guard, centrist lawmakers who seemed skittish by the pace of change.

The orchestra does the heavy lifting in advancing the drama, including during many stretches of spoken dialogue, accompanied by a few solo instruments or a florid piano, or, at times, skittish symphonic bursts.

definition: clouded as with sediment
details: If a liquid is dark and murky and you can't see through it, it's turbid. It’s usually used as a criticism — a turbid river is generally a polluted one, but then again a good pint of real ale should be turbid. Go figure.
examples: He looked down the lawn towards the turbid flood.
“It seems all too apt that this whale should appear in the turbid waters of the ominously named Gravesend, site of the opening of Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness.”
My trouble with the paragon of French Romanticism was, and remains, the turbid indefiniteness of his style, which never really coalesces and which topples, at times, into wackiness.
In these turbid waters, Manafort was like any other great white, only more so: The firm he ran with Roger Stone, among others, was dubbed “The Torturers’ Lobby” by critics.

definition: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
details: If you adulterate something, you mess it up. You may not want to adulterate the beauty of freshly fallen snow by shoveling it, but how else are you going to get to work?
examples: Food and Drug Administration policy, flood-soaked grain is considered adulterated and must be destroyed, according to Iowa State University.
The Consumer Healthcare Products Association said it supported FDA’s “efforts to identify bad actors selling adulterated or misbranded dietary supplement products.”
The system helped to identify adulterated hazelnuts associated with a record price jump, Verhaelen's team reported in the December issue of Food Control.
In 1906 the United States was the only major industrialized nation without strict laws forbidding the sale of contaminated and adulterated food.

definition: slightly salty
details: Something that is brackish is unpleasant and harsh, like the coffee you left on too long or the water in a muddy pond.
examples: The body floated beneath a bridge in the brackish flow of a waterway off the Pasig River.
An on-site treatment plant desalinates brackish seawater, a greenhouse supplies the kitchen and all fish is bought from locals.
The worst-run teams return year after year to this brackish well.
At a brackish inlet of the Harlem River, Skaife spotted a kestrel.

definition: make reference to
details: To cite something means to do right by whoever said it and give them credit — for instance, if you add a brilliant statement to a paper but you’re not the one who originally wrote it, you should cite, or point to, the original author.
examples: Johnson, 59, who played for the Lakers for 13 seasons, announced Tuesday he was stepping down citing his desire to return to the simpler life he enjoyed as a businessman.
Sen. Angus King, Maine independent, cited the “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it,” theory to press for changes to Mr. Trump’s far-reaching plans.
The two sides are deep in discussions, though the talks aren’t yet final, the Times said, citing unidentified people familiar with the negotiations.
Williams’ attorney confirmed the split to Page Six, and People cited a source confirming the same.

definition: something immaterial that interferes with action or progress
details: A deterrent makes you not want to do something. Let's say there's a giant pile of cookies being guarded by an angry dog — the dog is a deterrent.
examples: But defended the effectiveness of the tactic as a deterrent to migration.
The major deterrent to antagonizing Beijing is its blunt economic power.

But the separation of crying migrant children from their parents as a deterrent, and the housing of children in prisonlike conditions, will be some of the most enduring political images of the Trump era.
In fact, Trump is reported to be keen to resurrect the most controversial and amoral of all his anti-immigration ideas—separating families at the border as a means of deterrent.

definition: causing weakness or debilitation
details: What do standing out in the cold rain, a pile of homework, and an emotional breakdown all have in common? They're enervating: in other words, they completely drain you of physical and emotional energy.
examples: But the effort to be everything to everyone is enervating, and no doubt exhausting.
But far from being enervating, this helps to carry Johnson’s narrative along, allowing it to flow like a river.

But one theme he kept returning to, during the screed and in responses to journalists’ questions, was that of the disempowered black man, revived and ready to vanquish the enervating effects of women’s influence.
The form of the story seems no less enervating: like a long piece of reporting, with headlines, 17 of them — “Who was Burke? His Beginnings”; “Who is Blindman?”

definition: a feeling of evil to come
details: When you get a foreboding, you get a sense that something bad is going to happen. A foreboding is a foretelling, a sign or a glimpse, that "something wicked this way comes" — or might come.
examples: An extraordinary song, sombre and foreboding, alluding to both a serial child murderer in Düsseldorf in the early 1930s and to the rise of nazism.
Perhaps, at that point, a sense of foreboding descended upon him.
Her entire physicality is one of worry and foreboding, an air of impending doom that is telegraphed by a man carrying a “Jeremiah 11:11” sign in the film’s disquieting prologue.
The late Frenchman’s abstract paintings that are now on display, with titles like “One June early morning” – a nod to D-Day – and “fire”, are colorful, emotional and foreboding.

definition: not of prime or central importance
details: Incidental means secondary in time or importance. If you lose weight because you moved and must walk further to school, the weight loss was incidental to the move.
examples: The question is: Who decides what counts as “merely incidental”? Traditionally, the Senate relies on rulings from the Senate Parliamentarian.
While the word “incidental” is open to some degree of interpretation, it’s a real limitation.
Lots of things in everyday life throw off incidental rays of affirmation.
The attention seemed hazardously premature, as though Fike’s superstardom was a foregone conclusion, and incidental to whatever music he ended up producing.

definition: a small or moderate or token amount
details: If you want to describe a small amount of something, try modicum. If you have a modicum of interest in something, you are a little bit interested.
examples: It is about returning a bare modicum of accountability to American public life after years of congressional Republicans shirking their constitutional duty to hold the executive branch to account.
It's like I'm slowly gaining a modicum of respect.
The president of the United States not only lies routinely, but he believes other people’s lies without a modicum of skepticism.
Once more, a modicum of political nous is all that is required: understanding how retrograde, conservative views proliferate among very rich white people shouldn’t be this much of a stretch.

definition: a flowery and highly rhetorical address
details: If you attend a political convention, be prepared to hear a peroration — a long, lofty speech. If the speech really drags on, you might find yourself hoping for its peroration, as peroration can also refer to a speech's conclusion.
examples: In the press gallery, I was struggling to understand some senator’s flowery peroration.
Sometimes, of course, these perorations are quite personal.
In a striking peroration, Breyer reminded his colleagues that “at heart,” the issues before them “are simple”:
It is perhaps the most famous peroration of the second world war.

definition: the act of improving by renewing and restoring
details: Renovation is the act of renewing or restoring something. If your kitchen is undergoing a renovation, there’s probably plaster and paint all over the place and you should probably get take-out.
examples: Grachos served as director of the Contemporary Austin for six years, steering a renovation and expansion of the museum’s downtown space, the Jones Center on Congress Avenue.
Prosecutors say he used the money to buy luxury vehicles, country club memberships, vacations and home renovations.
The renovation calls for demolishing four existing buildings on the museum’s sprawling Wilshire Boulevard campus west of downtown Los Angeles.
The team will no longer play at “The Q,” but inside Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse, which is undergoing a $185 million renovation funded by the city and team.

definition: kill intentionally and with premeditation
details: Slay means to kill in a violent way. It has a mythic quality. You might slay the red knight. You might slay the dragon. You might slay the demon. But you probably wouldn't slay an annoying mosquito.
examples: A new Nipsey Hussle shooting mystery: Authorities now say a gunman injured two women at memorial vigil a day after the rapper’s slaying.
The double slaying was a major case in the Virginia Beach area, prompting the department to assign nearly all of its detectives to the case in 1973, according to an Associated Press report.

The lawsuit says the corrections department and halfway house did not immediately report the escape, and says authorities also failed to use Micheli’s social media posts to track him down before the slaying.
Police did not say how they linked Broadnax to the slayings.

definition: large deep serving dish with a cover
details: If a waiter brought a big, deep serving dish to your table, removed its lid, and began ladling soup into your bowl, you could confidently call the dish a tureen.
examples: “Good evening, brood,” Less Ellen greeted them, carrying a tureen from the kitchen.
Then he carried a tray over to our table with three lidded tin tureens on it, and started banging the tureens down.
The kitchen table was laid with homemade bread, butter, jam, a tureen of dried lamb tallow, and a haunch of fermented lamb.
I still remember the first gift I bought for my mom with my own money: a white porcelain soup tureen.

definition: associated by chance and not an integral part
details: Adventitious is a word you use to talk about things that "just kind of happen," not because you are trying to do them, but because they just come along.
examples: Karhiders eat four solid meals a day, breakfast, lunch, dinner, supper, along with a lot of adventitious nibbling and gobbling in between.
The great thing about tomatoes is that they form adventitious roots all along their stems, so overgrown seedlings, well watered, may still develop great root systems and bear lots of fruit.
Many commenters suggested that we establish a “threshold” for the unintended or adventitious presence of products of excluded methods in organic products.
But the most adventitious source of revenue was the North Sea – a source to which one Thatcherite would refer as "what we are using to finance unemployment".

definition: move or swing back and forth
details: To brandish something is to wave it about aggressively, as one might brandish a sword or tennis racket (if it's a particularly intense game).
examples: Faith groups brandished banners and made pleas for religious tolerance.
A few weeks later, Ashton, a seventeen-year-old with duct tape holding his sneakers together and a buzz cut, brandished a drawing of the earth with the caption, “I’m with her.”
The Department for Transport brandished the red card after concluding that the firm’s bids to run trains on the East Midlands, South Eastern and West Coast franchises were “non-compliant”.
Then he brandished a knife, swinging it in one victim’s direction and striking the other across the face, the complaint said.

definition: wearing or provided with clothing
details: Clad means "dressed or covered." Most kids go to school clad in jeans and t-shirts, but students in the Shakespeare club might show up clad in velvet gowns or leather breeches.
examples: Jokes, clips and footage related to India’s movie industry dominate the platform, along with videos in which young people, sometimes scantily clad, lip-sync and dance to music.
In one, three nuns, clad in heavy habits, hoed a field of tobacco.
The ruling Socialist Party staged a rival march in Caracas on Saturday but turnout was sparse, with just a few hundred people clad in red shirts and red baseball caps banging drums and dancing salsa.
The Green Bay Press-Gazette reports the memorial also contained inaccurate flight numbers for the downed planes and deteriorated in part because it was clad in indoor marble.

definition: an instrumentality invented for a particular purpose
details: A device is really anything that has a specific use. It might be a tool or object, or a plan that is devised to accomplish something. If it has a purpose, it is a device.
examples: They’re looking to get access to his electronic devices, letting them examine his private investigator’s allegation that Saudi Arabia obtained private information from his phone.
The plaintiffs also said the companies continued selling the faulty devices while failing to acknowledge the issue.
The device also features a 3″ speaker for robust audio production and ten unique, non-looping sound programs, each with their own richness levels.
The PGA Tour relented on its phone ban in 2011, asking spectators to put the devices on silent mode so as not to distract players.

definition: consume all of one's attention or time
details: Engage means to bind, catch, or involve. If your sink is stopped up, engage, or hire, a plumber to fix it. Otherwise the smell of rotten food in the garbage disposal will engage your attention (in a bad way).
examples: Russia and Belarus are allies with close political, economic and military ties, but they regularly engage in vociferous trade arguments.
Society will continue to be engaged in this case simply because it shook the foundation of what we understand to be normal and acceptable.
Christopher Henry Alexander Davis, 29, of Herndon, Va., reportedly engaged in a physical struggle with Secret Service officers after they tried to handcuff him.
“Young women are different now than when I was younger. Everyone is involved, civically engaged, and informed. I think that’s also why the show is doing so well.”

definition: seeing ahead; knowing in advance; foreseeing
details: Use the noun foresight to describe successful planning for the future. When it starts raining hard during your long walk to school, you'll wish you had the foresight to bring an umbrella.
examples: Somewhat hidden in the news of the snowmaking expansion is the foresight shown years ago by resort executives.
But it might be too much to expect Congress to move with foresight and wisdom in applying the brakes at the right time.
In the meantime, Carroll and Schneider deserve some credit for their foresight.

“Designer brands are gradually realising they must lose their haughty image if they want to sell their clothes to a generation consumed by the internet,” says Holly Friend, foresight writer at The Future Laboratory.

definition: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
details: Incipient means something is in an early stage of existence. In its incipient form, basketball was played with a soccer ball and peach baskets for goals. Bouncy orange balls and nets came later.
examples: First among equals at this are Ms. LaVoy and Mr. Brannon, who seem to carry the incipient knowledge of social change in their exquisitely modulated parries and retreats.
I confess: back in the 1970s, I was a tumour immunologist, entranced by the idea that incipient cancers are constantly erupting in our bodies and routinely culled by our own immune systems.

The government crackdown on incipient protests following Guaido’s declaration of an “interim” government shook not only La Vega, but also other traditionally pro-government zones, including the sprawling Petare district in eastern Caracas.

He points to a recent example of incipient authoritarianism – the young men from Covington Catholic college in Kentucky who hooted and taunted in the face of a Native American man on the National Mall.

definition: cause to be more favorably inclined
details: To mollify is to calm someone down, talk them off the ledge, make amends, maybe even apologize.
examples: In other words, Nielsen’s alleged heroism seems to lie chiefly in the fact that she didn’t break international or domestic law fast enough to mollify a president who doesn’t believe in international or domestic law.
The fear was mollified a few days after the accident when then-President Jimmy Carter, trained as a nuclear engineer in the Navy, visited the plant and calmed the tattered nerves of residents.
Subtle strains of guitar at the end only mollify so much.
The combat served as a kind of mollifying spell, to tide them over through the daily humiliations.

definition: perform an act, usually with a negative connotation
details: It's possible to perpetrate a good deed, but not likely. That's because perpetrate means to commit or be responsible for something — usually something mischievous or bad.
examples: The Democrat said the alleged arson was perpetrated by a "depraved individual", adding: "Hate is not a Louisiana value."
However, another part of the speech surfaced on social media this week in which Omar described the terror attacks perpetrated by Al Qaeda.
But another part of the speech surfaced on social media earlier this week, in which Omar described the terror attacks perpetrated by al Qaeda.
But as Pompeo warned Monday, the Revolutionary Guard’s leaders are masters of “nationwide con artistry and corruption . . . which they perpetrate against the regime’s own people.”

definition: the food served and eaten at one time
details: Whether it's a sumptuous feast you're sitting down to or just a simple bite to eat, repast is just another word for "meal."
examples: But the dissonance between respect and repast in Southern California goes beyond Farmer John’s murals.
Later in the day, everyone gathered for a last repast at a bar and grille in Secaucus.
Still, anticipating the Jerusalem repast, Mitchell Davis, the Beard Foundation’s chief strategy officer, said “all these Israeli places abroad, they lack brightness, a quality you find here.”
We snagged a bottle, as well as three jams Luke liked, and headed into the city for a midday repast.

definition: adroitness in using the hands
details: The noun sleight refers to being able to use your hands with ease, especially when doing a trick. Sleight is often used in the phrase "sleight of hand." If you are a good magician, you can make a coin disappear with sleight of hand.
examples: But soon, it seemed like a sleight of hand, all of it -- or maybe just hand flailing.

The judge accused Mr. Manafort of a sleight of hand throughout the criminal proceeding against him, including wrongly inflating his assets in a bail hearing and exaggerating the harshness of his conditions in jail.
A proposal from the conservative Alabama Policy Institute, based in Birmingham, indulges in similar wishful thinking and sleight of hand.
And though “The Once and Future Worker” offers a rousing call for an honest reckoning with American economic policy, it also indulges in its own sleight of hand.

definition: ostentatiously lofty in style
details: Turgid describes something that's swollen, typically by fluids, like a turgid water balloon that's way too big to resist dropping on your friend's head.
examples: The manner in which he went about trying to do so at Ipswich led to a major falling-out with the club’s fans who did not appreciate what they saw as turgid tactics.
It was kind of, I thought, turgid and melodramatic.
The subsequent process to hire Gregg Berhalter took almost a year and felt turgid, poorly organized, and only ever focused on one candidate – it was hardly a comforting first step into a new era.
The purpose of this “borrowed boats” strategy may also be to lend credibility to the content, since it’s not clear how many readers actually bother to open these turgid, propaganda-heavy supplements.

definition: someone who offers opposition
details: An adversary is an enemy or someone who opposes someone else. In tennis, you stand across the net from your adversary.
examples: Avenatti became one of Trump’s leading adversaries, attacking him on cable news programs and Twitter.
This time, testifying before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, the attorney general made headlines for comments suggesting he would investigate the president’s political adversaries.
We want the agency to be viewed as a resource, not an adversary.
“It’s not just competition against our adversaries,” Pence said.

definition: the trait of possessing muscular strength
details: Brawn means muscular strength. Brawn is thought of as the opposite of brains, but let’s face it — people can be strong and smart! No matter how smart you are, though, you must have big muscles to have brawn.
examples: Their game is a different kind of beautiful, one based on brawn and beating a man to his spot.
I guess Steve is all brawn and no brain, but honestly: these are not “compromises” – these are “realities”.
Porter didn’t always need brawn to best the Wizards.
But while that Italian term translates as “loudest,” brawn should be matched by character.

definition: someone who can perceive things not present to the senses
details: If you can predict the future, you may want to keep your clairvoyant powers to yourself. Otherwise everyone will be knocking down your door asking for the next winning lotto numbers.
examples: And what of his own clairvoyant character, last seen dropping the bombshell of Jon Snow’s parentage?
He once posed as an undercover clairvoyant to infiltrate the Psychic Friends Network, which became popular as late-night infomercials that offered psychic readings over the phone in the 1990s.
He logged multiple hours on the case, he says, following through on vague leads, many of them from self-proclaimed clairvoyants that ultimately led nowhere.
She was like, ‘No… of the United States,'” King recalled, adding that she thought the woman was a clairvoyant.

definition: grow worse
details: You've probably heard that organisms evolve over time. Well, life is complicated, and sometimes things devolve instead — to devolve is to get worse instead of better.
examples: This convoluted and unworkable plan continues to devolve as bill sponsors now try to appease business-lobby critics who will likely never sign onto any kind of family leave legislation.
Separating parents from their children at the border last year devolved into a humanitarian crisis and a public-relations nightmare.
This debate devolved into an “edit war,” a heated back-and-forth in which Wikipedians continuously edit an article to overwrite the other side’s changes and reflect the language they want.
Most of the projects failed or devolved into litigation by angry bankers and investors because huge sums of money were missing.

definition: call forth
details: Engender is a fancy way of saying "to make happen," like when you engender the spirit of teamwork and cooperation by encouraging others and doing your share of the group's work.
examples: And as her mother explained, Ogunbowale engenders a two-way connection, something of particular import for W.N.B.A. teams hoping to win both on the court and at the box office.
Does our narcissistic culture engender the sort of person we last saw strolling along a wooded path lost in thought?
The titles I chose were not so much intended to frame my intellectual landscape as to provide a frisson or engender a laugh.
The reason is that there is good evidence that the quantum theory of gravity will itself engender big violations of locality.

definition: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
details: It takes a bit of planning to forestall something, meaning stop it from happening. To forestall the effects of aging, exercise and take care of your health all your life.
examples: And this support forestalls the possibility of a serious nomination challenge in the upcoming presidential election.
Greater scrutiny from regulators may be required to forestall far greater problems.
This isn’t meant to forestall critiques of the ways violence is used in action stories.
To forestall Armageddon, we must pass the freshman congresswoman’s radical “Green New Deal.”

definition: demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
details: The adjective incisive describes something that is sharp, decisive, and direct. A comment that cuts right to the bone can be just as incisive as an actual knife.
examples: The acclaimed singer-producer will bring his smoldering tracks and incisive lyrics to the Roxy stage for a set that promises to be infectious and unfamiliar..
As it drives home that point, this production benefits from the incisive performances of Rocky Nunzio and Patrick Joy in the lead roles.
Though the commentary is incisive, the film’s loose structure often leaves the viewer feeling adrift watching a bunch of beautiful teens bicker and get busy.
Kerber held her serve throughout the second set, winning rallies with perseverance and incisive shot placement.

definition: an impelling force or strength
details: Momentum is generally used to mean increasing forward motion. A boulder rolling down a hill gains momentum. So does a great idea, a team on a winning streak, or the economy.
examples: Moon said Thursday it was imperative to continue momentum toward a third summit, and soon.
The protests gained momentum last week after Algeria's President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, in power for 20 years, resigned in response to similar demonstrations.
The protests gain momentum after the resignation earlier in the week by Algeria’s President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, in power for 20 years, in response to similar demonstrations.
A last thought from Dr. Sturm, who, for all of her momentum, cautioned that G-Beauty is a marketing concept and that nationality doesn’t tell you if a product is “clean.”

definition: continuing forever or indefinitely
details: Use the adjective perpetual to describe something that never ends or changes. If you're a perpetual procrastinator, your dilly-dallying ways are never going to improve.
examples: The work of checking one’s assumptions is continuous, perpetual; there is no end point, no “arriving”.

Lieutenant general Sir Tim Martin’s Devon neighbour lieutenant general Sir Frank Kitson’s Low Intensity Operations was avidly studied by all factions, all in perpetual schism over ideological minutiae invisible to the uninitiated.
Given the perpetual Trump chaos, Meyers said Nielsen’s resignation was not a surprise.
Others claimed lingering shortness of breath and perpetual exhaustion, but almost all said the most searing scars were psychological.

definition: cancel officially
details: To repeal something — usually a law, ordinance or public policy — is to take it back. For example, dog lovers might want the town council to repeal the law that says residents can have no more than four dogs.
examples: The Senate will vote on the repeal of Don’t Ask Don’t Tell as early as Saturday, according to Majority Leader Harry Reid.
The Senate vote Thursday was 17-6, with five Republicans joining 12 Democrats voting in favor of repeal.
The one exception was in 2016, when Vermont senator Bernie Sanders – locked in a battle with Hillary Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination – called for repealing the welfare reform law.
During the FCC’s repeal effort, millions of Americans wrote the agency in staunch support of the government’s rules, spurred on by Web activists and the likes of HBO’s John Oliver.

definition: a large number or amount or extent
details: Of all the many nouns referring to a large group of things, one of the most fun is slew, as in "I saw a whole slew of birds in the tree by the river."
examples: In the meantime, a slew of state governments began writing and implementing net neutrality protections of their own.
“When I look at the big picture, I see a slew of people newly active politically,” Toltz said.
He then went on to win the event and secure the final spot in this year’s Masters — along with a slew of other perks.
The actress plays Villanelle, a Russian assassin on the drama series and is forced to do a slew of varied accents and languages.

definition: attention and management implying responsibility for safety
details: If you babysit and tutor younger children after school, the kids are under your tutelage. You are responsible for their care and education.
examples: Under his tutelage, Tampa Bay advanced to three conference finals in the last four years and reached the Stanley Cup finals in 2015.
As her character begins to pursue a life of crime under J.D.’s tutelage, she transitions to the deconstructed garb of the outlaw: turtlenecks, sunglasses, soft-shouldered jackets.
His training was under the tutelage of his father, a blue-collar steelworker, who pushed him to be a “can’t-miss” prospect.

They develop an easygoing chemistry throughout “Captain Marvel,” in which Jackson and Clark Gregg — who plays a newbie agent under his tutelage — are smoothly de-aged through the miracle of digital technology.

definition: contrary to your interests or welfare
details: Steer clear of anything adverse. If it's adverse, it's working against you — like adverse weather conditions or the adverse effects of eating too much sugar.
examples: The flight on March 15 was “interrupted earlier than planned due to adverse weather conditions”, an Airbus spokeswoman said.
“Asthma is only one of the multiple adverse effects of pollution on children’s health. Governments must act now to protect children.”
—Mike Lange, the longtime broadcaster for the Pittsburgh Penguins, will miss the start of the playoffs after suffering an adverse reaction to medication for pneumonia.
“The adverse events from getting measles, they’re very, very, very low,” Dr. Lawrence Palevsky, a pediatrician in New York, said on the recent conference call.

definition: unrestrained by convention or propriety
details: With brazen disregard for the sign that said "no cellphones please" the woman took a long call in the doctor's office waiting room. Brazen refers to something shocking, done shamelessly.
examples: "Nearly 3,000 Americans lost their lives to Islamic terrorists on 9/11, yet Omar diminishes it as: 'Some people did something.' Democrat leaders need to condemn her brazen display of disrespect."
Binney recalls an agent responding that such brazen spying didn’t happen in America.
"Democrat leaders need to condemn her brazen display of disrespect."
The incident happened in Clackamas around 10:30 a.m. when the man made a "brazen entry" into the home through the doggie door that was captured on a surveillance camera.

definition: conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods
details: Use the adjective clandestine to describe something that is done in secret, like your clandestine attempts to steal your brother's Halloween candy.
examples: We are injured and sometimes killed by clandestine procedures.
Bachelet said the U.N. would be willing to help Mexico integrate its forensic files on the country’s 40,000 missing people, and strengthen its capacity to find clandestine graves and identify bodies.

In the closing months of Barack Obama’s presidency — at the height of a national election — high-level government officials with access to terrifying loads of clandestine information about American citizens began spying on domestic political opponents.
The team works in the former Naval Mechanics School, which was a notorious clandestine detention and torture center that held an estimated 5,000 prisoners and is now a museum for remembrance.

definition: an ornamental jeweled headdress signifying sovereignty
details: A diadem is a crown, or something on a crown. If you’ve just won the Miss America pageant, reach up your hand — that’s right — that rhinestone encrusted circlet on your head? That’s a diadem.
examples: I remove the diadem and set it in front of her.

She writes of “glimpses of sea and plain through the lattices of the gallery,” she describes gowns the colors of peach blossoms and lilac, and a little girl wearing a “jewelled diadem” over “pearl-woven braids.”
Evoking the coronas of blazing suns, the earflares would flank faces further graced with towering gold diadems and, most unfamiliarly, substantial nose ornaments.
“Well, there’s her lost diadem. I told you about it, remember, Harry? The lost diadem of Ravenclaw? Daddy’s trying to duplicate it.”

definition: consume all of one's attention or time
details: Engross is a verb that means to consume all of your attention or time. Once you engross yourself in the culture of high salaries and unlimited spending accounts, it's hard to go back to cooking at a sandwich shop.
examples: Until there is a miniseries, however, there is Mark Lamster’s engrossing biography, “Philip Johnson: The Man in the Glass House,” published by Little, Brown late last year.
The final work in the Pace show is a drawing of a man in a tower, engrossed in his work, while a bomber strikes the landscape outside.
I was disappointed, but as I started to engross myself in learning more about the mysteries of the brain, I replaced my passion for magic with psychology.
His meandering captions, which add up to an engrossing memoir of a life in fashion, triggered a jump in engagement.

definition: characteristic of or befitting a person in authority
details: Being formal is all about being taken seriously. If you're invited to the White House, you'll want to make a good impression, so it's a good idea to adopt a generally formal demeanor. No jeans or trash talking allowed.
examples: "I just wanted to do something that is clean and formal," she says, "and also, just with books."

"In the last Congress, the Committee on Ways and Means issued a formal report concerning a House resolution of inquiry seeking information substantially similar to the information you request," Mnuchin wrote.
In the absence of a formal route to get rid of May that does not risk a general election, Conservative lawmakers are looking at alternative ways to apply pressure.
Other strikes followed, but the workers were careful to not elect any formal leadership.

definition: severe, of weather
details: Inclement usually refers to severe or harsh weather that is cold and wet. When packing for a trip to the Caribbean bring tank tops and shorts, but don't forget a raincoat in case of inclement weather.
examples: WSU typically plays one or two games every year in inclement weather.

The Aspen Times reports Aspen Chamber Resort Association President Debbie Braun said Tuesday that the association instead will opt for a drone show, which was the plan last year before inclement weather nixed the show.
The match was delayed an hour at halftime due to inclement weather.
That off day after a team’s home opener was put into place for situations like this — inclement weather protection.

definition: relating to or involving money
details: If it has to do with money or currency, it’s monetary, like your childhood toy collection that has no monetary value, but you love it nonetheless.
examples: Singapore decides on monetary policy and releases GDP data Friday.
Similarly, Moore might be right that the Fed would function better if it bound monetary policy to a prudent rule.
Between those charges and his slender credentials as a monetary policy expert, it’s small wonder that even senators from a Trump-dominated party would hesitate to embrace a Cain nomination.
Reached by phone Monday, Cain said: “This is supposed to be about monetary policy. This is supposed to be about the Federal Reserve. It is not supposed to be about eight-year-old accusations.”

definition: continue to exist
details: When someone persists they keep going or hang on. If you want finish a marathon, you have to persist and keep running, no matter how many blisters you have.
examples: One genetic change that did largely persist six months after Scott returned to Earth affected his chromosomes.
Blizzard conditions persisted in the northeast corner of Colorado Thursday morning, but blizzard warnings were dropped for the rest of the state and Wyoming.
But fraudulent accounts persist – and sometimes they are operated by law enforcement agencies.

In a country where the myth of academic meritocracy persists despite plenty of evidence to the contrary, many people were shocked to learn that the education system was rife with illegal and unethical conduct.

definition: express discontent
details: The verb repine describes expressing gloom or discontent. Brooding, fretful, and sad — these are the traits of people who repine at their circumstances in life.
examples: She whispered a poem: “The storm is past, no more repining Behold! the gentle sun is shining” “Yeah,” muttered Charles, “but the track is still too heavy for Seabiscuit.”
Far from repining in the sheltered world of the rectory, she was surrounded by sensational, exotic, dramatic life.
Yet why repine where so much is left?
