Spare no pains, and repine at no difficulty.

definition: pour as if from a conduit that carries a rapid flow of water
details: Anything that resembles a water slide with a gate is a sluice — a narrow channel that controls water flow.
examples: Outside in front of the station the stream roars alongside the street, it rushes foaming from the sluices of the mill bridge.
At Eightmile dam, the Jantzers use scuba equipment to dive down and attach a winch to a sluice gate and alter its release.
She emptied and sluiced the bedpans, swept and polished floors, made cocoa and Bovril, fetched and carried—and was delivered from introspection.
As for Uefa, and indeed everyone else involved in trying to sluice a little extra cash from the world’s great shared sporting obsession, the message should be taken on board.

definition: someone new to a field or activity
details: A tyro is a beginner, a new recruit, or someone who is just learning something. If you are the new guy at the job and you're wearing a big dorky badge that says "Trainee" on it, you are a tyro.
examples: Tutor and tyro practiced together at Seminole some years.
This is what happens when Trump outsources diplomacy to a naive tyro like Jared Kushner--he gets played, and by extension the United States gets played.
"I fell into almost every trap awaiting the tyro writer."
It’s what a master would tell a tyro in just about any field, and I took the counsel seriously.

definition: a state of misfortune or affliction
details: When circumstances or situations work against you, you face adversity. Refugees from war-torn countries encounter terrible adversity.
examples: The dinner Friess referred to was the 2019 Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans banquet, which honored students who've overcome “economic adversity.”
Through such adversity, he gained wisdom not just about basketball but about life.
“Everybody deals with adversity in different ways,” he said.
Talk about flourishing in the face of adversity.

definition: a decorative pin
details: That fancy pin your Grandma used to wear on her blouse or lapel? It's a brooch, held in place by a sharp needle clasp.
examples: Her attire, however, was festooned with a golden brooch in the shape of the House mace — an ancient symbol of power.
When an expert told him it was a Celtic harness decoration and not a medieval brooch, he realised there might be more.
She was B. Tallis, not, as it said on the little rectangular brooch, N. Tallis.
Dazzling jewels encrusted on clothes, chokers, tiaras, brooches, headgear, swords and daggers capture the opulence of the Rathores.

definition: loud and clear
details: If you hear the clarion call of the stage, it means you want to be an actor. Clarion means loud and clear, and a clarion call is a call to something that is hard to ignore.
examples: That became a clarion call for the Seminoles.
It wasn’t just a physical barrier on the south border, it was a clarion call to racists and bigots.
It’s a quiet little movie that speaks the truth like a clarion call.
President Trump’s proposal to create a Space Force is a clarion call for future wars in space.

definition: thunderous verbal attack
details: It's pretty overwhelming when you ask your friend a seemingly innocuous question, like "Do you like hot dogs?" and she unleashes a diatribe about the evils of eating meat. A diatribe is an angry, critical speech.
examples: The main target of his diatribes, Iran, is often compared to biblical enemies and even the Nazis.
In their public debates, he said, while Mr. Corbyn stuck to diatribes about poverty, but Mrs. May was often “banging on about him personally.”
The governor at times was cut off when he tried to respond, with one Republican declaring he didn’t want to hear “an anti-coal diatribe.”
He toted a weapon and appeared — at least in his Internet posts — to buy into the militant’s embrace of violence and anti-Western diatribes.

definition: increase
details: Many people use the expression "enhance your chance" to point out ways to increase your chances of winning or earning a contest or prize. When you enhance something, you heighten it or make it better.
examples: Senators opposing the bill praised many aspects of it, including enhanced threat assessment requirements.
Justice Thomas, who goes to Mass every day before he starts work, said judges swear an oath, and swearing before God “actually enhances your view of the oath.”

But commissioners concluded that there are substantial benefits for Maine, as well, including reduced carbon pollution, lower electric rates and enhanced energy reliability, along with $258 million in incentives.
The company will also maintain an independent and confidential whistleblowing hotline and enhance oversight of both people and cultural matters at board level.

definition: leave someone who needs or counts on you; leave in the lurch
details: To forsake another person is to leave them entirely, usually in a moment of need.
examples: “The Lord himself goes before you and will be with you; he will never leave you nor forsake you. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged.”
But Hines’ foray into expansion mode, followed by the decision to forsake it, sets her apart.
She cheered Amazon’s decision to forsake New York for friendlier climes, taking at least 25,000 jobs with it.
Some will put all of their energy and effort into the game from an early age, forsaking schoolwork and intellectual development.

definition: at an angle to the horizontal or vertical position
details: If you're inclined to do something, you want to do it, you like doing it, and you may even have an inherent talent for doing it. Alternatively, if the sidewalk outside your house is inclined, that means it slopes upward.
examples: While many leaders said they were inclined to grant a Brexit delay, Macron expressed reservations, warning as he arrived at the summit that “nothing is decided.”
"But there is one noticeable generational split. The youngest of voters are far more inclined to say, 'hands off.'"
Davis remains under contract for another season, but the Pelicans may be inclined to deal him before the draft to maximize rebuilding options.

Even those readers who are inclined to engage deeply and broadly with the news are constrained by social-media filter bubbles, within which agreeable content, posted by people in their networks, is prioritized.

definition: sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch
details: When something goes on and on and on and on and on, the same way, for a long time, that's monotonous. Monotonous things are boring and repetitive, like that long story you've heard your brother tell a hundred times before.
examples: It was the sort of grinding, monotonous work where you moved from office to office, week after week, and no one really talked to you because you’d soon be gone.

The Rotten Tomatoes scores may insist that first is worse, but watching Fred Gwynne nail a Maine accent and spout cheesy dialogue is much more entertaining than this movie's monotonous series of lame jump scares.
Everything was as monotonous as a screen saver, until the hosts began talking about persecution.
Heatherwick chose it to break up the monotonous grey Manhattan skyline.

definition: stubbornly unyielding
details: If something is persistent, it just won't stop. If you're persistent in your suggestions for a trip to Mexico, maybe your parents will eventually give in and take you there.
examples: Addressing reporters at the start of the retreat Wednesday, Democratic leaders highlighted the historic diversity of the freshman class and played down any notion of persistent division.

“Comprehensive and persistent policy in these areas will contribute to increasing the standard of living for all population segments and to reducing inequality in the economy,” it said in its 2018 review.
Watch Texas Tech play defense, with its persistent switching on screens, and its disciplined funneling of dribblers toward the baseline.

These span decades of black-and-white photography and suggest a persistent and unsurprising consistency in our relationship to photographs: We use them to assert our existence, to mark our place in the world.

definition: fill something that had previously been emptied
details: To replenish something is to refill it. If you have a pet pooch, you’re probably obligated to replenish his food bowl to avoid being barked at incessantly.
examples: In a bid to save on labor costs, it’s betting on robots to clean floors, sort inventory, and replenish out-of-stock items in its stores, as reported by The Wall Street Journal.
The brain is not a muscle, he said, but it does need to rest and replenish like a muscle does.
In his “Ornithological Biography,” Audubon records a staggering massacre of thousands of passenger pigeons with similar remove, noting only that the birds will quickly replenish themselves.
He often cared less about the sports than about sports as a mode of guy talk, a morality play, a ground for argument, replenished each day.

definition: a small number or amount
details: A smattering is a small but inexact amount of something. If you know a smattering of things about Australia, then you don't know much.
examples: The only smattering of graffiti was barely visible, beside the tracks.
The upshot is there is always a smattering of players who logged meaningful minutes returning.
The kids all rushed in, mostly girls and a smattering of Magic: The Gathering boys.
No longer is the weekend a celebrity Super Bowl on the Potomac with a smattering of actual journalists gawking from the sidelines.

definition: make reference to
details: This one's easy. An advert is an advertisement: just shorten advertisement, and you get advert. Of course, as a verb, to advert to something means to refer to it.
examples: The regulator said it received six complaints after the advert was broadcast on TV, video on demand and Instagram in December.
Facebook explained that because the post in question was an advert, it was subject to stricter standards than normal posts.
The food chain apologised, conceding the advert was “insensitive and does not reflect our brand values regarding diversity and inclusion.”
In the latter case, a Swiss court ruled that the advert was not a call to murder but covered by artistic freedom of expression.

definition: a natural stream of water smaller than a river
details: A brook is a small stream. On a hot day, you might enjoy wading in a babbling brook. As a verb, brook is a rather stuffy word for "put up with." The lord of the manor might say, "I will brook no trespassing on my land."
examples: The Department of Environmental Management is releasing 75,000 brook, brown and rainbow trout for opening day Saturday.
Pax peered over the edge and saw a silver brook, studded with black stones, glinting between green reeds and purple blossoms.
He visited the frescoes at the Basilica of St. Francis, in Assisi, and was transfixed by the mountain brook in one of them, which seemed as real as the wall.
Forest officials say access to area snowmobile trails, a pond, brook, and hiking trails are now protected.

definition: separate or cut with a tool, such as a sharp instrument
details: Cleave, a verb, has two very different meanings. It can describe cutting or splitting something apart with a sharp instrument, or — oddly enough — it can describe sticking to something like glue.
examples: The great hemlock bough lay across Gray’s chest, cleaved from the tree.
Apartheid cleaved countless fathers from their families, forcing men from rural households to the cities in which they toiled as migrant laborers.
“The Troubles” seems incommensurate — euphemistic even — as a descriptor of the social fission that cleaved apart Northern Ireland in the late 20th century.

For years after, Jackson’s pop-star persona was permanently cleaved in two — music fans continued to enjoy the art of Michael Jackson, the supremely creative entertainer of the “Thriller” era, while grappling uncomfortably with the allegations.

definition: a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses
details: A dichotomy is an idea or classification split in two. When you point out a dichotomy, you draw a clear distinction between two things.
examples: It’s also important to beware of false dichotomies.
Friedman suggested the dichotomy between his strategy in Tampa Bay and Los Angeles was “more circumstantial than anything philosophical.”
But … should you happen to consider the cranial dichotomy that is the mullet — “business up front, party in the back” — the element of extreme contrast is somewhat similar.

More than most other European art filmmakers of her generation, Denis rejects the usual dichotomy of humanism versus nihilism; elements of both recur throughout her filmography, often in the same film.

definition: something that baffles understanding and cannot be explained
details: Use the noun enigma to refer to something that is a puzzle or a mystery. Why do you have to learn difficult words like this? That is an enigma.
examples: LOL at the idea of Aaron being an enigma but yeah.
And each purified sentence is itself a story, a kind of suspended enigma.
Harnik got the shot — a portrait of a man, half masked by the shadow of his rearview mirror, his lips flat and inscrutable — one of the first new photos of an enigma in months.
The hoarse reply that emerges from her doppelgänger’s throat—“We’re Americans”—is one of many enigmas that stay with you after seeing Us, the new horror movie from writer-director Jordan Peele.

definition: strength of mind that enables one to endure adversity
details: Fortitude refers to strength in the face of adversity or difficulty. Eating fried worms might require a lot of intestinal fortitude.
examples: The multilingual thesp emanates the colossal fortitude of someone who’s shed her last teardrop, but salvaged enough hope to carry on and morph into a stone-faced combatant.
He is convinced of the mental fortitude provided by the momentum he gained last season when he held a final-round lead at the British Open, contended late in the P.G.A.
They credit Mr. Netanyahu, whose strategic vision values power and fortitude above all, with piloting Israel to unprecedented diplomatic heights and believe still more is possible.
Though far from an exercise in consistency, it was one of fortitude, and one that's been long in the making for the journeyman.

definition: encompassing much or everything
details: Call something inclusive when it's designed or inclined to include. An exclusive club might let you in, but an inclusive one will ask you to join, no strings attached.
examples: We will be curious and sincere in our attempt; we will welcome new voices to work alongside the exceptional team already in place to create a conversation that is inclusive, expansive and smart.
And let’s replace Hardin’s flawed metaphor with an inclusive vision for humanity—one based on democratic governance and cooperation in this time of darkness.
She says women should continue to “rock the boat” and redefine the message that’s positive, ambitious, inclusive and “brimming with hope.”
This will help drive economic inclusive and sustainable growth and create a more cohesive and stable social fabric.”

definition: of no legal significance, as having been previously decided
details: When a point is moot, it's too trivial to think about. If your basketball team loses by 40 points, the bad call by the official in the first quarter is moot: it isn't important.
examples: The status change rendered the investigation moot, since retired judges are not subject to the conduct rules.
It’s for a plan that will almost certainly be rendered moot when the EU rejects it Wednesday.
All of this may soon be moot, though.
Although this victory was a minor one — it became moot once the FBI’s computerized National Instant Criminal Background Check System went online in 1998 — Mack found a national platform.

definition: transparently clear; easily understandable
details: Perspicuous is an adjective describing language that is clear and easy to understand. When you give a presentation, you should speak in a perspicuous manner so that everyone will be able to follow you.
examples: One must be extremely exact, clear, and perspicuous, in everything one says, otherwise, instead of entertaining, or informing others, one only tires and puzzles them.
There is one thing in the world that must always be faultlessly perspicuous and distinct, and that is a marching order in time of battle.
His descriptions of the Rickets, Rupture, Rheumatism, Scrophula, Dropsy, Scurvy, &c. are equally perspicuous and perfect.
In explaining and defending the doctrines and precepts of Christianity he was calm, perspicuous, and often very ingenious.

definition: repeat an earlier theme of a composition
details: Reprise means "repeat an earlier role." If you’re asked to reprise your role as "kid entertainer" at the annual family reunion, that means people want you to do it again this year.
examples: The episode’s other song is a very brief final reprise of “West Covina” that brings the show full circle, with Paula and Rebecca clasping hands over a shared mission.
He also began reprising various promises about what a future plan to repeal and replace parts of the Affordable Care Act might achieve.
“Same Things Twice” reprises the band’s galloping style and another dream-like transition blends it into “I Almost Didn’t Notice,” which is China Crisis-like smooth.
The duo later reprised their role for Netflix’s reboot “Fuller House.”

definition: weep convulsively
details: If you're so upset you're crying loudly, taking in big gasps of air and heaving your chest, you are sobbing.
examples: I was crying, sobbing, saying I would do whatever she wanted.
It’s great that you’ve already found a neutral rebuff to her outrageous comments about your parenting, but I’m concerned that she apparently spends hours afterward moping around your house sobbing.
“Comeoncomeoncomeon,” I’m shouting and sobbing and my lungs hurt and my throat hurts.
As the teens spoke, some attendees sobbed quietly in the crowd, leaning on friends in anguish.

definition: active support of an idea or cause
details: When you give your active support to an idea or cause, you are showing your advocacy for that cause. Your advocacy for an animal rights group might help raise money to save stray pups.
examples: The film will be screened at local children’s advocacy organizations and juvenile centers, where Lockhart plans to organize educational workshops.
Around that time, Mr. Shuchart joined the Center for American Progress, a left-leaning public policy and advocacy group, as a senior fellow focused on immigration issues.
A liberal advocacy group will launch a digital ad campaign against Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in an attempt to get him fired from his position as a professor at George Mason University.
The governor also supports a further lowering of the mandatory starting age to 5, as part of his advocacy for implementing universal full-day kindergarten.

definition: rudely abrupt or blunt in speech or manner
details: If you ask a salesperson for help finding something and all you get in response is a brusque "Everything's out on the shelves," you'll probably take your business elsewhere. A brusque manner of speaking is unfriendly, rude, and very brief.
examples: But there was a catch: They also were measurably numbed to intrusive or brusque touches.
The New Yorker temperament is famously brusque, but I was at fault in this case.
But Stuart Cobbett, a lawyer who sat on McGill’s board of governors with Mr. Butts, said his style was “direct but polite, never brusque.”
Large and somewhat brusque, Barker was a forty-two-year-old psychiatrist with a keen interest in esoteric mental conditions.

definition: change from a liquid to a thickened or solid state
details: When liquid starts to thicken and become solid, it coagulates. When you get a cut, the blood flowing from the wound will coagulate: it will start to clot and form a solid scab so you will stop bleeding.
examples: Plasma infusion is an approved use by the FDA in trauma settings or in patients whose blood doesn’t coagulate.
These cars, in turn, coagulate the arteries of the city, blocking the remaining fleet of buses, causing a downward spiral of decreasing ridership and growing traffic.
Blood coagulates on the ground, and to the side I see about eight or ten inmates hauling bodies into the back of a truck.
Where tofu is coagulated soy milk curds, tempeh is whole cooked soy beans fermented into a savoury “cake”.

definition: an authoritative declaration
details: "You are what you eat" is a dictum, and so is a law requiring you to curb your dog. A dictum is a formal pronouncement, a rule, or a statement that expresses a truth universally acknowledged.
examples: So, 12 years after Mann’s dictum, I am still struggling.
Or do his machinations reflect the slipperier realpolitik of Sun Tzu’s “The Art of the War,” with its famous dictum, “All warfare is based on deception”?
He readily agreed to an editor’s dictum about the parameters of his job.
James’s dictum applies equally well to other sorts of crimes, particularly when the details seem to serve a larger political narrative.

definition: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something
details: To enjoin is to issue an urgent and official order. If the government tells loggers to stop cutting down trees, they are enjoining the loggers to stop.
examples: Public Citizen is seeking "a court order declaring the department's and DeVos's action unlawful and enjoining them from blocking access" to its site.
What would happen is the court would enjoin and then strike down the law.
Three weeks later, the government sued, asking a federal judge to permanently enjoin U.S.

“Further, the Commission should enjoin respondents from any future violations and impose any necessary and appropriate remedies to ensure respondents' future compliance with the Federal Election Campaign Act.”

definition: lucky; occurring by happy chance
details: Fortuitous means by chance, like a lucky accident. If you and your best friend's families happen to go on vacation to the same place at the same time, that’s a fortuitous coincidence!
examples: After the match, Moore joked on social media that the result was “never in doubt” – in response to a clip of her fortuitous shot to save match point.
The Canadiens took the lead with the help of a fortuitous bounce with 5:22 left in the period.
But Berg called this winter a “fortuitous anomaly.”
That Virkenes’ and Aarseth’s relationship ended in paranoid rivalry and hideous violence is, again, either terrible or marketably fortuitous, depending on your outlook.

definition: the quality of disagreeing
details: Incongruity means out of place — something that doesn't fit in its location or situation. The art show patrons couldn't help but chuckle at the incongruity of a toilet sitting in the middle of an exhibition of Renaissance paintings.
examples: Yet this problem of dramatic incongruity appears strangely relevant to the current moment; the intensely self-involved preoccupations of the élite operatic characters render them blind to the casual ferocity of the hard-drinking, war-loving chorus.
Others point to an incongruity in the competencies of scientific and industrial fields.
The latest plan might enable the United States to finally realize their full potential, but only if elected officials resolve the incongruities in their own policies.
The incongruity of the music played at Trump rallies is one of the distinct pleasures of attending these events.

definition: suggesting the horror of death and decay
details: If the first section of the newspaper you read is the obituaries, you could be considered morbid. Morbid is a word used to describe anyone who spends too much time thinking about death or disease.
examples: This morbid game never ends, of course, because new contenders for the title emerge almost daily.
A considerable number of comments under the poll condemned it as a "morbid" idea and said the police should protect everyone's constitutional rights.
But the most pressing reason for seeing Trump’s tax returns isn’t to satisfy morbid curiosity.
Brexit is just one morbid symptom of a diseased, disintegrating social order.

definition: characterized by a lightly saucy or impudent quality
details: This sassy little adjective pert is lively and bold, like your pert best friend who storms in and demands to borrow your favorite jacket.
examples: But each tweet - posted roughly every two minutes for a full hour - was customised into a pert, motivational motto, depending on whom it was targeted at.
Quick: There she is, in her pert maid’s uniform, running lines with her actress employer.
That pert little waxed and styled adornment signals the Belgian detective’s fastidiousness.
Tossing aside her signature pert coolness, she lets us see the flash of fire in Colette’s eyes.

definition: express criticism towards
details: Reproach means to mildly criticize. If you show poor manners at your grandmother's dinner table, she will reproach you.
examples: “Their commitment to ensuring the health and well-being of our neighbors experiencing homelessness is beyond reproach and sets a standard to which everyone should aspire.”
Fox News suspended Ms. Pirro after she questioned a Muslim lawmaker’s loyalty to the United States, a move that prompted Mr. Trump to reproach the network in a series of Twitter posts on Sunday.
But the Max jets continued to fly, reflecting the confidence of Boeing, regulators and pilots that the planes were beyond reproach.
Despite the reproach, Trump seized the opportunity to publicly rebuff Congress and show his commitment to the border wall.

definition: friendly and pleasant
details: When you're sociable, you're willing to talk and be friendly with other people. At a party, it's a good idea to be sociable and make new friends rather than standing off in a corner by yourself.
examples: He remembers the young cellist as a laid-back, sociable guy with baggy shorts and a ponytail.
“While I find most software engineers to be a bit introverted, I thought James was really smart and very sociable and outgoing,” Ms. Tsui said.
He is sociable – his tales tend to involve chains of friends and chance meetings.
But the subjects whose training included acceptance and equanimity were measurably more sociable.

definition: a person who pleads for a person, cause, or idea
details: An advocate (AD-və-kit) is someone who supports a cause, like an advocate for outdoor recess. Advocate (AD-və-kate) is also a verb meaning to speak in favor of, so you can advocate for that outdoor recess by urging your school to play outside!
examples: Taggart advocates removing the Confederate battle emblem from the Mississippi state flag, saying it’s divisive.
The group, which advocates on behalf of wilderness designations in the state, sent workers into the field on several nights in April and July of 2018.
“Trusted pro-life legislators and advocates agree with me that this bill moves our state and the pro-life cause in the wrong direction.”
On March 28th, Obama held a meeting in the White House with five advocates for greater transparency in government.

definition: idyllically rustic
details: As an adjective, bucolic refers to an ideal country life that many yearn for. If your parents wanted to raise you in a bucolic environment, you may find yourself living 45 minutes away from the nearest movie theater or person your age. Not ideal.
examples: For another project, she canvassed the walls of a sitting room, literally, with murals from Harter depicting bucolic rolling hills in the English countryside.
So: We’re somewhere outside the one-stoplight town of Franklin, above a bucolic valley west of the Shenandoah Mountains where hills choked with oak and hickory trees rise and fall like banjo rolls.
For those whose tastes ran to the bucolic, there was a New England barn.
They travel through a landscape that would be bucolic if it weren’t for the destruction wrought by the cyclone.

definition: the shore of a sea or ocean
details: The noun coast describes the area where the land meets the sea — the seashore. When your mom says, "We're going to the coast," pack your bathing suit, because you'll be near the ocean.
examples: In another recent project, archaeologists uncovered an “unprecedented” 7,000-year-old Native American burial site beneath the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Florida.
The Japanese military and coast guard and a United States Navy P-8A maritime patrol aircraft searched overnight for the missing jet and its pilot, officials said.
What is believed to be Moore’s body was found on the coast several miles away March 31.
I live in “flyover country”, far from America’s metropolitan coasts.

definition: instructive, especially excessively
details: When people are didactic, they're teaching or instructing. This word is often used negatively for when someone is acting too much like a teacher.
examples: Was it vital to emphasize these experiences, and was it tricky to avoid becoming didactic?
What emerges is a story as didactic as it is brave.
These didactic interludes, often marked off as separate chapters, provide a charming, informative guide; the pages breathe easily, cleverly composed and uncluttered.
Those whose work was never political or didactic are apprehensive about being framed as black artists, rather than as just artists.

definition: hold spellbound
details: To enrapture someone is cast an irresistible spell over them, to make them feel "rapture." I was enraptured by her gorgeous voice and stunning way of interpreting a song.
examples: Each ambled on for seven to 11 minutes, elaborated by Franklin’s enraptured whoops, cries and fills.
I remembered how, as a young student, nineteen years old, I’d been enraptured by this.

They emit a disorienting, enrapturing flood of images and music taken from broadcast television and video art and programmed to repeat relentlessly, mutate wildly and change abruptly, although a driving, danceable beat is constant.
Boys and girls from the Kalkaska Memorial Health Center Child Development Center and Preschool were enraptured by the yuletide stories shared by residents of the Kalkaska Senior Living Center.

definition: providing nurture though not related by blood or legal ties
details: To foster is to nurture something. A teacher could foster creativity by providing crayons to every student. You can also foster a child, which means the child lives in your home for a time.
examples: So yes, that fosters some friendly competition in the secondary.

It was trying to get around those legal limits that prompted the administration last spring to begin forcibly separating migrant children from their parents — detaining parents indefinitely while sending children to shelters and foster care.
State officials said they work with independent third-party contractors who check in on the more than 80 Oregon children in foster care placed in out-of-state facilities.
There are currently more than 80 Oregon foster children placed in out-of-state facilities.

definition: lacking worth or importance
details: If something is considered of little worth or importance, it is inconsequential. If astronomers forecast a tremendous meteor shower, it might turn out to be no more than space junk, too inconsequential to record.
examples: The shorthand rhetoric is often misleading, and usually lazy, but it also tends to be inconsequential.
And for many, what was lost last month was the detritus of the early age of social media, and an inconsequential period for popular music.
Rank was inconsequential as our conversations turned to shared passions, concerns and goals.
An indecisive and inconsequential intervention that ultimately changed nothing.

definition: harshly ironic or sinister
details: If you like Edgar Allan Poe and "The Addams Family," you have a taste for mordant entertainment — that is, anything particularly grim or dark in nature.
examples: A mordant sense of humor informs many of the scenes, as when Georg asks for a room and is told by the landlady that he must produce papers proving his travel plans.
Each post carried its own mordant title: “The Mother Popsicle,” “The Frustrated Sleeper.”
It’s spare and often funny in a mordant sort of way.
As another existentially immobilized Beckett character once mordantly observed, “Nothing is funnier than unhappiness, I grant you that.”

definition: stubbornly unyielding
details: If you won’t take no for an answer, you’re pertinacious. The same holds true if you stubbornly push on a door despite a sign that says “pull.” Pertinacious means unyielding or perversely persistent.
examples: China Daily, the government’s English-language newspaper, ran an editorial on Huawei arguing, “What propels Washington’s animosity against China is its pertinacious Cold War mentality, with which it continually distorts the reality of international relations.”
They are anything but a phlegmatic people, yet they are obdurate, they are pertinacious, they finish plastering joints.
Second, we are an ingenious, resourceful and pertinacious species.

The pertinacious meme that we would somehow benefit from eating more saturated fat, and thus its principal sources – meat, butter, cheese – is a product of misinterpretations of sequential answers to a series of dubious questions.

definition: a person without moral scruples
details: There's no way around it, a reprobate is a bad egg. The black sheep of the family, missing a moral compass — a reprobate's been called everything from a deviant to an evildoer to a scoundrel.
examples: How was this talented reprobate viewed among his compatriots at the time?
Reilly told tales of caddying for the “great, near great and reprobates of golf.”
Was Raymond a normal teenager or a lawless reprobate, as some claimed?
Like that pre-Civil War Supreme Court case, Trump will forever be condemned as a racial reprobate whose words and actions inspired white supremacists and neo-Nazis.

definition: full of anxiety and concern
details: When you hear the word solicitous, think of your mom — attentive, caring, and concerned. It's nice when your waiter gives you good service, but if he or she is solicitous, the hovering might annoy you.
examples: Or he might just be more solicitous to the religious freedom of a white Buddhist than to that of a black Muslim.
Trump is likely also too solicitous of Israel for their tastes.
He doesn’t want to look needy or solicitous.
He said he really “was not in favor of” loosening OxyContin regulation and was simply being “polite” and “solicitous” of his own employee.

definition: characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste
details: The adjective aesthetic comes in handy when the subject at hand is beauty or the arts. A velvet painting of dogs playing poker might have minimal aesthetic appeal.
examples: Davis conveys these insights with a wistful, dreamlike aesthetic languor.
The aesthetic choices of Nolan and Snyder in particular proved to be a poor fit with any character outside of Batman.
“But right now, people really appreciate the aesthetic, the imperfection. Imperfect is the new perfect.”
Even by the aesthetic standards of Augusta National, it is stunning.

definition: gold or silver in bars or ingots
details: If you wanted to rob Fort Knox and take all of its gold, you'd plan a heist to get the bullion. Bullion is gold or silver in bulk, often in the shape of a bar.
examples: However, the bullion remained in the custody of the Bank of England, despite the Central Bank’s request to repatriate it.
So the prospect of the global economy slowing next year, and the risk that the US government shutdown rumbles on, is good for bullion.

In her new memoir, “Becoming” — a book whose reportedly enormous advance rendered its contents almost as closely guarded as the bullion at Fort Knox — Michelle Obama puts to rest any speculation about her political ambitions.
Sign you’re an unlucky heir: Your grandmother added a note to her will that she left you a box of gold bullion but forgot where she put it.

definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering
details: When you coax someone, you try to convince him gently, with pleasant words and maybe a little flattery. You’ll have to be patient, as you can’t rush someone you’re trying to coax.
examples: But rather than transplanting cells grown in the laboratory, Reh aims to coax cells that are already in the retina to differentiate into fresh neurons.
That suggested it may be difficult to coax the North back into engagement after the failed talks.
Britain’s exit from the EU was still hanging in the balance on Monday as Prime Minister Theresa May tried to coax the Labour Party into agreeing a divorce deal, two days before an emergency summit.
He frequently held court with reporters as staffers unsuccessfully tried to coax him to return to his office.

definition: lack of self-assurance
details: The noun diffidence refers to a lack of self-confidence. Your diffidence might be the reason why you never say "hi" to the cute guy or gal in the elevator or why you never ask for a raise.
examples: In person, he was as deeply serious about his art as I expected him to be, and yet engaging and friendly despite his obvious diffidence.
In both Gosling and Gyllenhaal, meanwhile, there’s a quiet, sad-eyed diffidence that gestures toward a new kind of leading man, or at least a new perspective on the ones of yesteryear.
Even on the set of his own show, he speaks quietly, almost to the point of diffidence.
Thomas’s gentle diffidence, and his director’s fiercely rigorous style, leave his motives denser than unproved sourdough.

definition: fix firmly
details: If you ensconce yourself somewhere, you settle in for quite a while, such as when you're home with the flu and ensconce yourself on the couch with the remote control, tissues, your phone, and a big glass of orange juice.
examples: Russia is seeking to ensconce itself on NATO’s southern flank by helping a former general in Libya fight for control over his government and vast oil market.
White middle-class boomers, ensconced in suburban rumpus rooms, were nonetheless vulnerable to a soup of environmental threats.
West Ham, now ensconced in London’s Olympic Stadium, sees itself as one of England’s top clubs in a few years.
The point may be facile, but when the Republican opponent happens to be a former reality TV star now ensconced in the Oval Office, “Betomania” is not to be sniffed at.

definition: noisy quarrel
details: If your marching band gets into a fight with another school's pep squad, your principal might say the fracas was uncalled for and undignified. A fracas is a noisy quarrel.
examples: The right fielder was suspended two games for his role in a bench-clearing fracas Sunday in Pittsburgh.
The Reds got manager David Bell back from a one-game suspension for his part in a fracas in Pittsburgh on Sunday.
The Reds were missing outfielder Yasiel Puig and manager David Bell, suspended for their part in a fracas in Pittsburgh on Sunday.

definition: make into a whole or make part of a whole
details: To incorporate is to include or integrate a part into the whole. Incorporate is a more active version of the word "include"; if you incorporate, you are adding something to the mix.
examples: Defense Fund scientist David Lyon says the analysis incorporates methane-sensor measurements at about 90 locations.
He said the scattershot market of shadowy web sites, often incorporated overseas, that replaced it are often harder to track.

But it also incorporates contemporary images of violence and protest, and it is distinguished by Gates’s onscreen presence, talking to the camera while strolling through the story’s locales and interviewing inheritors of the struggle.
I like these tools because they incorporate search, social and the conversations around them.

definition: not growing or changing; without force or vitality
details: Something that is moribund is almost dead, like a moribund economy that has been stuck in a recession for years.
examples: This private-equity fund, using money appropriated by Congress, is helping finance new small and medium-size businesses that are creating jobs and entrepreneurial energy in the sometimes moribund, statist Egyptian economy.
He works in real estate, a thriving corner of Egypt’s otherwise moribund economy.
He agreed with Trump about location - saying North Korea sits “between four big economies that are far richer but increasingly moribund.”
He agreed with Trump about location — saying North Korea sits “between four big economies that are far richer but increasingly moribund.”

definition: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand
details: Something pertinent is relevant and on-point. If you give your best friend pertinent advice, that means the advice is appropriate for the situation.
examples: Democrats were taking other steps to try to get ahold of information pertinent to the Russia investigation.
But the Administration overall rejected the idea that the asylum system was pertinent to these flows.
In all pertinent details, Murphy’s claim was less timely than Ray’s—as both the federal district and appeals court explained in denying his suit.
“And that includes everything that might be pertinent to this.”

definition: severe disapproval
details: Reprobation means disapproval. Severe disapproval. If you want to find out what it means for yourself, try telling your nasty boss what you really think of him.
examples: But his constant complaining, his theatrical tumbles and repeated attempts to win penalties earned widespread reprobation.
Mild reprobations such “it is unfortunate the president said that” were laughable understatements incompatible with a proper conscience and more the result of strategic thinking.
Public shaming and reprobation of a "perpetrator" is something new, and changes all the rules.
His defense of the truth, however, apparently was enough to earn him Gingrich’s reprobation.

definition: grave or even gloomy in character
details: Funerals are often somber affairs, and you might have a somber expression on face after your teacher hands back an exam you failed. Somber is used to describe situations, facial expressions, or moods that are dark, gloomy, or depressing.
examples: Traditionally a frenetic and celebratory day of lawmaking, Monday will instead open on a somber note, with lawmakers awaiting word of funeral plans and uncertain about who will claim the speaker’s mantle.
Yet minutes later, talking with reporters, a more somber Biden emphasized that "I’m sorry I didn’t understand more."
The Northgate closure marks a somber milestone for the Seattle mall.
“Free Spirit” is a fuller, layered 17-track album of unrushed, somber pop from an artist extending his wings and proving why he’s one of the most exciting voices in music today.

definition: diffusing warmth and friendliness
details: Affable means friendly, pleasant, and easy to talk to. An affable host offers you something to drink and makes you feel at home.
examples: While Fisher’s image was more volatile, the product of New Hollywood’s wild, maverick filmmaking, Reynolds conveyed an affable stability.
The affable O’Rourke—the only male candidate of the day not dressed in a suit and tie—agreed, and told Baker about his difficulties explaining the current system to his children.
Flake breaks momentarily from his affable demeanor when pushed.
This eagerly affable woman seems to crawl through life in a defensive slump, glancing anxiously over her shoulder.

definition: a protective structure of stone or concrete
details: A bulwark is a wall built for protection or defense. If you and your pals build a secret fort for girls only, you might want to build a bulwark to surround it — with a "No Boys Allowed" sign posted prominently.
examples: Barr was appointed by Trump earlier this year and is seen by some as a bulwark to legal jeopardy for the president.
They and Egypt also see him as a bulwark against the rise of political Islam, especially the Muslim Brotherhood.
And it took the chamber one step closer to ending the defining procedural bulwark of the Senate, the 60-vote requirement to move ahead with most legislation.
His little oasis is a bulwark against reality, filled, some evenings, with opera singers, artists and other like-minded souls.

definition: the closing section of a musical composition
details: A coda is a concluding segment of a piece of music, a dance, or a statement. It's usually short and adds a final embellishment beyond a natural ending point. Like this.
examples: The song’s coda samples a video from Sol’s brother’s wedding eight years ago, before his 2012 breakout “Yours Truly” LP.
Sturkey’s book is a portrait of a Mississippi town from its founding in 1882 through the depredations of racial apartheid, ending with a brief coda on the civil rights movement.
A brief coda shows him back in Turin, pondering his experience.
I asked Martin McDonagh, the director and writer of the movie, what he thinks about that coda.

definition: lacking self-confidence
details: The adjective diffident describes someone who is shy and lacking in self-confidence. If you are shy and have a diffident manner, you should probably not choose one of these professions: substitute teacher, stand-up comic, or lion-tamer.
examples: In a very diffident tone, he said, “Stevie, you misspelled cemetery.”
Muna, introduced as “Queen” opens, is an engaging main character, the diffident and amnesiac twin sister of Sakti, a powerful witch who also suffers from amnesia.
Under the capital’s dim streetlights a diffident group of mostly young men gathers.
He was diffident about engaging with it, and as a result, his career, after a much-noticed start in the 1960s — biennials, prizes — slowed way down outside of France where, at 90, he still lives.

definition: take place or happen afterward or as a result
details: If something happens after something else, it will ensue, meaning it will follow after or be the result. When a sneeze comes out, and he hears the "Achoo!," a "Bless you" or "Gesundheit" soon will ensue.
examples: Then one day, just outside of her cell window, she sees a falcon fighting with a guard drone and in the ensuing battle, a baby bird ends up in her cell.
Mr. Northam said in January that in the event of a seemingly unviable fetus being born, a “discussion would ensue between the physicians and the mother” to decide whether to resuscitate the child.
Maybe you did something that hurt your spouse and are now reminded of that fact every time an argument ensues.
Human rights abuses ensued by soldiers not trained for police work, from torture to extrajudicial killings.

definition: easily irritated or annoyed
details: If you're prone to picking fights, making snarky comments, and being frustratingly stubborn, you're fractious. And odds are you're not invited to too many parties.
examples: Within the Democratic Party, an already fractious debate will become even more heated.
That many affectionately called him “Coach” was derived from his earlier work as a high school teacher and coach but also from how he managed the fractious egos and shifting alliances of Annapolis.
May, meanwhile, is a weakened leader, chairing a fractious cabinet — filled with feuding “remainers” and “leavers” who aspire to replace her.
Cabinet sources say the seven hours of meetings in Downing Street were at times fractious and bad tempered.

definition: impervious to correction by punishment
details: Someone incorrigible seems to be beyond correcting, improving, or changing. When you talk about an incorrigible bully, you're saying they're always going to push other people around.
examples: It was composed in the form of the Super Bowl-week diary of Billy Clyde Puckett, a talented but incorrigible running back for the New York Giants by way of Texas.
Lauren Sanchez’s brother is a scrappy agent for a roster of reality TV personalities and an incorrigible gossip even in a town full of them.

All those closeups of himself looking incorrigible, or lapping up the adoration of others, or getting down to business with women young enough to be his great-granddaughters – these were staged and approved by him.
Prosecutors portrayed him as an incorrigible grade school dropout.

definition: showing a brooding ill humor
details: A morose person is sullen, gloomy, sad, glum, and depressed — not a happy camper.
examples: Tracey Thorn’s reaction to that Robert Smith moment on Twitter was insightful, noting that a woman behaving in a similarly arsey fashion would probably be instantly derided as a morose diva.
As well as feeling relieved by the transformation of their formerly quiet and morose daughter, they say they were persuaded by her reasoning.
“When I Die” is more peaceful and joyful than morose.
Seth Hyden, with a rich laugh and a personality a long way from morose, nonetheless carries 13-12 in his pocket, with the kickoff return saved on his phone.

definition: spread or diffuse through
details: To pervade means to be present throughout, to exist in every part of. If you have too many cats, the horrible smell of cat pee will pervade your house.
examples: The conventional breadwinner/homemaker stereotype also pervades ideas of science workloads.
This dismal view of my gender pervades the novel, and in all objectivity, I’d say it is a flaw.
The next old-but-new technology to pervade our lives may be so-called neural interfaces.
In the end, it never pervaded the U.S. market.

definition: refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid
details: To repudiate something is to reject it, or to refuse to accept or support it. If you grow up religious, but repudiate all organized religion as an adult, you might start spending holidays at the movies, or just going to work.
examples: With an unprecedented number of qualified and experienced women running for president, it seemed logical, even inevitable, that a similar wave of female voters would embrace the chance to repudiate Trump and shape history.
It repudiates the idea of a Palestinian state and stresses Israel’s biblical and religious connections to land Palestinians seek for a state.
Prosecutors ultimately repudiated Fuhrman, and Darden maintained that the former detective's views on race did not erase all the evidence against Simpson, the former football star.
The legend of Bannon is that of a self-proclaimed intellectual who is repudiated by intellectuals and marshals the masses to get his revenge.

definition: full and loud and deep
details: Used to describe sound or speech that is full, rich, and deep, sonorous is a great word for snoring, for bass voices, and for low notes on the tuba.
examples: It was the name that punctuated the sonorous prayers in Ge’ez and Tigrinya, that hung in the air fragrant with incense, that was murmured between songs in the thrumming pews.
Hometown: I just like the sound of it — sonorous and acoustic.
Nao is a master of tone and control, acrobatically landing every note of her range, from a blown-glass falsetto down to her sonorous lower register.
Newell is seventy-six and ailing, but he was how I imagined he would be, based on newspaper clippings and recordings of his music: warm and optimistic, with thick hair and a sonorous baritone.

definition: have an influence upon
details: Affect is most often used as a verb meaning “to have an impact on,” as in “The tornado barreling towards us will affect our picnic plans.”
examples: The most emotionally violent scene in “Mary Magdalene,” an imperfect but affecting vision of New Testament times, depicts not a crucifixion but an exorcism — or rather, a failed attempt at one.
In March, a reporter met with five affected families at Army Fort Meade in Maryland, the largest military installation in the capital region and site of the secretive National Security Agency.
One genetic change that did largely persist six months after Scott returned to Earth affected his chromosomes.

Immune system genes especially were affected, putting it “almost on high alert as a way to try and understand this new environment,” said study co-author Christopher Mason, a Weill Cornell Medicine geneticist in New York.

definition: grow and flourish
details: Use the verb burgeon to describe something that is growing, expanding, and flourishing. If you have a green thumb, in the spring your flower gardens may burgeon. If you don't have a green thumb, your collection of plastic plants may burgeon.
examples: The measure represents Democrats’ effort to find the sweet spot between addressing a burgeoning humanitarian crisis and not lending credibility to Trump’s assertion that hordes of immigrants are invading the country.
It opened a flagship store on Magazine Street in 2011, followed by a second location in the burgeoning downtown area in 2016.
The burgeoning industry is epitomised in the annual Haiti Fashion Week which this year will mark its sixth edition.

definition: a supplement to a will
details: A codicil is a supplement to a will. If your will is already written and you want to alter it, you add a codicil.
examples: According to senior figures in the UK government, Cox’s plan A is a “codicil” that would allow the UK to quit the backstop unilaterally with one year’s notice.
Yet many were spooked by Brady’s comments on Sunday night that the change would not require rewriting the agreement, but that a “codicil” with the new arrangements would suffice.
But politics is also about theatrics, and the EU may well offer Britain some sort of wording - a note, an addendum or a codicil - that “clarifies” issues around the backstop.
But politics is also about theatrics, and the EU may well offer Britain some sort of wording — a note, an addendum or a codicil — that "clarifies" issues around the backstop.

definition: spread out; not concentrated in one place
details: Diffuse means to spread out. Candlelight can diffuse a soft glow throughout a room. A diffuse idea is one that spreads from person to person, and a diffuse speech is scattered and unclear.
examples: And their small size enables them to diffuse widely through the eye and therefore infect a large number of cells.
This way the shine doesn’t get diffused from multiple strokes.
These rounded pieces, which resemble eyes but also planets, diffuse the light yet don’t block it.

definition: provide amusement for
details: If you want to entertain, you've got to hold people's attention, usually with something amusing. Clowns, music, silly jokes, and a good game of charades can all be used to entertain.
examples: And it's also very entertaining and very funny, unexpectedly funny.

He was handed a difficult situation that became worse when star forward Kevin Love underwent foot surgery in November, effectively ending any thought the Cavaliers entertained of competing for a playoff spot.
She also went to Vietnam to entertain the troops and was celebrated as a writer.
This much is certain: Right now, Bennett won’t entertain any of those thoughts from the previous two paragraphs.

definition: a distinctive odor that is pleasant
details: A fragrance is a smell, usually a pleasant or sweet smell. Often perfumes are called fragrances.
examples: He settles in as the calming fragrance of cedar wafts from the vent.
Meanwhile, at Fokker Technologies, engineers are working on infusing the cabin with distinct fragrances.
Only last year did Kim and Kylie start selling their makeup and fragrances at the chain Ulta, trying to appeal to older buyers.
“That to me is one of the most inspirational aspects of living and working in fragrance here.”

definition: teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions
details: To inculcate is to teach through frequent instruction. If you repeatedly tell your brother how important it is to be responsible, then you’re trying to inculcate in him a sense of responsibility.
examples: Cultures also differ in their conceptions of truth and inculcate different perceptions of reality.
“This poem and the subsequent one signed by Clyde are redolent of the jargon of ‘gangster-ese’ which Depression-era Americans were inculcated with through the media of films, radio and pulp fiction.”

His single-minded goal since inheriting a beaten-down Husky program last year was to inculcate into his players the same single-minded zone defense principles that led Syracuse to such success in his previous life.
“It was inculcated in me since I was young,” said Rachel Yeo, 24, a senior studying journalism at the National University of Singapore.

definition: cause to feel shame
details: To mortify someone is to cause them extreme embarrassment. Your mother may not have been trying to mortify you when she showed up at your senior prom with a bunch of unicorn balloons, but she did.
examples: An American Airlines flight attendant said she was “mortified” after a passenger bumped into her and she accidentally sprayed her company’s CEO with a tray full of drinks on a flight recently.
Flores wrote that the incident left her “mortified,” “uneasy,” “powerless,” and “gross.”
She said the experience mortified, embarrassed and confused her.
“He leaned further in and inhaled my hair. I was mortified.”

definition: spreading or spread throughout
details: When something is pervasive, it's everywhere. Common things are pervasive — like greed and cheap perfume.
examples: Both publications regularly reported on African American success stories but also confronted pervasive racism in the United States.
And based on the pervasive coverage, it appears that they were successful.
Because noise is so pervasive, it is hard to study the impact as it ramps up.
FBI Director Christopher A. Wray, addressing Congress this month, offered a different assessment, saying that white supremacists and other violent extremists were “a persistent, pervasive threat.”

definition: offensive to the mind
details: Repugnant refers to something you detest so thoroughly it threatens to make you physically sick, like the idea of marrying your sister. Or wearing last year's jeans.
examples: To some people, the notion of promising parts of your future labor income to someone or something else sounds repugnant, almost like a kind of slavery.
People who were Jehovah’s Witnesses sued the state, saying the phrase was “repugnant to their moral, religious and political beliefs.”
While inoffensive may be a whole lot better than repugnant, it offers a lot of room for bottles that may be more distinctive and striking.

In the letter, Waszul’s attorney argues that King’s meme violated the Toronto-based illustrator’s “moral rights” under Canadian law, as it associated Waszul’s work with “words and ideas that are repugnant to our client.”

definition: inducing sleep
details: Something that is soporific is sleep-inducing. Certain medicines, but also extreme coziness, can have a soporific effect.
examples: United’s problem was in defence, though, as this 45 minutes began as the first did with a concerningly soporific approach.
Players adapted so quickly that the rounds were completed some 30 minutes quicker than the usual soporific near-five-hour average for a threesome.
It’s intolerably boring; the expanse of space in the game is huge and empty, aside from some treasure and tedious battles, and navigating it is soporific.
Still, the moment of induction seemed purely adolescent: She and her sister wanted an escape during a soporific visit to their grandparents.

definition: a close connection marked by community of interests
details: If you get along with someone very well, you have an affinity with them. Sometimes opposites attract, so you might feel a strange affinity to someone who is seemingly very different from you.
examples: Some of Mr. Trump’s affection may be explained by his general affinity for strongmen.
But Johnson repeatedly mentioned Buss’ affinity for Walton and Johnson’s desire not to cause upheaval between them.
This sort of contradiction—the affinity toward both life and death—runs through much of Tsushima’s work, and it tends to invite a biographical reading of her books.

definition: polish and make shiny
details: That seductive gleam on that Porsche behind the dealer's window? It's called a burnish, a gloss only achieved by loads of polishing. Likewise, you can burnish a resume by polishing it until it's perfect.
examples: Opposition to the project helped Nadler burnish his liberal reputation as he fought the Queens-born real estate developer, whom many in Manhattan considered an interloper.
Moretti played on junior teams in European and world championships, burnishing his credentials as one of the top international prospects before choosing Texas Tech over Indiana, Connecticut and Utah.
And if the Senate would ever eliminate the legislative filibuster, senators would likely follow the course burnished by Reid and McConnell for the Nuclear Option.

definition: powerfully persuasive
details: When you make a cogent argument, it means your argument is clear and persuasive. In these days of 24-hour entertainment news and sound-bite sized explanations of complex government policy, it’s hard to find a cogent argument amidst all the emotional outbursts.
examples: At its heart, the play is most cogently and pressingly about female empowerment, that most unsettling of worldwide political forces.

Our intuitive understanding of the concept of information—as cogently captured by Claude Shannon in 1948—is that it is merely a measure of the number of possible states of an independently existing system.
Along the way, “Hummingbird” offers cogent commentary on the way unbridled avarice drives the search for even the smallest advantage in the cutthroat world of high finance.
The crossover is obvious with regard to subject matter, although Oprah cogently opines that the word "abuse" lacks accuracy and is confusing.

definition: a message that departs from the main subject
details: When your essay about French cooking starts describing a childhood trip to Disneyland, it's taken a digression — it's strayed from the main topic.
examples: Then a digression on badger hair, loosely presaging the key discovery of the tumour-causing Rous sarcoma virus.

His celebration of this American empire is soaring and sincere — “the second home of every free person on the planet” — and often incomprehensible, laced with name-dropping digressions, circuitous analogies and mixed metaphors.
It’s her self-effacing buoyancy that sustains the piece, even at the few moments when it teeters on the brink of excessive digression.
“I am interested in understanding how she and I are relatives,” the narrator says in one of her better digressions, and one answer she contemplates is: in Minkowski spacetime.

definition: the branch of zoology that studies insects
details: Entomology is the study of insects. If you want to know all about ants, roaches, scorpions, and skeeters, entomology is for you.
examples: Of all the scientific fields, natural history benefited most from the slave trade, especially botany and entomology.

“The migration is not only happening here in North America. It happens between Africa and Europe as well,” Brian Brown, curator of entomology at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, told the publication.

In the years following its publication, Jünger completed an astonishing self-transformation into an exceptionally well-read and cosmopolitan intellectual, one particularly passionate about French culture, entomology, mysticism and philosophy.
The museum’s anthropology, ethnography, palaeontology, geology, entomology, arachnology and malacology collections were all housed in the palace – and most of them were destroyed, she said.

definition: filled with or attended with
details: Fraught means filled with something — often something bad. Your Thanksgiving was fraught with awkward moments when your family saw your blue hair, and it only got worse when you told them you'd quit law school to join the circus.
examples: But his relations with American presidents continued to be fraught, and he and President Obama developed a deep mutual disdain.
EU leaders were set to grant Prime Minister Theresa May a second postponement to Britain’s fraught exit at an emergency summit on Wednesday but were expected to argue over how long and on what terms.
That modern-day politicians stir controversies when they praise any Mussolini accomplishment, particularly infrastructure, underlines the dictator's fraught legacy.
Pressing probably is the best way of disrupting City’s flow, but it is an approach fraught with risk: when it went wrong for Liverpool last season, they lost 5-0.

definition: make amends for; pay compensation for
details: To pay compensation for a loss, damages, or similar expense is to indemnify. "The insurance company indemnified its customers for their claims after the severe storm — one customer lost three cars, a row boat, and a golf cart."
examples: The proposed regulations by Faulconer would also require operators to indemnify the city from liability claims and carry insurance policies.
Seinfeld left a voicemail in June to “offer my apology for this nuisance and assure you that you will be completely indemnified,” according to the lawsuit, Newsday reported.
The defendants want a global settlement — a comprehensive agreement that will indemnify them against further lawsuits.
And yes, there were precautions administrators took to indemnify themselves against all eventualities.

definition: a tiny piece of anything
details: Say the word: mote. It's short and quick, isn't it? The word corresponds to its meaning, which is something tiny: a speck of dust, a bit of fluff, a speckle of gold in the prospector's pan.
examples: It was lighting up his walrus whiskers and the perpetually joyous dust motes.
Save for a blip of a scene from “Thriller,” no official footage of music videos that might ignite a mote of nostalgia bedecks its architecture.
The lamp in the rocks on the side of the hill was little more than a mote of light and after a while they walked back.
“He would open the curtains a little bit and just study the dust motes, as if it was like a universe of stars that were floating around,” Clark recalls.

definition: easily irritated or annoyed
details: Choose the adjective petulant to describe a person or behavior that is irritable in a childish way.
examples: He was suspended for what the team saw as petulant behavior after being pulled from a game Jan. 8.
He into petulant teen, me into screeching banshee.
The majority of social interactions are routinely painful, and the only ones that are not involve a set of long-standing friends who I keep about me like the petulant child-queen of a medieval court.
Ryan Adams, that famously petulant songwriter who was recently exposed in the New York Times for his alleged transgressions against women.

definition: cancel officially
details: If you get a call saying a company has decided to rescind your job offer, it's back to the classifieds for you. Rescind is an official reversal.
examples: Ecuador's president, Lenin Moreno, said Thursday that his government made a "sovereign decision" to rescind Assange's political asylum due to "repeated violations to international conventions and daily life."
The chances of the Senate extending the electric vehicle tax credit, which President Trump proposed rescinding in his most recent budget request, aren’t great, according to analysts.
Border Patrol, to lead ICE but rescinded the nomination last week.
Chamber of Commerce, which scaled back the event and rescinded some invitations on short notice last week.

definition: adornment consisting of a small piece of shiny material
details: Do you like your outfits to have flair? A little sparkle? Then you're probably a fan of spangles, or small, shiny decorative things like sequins.
examples: Costumes comprising track suits and spangled tops illustrate the opposing aesthetics of athleticism and glamour, both of which are staples of Abraham’s movement.

definition: cause physical pain or suffering in
details: To afflict is to cause suffering, pain, or misery. It’s often associated with medical conditions. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is most likely to afflict someone who spends many hours every day typing on our computers.
examples: “There will be school vacation. There will be more and more families together. The last thing we want to see is more family members afflicted by this disease.”

definition: a support usually of stone or brick
details: You can buttress an argument with solid facts or your financial portfolio with safe investments. You may find that giving compliments to everyone you meet buttresses your popularity. To buttress is to sustain or reinforce.
examples: Réservesuisse said that, of the 15 companies with mandatory coffee stockpiles, 12 wanted to continue, in part because the system helped buttress the supply chain.

definition: having the same ancestral language
details: When you're learning a new language, a cognate is an easy word to remember because it looks and means the same thing as a word you already know. For example, gratitude in English means the same as gratitud in Spanish.
examples: Called “Climate of the Hunter,” its closest cognate is perhaps Joni Mitchell’s work of the era: humming bass, philosophical musings, maddening diversions, unresolved refrains.

definition: showing frivolous or superficial interest; amateurish
details: Though dilettante might sound like a nice French word, don't use it on your friend who thinks he can play the guitar after several short lessons. A dilettante is an amateur, often one who pretends to be very knowledgeable.
examples: That narrative suggests that, by the eighteenth century, the Royal Society was dominated by trivial pursuits and aristocratic dilettantes rather than disciplinary experts.

definition: ask for or request earnestly
details: To entreat is to ask for something that is really important, like when you entreat the jury to spare your life.
examples: The next day, at a hearing on Capitol Hill, relatives of four of the six Americans currently imprisoned or missing in Iran entreated Trump to bring them home as well.

definition: a noisy fight
details: The word fray is all about friction. A frayed rope has been rubbed so much its fibers are wearing away. People experiencing friction are involved in a fray, or a noisy fight.
examples: “Like the thing on the end of your shoestring, it helps it keep from fraying,” she says.

definition: not fixed or known in advance
details: Indeterminate means not known or decided. When someone contracts a rare stomach parasite but has not been traveling internationally, you might say it had indeterminate origins.

definition: a flamboyant deceiver
details: A mountebank has a talent for tricking people into buying things, like the mountebank who charms women into buying "magic beauty pills" for hundreds of dollars, though they are just ordinary vitamins you can buy anywhere.
examples: And Ricky goes to his library and then sends me an entire description of what the mountebank would be doing.”

definition: the humanistic study of language and literature
details: Philology means the study of language. Not learning specific languages per se, but grammar and history, and how sounds and meanings change over time.
examples: And some of its translations are simply incorrect, as we’ve learned thanks to advances in Near East philology and archaeology since the 19th century.

definition: a decision to do something or to behave in a certain manner
details: The noun resolution has a few related meanings having to do with being firmly determined about something. If you lack determination, you'll never fulfill your New Year's resolutions.
examples: As technologies continue to improve, Goodsell says the resolution of the mesoscale he depicts—10 to 100 nanometers—becomes sharper and sharper.

definition: a quarrel about petty points
details: You probably recognize the word spat from the phrase "lover's spat," which describes a minor squabble between a couple. The spat is usually over something as silly as which partner has to do the laundry, and the relationship usually recovers quickly, with no long-term harm done.
examples: For split read “rift”, or “spat”, according to reports, unable to resist perpetuating rumours of rows between the brothers, or – even better – between their wives.

definition: a cause of great suffering and distress
details: An affliction makes you suffer, but you have to deal with it anyway. Diseases are often said to be afflictions, but the word can mean just about anything that causes great suffering.

definition: healthily plump and vigorous
details: Marilyn Monroe and the triple loop roller coaster: What do they have in common? Some serious curves. But you could only call the lady buxom, or totally voluptuous.
examples: By 1922, Strand was married to the beautiful, buxom, boisterous Rebecca — “Beck” — a daughter of Rachel Samuels, a Jewish opera singer, and Nate Salsbury, Buffalo Bill Cody’s partner in the Wild West show.

definition: cause to form a united, orderly, and consistent whole
details: When things cohere, they come together in a meaningful way. It wasn't until we won a game that our team finally cohered, and we actually felt like a unit.

definition: quietly and steadily persevering in detail or exactness
details: Someone who is diligent works hard and carefully. If you want to write the epic history of your family, you'll have to be very diligent in tracking down and interviewing all of your relatives.

definition: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day
details: Something that is fleeting or short-lived is ephemeral, like a fly that lives for one day or text messages flitting from cellphone to cellphone.
examples: But “wanting” is a child’s emotion, ephemeral and shallow.

definition: a mural done with watercolors on wet plaster
details: Whether you've studied art history or not, you're probably familiar with the world's most famous fresco: Michelangelo's paintings on the walls and ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Rome.

definition: something that serves to suggest
details: An indication is a sign––it indicates, or suggests, some conclusion. The way you blush furiously when a certain someone talks to you is an indication that you have a crush on them.

definition: a large indefinite number
details: A multitude is a very large number or a huge crowd. If you see a multitude of zombies approaching, you're in trouble.

definition: relating to the investigation of existence and knowledge
details: To be philosophical is to stay detached and thoughtful in the face of a setback, or to approach a tough situation in a level-headed way. When his girlfriend left him, Bernard was philosophical: "If she loves me, she'll return."

definition: find a solution or answer
details: To resolve is to settle or make a decision about something — often formal. A college's board of directors might resolve to recruit more minority students. As a noun, resolve refers to a strong determination to do something.
examples: A crackdown will not resolve the desperate economic crisis that brought years of simmering resentment on to the streets last December.

definition: a large number or amount or extent

definition: having an abundant supply of money or possessions of value

definition: a group of people having approximately the same age

definition: decrease in size, extent, or range

definition: not varying
details: The adjective equable means "not easily irritated" or "steady," like someone's equable manner that makes everyone instantly feel comfortable.

definition: showing little emotion

definition: an example regarded as typical of its class

definition: embellish; increase the scope, power, or importance of

definition: the arrangement of the hair

definition: thickly covered with ingrained dirt or soot
details: If something is dingy, it's dirty. If you spend your days as a chimney sweeper, you probably look pretty dingy.

definition: steadiness of mind under stress
details: If you take the news of your parakeet's death with equanimity, it means you take it calmly without breaking down. Equanimity refers to emotional calmness and balance in times of stress.

definition: a wilderness at the edge of a settled area of a country
details: A frontier represents uncharted territory. It could be a remote piece of land or a new field of study, but if someone calls it "the frontier," you are challenged to explore it.

definition: produce a literary work
details: The verb indite, rarely used today, means "compose" or "put down in writing," like when you find a quiet place to sit down with your notebook and pen and indite a journal entry or a first draft of a short story.

definition: very generous
details: If you give your best friend a bracelet for her birthday, then you’re a good friend. If you give her a diamond bracelet, a racehorse, and an oil well, then you’re a munificent friend, meaning you are very lavish when it comes to giving gifts. (And it’s possible you may also be broke.)

definition: righteousness by virtue of being religiously devout
details: Piety is devotion to God or to religious practices. Nuns who pray all day long are famous for their piety. If you have filial piety it means you're devoted to your parents.

definition: a new or reserve supply that can be drawn upon when needed
details: A resource is any personal talent or outside supply that can be tapped for help or support.

definition: plausible but false
details: Use specious to describe an argument that seems to be good, correct, or logical, but is not so. We live on the earth, therefore the earth must be the center of the universe has been proven to be a specious theory of the solar system.

definition: a sum total of many heterogeneous things taken together
details: To aggregate is to collect many units into one. If you're writing a novel, you might create a character who is an aggregate of five or six real people.
examples: The Italians suffered a fright in the last round of this tournament but only because they took their foot off the pedal after romping into a 4-0 aggregate lead over RB Salzburg.

definition: work together on a common enterprise or project
details: When you work together on shared goal, you collaborate. If you don't just split a project up evenly but work together on creating solutions, you collaborate.
examples: In the indictment released on Thursday, prosecutors accuse Assange of entering into a conspiracy with Manning through the webchats to “collaborate on the acquisition and dissemination of the classified records”.
But when asked if there are other US artists with whom he would like to collaborate, Niska is hesitant.
“Walk the Line,” “The Hunger Games” and “Crazy Heart,” which also brought him an Oscar for collaborating on the best original song.
Yesterday, Google announced that it would let you create and collaborate on Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides files through Dropbox Business as well.

definition: force or effort
details: The word dint is used to indicate that something came about through a particular force or means. So if you make a lot of money, that’s probably by dint of hard work.
examples: By dint of personality and practice, Fechheimer was an inconspicuous character.

What looks at first like a solid, well-carpentered exercise in downbeat indie realism ends up, by dint of its unexpected tonal and temporal leaps and sudden formal ruptures, in less easily definable territory.
