By dint of its location in Manhattan, a few miles south of the Trump Organization’s offices on Fifth Avenue, the Southern District was a natural landing spot for the Cohen case.
And while the children immersed in the elite-admissions obstacle course aren’t the norm, many of them will — by dint of their backgrounds, ambitions and, yes, talents — be tomorrow’s leaders.

definition: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
details: When you are unwilling to make a decision and almost intentionally go back and forth between two choices, you are equivocating. When politicians equivocate, they are often afraid of upsetting, and thus alienating, voters with their decisions.
examples: On Monday, the newly resigned Labour lawmakers castigated Mr. Corbyn, accusing him of equivocating over Brexit and tolerating anti-Semitism within the party.
“It drives me insane. I'm always equivocating. I'm a Gemini!”
The congresswoman equivocated and failed to accept full responsibility for her actions.
Trump continues to equivocate on whether Russia interfered in the 2016 election on his behalf, contradicting the unanimous assessment of all the top intelligence officials currently serving.

definition: become productive or fruitful
details: A newly planted apple tree can take years to fructify, but when it does there will be plenty of apples to go around. To fructify is to “produce fruit,” or “become fruitful.”
examples: He wrote that politicians are often asked to lower taxes to “leave the money to fructify in the hands of the people.”
“We’re just starting to see that interest in the sport beginning to fructify now … this fight is bankable,” Nelson said.
Or rather, it was a productive and fructifying pain.
Those discussions fructified into the present partnership more than a year later.

definition: disinclined to work or exertion
details: Indolent is an adjective meaning slow or lazy. It can take an indolent teenager hours to get out of bed on a weekend morning. Often it's noon before he finally comes shuffling down to breakfast in his pajamas.
examples: "Prostate cancer is not one disease - many are indolent - and early detection means knowing about it for longer when it may never impact on life expectancy," she added.
On its own, the broth is almost indolent, flavor and texture inseparable; you taste plushness, and it lasts and lasts.
Based on a short story by Jack Ritchie, “A New Leaf” stars Matthau as Henry Graham, an indolent playboy who’s burned through his fortune.
“Perhaps quarreling. . . . Cannot read in the evenings. . . . Anxiety and responsibility. Perhaps my wife won’t like London; then the sentence is banishment and degradation into indolent, idle fool.”

definition: reflect deeply on a subject
details: As a verb, to muse is to consider something thoughtfully. As a noun, it means a person — especially a woman — who is a source of artistic inspiration.
examples: Between philosophical musings and scientific debates — how different beers are related, how different primates are related — the researchers cracked another beer, sampled it, discussed it and then jotted down notes.
Primarily known to the public as a sensational dancer and comedienne, by the time she first worked with Fosse, on Damn Yankees, in 1955, she was far more than just an instrument or a muse.
Monday, he mused that he might be interested in doing a pop-up restaurant.
She was his muse and a ferocious dancer in her own right.

definition: make off with belongings of others
details: To pilfer is to steal something, typically of small value. Minor thefts, like taking a roll of toilet paper out of a public bathroom or napkins from the Early Bird Buffet are what your grandfather, for example, might pilfer.
examples: More recently, eight members of the police department’s elite Gun Trace Task Force were convicted of crimes including fraudulent overtime claims and pilfering hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash, guns and drugs.

He said the committee looks forward to hearing Shanahan explain “how he intends to pilfer the military construction accounts, circumvent the intended nature of the law, while simultaneously abusing the trust of the American people.”
She even pilfered the charity’s coffers to pay for her son’s criminal defense, according to a federal criminal complaint.

NSO and DarkMatter also compete fiercely with each other, paying handsomely to lure top hacking talent from Israel, the United States and other countries, and sometimes pilfering recruits from each other, The Times found.

definition: a sum of money paid in compensation for loss or injury
details: Restitution is the act of making up for damages or harm. Remember the time you knocked the ball out of the park, scoring a home run but breaking a house's window in the process? You had to make restitution for the broken window, paying for its replacement.
examples: Monika Grütters, the German cultural minister, described the case as an “exemplary resolution” to one of many second world war restitution cases, most of which are far less straightforward.
The records say that in return for her pleas prosecutors will recommend three years of probation, suspended five-year prison terms and that Griffin pay restitution.
There was no apology, no restitution — in fact, intimidation of the community only continued after the killings.
Carter was ordered to pay $70,513 in restitution to his former employer and to forfeit $286,251 representing proceeds from his drug trafficking activity, according to the U.S. attorney’s office.

definition: resembling or characteristic of a phantom
details: When something is spectral, it has a ghostlike quality; it seems to vanish or disappear. You may have heard of ghosts referred to as "specters": that means that they're spectral.
examples: The two types of display rely on metamerism, a phenomenon by which combinations of light that look the same actually differ in their spectral make-up, says Lucas.
Meals are served by the Dane’s spectral children, who recall — to Louie and to us — the malevolent bairns in “The Turn of the Screw.”
The duo, who described themselves as an “international supersonic spectral wave Liverpool band” on their social media accounts, were killed alongside their tour manager, Trevor Engelbrektson.
Berlant felt Trump’s spectral presence everywhere, his bluster mimicked and channelled by the Party establishment.

definition: infringe on the rights of
details: To aggrieve someone is a lousy thing to do. Not sure why? See the "grieve" in there, and you'll see why. It means to bring someone sorrow.
examples: That’s because it works, particularly among aggrieved people immersed in certain ideological climates.
Mr. Wilson, who was abused as a child by an adoptive father, sounds aggrieved.
It was on their behalf, after all, that I spent so many years raising truckloads of cash and enduring a veritable tsunami of aggrieved complaints.
These community groups play a vital role in spreading the word about wage theft and in connecting local enforcement agencies with aggrieved employees, according to Haeyoung Yoon.

definition: assembling in proper numerical or logical sequence
details: A collation is the collection and ordering of materials, usually paper. It can be tedious and repetitive work, so most people are more than happy to let a copy machine do the job for them.
examples: For Cook, that system of data collection, collation, and targeting amounts to a “data-industrial complex,” which threatens both privacy and democracy itself.
From touring, sales, copyright legislation, to royalty collation.
“The massacres against children in Yemen by the collation forces proved that children’s rights are a big lie,” said Mohammed Abdulsalam, a Houthi spokesman.
The U.S.-backed Saudi collation is seeking to restore Yemen’s internationally recognized government back to power.

definition: a song or hymn of mourning as a memorial to a dead person
details: A dirge is a song of mourning, performed as a memorial to someone who’s died. As you might imagine, a dirge is usually quite sad. Another word with a similar meaning that you might know is “requiem.”
examples: If Osaka were to win and hear the music of cheers instead of the ugly dirge of boos, it would be wonderful and long overdue.
In its original form, the song played like a kind of funeral dirge, with McCartney singing, “Dear friend, what’s the time? / Is this really the borderline?”
Starting as a dirge and ending as an ode to joy, “Never-Ending Man: Hayao Miyazaki” provides a privileged glimpse into the creative processes of one of the greatest animators who ever lived.
“The Mortal Remains” brings all these tales together beautifully, by which I mean in a coda that is somber and hauntingly unsettled, like the last note of a dirge.

definition: become ground down or deteriorate
details: When soil or land erodes, it wears away or is removed. Many beaches seem to get smaller and smaller, as the endless wash of the waves begins to erode the fine sand.
examples: But trust is eroded when public-sector projects fail, limiting the ability to govern effectively in the future.
The city enjoys rights unseen on the Chinese mainland, which are protected by the 50-year handover agreement between Britain and China, but fears are growing that those liberties are being eroded.
But our environment attempts to smooth our rough edges over time, just as ocean waves erode seashells to be similar looking even though their shapes are initially distinct from each other.
Every blustery, ignorant threat erodes trust, at home and abroad.

definition: avoiding waste
details: A person who lives simply and economically can be called frugal. Buying clothes at a consignment shop would be considered frugal. Not getting your mom a gift for her birthday — that's just cheap.
examples: There also is evidence that Americans are not just moving to smaller homes in town but fleeing high-tax states altogether as they search for more frugal digs.
She wasn’t a hippie, but she was frugal, and the box of Velveeta cost as much as a whole fryer.
He plans to finance his travels with savings, credit cards and frugal living on the road while posting it all on his social media accounts.
I grew up pretty frugal on the farm.

definition: unable to move or resist motion
details: Something that's unable to move or moving without much energy can be described as inert. Wind up in a body cast and you’ll find yourself not only itchy, but totally inert.
examples: We think of bones as white, brittle and inert, not rich and dynamic.
“Chuck was talking about a very specific kind of anger that was engendered by a kind of malaise: ‘We’ve been inert so long, we need to sprint into our next evolution of ourselves.’
The engine uses inert gases - energised by electric power from the solar arrays - to provide gentle, non-stop thrust.
In June 2017, Fears "obtained the labels from Volious, armed the mail bomb, and was surveilled by the FBI delivering the inert explosives package" to a U.S.

definition: gather or bring together
details: Originally meaning only to gather soldiers, muster's definition has been expanded to include gathering up just about anything — you can muster up some dinner, some friends, or even some ketchup, pickles and mustard.
examples: There may be a chance of mustering some bipartisan support again in the Senate again.

The team observed the black hole over five nights in April 2017 and mustered enough resolution to capture the distant objects by linking up eight observatories across the globe — from Hawaii to the South Pole.
In Germany, the far-right Alternative for Germany, which in 2013 couldn’t even muster the 5 percent of the vote needed to be seated in the Bundestag, is now the largest opposition party.

What’s really most remarkable about his work is the fact that he managed to produce it while lifting the family luggage, shepherding three children onto airplanes, attending school plays, paying orthodontists, and mustering college tuition.

definition: steal goods; take as spoils
details: To pillage is a term of war that means to take everything of value from a place that you've conquered, but these days, pillage can be used to talk about anyone who takes what's not theirs.
examples: In a social media post on Tuesday, Zhao questioned why the Japanese military did not pillage and destroy the Beijing Palace Museum during the Second Sino-Japanese War.
He denounced the pillaging as “a gross affront to humanity at large.”
In an interview with the Mexican daily Excelsior, Leopoldo Best, the son of one of the muralists, likened the removals to an act of “cultural pillage.”

Some 465 houses and buildings were burned down or pillaged, including two primary schools, a health centre, a health post, a market and the office of the country's independent electoral commission, the UN said.

definition: under control
details: Use the adjective restrained to describe something that's kept under control, such as strong emotion or even physical movement. If you're angry but you don't want it to show, you might speak in a restrained manner.
examples: Puig grabbed Pirates bench coach Tom Prince in the ensuing melee and attempted to put him in a headlock before being restrained by teammates.
Also, in the future, if you don’t want co-workers to invite themselves along to your social gatherings, offer a more limited and restrained description.
It says something about Trump that such actions were apparently too moderate and restrained for his taste.
Police said they were still trying to identify a man who allegedly kicked Connolly while the teen was restrained on the floor by Anning’s supporters.

definition: a broad range of related objects, values, or qualities
details: A spectrum is a broad range of similar things or qualities. Like the wide spectrum of political beliefs in this country, ranging anywhere from super conservative to uber-liberal and everything in between.
examples: Across the political spectrum, voters want law enforcement to focus more resources on the most serious crimes.
The only way to truly reflect our community is to provide content that spans the spectrum.
The party leaders said their "exceptional outcome" proved that a broad spectrum of Israelis sought "a true alternative" to Netanyahu's 10 consecutive years in office.
Incandescent and fluorescent lighting in homes and offices does a poor job of replicating the spectrum of the Sun’s rays.

definition: moving quickly and lightly
details: On water skis she was agile and made sharp turns and long arcs cutting through the water, but she was a lot less agile on the snowboard, landing on her face and hands as she clunked down the slopes.
examples: Despite being the source of many technological innovations, academics seem to be late in adopting the agile approach.
"Even with an adjustment of the force, we will continue to remain agile in support of existing U.S. strategy."
“Even with an adjustment of the force, we will continue to remain agile in support of existing U.S. strategy.”
My paddleboard, 10 feet long, agile and quiet, became the perfect vehicle for seeing Washington.

definition: corresponding in size or degree or extent
details: The word commensurate has to do with things that are similar in size and therefore appropriate. Many people think the death penalty is a commensurate punishment for murder. In other words, the penalty fits the crime.
examples: The censure “will publicly reprimand each officer for their actions commensurate with their respective levels of responsibility,” the letter reportedly said.
The group is asking Amazon to set timelines that keep with the scientific consensus to avoid ever-greater climate catastrophes, and commensurate with the company’s industry-leading position.
The average basketball player in a big-time program does and is not being paid commensurate with the revenue he brings in.
Or maybe it’s America itself that lacks delicacy, and the series, taking its excesses as its subject, is just responding with commensurate force.

definition: free somebody from an erroneous belief
details: Disabuse means to free someone of a belief that is not true. Many teachers of health find that when they teach, they spend as much energy disabusing kids of false beliefs as they do giving them the facts.
examples: And the experiences of the Obama Administration should disabuse Democrats of the notion that more moderate proposals would fare any better.
“He did nothing to disabuse that notion because it added to his back story and made him more attractive to visiting consultants and women,” Mr. Caputo said.
A quick stroll around any academic institution focused on science and medicine would quickly disabuse anyone of this notion.
She was assigned more luxurious cars and felt she was getting somewhere until the relatively paltry $1,000 tip she received at the end of the seven weeks disabused her.

definition: straying from the right course or from accepted standards
details: Something or someone described as errant has gone astray or done wrong by going in an unexpected direction. An errant bird might end up in northern Canada while his friends fly to southern Mexico for the winter.
examples: He plunked two hitters with an errant pitch, saw hard contact on baseballs put in play, and overall struggled to locate his pitches.
“Any contention that Nicholas Sandmann’s defamation lawsuit is politically motivated is errant nonsense,” said Mr. Wood.
Authorities told the Times that it appears that Licon was hit by an “errant driver” while conducting a traffic stop on the shoulder of the freeway.

definition: prudence in avoiding waste
details: If you try to avoid waste by reusing and repurposing items that most people would throw away, your frugality will save you money.
examples: The second lesson is that in good decision making, frugality matters.
But when did the frugality that cost them Mack, arguably the NFL’s best defensive player, and the long-range plan that led to Cooper’s departure turn into opening the vault so wide?
Le called for frugality in government, warning repeatedly against waste, bureaucracy, hedonism, extravagance and “formality for formality’s sake.”
Despite Amazon’s reputation for frugality, it will occasionally dig deep to project an image of a hip, forward-thinking company.

definition: incapable of being avoided or prevented
details: If something is inevitable, it will definitely happen, like death or tax season.
examples: Work-family justice stresses that the conflict between work and family is not an inevitable feature of contemporary science careers, and it’s not the fault of women or parents.
Westeros becomes a vacant wintry wasteland as the engorged army of the dead pushes south to continue its inevitable path to victory and world domination.
A parting of logistical ways for the brothers was always inevitable, aides say.
Was the avoidable Great Chaos, now in its 12th year, cured by this inevitable but unschedulable catastrophe?

definition: bind the arms of
details: Many cars use rack-and-pinion steering, in which the steering wheel turns a small-toothed pinion gear, which engages the larger rack that turns the car's wheels.
examples: Perhaps it is the novelist’s aspiration to universality, the fear that specificity pinions art’s wings.
With Michael cutting me off from the board and boxing me in from the executives below, I felt pinioned from the start.
Julio broke from the men and sprang at me again, but the marshal met him and they struggled until the other two pinioned his arms again.
They were very small to look at, yet he knew, somehow, that they were huge, with a vast stretch of pinion, flying at a great height.

definition: a person working in the service of another
details: A retainer is something that holds something else in place. After your braces are removed, a retainer keeps your teeth from moving out of their new perfect position.
examples: The yearbook group pays him a retainer because he says his time is too valuable to work on puerile and fleeting pursuits like the high school yearbook for free.
She seems like the type who would actually wear her retainer at night instead of letting it collect dust on some bathroom shelf.
But after that hectic week following the Ethiopia crash, Boeing turned to Sard Verbinnen, a crisis communications firm based in New York that it kept on retainer, for assistance.
Mr. Schmidt estimated that 15 to 20 percent of seniors at his school hired outside help, with some parents paying up to $8,000 per month to keep a consultant on retainer.

definition: said or done without having been planned in advance
details: Something spontaneous happens when you're least expecting it. Spontaneous things are natural or instinctive, and they happen without warning.
examples: During Sunday night’s episode of “Keeping up with the Kardashians,” the reality star addressed West’s spontaneous rant on “Saturday Night Live” when he appeared as the musical guest last September.
Channel 4 said it was a "spontaneous comment" noting that ethnic minorities were under-represented for a London demonstration of this size, and said the channel regretted any offence caused.
It was there in the spontaneous substitutions that kept the Bruins rested in back-to-back competitions, and in their relentlessness after teammates erred.
"If you were to analyse the show, you would think it is very spontaneous," he said.

definition: relating to rural matters
details: Use the word agrarian to describe something related to fields, farming, or rural matters. The school calendar is still based on the old agrarian calendar, when children needed to be off during the summer to help with planting and harvesting.
examples: They represent a form of government best suited to the agrarian lifestyle of 100-plus years ago.

It is against this backdrop that Democrats are looking to a us-v-them style of politics redolent of the US agrarian revolts of the 1890s – the movement that spawned the word “populism” in the first place.
The population in the highlands is mostly indigenous, and people’s livelihoods are almost exclusively agrarian.
At the same time, the agrarian rhetoric of the restored South was always an anti-modernist rhetoric, antagonistic toward bourgeois free enterprise.

definition: feel or express sympathy or compassion
details: When you commiserate with your buddies, you're sharing your lousy feelings. People who commiserate have the same negative feelings about something.
examples: But just one winning ticket was sold in Wisconsin, Powerball officials said early Thursday morning, leaving the disappointed losers to commiserate on Twitter.
Instead, they commiserated about the difficulties of adjusting to life when you are over 7 feet tall and 4,500 miles from home.
We drank there for years — for birthdays, to farewell colleagues, to celebrate engagements, to commiserate over divorces and illness.
Walking hand in hand with those affected, Ardern’s focus was on grieving and commiserating with the affected community.

definition: discontented as toward authority
details: The adjective disaffected describes someone who is dissatisfied or rebellious. Usually if you're disaffected, you're upset with people in authority. You and your fellow disaffected workers might become so upset about the lack of raises that you decided to boycott work.
examples: The disaffected residents of Manchester — owners of small businesses, intellectuals and weavers toiling in the newly mechanized mills — plan a mass meeting.
The idea that Democrats need a unifying figure to lure disaffected Trump voters in key states?

The problem begins with the architecture of the internet, which encourages anonymity, empowering bad actors, while also enabling the disaffected to find each other and coordinate their activities at a scale never previously possible.
Writing on his blog at the beginning of March he dismissed what he called “radical leftist critics” for saying that he was appealing “to disaffected and angry young white men”.

definition: belonging to some prior time
details: If your dad used to play in a punk band, but is now a computer programmer, you could call him an erstwhile punk rocker. Erstwhile means "former."
examples: She then became one of two dozen black children who integrated a school in the erstwhile Confederate capital, braving taunts, shoves and being stuck with pins.

While 100 days in office may not be long enough to judge the president's performance, some of his erstwhile supporters are now expressing doubts about his ability to lead the largest democracy in Latin America.
In 2017, he bought the rights to the erstwhile Channel 4 drama Top Boy, which follows the lives of people involved in drug dealing and gang life on the fictional east London estate of Summerhouse.
The State Department reached again into the ranks of Fox News Channel almunae for a new spokesperson, but this one is an erstwhile conservative critic of President Trump.

definition: hinder or prevent, as an effort, plan, or desire
details: When you frustrate someone, you do your best to annoy, confuse, or even torment that poor person. Maybe you constantly change your mind — that's sure to frustrate anyone who tries to make plans with you.
examples: The most frustrating thing about "Her Smell," however, is its vague understanding of exactly what is supposed to be going on with Becky.
Nielsen was reportedly frustrated with the difficulty of getting other departments to help deal with the growing number of families crossing the border.
The animating feature of the book is that you are frustrated and annoyed with the liberal consensus, which is “shrilly” and “condescendingly” looks down on Trump voters.
She says she knows the whole country is frustrated by this delay.

definition: incapable of failure or error
details: "Fallible" means capable of making mistakes — or, easier to remember — capable of failing. Infallible means exactly the opposite — incapable of failing.
examples: But the Supreme Court is infallible because it is final, as Justice Robert Jackson once observed.
Polygraph tests – often referred to as lie-detector tests – are not infallible and their accuracy rate is estimated to be anywhere between 90 and 70 percent.
Perhaps the methods that brought him success started to seem like infallible rules that would always yield winning results.
Defense attorney David Harrison is challenging the perception that DNA testing is infallible.

definition: having or showing or expressing reverence for a deity
details: If someone is deeply religious and visibly follows all the moral and ethical codes of his religion, he is pious. Don't become a priest if you're not prepared to live a pious life.
examples: Along with Han settlers, they felt increasingly unsafe travelling to the region’s Uighur-majority areas, and uneasy in the presence of pious Turkic Muslims.
This man who never really knew him, cobbling together crib notes for a eulogy with no meaning, all pious insouciance.
The production schedule also jumped around, meaning she might be playing the youthful, optimistic Alison of the 1940s in the morning and the intense, pious Alison of the 1960s right after lunch.
And most of all, it plays directly to his conservative, pious support base, who lap up his strongman rhetoric.

definition: good at remembering
details: If something is retentive, it is able to hold something else, so be glad if you have a retentive mind and grab a sponge if you need something retentive to sop up water.
examples: Certainly some qualities of mind popularly associated with so-called high-functioning autism — focus, computational ability, a retentive memory, a preference for rational argument over feeling — are useful in most academic fields.
Patsy archly described someone as so anal retentive “she couldn’t sit down for fear of sucking up the furniture!”
When someone is categorized as being anal retentive it refers to Freud’s anal psychosexual stage.
"I'm a weird combination of anal retentive and anal expulsive," he says while standing in front of a giant refrigerator crammed with film.

definition: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
details: Sporadic is an adjective that you can use to refer to something that happens or appears often, but not constantly or regularly. The mail carrier comes every day but the plumber's visits are sporadic––he comes as needed.
examples: Their opposition ebbed in recent weeks after sporadic talks overseen by McConnell and Schumer to unfreeze some of the nominations fell apart.
Even if those instances were far more sporadic in last summer than they were during his first full season in the majors in 2017.
The election was marred by sporadic violence, with five dead and scores injured across Turkey.
After sporadic rain during the first two games of the series, the roof at Marlins Park was opened Saturday.

definition: someone who acts as an assistant
details: Remember that aide with an "e" at the end is a noun. It refers to a person who helps or acts as an assistant, such as a nurse's aide or a presidential aide.
examples: Most recently, she smeared White House aide Stephen Miller as a white nationalist.
Former Trump aide, Carter Page, was spied on extensively by the U.S. government, even though it was obvious from the very first day that he was not a Russian spy.
One congressional aide said that the DHS inspector general’s office wrote back recently in response to a request to investigate ICE’s handling of the Trump case.
Senate account, and the cash on hand was about $11 million at the end of the quarter, a campaign aide said.

definition: a special group delegated to consider some matter
details: The word commission has several very different meanings, but in its most basic meaning, commission is the act of passing a responsibility to someone else. If you receive a government commission, that means you have been assigned a task by the government.
examples: Asked during a trade commission hearing to specify which airports, an expert witness for Boeing replied that “sometimes Denver would qualify as that.”

The 18th Street Arts Center, which received $45,000 for five new artist commissions tied to live events examining the roles architecture and cultural policy play in social life and civic engagement in American communities.
This sounds a bit like Gordon Brown’s proposal for a people’s royal commission to find a version of Brexit acceptable to the country.
The state commission and the state’s courts rejected appeals filed by the Kleins.

definition: pronouncing as wrong or morally culpable
details: If you show up for Thanksgiving dinner an hour late and covered in mud from a tag football game, your parents will give you a look of disapprobation. This means they seriously disapprove of your actions, despite the fact that you scored the winning touchdown.
examples: Boys would pick on him, he said, but he refused to fight them, which only brought more disapprobation.
Though the movie was subjected to a good deal of critical disapprobation, it was wildly popular.
The thumb turned, extending from the hand, was translated from Latin as a sign of "disapprobation" in a number of instances that the Oxford English Dictionary records.
Transgender people are “still considered immoral and distasteful and looked at with disapprobation in much of the community,” Johnson told me.

definition: having or showing profound knowledge
details: If you call someone erudite, that means they show great learning. After you've earned your second Ph.D., you will be truly erudite.
examples: Brown was typically attired in all black and typically erudite when we met last week in his apartment with sweeping views of San Francisco.
Mizrahi describes his mother, Sarah, erudite and a devotee of high fashion.
He was “the very best benefactor and collaborator, as erudite as he was generous,” she said.
Her book is a plea, at times an erudite polemic, to wrest back some of that control and moral authority from science to society at large.

definition: criticize severely
details: Watch a bomb fulminate or explode and hope you're under safe cover. Have your parents fulminate or blow up at you for coming home past curfew and hope you're not grounded for too long.
examples: The president prefers fulminating, as though the migrant surge might evaporate in the face of his fury.

Tarrant fulminated about hordes at the gate from Australia, where white settlers first established a colony in 1788, and, over the next century, proceeded to murder, kidnap, and subjugate the Aboriginal population.
"Not one of the fulminating television-news anchors exhibited the criticality demanded of their profession," she said.

Most saw an abrupt, sometimes angry, man quite literally fulminating at the mouth; while I saw a loving, caring, and compassionate grandfather who would put his grandchildren ahead of himself and before all else.

definition: occupy in large numbers or live on a host
details: The verb infest means to invade in large number, often resisting control and causing damage or hardship. Bedbugs can infest people's belongings and even their bodies, or mice may infest your kitchen if you leave the cheese out too often.
examples: When drugs infested the school, Drake became a police informant.
Shortly before that, Trump posted a slightly broader tweet using the term "infest," but largely in reference to illegal immigrants and specifically MS-13.
But Syria and Iraq are infested with sleeper cells.
There are around 2,600 species of termites, and only about two dozen infest and destroy buildings.

definition: a sudden outburst of anger
details: The verb pique means to make someone angry or annoyed. But when something piques your interest or curiosity, here the verb pique just means to arouse, stimulate, or excite.
examples: It also appeared to pique Mr. Paul’s questioning about whether the United States was outlining a foundation for war.
Also a fit of pique: the lack of sundresses in the early morning.
He reads articles online about breakthrough technologies that pique his interest.
He attributed the action by his daughter to a “fit of teenage pique” and said that they bore no animus toward her over the episode.

definition: reluctant to draw attention to yourself
details: Reticent means either quiet or restrained. If you're reticent about your feelings, you like to keep them to yourself, and you're probably quiet in rowdy groups where everyone is talking over each other.
examples: “I think he’s also kind of reticent to exploit things that are personal for political gain.”
The normally reticent Lou Williams spoke up after all the changes were made, imploring his teammates to stay the course and live with the consequences.
In public, however, Saudi Arabia’s relationship with Israel remains cautious and reticent.
Men as consumers are “reticent to buy into something that seems too polished,” says Mandle.

definition: plausible but false
details: Something false or inauthentic is spurious. Don't trust spurious ideas and stories. Spurious statements often are lies, just as a spurious coin is a counterfeit coin — a fake.
examples: But, he added, “a huge number of the inquiries I get are spurious.”
In the form of a spurious amendment to that last bill, the Republican congressman Sean Duffy effectively added a sixth: a version of the Green New Deal.
A spurious comparison of two different types of societal offenses leads to the implication that liberals believe racially charged language is an offense worse than murder.
They are very good at shutting climate into an echo chamber of spurious scientific uncertainty.

definition: liveliness and eagerness
details: Someone with alacrity shows cheerful willingness and eager behavior, like a kid whose mother has told him he can buy anything in a candy store.
examples: The choral singers need the utmost alacrity and clarity to do justice to the often-convoluted lines of Bach’s brilliant choruses.

Characters who seem destined to be recurring buddies, rivals, or mentors are killed off with shocking alacrity, with magic providing an excuse for why Belgrave’s campus isn’t swarmed with reporters responding to those deaths.
Often technology that doesn’t totally work is embraced with alacrity.
They rolled a maul in their own half and when Ken Owens lost possession, England counter-attacked with alacrity.

definition: perform an act, usually with a negative connotation
details: To commit is to fully dedicate yourself to something. To commit yourself to being the coolest kid on the beach means spending hours at the mall trying on trunks and flip-flops.
examples: At media day last September an excited Walker sounded committed to re-signing with the Hornets, saying he “wanted to create something” in Charlotte.
The inspector general’s office says Chicago police are committed to improvements but that some police proposals “substantially diverge” from report recommendations.

To probe these matters, military inspectors general from each branch are conducting internal investigations, interviewing families away from commands and housing operators, and exploring whether private contractors breached their agreements or committed financial fraud.
It charges him with “conspiring to commit computer intrusion,” a crime carrying a punishment of up to five years in prison.

definition: having or revealing keen insight and good judgment
details: Discerning people pick up on subtle traits and are good judges of quality — they're the ones who can tell if your cupcakes are homemade from the finest ingredients or totally from a box mix.
examples: With considerable grace and beguiling modesty, the movie frames its subject as one of Christ’s most discerning followers and a crucial witness to his ministry, death and resurrection.
Geoffrey Crew, an astronomer at MIT who helped coordinate the data processing, compared the effort to discerning a concerto played at a piano that is missing several keys.
The bureaucratic quantification of public administration goes far beyond an attempt at discerning efficacy.

“The four pillars of Brunei’s tourism products, these elements offer a unique blend of modern refinement, scenic culture, cultural reverence and majestic opulence for the discerning traveler,” the “Imagine Brunei” campaign continues.

definition: avoid and stay away from deliberately
details: If you eschew something, you deliberately avoid it. If you live the bohemian life in the city, then most likely you eschew the suburbs.
examples: The more the United States embraces extreme Israeli policies, the more Americans will refuse to back Israel as long as it denies rights to Palestinians, eschews diplomacy, and undermines the very nature of Israeli democracy.
But for the second year in a row, Mystics Coach and General Manager Mike Thibault eschewed the list of players the league deemed worthy of an invite to New York and a spot on ESPN.
The P30 Pro eschews an earpiece and instead vibrates the screen to generate call sound, which works shockingly well.
Both eventually abandoned the approach, concluding that it did not work, and Mr. Mulvaney eschews the hub-and-spoke term to avoid associations with those failed experiments.

definition: a worker who holds or is invested with an office
details: A functionary is someone who fills a specific role in a political party or some other organization. We tend to picture them as people in gray suits who follow the boss's orders and don't think for themselves.
examples: Rather, he thumbed his nose at the museum’s brass — “all elites,” in his sour opinion — and hung naive paintings of flowers wrought by his father, a mid-level bank functionary.
During her five years in the job she put 68 high-level functionaries on trial, including 14 government ministers or ex-ministers and 53 deputies from both houses of the Romanian parliament.
This time, the functionaries in the gray flannel suits were women.

Holocaust survivor Primo Levi said: “Monsters exist, but they are too few in number to be truly dangerous. More dangerous are the common men, the functionaries ready to believe and to act without asking questions.”

definition: arousing to action or rebellion
details: In medical terms, something that is inflammatory causes a local reaction that shows up by swelling, heat, pain, and redness. If you are stung by a bee, you may have an acute inflammatory reaction to the sting.
examples: Dickerson, a medical doctor, said some of the statements from law enforcement against the bill were inflammatory, misleading and disingenuous.
More recently, the composition of exhaled breath was shown to be different in patients with lung cancer, inflammatory lung or liver disease, hepatic or renal dysfunction or diabetes.
Trump also reportedly fixates on immigration because he believes he won the 2016 election by being an inflammatory hard-liner on the issue, leading chants about a border wall at every rally, etc.
An image I saw as thought-provoking was, instead, seen by Wahl as inflammatory.

definition: concise and full of meaning
details: A pithy phrase or statement is brief but full of substance and meaning. Proverbs and sayings are pithy; newspaper columnists give pithy advice.
examples: Reducing important messages to catchy slogans or pithy comments does not validate the value or idea one was hoping to spread — it does just the opposite.
For now, the new initiative is called the Collaborative Fund for Women’s Safety and Dignity, although there are plans to shift to a pithier name.
Scott Hechinger, a public defender in Brooklyn and a pithy presence on criminal justice on Twitter, made a similar point.
As a concept, that sounds cloying and self-involved, but if Adlon ever dangles her storylines close to those edges, she yanks them right back with a pithy line, or another abrupt end to a scene.

definition: the group following and attending to some important person
details: A retinue is a group of people that accompany an important person. If you're a king or queen, you can think of a retinue as your royal crew or posse.
examples: By contrast, Showalter and colleagues were actively hunting for moons to add to Neptune’s retinue.
Guban, the play tells how, during a visit to Moscow, the Devil and his rowdy retinue wreak gleeful havoc on the atheistic, bureaucratic Soviet order.
Gilded palanquins and chariots, preceded by runners and followed by retinues of servants, began to appear from the direction of the noblemen’s villas.
Ditto the protectors and the retinue, the shrinking pool of people to trust, the barrier built between you and the audience.

definition: sordid dirtiness
details: If something is extremely dirty, filthy or just plain disgusting, it falls into the territory of the noun squalor. We’re not just talking about a messy room. We’re talking about a dungeon riddled with rats and roaches.
examples: Statistics alone can't capture the cruelty and squalor of slave ships, though.
Penniless and uneducated, you’re viewed by affluent white society as every bit as inferior as the blacks you live among in overcrowded squalor.
"And there other jails with truly Third World levels of squalor and misery."
“And there other jails with truly Third World levels of squalor and misery.”

definition: a small recess opening off a larger room
details: Chapels in churches are often alcoves. Picture one set off to the side with a vaulted ceiling, separated by pillars and a small railing. See that and you see an alcove, defined.
examples: In her office, stock from her burgeoning line of products is stowed on elevated alcove shelving, which she reaches using her antique step ladder.
Two bedrooms, two baths, cozy pine “open concept” interior, cathedral ceiling, great room, dining alcove, 1,764 square feet.
He found it much more convenient to meet the many people vital to his job at his alcove table in the Blackfriar.

Police say in a news release that the woman, Chrystal Thompson, originally thought a hand warming device accidentally set her blankets on fire Thursday night while she slept in the alcove of a business.

definition: confused movement
details: A commotion is a noisy disturbance. If you're trying to quietly concentrate on reading this, you wouldn't want the person next to you to cause a commotion, or it would distract you.
examples: Seeing the commotion, Bathily shouted, “I’ll stop him, officers!” and kicked into gear, speeding ahead of the suspect and blocking his path with the bike, according to a Facebook post shared by the precinct.
Hart was later said to be OK after the commotion died down at the Barclays Center.
She says visitors contacted authorities after hearing commotion.
Before the commotion Monday, hundreds were gathered peacefully in the area, with fans and friends sharing memories of Hussle via a megaphone.

definition: cause to lose one's composure
details: To disconcert is to unsettle someone, make them feel confused and out of sorts. It's a mixture of to embarrass and to creep out.
examples: I find it disconcerting that your slightly overweight husband is so unattractive to you.
“And what’s a bit disconcerting, too, is that you never meet them,” he said of the new Chinese proprietors.
White people are being radicalised at an alarming rate and in disconcerting numbers.
How disconcerting it was as a teenager to open a novel with such a simple, sentimental title and read those unaccountable first lines: “124 was spiteful. Full of a baby’s venom.”

definition: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
details: Pssst... do you know the secret handshake? If you haven't been brought into the inner circle of those with special knowledge, esoteric things will remain a mystery to you.
examples: It’s also driven by different imperatives — an academic may choose to research an esoteric topic of interest, while a corporate research team tends to be driven by the demands of the market.
Only half a century ago, black holes were considered, in the words of Italian physicist Carlo Rovelli, “the barely credible predictions of an esoteric theory.”
Although it might seem at first glance to be a rather esoteric quest, researchers say it bears down directly on the question of how much the world is likely to warm in the centuries ahead.
A founder of a field called geometric analysis, Dr. Uhlenbeck approaches minimal surfaces esoterically, under the banner of “variational methods in geometry.”

definition: provide with objects or articles that make a room usable
details: If you provide something needed, you furnish it. You can furnish an answer to a question in an interview, furnish the snacks at a party, or furnish a room by filling it with couches and chairs.
examples: Used to create everything from book ends to home furnishings, concrete fits in especially well with modern, contemporary, rustic and industrial architectural design.

This, after the retailer said its turnaround initiatives including its experimental store formats, investments in its decorative furnishing business and digital platforms would drive its revenue growth and gross margin in mid and long term.
The request cited a 1924 federal law that states the IRS “shall furnish” the records at the request of lawmakers tasked with tax oversight.
Neal is relying on a 1920s-era law that says the IRS “shall furnish” any tax return requested by the chairmen of key House and Senate committees.

definition: lacking in sophistication or worldliness
details: Someone who is ingenuous shows a childlike innocence, trust, and openness. One of the things kindergarten teachers value is the chance to work with kids while they're still relatively ingenuous––their open, trusting natures are a joy.
examples: Esi’s childhood world is one of dreams, visions, and premonitions, which burst onto the screen with a spare, frank simplicity, reflecting the precocious yet ingenuous sensitivity with which she confronts implacable realities.
He is once more an ingenuous doofus; she is a lot more skeptical, if also more vulnerable than she lets on.

“In addition, gambling paraphernalia of all kinds, celo tables, poker and belita layouts, every device known to the ingenuous minds of the gambling fraternity, were found in what were once notorious resorts.”
But there is a touch of the deliberately ingenuous in what he says.

definition: cause to be more favorably inclined
details: When a husband shows up with flowers after he's fought with his wife, he's trying to placate her. If you placate someone, you stop them from being angry by giving them something or doing something that pleases them.
examples: The move was viewed as a bid by Mr Modi to placate small traders, also a key voter base.
There will be no adoring fans seeing her as innocent Aunt Becky from Full House, and no handlers, agents or red carpets to placate her in that austere courtroom.
To placate Washington, the Pakistani government goes through the ritual of issuing banning orders on those groups, but in practice, any change is minimal.
Trump’s veep, Mike Pence, is a former congressman and governor but his selection placated the religious right.

definition: not arrogant or presuming
details: If you are a retiring person, you avoid being at the center of attention. You can often be found in the library and other quiet places, and if someone compliments you, you're likely to blush and change the subject.
examples: “I’m not retiring,” Justice Thomas declared in an appearance last month at Pepperdine University.
Nowitzki announced he was retiring Tuesday night following Dallas’ final home game of the season.
After a pregame video tribute to Wade, the retiring superstar went over and hugged each of his three friends.
But retiring his number 29 might be another issue.

definition: excessively fastidious and easily disgusted
details: If you fainted or threw up at the sight of frog intestines in biology class, you’re squeamish — easily nauseated or shocked by unpleasant, icky things. No horror movies for you!
examples: Apparently, she needed to step aside for somebody less squeamish.
It’s not squeamish to say that some of her arguments are not simply uncomfortable but offensive, almost strategically so.
When doctors were performing the C-section March 12, Buckley said, her husband almost fainted — not because he was squeamish but because he was so worried about her.
Talking about bathrooms leaves a lot of people squeamish.

definition: arouse hostility or indifference in
details: When you alienate people, you make them stop liking or caring about you. Show up at a conference of cat lovers with a sign around your neck that says, "I hate kittens," and you'll learn firsthand what that means.
examples: Trump’s disregard for Palestinian interests is yet another reaffirmation for many that Trump’s America is racist; it will further alienate America from global partners and publics.
But tough economic polices might further alienate voters and hurt Mr. Erdogan’s chances of retaining power in Istanbul by forcing a repeat election.
It certainly wouldn’t alienate the collectors, who often look for inexpensive wines that play above their price.
But the approach also risks alienating moderate suburban voters, including those who took a chance on Trump’s candidacy in hopes that his dealmaker persona would overcome Washington gridlock.

definition: a deep awareness of and sympathy for another's suffering
details: If someone shows kindness, caring, and a willingness to help others, they're showing compassion.
examples: While we must abide by the rule of law, we can’t forget our call to compassion and we must remember – at some point in our lives and those of our ancestors – we were all strangers.
The center says this year’s daylong leadership forum will focus on those “tackling today’s most pressing challenges with compassion.”
“I felt a deep sense of compassion for the players and the coaches,” Carla Williams said this past Friday.
There is compassion for the weak and none for bullies of any rank, title or class.

definition: sad beyond comforting; incapable of being soothed
details: If you are sad and can't be cheered up, you're disconsolate. Why are you disconsolate after scoring a touchdown? Oh . . . for the other team.
examples: I was in England that week, watching demonstrators in the street: angry, boisterous, distressed, disconsolate, some waving the starred flag of the E.U., some draped in the Union Jack.
As her depression deepens, her prose grows more self-aware and more gravely disconsolate.
The gossiwor, played only in the king’s presence, produces a preposterous disconsolate bellow.
First, a disconsolate Scarlett O’Hara weaves her way through hundreds of injured Confederate soldiers lying prostrate on the streets of downtown Atlanta.

definition: choose and follow a theory, idea, policy, etc.
details: Use the verb espouse to describe the actions of someone who lives according to specific beliefs, such as your friends who espouse environmentalism and as a result walk whenever possible instead of taking the car.
examples: And to appeal to as many voters as possible, he espoused no firm policy positions and said little about fundamental issues like the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory suggests the government he forms in a record fifth term is likely to espouse more nationalistic views and show little inclination to negotiate peace with Palestinians.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s apparent election victory means the government he forms — his fifth — is likely to espouse more nationalistic views and show little inclination to negotiate peace with Palestinians.
They espoused the same racist conspiracy theories that the Judiciary Committee was trying to address.

definition: secret and sly or sordid
details: If you're looking for a formal adjective to describe something sly or secret, sneak in furtive. Let's hope the teacher doesn't see your furtive attempts to pass notes in class!
examples: APS seems comfortable employing furtive tactics to slip into classrooms controversial topics to which parents might object.
She clearly thinks I am insane, pointedly ignoring my furtive readjustments when Theresa shifts around as I sing.
On weekends, he drank heavily in the furtive bars that are scattered around downtown Cairo.
Her lavish descriptions of extravagant dinner parties, furtive meetings and daring escapes wrap you in sumptuous sensory detail.

definition: deeply rooted; firmly fixed or held
details: Use the adjective ingrained to describe the strong beliefs of someone who has thought that way for a very long time, such as the ingrained patriotism of a 20-year military veteran.
examples: “With the military, it’s now ingrained in the culture and mission there, which I think is the biggest change over the last 10 years.”
"That was ingrained in me from my grandparents to my parents and through the '60s," he told The Associated Press in 2002.
“But white supremacy is a far more dispersed and deeply ingrained ideology in Western society. It will be far harder to defeat than jihadism.”
Labour lawmakers in Britain quitting their party and citing ingrained anti-Semitism.

definition: the property of being physically malleable
details: Plasticity means "changeability" or "moldability" — clay has a lot of plasticity, but a rock has almost none.
examples: “Scott really showed one of the best examples of human plasticity and adaptability that we’ve ever seen.”
This is due to their phenotypic plasticity - the capacity of an individual organism to alter its physiology or gene expression in response to changing environmental conditions.
With brain plasticity, the brain is much more a function of experiences.
This rewiring, or plasticity, is thought to cause the antidepressant effect.

definition: a quick reply to a question or remark
details: A retort is a short, clever response to someone's comment or question. If you want to keep the peace during dinner, you should probably bite your tongue instead of making sarcastic retorts to everything your little sister says.
examples: “I'm not going to play these playground tactics with you. I'm going to keep the focus on black America,” Owens retorted.
“I believe I am,” Roland retorts and places his jersey on the coach’s desk.
“Because he’s a nematode?” she retorted while the crowd roared in laughter, comparing the president to the roundworms found as parasites in animals and plants.
Lowey used Twitter to “urge her to retract this statement and engage in further dialogue with the Jewish community,” which in turn prompted a public retort from Ocasio-Cortez.

definition: characterized by dignity and propriety
details: Something that is staid is dignified, respectable — possibly even boring, like a staid dinner party that is heavy on the important guests but light on the laughs.
examples: My wife, Julie, on the other hand, finds hymns a bit too staid and static.
Combine traditionalism and innovation in staid and shocking balance.
The old town is staid and stately: 12 of its mainly baroque buildings are Unesco-listed as “Classical Weimar”.
It will be one of the biggest trades in the 94-year history of the typically staid Giants franchise and may prove to be the most controversial.

definition: lessen the intensity of or calm
details: The verb allay is used when you want to make something better or eliminate fears and concerns.
examples: His testimony seemed to do little to allay their fears, as lawmakers suggested afterward they would press ahead with legal action to compel him to turn over more than he now intends.
Buyers say Snap’s latest announcements may allay audience growth concerns Tim Peterson talks to ad buyers who are impressed with Snap’s announcements from last week.
To allay those concerns, lawyers for Calpers were allowed to see information about the well findings.
Those concerns were allayed Monday as new economic data suggested a brighter outlook for the U.S. economy.

definition: force somebody to do something
details: Compel means to force or drive someone to do something. Even if you don't like toast, when you visit the toast-eating natives of Shrintakook Island, you'll be compelled to eat it, or they will not trust you.
examples: The EPA on Thursday declined to compel Boston-based GE to restart dredging in the Hudson River.

“We thank Newmont’s shareholders for their overwhelming support for this compelling value creation opportunity as we build the world’s leading gold company,” Newmont Chief Executive Gary Goldberg said in the statement.
His entry explains that he went to college to learn to tell compelling stories, but that he needed student loans to pay for it.
“This is about creating a constitutional right to discriminate. Ending discrimination is a compelling state interest, so I don’t expect them to open this door,” she said.

definition: not in agreement or harmony
details: If you believe that movies should entertain, but your friend insists that movies should inspire, then the two of you hold discordant views on the purpose of movies. That means your opinions are in conflict.
examples: The idea of purposeful listening—which is to say, merely listening—is becoming increasingly discordant with the way that music is sold to us.

Logan Bayroff, a spokesman for J Street, the liberal Jewish organization, said the president’s remarks about immigrants and minorities were “extremely discordant and extremely disgusting to the majority of Jewish people.”
Critics in Italy say the Saudi human rights record is discordant with the values of a democratic country embodied by La Scala.
Experts caution that some of O’Rourke’s gestures in Iowa were discordant with his speech.

definition: set up or found
details: To establish something means to begin it or bring it about. If you want everyone in your family to bring you chocolate every evening, you can establish a “Chocolates for Me” policy requiring it.
examples: And when they were ready to sign the papers to establish the league, they leaned on the hood of the car to finish up.
Under the current proposal, the Space Force would be established under the Air Force, as the Marine Corps is under the Navy.
A proposed amendment to the bill would require the State Public Charter School Authority to establish a five-year plan that includes the growth projection of charter schools.
Genetic genealogy is the use of DNA testing in combination with traditional genealogical methods to establish the relationship between an individual and their ancestors.

definition: producing no result or effect
details: When something fails to deliver a useful result, you can call it futile. Hopefully all the time you're spending studying vocabulary won't turn out to be futile!
examples: Twist, who’s lived in the community off and on since the 1970s, said that when the weather is warm he’ll walk his property, pulling up seedlings in an almost futile effort to eliminate potential fuels.
London’s slogan was as futile as Take Back Control.

Republicans hold the two-thirds majorities needed in both chambers to override a veto but at least a few GOP lawmakers were expected to vote against overturning Kelly’s action, making an attempt futile.
Going to try your best not to, but it's futile.

definition: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
details: To ingratiate is to make obvious efforts to gain someone's favor, in other words — to kiss up to someone.
examples: The movie seems to spring from a curious awareness of how unnecessary it is, and it responds in the manner of an uninvited guest, with no interest in behaving or ingratiating itself.
The accusers’ stories depict an out-of-touch, insubstantial old man desperate to ingratiate himself to everyone.
After he ingratiates himself with his new friends, he takes down his dinosaur posters and replaces them with tear-outs from skating magazines.

As she ingratiated herself into the New York party scene, prosecutors said, Sorokin started talking up plans to spend tens of millions of dollars building a private arts club with exhibitions, installations and pop-up shops.

definition: a trite or obvious remark
details: If an executive gives a speech that begins, "This business is all about survival of the fittest. You need to burn the midnight oil and take one for the team," his employees might get sick of listening to these meaningless clichés and tell him to cut the platitudes.
examples: He’s not given to banalities, and he’s too rigorous in this thought process—and too realistic about himself—to pump himself up with thin platitudes.
Asked how he would handle Gaza differently from Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Gantz rambled between platitudes about “rebuilding our deterrence” and “using our strength,” but offered no actual solutions.
But we didn’t hear much from Apple itself on why it picked these shows to develop, beyond some broad platitudes about storytelling.

Gerardo Torrado, the federation’s sporting director, introduced Martino in Spanish and English, showering him with platitudes and explaining how he “fits perfectly with the way we want the national team to be coached.”

definition: tighten one's belt; use resources carefully
details: When times are tight, it's time to retrench. That means rethink your budget, cut back on the spending, and use your pennies wisely.
examples: Consider again, the unfortunate contrast with May’s Conservative party, dogged by accusations of institutional Islamophobia and not only refusing to do much that is decisive, but retrenching in its denial that there is a problem.
When airlines retrenched during the Great Recession, both Boeing and Airbus used deferrals and other arrangements to persuade airlines to keep orders from evaporating.
And – despite President Trump’s recent statements to the contrary – economic and domestic pressure is not forcing Iran to retrench.

Districts that once represented the beating heart of the Republican Party rejected President Trump’s avowed nationalism as a form of bigotry, while Democrats further retrenched from the agricultural and industrial communities where they once dominated.

definition: a strong wooden or metal post driven into the ground
details: A stake is a wooden stick, sharpened on one end and used to mark property lines (or slay a vampire).
examples: Neither the shareholder letter nor the proxy statement made reference to Bezos’ divorce from MacKenzie Bezos, which will diminish his ownership stake, but not his voting rights.
The airline issued the statement after the U.S. said it was scrutinizing the Qatar state-owned carrier’s 49 percent stake in the Air Italy.
Maduro’s alliances with Cuba, Russia, and China raise the stakes of this crisis.
In this year’s vote, the very idea of Europe is at stake.

definition: report or maintain
details: If you accuse someone of committing a crime but the proof of the wrongdoing isn't yet found, use the verb allege. You might allege that your sister broke a vase, just because no one else was home when you heard the crash.
examples: A probable cause statement shows the alleged abused occurred in Utah when the girl was between the ages of 7 and 9.
Many protesters said that Auf, who is under US sanctions over alleged atrocities in Darfur, represented no change at all.
Intelligence sources alleged Russia was involved in the initial hacking.
A judicial panel began the review in response to citizen complaints after The New York Times published a story alleging the president and his siblings evaded inheritance taxes.

definition: a publication containing a variety of works
details: When you search an online encyclopedia, you are searching a compendium of information on just about everything. A compendium is a comprehensive collection of something.
examples: The group, formed under Barack Obama’s presidency, provided guidance to the government based on the National Climate Assessment, a major compendium of climate science released every four years.
The WHO says it will formally recognize traditional medicine in its compendium in May, meaning more mainstream recognition of practices dating back more than 2,500 years.
She’s been prescribed a dizzying compendium of psychotropic drugs – none of which seem to work and some of which cause side effects.
Basically a compendium of sexist jokes, the dyspeptic work was aimed at an audience of “the ordinary set of giddy-headed young men,” and it was very popular.

definition: the state of being held in low esteem
details: Discredit means to cause mistrust or cast the accuracy of something into doubt. If you say that schooling is important to you, but you never study, your actions discredit you and your words.
examples: “They were trying to use those things in my life to discredit me.”
Reportedly, he hopes to return to last year’s morally and legally discredited family separation policy.
It's hard to think of anyone in this country more discredited than Max Boot.
“I’m the one who stopped it,” Trump said, before repeating his discredited claim that family separations were an Obama-era practice.

definition: the condition of being honored
details: Esteem is all about respect and admiration. If you have high self-esteem, it means you like yourself. When you say, "My esteemed colleagues," you are saying you have nothing but the highest respect for them.
examples: The American Pianists Association awarded its 2019 Cole Porter Fellowship on Saturday to Emmet Cohen, a rising star whose résumé already includes stints with some of jazz’s most esteemed elders.
Written and directed by esteemed film critic and programmer Kent Jones in his narrative feature debut, “Diane” is first and foremost a showcase for actress Mary Kay Place in the title role.
But I think that black women who are entertained by Perry, from his initial audience of church-goers to younger, secular crowds, are not deriving their sense of personal esteem from his sermons.
On the evidence of this show, I don’t quite rank the esteemed Walker Evans with them, but he’s well represented here too; and all the photography here, by many hands, is rewarding.

definition: existing as an essential constituent or characteristic
details: Use the adjective inherent for qualities that are considered permanent or cannot be separated from an essential character.
examples: Huge themes are explored, including the plight of the underclass, the notion of inherent criminality, the force of justice and the role of citizens.
The practice is against the law, and as such carries inherent risks – including malware attacks.
The real show at Augusta begins on Thursday, and all the thrills and angst and theater inherent to it.
But critics long complained about inherent bias in the data — gathered by officers — that underpinned the tools.

definition: enter a defendant's answer
details: To plead with someone is to try to convince them to see it your way. Your kids may plead with you to let them go on the super-huge outrageous roller coaster built in 1968, but you know better.
examples: Michael Soares pleaded not guilty at his arraignment Thursday and was held without bail.
Hutchinson pleaded not guilty to the charges Thursday morning.
Court records show he appeared in court and pleaded not guilty Monday.
According to notes that she made after the meeting, Hayden pleaded with her to stop agitating against the program.

definition: unrestrained merrymaking
details: Revelry is a wild, fun time. If you enjoy the revelry of a New Year's Eve party, you might pay for partying hard the next day.
examples: With gays no longer flung from rooftops, beheadings halted, and crucifixions returned to antiquity, this revelry was just right.
The cameras are attached to trees or fences, chained with cable locks and left to record animal revelry on digital memory cards.
The revelry for a game involving teams within reasonable driving distance of Louisville began hours before tip-off.
But the locker-room revelry is trumped by one scene from the 2017 Final Four that linked the program’s past to the present.

definition: enduring strength and energy
details: If you can run for a really long time, or carry a heavy box a really long way, you have stamina. Stamina is staying power or enduring strength.
examples: But Mr. Netanyahu proved once again that his talents, stamina and willingness to do what it takes to win are all unmatched in Israeli politics.
Even after the occasional subpar performance, these Islanders do not panic, showing a mental stamina that bodes well for playoff success.
He said: “I don’t see many people with your stamina or your outlook.”
Even small improvements would likely help improve your stamina for both of you, if you’re that concerned and inclined to put in the effort.

definition: the act of binding yourself to a course of action
details: Every second grader knows how to pledge allegiance to the flag, but do you think they realize when they place their right hand over their hearts that they're expressing loyalty to what we call the "Red, White, and Blue"?
examples: The researchers created a mathematical measure of overall "flexibility"—how likely regions were to change their "module allegiance" and sync up with a different set of partners.
He is now seeing that allegiance slipping away as his most senior generals openly speak of taking over.
In March she suggested that supporters of Israel were pushing for U.S. politicians to declare "allegiance" to that nation.
He was originally a fan of both Manchester United and Fulham, but chose his current allegiance in 2006 when both teams were in the Premier League.

definition: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
details: If only the world were populated entirely with complaisant people! Complaisant means willing to do something to please others, and complaisant people or animals are wonderful to be around.
examples: Onstage, there was absolutely nothing complaisant about her.
These cases are quite different from the phoney stories planted by studio flacks from time immemorial, dependent on co-operative artists and a complaisant press.
The GPA ethos takes spirited children and pushes them to be hard working but complaisant.
Last month, in the Times, a respected house and techno veteran named Marea Stamper suggested that some of today’s complaisant “tropical house” wasn’t really tropical, and wasn’t even house music.

definition: marked by prudence or modesty and wise self-restraint
details: Discreet describes someone or something that is appropriately quiet, prudent, and restrained. If you are wearing a discreet gray suit, it is unlikely that anyone at that business meeting will notice you.
examples: A week or two after reporters were approved for prescriptions, the medications arrived in discreet packages.
No. When Anne was executed in 1536, Cromwell, a discreet but thoroughgoing Protestant, made sure that there was no return to the pope.
The week’s subsequent triumphs only further vindicated the central conservative consolation, more comforting than any discreet political victory: reality, eventually, reasserts itself.
The legal changes were announced in a discreet notice on the attorney general’s website, it said.

definition: arouse hostility or indifference in
details: To estrange people may sound like adding wobbly antennae and an extra eyeball to their faces. Really, estrange means to push apart people who were once close to each other and cause them to be like strangers.
examples: More than nine years separated the strangulation of a woman in her Upper West Side apartment and the conviction of her estranged husband, Roderick Covlin, for her murder.
And Lieberman, though personally estranged from Netanyahu, is ideologically congenial with him—if ideology is the right word for seeing Arab Israelis best approached by intimidation.
Rooney’s characters are similarly estranged from their environments and from one another.
And not long after becoming estranged from his youngest son, Jim, Guy started confiding in Laura that he was considering suicide.

definition: not friendly
details: Censorship is inimical to freedom. So, most teenagers would argue, are curfews. To be inimical is to be harmful, antagonistic, or opposed to something.
examples: The next day, Dr. Mechanik sent Mr. Westenberger another email, this one more inimical than lyrical, the words not so much tugging at his heart strings as much as they just tore.
The violence in her household was a private matter; invoking the police was, in this perspective, seen to be siding with an element considered inimical to her community.
But whereas Bosch’s crushing vision rests on a view of the material world as fallen, sinning and inimical to God, Bruegel’s vision quite knowingly sets God off to one side.
Whatever happens, the bedrock assumption that public blockchain networks are inimical to centralized private or public control needs to be qualified.

definition: a full supply
details: The noun plenitude means the state of being full or complete; also, an abundance. After the thirty inches of snow your town got over the weekend, you may joke that you have a plenitude of snow.
examples: Today the informational plenitude, range and instant access Hernando imagined for his universal library doesn’t seem at all quixotic.
Most of us drink somewhere between these ideals, of course, adrift in the sea of swill, the plenitude of plonk that defines supermarket wines.
Somehow, this plenitude is well served by only three lifts — a gondola that brings skiers more than halfway up the mountain and two chairs, the Ripper and the Stoke, that access the top.
For City Center, justly proud of that period and wishing to celebrate it with a festival, this range and plenitude was both an embarrassment of riches and a problem.

definition: a feeling of profound respect for someone or something
details: Reverence is a feeling of deep respect or awe — like what you have for a president, a hero, or a favorite football player.
examples: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Augusta National is a place of reverence and remembrance.
His reverence for exploring every corner of the world, even the sites of its most shameful histories, is infectious.
“My actions reflect an abiding reverence for our democracy and our institutions, and are in no way based on emotion of the moment or partisanship.”

“The four pillars of Brunei’s tourism products, these elements offer a unique blend of modern refinement, scenic culture, cultural reverence and majestic opulence for the discerning traveler,” the “Imagine Brunei” campaign continues.

definition: stop the flow of a liquid
details: Use the verb stanch to describe stopping a liquid from spreading. A bandage can stanch bleeding and thick towels can stanch the flow of water across the kitchen floor when you drop a full glass of water.
examples: The IRS commissioner aimed to stanch the country’s losses with what he proclaimed would be “a game-changing strategy.”
One is their limited capacity to stanch emigration and close their borders in the face of waves of their own citizens fleeing crime, violence and dysfunction.
She was stanching the blood with paper towels.
Closing the border is also unlikely to stanch the influx of asylum seekers, he said, because federal law authorizes them to request protection once they step on U.S. soil.

definition: a style that describes a subject by suggestive resemblances
details: The figurative style known as allegory has nothing to do with alligators — unless you're telling a story where alligators represent evil forces snapping at humanity.
examples: Serling, who died in 1975, envisioned “The Twilight Zone” as a delivery system for parables with deliberate messages of social justice and allegories of human weakness and folly, coated in a digestible layer of fantasy.
Ms. Soper performed the second selection, as an allegory of Reason, in which a neo-Classical piano part adds arch prettiness to a text that cleverly spins variations and puns on the same key words.
Here, the technique is applied to an allegory of nearly suffocating self-seriousness, to much less powerful effect.
From that moment on, “Styx” becomes a kind of moral allegory, crossed with an almost unbearably tense nautical thriller.

definition: disposed to act in accordance with someone's wishes
details: If you are willing to submit to someone's request, then you are compliant. Parents like it when their teenagers are compliant and follow the rules. Teenagers, on the other hand, are probably not as compliant as parents would like to think!
examples: Jennifer Hillman, a professor at Georgetown Law, said they appeared to be compliant with WTO rules, as long as the United States waited for the organization’s final decision before imposing its tariffs.
“I’m trying to be compliant with the law, but no one seems to be fully aware of what the law is and isn’t,” said C.J.
The investigation will look into whether the contractual arrangements between the U.S. company and EU institutions to process personal data are “fully compliant with data protection rules.”
A court docket shows a Medina Municipal Court judge in 2013 ordered Rini to be "compliant" in taking his psychiatric medication.

definition: a difference between conflicting facts or claims or opinions
details: A discrepancy is a lack of agreement or balance. If there is a discrepancy between the money you earned and the number on your paycheck, you should complain to your boss.
examples: In a statement, Hunt said its own audit first detected payment record discrepancies in 2017.
In most instances these differences are very small - less than a 1 percent discrepancy between block-level estimates and census figures for the city.
