Former federal prosecutor Joyce White Vance also noted the discrepancy between reports about the campaign’s briefing and the AG’s testimony.
Even when students do become aware of the discrepancy between these separate classes, and try to do something about it, their activism tends to run, inevitably, in four-year cycles.

definition: causing improvement in the offspring produced
details: Something eugenic relates to the idea that self-selecting genetic characteristics, like hair or eye color, can improve a race. The Nazis' eugenic plans to create a "master race" marked one of the darkest periods in the twentieth century.
examples: Setting is fate, we are to understand — and Herbert implicates the entire society in the killings, its patrimony of violence, eugenics and amnesia.

In the same filing, the state’s attorneys said: “Doctors must be viewed as healers, not as enablers and practitioners of eugenics and, more specifically, of overt racial discrimination, gender discrimination, and disability discrimination.”
The eugenics movement started in England and the U.S., not in Germany.
Nazism starkly illustrated the horrors that were a logical endpoint of eugenic privileging of population composition over individual human life.

definition: matchless
details: Use the adjective inimitable to describe someone or something that is so special or unique, it is impossible to duplicate, like that superstar tennis player with the inimitable serve no other player can copy.
examples: Then he called Marina Abramovic, who in her inimitable style said: “Why call it that? When they made Apple, they didn’t call it the Apple Computer.”
Although Sweet took a looser, more colorful approach than Monroe, whose black-and-white work was more studied, their collaboration resulted in a poignant tribute to an inimitable time and place.
The inimitable James Baldwin captures the depth which both burdens hope and inspires it.
The show skillfully reminds us that Blagojevich’s TV appearances a decade ago were meant to curry favor with the public—a fact that Trump himself remarked on, in his inimitable, racially gross way.

definition: affording an abundant supply
details: Something that's plenteous is abundant — there's plenty of it. If the spaghetti at dinner is plenteous, you won't think twice about having seconds, or even thirds.
examples: To put it succinctly, Truman took the side of a tiny people with no oil against a plenteous people with lots of it.
He calculated that one-fifth of the produce of years so extraordinarily plenteous would serve for the seven scarce years.
“And there from day to day We lingered a full year, and banqueted Nobly on plenteous meats and delicate wines.”
Abundant and plenteous refer to largeness of quantity; as, abundant stores; plenteous harvests.

definition: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
details: When you have great awe and respect for someone or something, and you show it by respectfully worshiping that person, thing, deity, or musical group, you are being reverent.
examples: Johnson is one of a very small handful of players who other players talk about in reverent tones of awe at times.
James Herriot, the pen name for English veterinarian James Alfred Wight, is known for his series of reverent animal stories published in the 1970s celebrating the integrity of animals in our world.
This new, reverent language around dieting offers innumerable euphemisms for eating disorders.
He tells me all this slowly and precisely, his tone reverent.

definition: having a sharp inclination
details: Steep means sharply angled. When hiking trails lead straight up mountainsides, they've got a steep incline. Steep also means "to soak in," as in steeping a tea bag in boiling water.
examples: Two weeks ago, the benchmark loan rate marked its steepest weekly drop in a decade, from 4.28%.
But, alas, the price of revolution, of dignity, of freedom, is often treacherously steep.
The goats recently chewed a swath through Pioneer Park near Margaret Rodda’s Victorian home, which sits on a steep draw above a creek.
It requires a proper interagency master planning process, one steeped in community consultation.

definition: provide physical relief, as from pain
details: Do all these words make your head ache? If so, take an aspirin to alleviate, or relieve, your pain.
examples: Heather voted to leave the EU, but she no longer believes Brexit will deter immigrants or alleviate the pressure they’ve put on hospitals and public housing.
As she prepared for a surgical procedure to alleviate pain in her shoulders and back, doctors noticed something else.
There he expressed support for security initiatives and programs to alleviate hunger.
She said they explained that ending the contract would alleviate the city of potential future litigation.

definition: behave in a certain manner
details: Comport means to behave, and particularly to behave well. If you attend a school for social etiquette, you will learn how to comport yourself properly at the dinner table.
examples: In January, rumors surfaced on social media criticizing how Moos comported himself in public and predicting an imminent firing.
This certainly comports with many experts' assumptions about how such a report would be organized.
That is simply a lie, and he knows it, but of course, the press reports his statements uncritically and without informing the public that what Nadler says does not comport with the law.
And regardless of whether those facts comport with one’s political preferences, we should all be willing to accept the facts, whatever they may be.

definition: constituting a separate entity or part
details: Discrete means separate or divided. A discrete unit is a separate part of something larger. A room is a discrete space within a house, just as the crankshaft is a discrete part of a car engine.
examples: The approach, with roots in the 18th century, describes the structure of networks of discrete, interacting parts, be they friends linked on social media or grains in a sand pile.
He and his collaborators also explained the quantum Hall effect — in which a material’s electrical resistance varies in discrete steps — as another type of topological persistence.
A spokesperson for Desmond told the outlet that he assisted with “a discrete reporting matter for a subsidiary company that was resolved with no tax impact.”

Although the exhibition includes a number of large installations, Ward is best as a creator of curious and discrete sculptures, ones that remind us that our world is filled with potentially magical objects.

definition: a formal expression of praise for someone who has died
details: At every funeral, there comes a moment when someone speaks about the life of the person who died. The speaker is delivering what is known as a eulogy. A eulogy is a formal speech that praises a person who has died.
examples: In “All My Puny Sorrows,” a woman giving a eulogy is interrupted by her toddler, who opens the urn and scoops the ashes into his mouth.
This man who never really knew him, cobbling together crib notes for a eulogy with no meaning, all pious insouciance.
“I disagreed deeply with Strom on the issue of civil rights, and on many other issues, but I watched him change,” he said in the eulogy.
It’s a script for a commemorative ceremony, a eulogy banked years before its occasion.

definition: characterized by injustice or wickedness
details: Something that is iniquitous is extremely immoral or wicked, such as an iniquitous political regime that assassinates its enemies.
examples: The law calls such work “dehumanizing” and based on a “highly iniquitous caste system.”
“The amount of suffering in this country, when compared to its resources, is iniquitous,” he writes.
In a statement released by their lawyer, Robert Bennett, members of Ms. Damond’s family applauded the charging decision and called it “one step toward justice for this iniquitous act”
But it also brought the temporary relief of a shared purpose in the effort to defeat the one combatant so iniquitous that almost every participant in the war finally saw it as their enemy.

definition: extreme excess
details: Plethora means an abundance or excess of something. If you have 15 different people who want to take you on a date, you have a plethora of romantic possibilities.
examples: She said blacks in the U.S. are facing a plethora of issues and Democrats appear intent on trying to focus on items like white nationalism.
Modelling HFpEF is challenging because of the complex interplay of many contributing factors and the plethora of clinical manifestations of the disease.
My team collected a plethora of social media data and also conducted interviews with a range of tobacco brand ambassadors, party attendees, influencers and industry insiders from around the world.
He’s tapping a lifetime of thinking on a plethora of subjects for something of an epic poem of his own, now running about 5,000 lines, he said.

definition: an abstracted state of absorption
details: If you're relaxing on the beach, dreaming of how you will never have to get up and go back to work, you're engaged in a reverie, or pleasant daydream.
examples: He seemed to be watching in a reverie as terrain emerged—tundra, ocean, blankness, covering the paths he’d just travelled.
In his only published essay about another novelist, which appeared in 1968, Williams objected to Henry Miller’s “almost mechanic alternation” of narrative and reverie.
Its successor, “When I Get Home,” is something different: a reverie, a meditation, a therapeutic retreat, a musicians’ playground.
He leaned in to photobomb the Adams clan taking a photo, then resumed his reverie.

definition: very loud or booming
details: The adjective stentorian describes a booming voice. If you're teaching a group of unruly kids, you'll need to practice a stentorian voice to be heard above the din.
examples: Once he steals the gold, forges the magic ring and becomes the gods’ powerful nemesis, this Alberich dominated the rest of the opera, rather than, as usual, a stentorian Wotan.
But the self-help framework — the stentorian assertions of diagnosis and cure — does Havrilesky a disservice.
Her stentorian voice meant her lifts wisely kept their hands to themselves.
A stentorian voice-over described his plans to protect Social Security, “diversify the economy” and protect the coal industry.

definition: make an indirect reference to
details: When you allude to something, you don't identify it or mention it specifically. If you allude to the fact that a cop is sitting right behind you, your friends might stop talking about their plans to rob a bank.
examples: An extraordinary song, sombre and foreboding, alluding to both a serial child murderer in Düsseldorf in the early 1930s and to the rise of nazism.

Several times, the complaint alludes to Ms. Huffman’s “spouse,” noting that Mr. Singer told the authorities that he met with Ms. Huffman and her spouse to explain how “the college entrance scheme worked.”
On the back, the brief script goes from left to right, and alludes to an informal contract.
“That era was kind of the birth of DNO being an operation,” Mr. Currie said, alluding to a shift for his brand from hobby to career and viable business.

definition: broad in scope
details: When you want to describe something that includes all or most details, you can use the adjective comprehensive. If you get the comprehensive treatment at a spa, it might include massage, manicure and a facial.
examples: Film Cram’s season 7 recap is 10 times as long, but offers a much more comprehensive look at what happened last season.
An agency spokesman declined to comment on how the agency “performs its mission,” but said that its activities are constitutional and subject to “comprehensive and rigorous” oversight.
While some on the right may worry that a UBI would reduce work incentives, comprehensive research on Iran’s UBI found that most residents did not cut back on work hours.
Contacted by Sotheby’s, the library provided a comprehensive inventory of lost objects, which most cultural institutions compiled after the second world war, from which a match was made.

definition: not earmarked; available for use as needed
details: Discretionary means it's up to you to decide. Bathing regularly is a discretionary act, so you can opt not to do it if you want; note, however, that your friends might disagree with us on this.
examples: Sequestration lingers to this day over what Congress terms as "discretionary" spending.
Your payments would be 10% of your discretionary income, defined as the difference between your total income and 150% of the poverty guideline for your family size and state of residence.
The choice of residence is often seen as a discretionary one.
Under the measure, a city would be ineligible for discretionary funds or grants administered by the state if the attorney general determines it is an illegal sanctuary city.

definition: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
details: Pardon me, but when a polite term is substituted for a blunt, offensive one, you should call it a euphemism.
examples: Take Back Control was a euphemism for the balkanisation of Britain, for atomisation, for communitarianism based in ethnicity, class, place, faith.
Dulles, appreciative of life’s ironies, was amused by the euphemism given to Gottlieb’s task force within the CIA’s Technical Service division.
Mineral wool is a euphemism for a material made by melting rocks.
Towering barriers — “peace walls” is the official euphemism — bisect neighborhoods, preserving stability by separating communities.

definition: not established by conditioning or learning
details: If a characteristic or ability is already present in a person or animal when they are born, it is innate. People have the innate ability to speak whereas animals do not.
examples: Often, confidence requires believing that a talent is learnable rather than innate.
This wasn’t exactly a conscious decision; it was more of an innate movement, like a deer going to a salt lick or a goat going to the top of a hill.
Such languages would be better suited to responding to internal compasses, added Kirschvink, and would help men and women to think in ways that keep them tuned to their innate abilities to navigate.
But in time, something of a mystery begins to develop, suggesting that Diane is driven by penance as much as an innate sense of altruism.

definition: examine thoroughly and in great depth
details: To plumb a body of water, you measure its depth. To plumb a house, you connect all of its pipes. To make carpentry plumb, you get it exactly vertical.
examples: The U.K. taught me that the opposite of "British" is "plumbing."
Scientists are now plumbing genomes for other clues to Homo sapiens’ survival, looking at our metabolisms or resistance to disease, he said.
“I cook. I clean. I do window glazing. I do ceramic tile. I do linoleum tile. I do plumbing. I do plastering. I do painting. I’m good on the computer.”
The A’s are still contending with antiquated plumbing at the Oakland Coliseum, the team’s home for the past 51 years.

definition: intense aversion
details: Revulsion means an intense, violent, sometimes physical dislike of something. People feel revulsion to different things. You may feel revulsion at the thought of seeing a horror movie, but other people can't wait to be scared by the latest zombie or slasher flick.
examples: Trump doesn't recognize the fundamental difference between victory and defeat, but then, Hillary didn't recognize the key distinction between support and revulsion in 2016.
In a feature titled “The Year of Outrage,” Slate magazine documented 365 incidents, one for every day of the year, that incited widespread revulsion or protest on social media.
A revulsion for Hollywood and its fraudulence still lingers.

What distinguishes Potrykus is his willingness to force this pain — as he did with “Ape” in 2014 and, a year later, “Buzzard” — to the point where our initial revulsion for a character transforms into compassion.

definition: a symbol of disgrace or infamy
details: If something has a negative association attached to it, call this a stigma. Bed-wetting can lead to a social stigma for a six year old, while chewing tobacco might have the same effect for a sixty year old.
examples: But the illegality of abortions creates a social stigma.
But others decide to disclose to gain support, exercise their civil rights, and break the stigma.
In 2017, the princes led a campaign to erase the stigma of mental health illness and spoke of their personal struggle following their mother’s death in a Paris car crash in 1997.
I don’t ascribe stigma to it and neither do they.

definition: remote in manner
details: Someone who's aloof isn't warm and friendly, instead being distant and reserved. That emotionally cold and detached fellow who keeps to himself, drinking espresso and reading French philosophy, would best be described as aloof.
examples: From afar, she is the reserved, aloof foil to the colorful Grace Coddington, another Vogue editor.
Both are quirky and dryly funny, with a distinctive style that blends aloof New York art-punk and European ennui.

But for that to happen, “a profound reconciliation” was needed between Venezuela’s opposition – long regarded as an opulent, aloof, and overwhelmingly white elite – and the poor, “and this needs to start now”.
I realized how...professionally aloof his words were.

definition: an accommodation in which both sides make concessions
details: A compromise is a way of settling differences by everybody making concessions. If you want to stay out until 10 and your friend wants to stay out until midnight, 11 is a good compromise.
examples: Democrats, though, charged that this week's testimony indicated Barr was a compromised witness.
EU officials and diplomats said the new October deadline was a compromise between French President Emmanuel Macron and most others, including Germany, which wanted a longer extension.
“If the government is serious, the red lines must move and we must see a real compromise,” he said.
Unusually, the EU’s two most powerful leaders failed to reach a Franco-German compromise at their bilateral meeting in Brussels before the summit with the other EU leaders started, diplomats said.

definition: showing or indicating careful judgment and discernment
details: Someone discriminating has fine-grained judgment and can tell, for example, the difference between pretty good cookies and incredibly great cookies — a valuable skill.
examples: "Yale is discriminating against religious organizations," Hawley told "Fox & Friends" Wednesday morning.
Federal law forbids companies from discriminating against pregnant women and mandates that pregnancy-related health-care expenses be covered in the same way as other medical conditions.
A federal judge is weighing a lawsuit accusing Harvard University of discriminating against Asian-American applicants.
She was not surprised that the Saints adamantly denied discriminating against women or that they threatened to sue her for defamation.

definition: any pleasing and harmonious sounds
details: Shakespeare's language is a good example of euphony: pleasant, musical sounds in harmony, as with “To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow / Creeps in this petty pace from day to day.”
examples: He was richly alive to cadence and euphony.
Viols, cousins to the modern string family, produce dainty sounds that blend together with the utmost euphony when played well.
And when he played a zither, its euphony cascaded through the room.
Its easeful euphony clearly made a strong impact on the audience.

definition: not injurious to physical or mental health
details: Something that's innocuous isn't harmful or likely to cause injury. Public figures like mayors and governors have to expect they'll get critical or even hurtful emails and phone calls, as well as more innocuous feedback.
examples: It seemed innocuous at the time, a cousin of common, easily treated fungal infections.
For a game that turns the Capital into a war zone, “The Division 2” aims to be as innocuous as possible.
Pompeo’s innocuous acknowledgment that he holds a faith shared by many others in public office, including many on the Left, was apparently too much for The New York Times.
The advice itself is mostly innocuous; it’s just that the entry point to the advice, and the mental health speculation, happens to be the lives of real people.

definition: drop sharply
details: The verb plummet means "to drop sharply," like eagles that plummet toward earth, seeking prey, or school attendance that plummets when there is a flu outbreak.
examples: Not coincidentally, the pace of advance ticket sales for Coachella suddenly plummeted.
It plummeted into single digits in terms of parliamentary seats.
The Labor Party, which founded Israel and dominated politics for its first 30 years, plummeted to a historic low of just six seats in the 120-member parliament.
Similarly, the Labor Party, once practically synonymous with the state of Israel, plummeted into single digits in terms of parliamentary seats.

definition: using language effectively to please or persuade
details: Rhetoric is speaking or writing that's intended to persuade. If your goal is to write editorial columns for "The New York Times," you should work on your rhetoric.
examples: The shorthand rhetoric is often misleading, and usually lazy, but it also tends to be inconsequential.
There is all this rhetoric and messaging by the NRA and other parts of the right wing which connects guns to fear of "black crime" or "crime by minorities."
“I really hope that it wasn’t just campaign rhetoric.”
But what happens to those who don’t understand this feminist rhetoric?

definition: artificially formal
details: The adjective stilted describes something—usually a style of writing or speaking—that is unnaturally formal.
examples: The discussion of Austen was stilted at first, but it gained animation as we grew more comfortable with each other and the material.
The tone taken by many other sitcoms was more stilted.
She played snooty socialite Tracy Lord, the role made famous by Katharine Hepburn, but critics panned her performance as stilted.
You mention that your stilted note was from the partner you shared most with.

definition: showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others
details: Someone who is altruistic always puts others first. An altruistic firefighter risks his life to save another's life, while an altruistic mom gives up the last bite of pie so her kid will be happy.
examples: Like the collaboration of Serita and Wang-Breal, the court takes a similar altruistic approach to the defendants, trying to serve those that appear in it.
There is nothing altruistic about any of this.
But now that he’s not running, such spending would look far more altruistic—assuming of course he follows through on that plan.
Busch doesn’t want disappearance to sound like an option only for the privileged, so she ends her book with comments on how diminishing the self might lead one to become kinder, more altruistic.

definition: an artistic device or effect
details: If you’re always boasting and can’t stop talking about yourself, you have that character flaw known as conceit. Your friends — if you have any — may also complain about your arrogance, vanity, and egotism.
examples: I’m eager to see the show find yet more creative ways to expand upon its central conceit: that even in the antiseptic, brightly-lit modern world, monsters are all around us.
The fanciful inclusion of an imagined letter back from Welles, read by Jack Klaff, is Cousins regrettably stretching his conceit to its breaking point.
The time-loop conceit allows the show to explore its themes without forcing viewers to confront the misery and degradation of serious addiction.
The film is a nervously-shot, dizzying hodgepodge of ideas, symbolism and conceits — and a bummer from start to finish.

definition: tending to cover a wide range of subjects
details: If people accuse you of rambling from topic to topic in your speech or writing, they may say you have a discursive style — with changes in subject that are hard to follow. But it's okay because unicorns are shiny.
examples: During Mr. Trump’s 50 minutes of discursive remarks, which were ostensibly to announce a national emergency to build a wall along the southern border, the president appeared to be taking that challenge himself.
Among socialists, he attracted negative attention for discursive essays he wrote in florid, wandering prose.
Mr. Trump’s discursive style delighted his crowd, though protesters heckled him more frequently than at other rallies since he became president.
Newscasts and newspaper articles would describe debates among bloggers and social-media users from a distance, as discursive curiosities.

definition: tending to vanish like vapor
details: A beautiful sunset, a rainbow, a wonderful dream right before your alarm clock goes off — all of these could be described as evanescent, which means “fleeting” or “temporary.”
examples: The design, like the name, plays off the fashionable idea that culture should be both grand and provisional, spectacular and temporary, awe-inspiring and evanescent, like a giant dance party or an epic flash mob.
Until then, her successor is a matter of key importance to the stability of an evanescent art.

“The Mustang” is direct and almost perilously familiar — it draws from both westerns and prison movies — yet it is also attractively filigreed with surprising faces, unusual genre notes and luminous, evanescent beauty.
These evanescent waves greatly enhance the transfer of heat between the objects, compared with when they are separated by a larger gap.

definition: difficult or impossible to understand
details: Any person or thing that's mysterious, mystifying, hard to read, or impossible to interpret is inscrutable. You ever notice how it's hard to tell what some people are thinking? Those folks are inscrutable.
examples: However, the observations do not yet reveal anything about the black hole’s inscrutable interior.
The fossil record was a vast unknown, as inscrutable as the ocean depths themselves.
In the end, his positions on health care were often a bit inscrutable and seemingly contradictory.
“Hi,” he said after a moment of silence, the expression in his eyes inscrutable.

definition: the arithmetic operation of summing
details: A plus is an “advantage” or an “asset.” You might look silly walking around with flippers all day, but if you lived underwater, they would definitely be a plus.
examples: They asked for documents on potential acquisition and operation of the regional networks plus MLB’s strategies.
The NHS advises against booking procedures advertised as a “treatment plus a holiday.”
The proposal is backed by many in Labour and other opposition parties, plus some of May’s Conservatives.

definition: a traveler who actively sits and travels on an animal
details: Riders are people who are in motion — riding bicycles, subways, horses, roller coasters and much more. Another kind of rider is a special list that attaches to, or "rides along" with, a contract.
examples: Safety experts say riders will need to confirm the car’s license plate and ask the driver to recite the rider’s name and destination.
When riders open the app, they’ll see a message about updated pricing information and will be asked to acknowledge the change to unlock a scooter.
A recent federally funded report found that a majority of the riders on airport lines are not going to the airport.
Instead of owning the scooter outright, riders will now find Inboard’s scooter as part of fleets operated by other companies.

definition: supply sparingly and with restricted quantities
details: The noun stint means a set amount of time in which you do something — often work of some sort. "She served a stint in the army, followed by a stint in an office setting, before settling on a career as a lounge singer."
examples: He emerged as the leading candidate at BYU after his successful stint at Utah Valley, where he compiled a 77-56 record over four seasons.
As for the Tacoma, taller drivers may not be able to find a comfortable position for long stints on the highway.
Her time at The Post also includes a five-year stint in the Travel section.
The American Pianists Association awarded its 2019 Cole Porter Fellowship on Saturday to Emmet Cohen, a rising star whose résumé already includes stints with some of jazz’s most esteemed elders.

definition: bring or combine together or with something else
details: To amalgamate is to combine different things to create something new. Institutions — such as banks, schools, or hospitals — often join forces and amalgamate with one other. But other things — like musical genres — get amalgamated as well.
examples: His turntables occupied a corner under bookshelves, where he endlessly practised beat-matching, and our record collections amalgamated.
The Democrat-led House last week approved one amalgamated spending bill, addressing six areas of spending and one measure to fund the Department of Homeland Security through Feb. 8.
She, too, uses Cunningham’s vocabulary — but she amalgamates it with movements from sport and pedestrian movement.

In the industrialized world, smaller producers can’t survive, their land amalgamated into the holdings of ever larger farms — in the process decimating rural and small town economiesand threatening public health.

definition: an abstract or general idea inferred from specific instances
details: A concept is a thought or idea. If you're redecorating your bedroom, you might want to start with a concept, such as "flower garden," or, if that's too femme, "black hole in outer space."
examples: They draw lines to connect related words and phrases, stretching the lines to put distance between dissimilar concepts.

Benedict wrote that after the Second Vatican Council there was a “far reaching breakdown” of the traditional methods of priestly formation that coincided with a dissolution of the Christian concept of morality.
A last thought from Dr. Sturm, who, for all of her momentum, cautioned that G-Beauty is a marketing concept and that nationality doesn’t tell you if a product is “clean.”
Ms. Quant did not attend previews of the show, but Ms. Lister said she supported the concept.

definition: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
details: If you feel that something isn't worthy of your consideration, you may disdain it (or treat it with disdain).
examples: But his relations with American presidents continued to be fraught, and he and President Obama developed a deep mutual disdain.
His writings as a college student at Duke University showed a disdain for multiculturalism and hardened a reputation as a rightwing ideologue.
“This is done with no regard for gun owners and in fact an outright disdain for rural residents,” he wrote in an email.

Even the contenders were not immune: Kyrie Irving kept rocking the boat for the Boston Celtics, and the Warriors’ Kevin Durant repeatedly flashed his short-tempered disdain for the media and his critics.

definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment
details: If something is evident, it's visible. If you blush furiously and start shaking every time your crush comes near, your infatuation will be evident to everyone.
examples: “So if you were following along, I think it was pretty evident early on that the show was going to get ahead of the books.”
For immigration, though, the effects are rapid and evident.
As an example, he cited the line: “Whatever is hidden shall become evident and nothing shall remain unavenged.”
Crowds at National Harbor Tuesday afternoon were enjoying warm spring weather, but concerns over the case were evident.

definition: devoid of feeling and consciousness and animation
details: Insensate is a word to describe something without feelings or consciousness. Cars, computers, and stuffed animals are all insensate (though some of us occasionally project thoughts and personalities onto them).
examples: Summer of 1918—Breath of hope that sweeps over the scorched fields, raging fever of impatience, of disappointment, of the most agonizing terror of death, insensate question: Why?
Slumped by the fire, in the midst of all of that shouting, was Dr. Trefusis, insensate, shivering though near flame, stubble upon his cheeks and chin, his scarce hair still clammy.

In a federal court documents filed last week, Ledford’s attorneys said years of taking a drug for nerve pain changed his brain chemistry, which means pentobarbital will not reliably render him unconscious and insensate.
Cardona favored a cocktail of heavy tranquillizers and Red Bull, administered at regular intervals throughout the day, which rendered him alert but insensate.

definition: a platform raised above the surrounding level
details: A podium is a raised platform like the kind Olympians stand on when they win a medal or like the overturned crate in the garage where you pretend to accept your Academy Award.
examples: Both politicians took to the Plymouth Church podium the other evening.
“Short of John Wooden sitting next to me on the podium, you will never get consensus from your fans whether it was a good hire or not,” he said.
The players and coaches walked down a path set off by barricades, high-fiving fans on their way to a podium.
The Italian marque filled the podium after also sweeping the four-car front row.

definition: disturb, especially by minor irritations
details: To rile someone is to annoy or bother them. For example, a friend might rile you by constantly texting when you're trying to have a conversation with her. You can also rile water, meaning you make it muddy by stirring it up.
examples: Sen. Mazie K. Hirono, Hawaii Democrat, said the Republican push for the bill was meant “to rile up the Trump base.”
And it’s a president, convinced that hard-line immigration rhetoric and policies are key to his political brand, who is more intent on riling up his base than forging a workable solution.
Both camps are trying to rile up their bases to become the largest party in parliament while also convincing the smaller parties to join them in a coalition after the results become known.
The style sent shock waves through the golf community and riled a nation-wide debate over whether collarless golf shirts were "golf appropriate."

definition: make an express demand or provision in an agreement
details: To stipulate something means to demand that it be part of an agreement. So when you make a contract or deal, you can stipulate that a certain condition must be met.
examples: The TSA’s official rules for handling and traveling with cremated remains stipulates that officers may not open crematory containers.
The bill also prohibits dispensaries from using medical symbols, like a cross, and stipulates that advertisements must contain one of four medical warnings.
The challenge is to justify her incarceration if we stipulate that she wasn’t.
Gun companies are protected from most legal action when their weapons are used to commit a crime, as stipulated by Congress in 2005.

definition: having more than one possible meaning
details: Look to the adjective ambiguous when you need to describe something that's open to more than one interpretation, like the headline "Squad helps dog bite victim."
examples: Albritton insists he’s not trying to neuter the ethics law, but instead is seeking “clarity” because public officials are confused about what they see as an ambiguous law.
She says that his secretive and morally ambiguous behavior reminds her a lot of the president.

Sensitivity, in contrast, involves a difficult, awkward, ambiguous encounter between two differently shaped bodies that are themselves ambiguous—and this meeting, this sensing, requires and takes place in time.
What’s best in this “Oklahoma!” is the morally ambiguous cue Fish develops so smartly from Rodgers and Hammerstein’s own narrative impulses.

definition: something that interests you because it is important
details: Concern is both a noun and a verb. As a noun it's something that you find particularly important. If you love pizza, getting the crust just so is a major concern during your pizza party.
examples: But both the World Bank and its sister organisation, the International Monetary Fund, are concerned about the risks of corruption and over-indebtedness.
Dan Arking, a professor at Johns Hopkins Medicine who was not involved in the study, agreed that the finding is concerning.
That said, it is important to note that traveling to Mars or other long-distance explorations presents an additional concern: radiation.
And the slowdown in growth looks more concerning against that backdrop.

definition: exit from a ship, vehicle, or aircraft
details: Use the verb disembark to describe leaving a ship, airplane or other type of vehicle, like making sure you haven't left anything in the plane's overhead compartment before you disembark.
examples: Two children, aged one and six, and their mothers were given permission by Italy’s interior ministry to land in Lampedusa for medical reasons but the women refused to disembark without their husbands.
Witnesses also say the riders were disembarked via a set of metal steps on the side of the track.
Restoring the ride-free zone entails adjustments, to collect fares when disembarking rather than boarding.
As the Mortons prepared to disembark, they were arrested by federal agents.

definition: make worse
details: For a formal-sounding verb that means to make worse, try exacerbate. If you're in trouble, complaining about it will only exacerbate the problem.
examples: Officials were hoping the latest big storm wouldn’t exacerbate flooding along already swollen rivers.
But rather than address this humanitarian crisis, the president and his trusted satrap seek only to exacerbate it for political gain.
Environmentalists were quick to criticize the orders issued Wednesday, which they said would exacerbate climate change.
Kevin Washington: The hardline approach that Trump takes exacerbates the psychic trauma encountered by non-white populations while at the time emboldens those holding racist views.

definition: barely able to be perceived
details: The adjective insensible is used to describe someone who is unconscious. If you keep your bowling ball on the top shelf of the closet and it rolls out and conks you on the head, you will be probably rendered insensible.
examples: But with Bosie murmuring poisonous advice in his ear, Wilde famously, stupidly delays — as if insensible to his own impending doom.
With so many awards in circulation — this year’s trophy-count clocked in at an insensible 84 — it’s hard to tell whether the Grammys are getting any closer to solving their many problems.
Some readers will be dismayed that Bering seems insensible to larger sociological concerns.

During a December 2016 inspection of the facility, federal officers reported the premises lacked proper, operable equipment to stun or otherwise render the animals insensible to pain, as required by law.

definition: a quality that arouses emotions, especially pity or sorrow
details: The noun poignancy refers to something that is deeply touching, especially something that brings forth strong emotions like sympathy, sadness, or sorrow. The poignancy of the movie may bring you to tears. Bring tissues. Lots of tissues.
examples: That’s the poignancy of Burns’s book: It illustrates the gap between knowing the right thing and getting it done.
But Harrison’s music is shaded with poignancy and sweetness, and this palpable warmth is in the dancing too.
Why shouldn’t I lean into the poignancy, made manifest on the stage, of a familiar struggle?
But it couldn’t compete with the pristine integrity and shaggy poignancy of “Columbia Icefield,” often gloomy yet somehow never quite depressing.

definition: stir up so as to form small waves
details: A ripple is a small wave on the surface of something, such as a ripple that forms a ring around the spot where you threw a pebble into the pond.
examples: In 2016, scientists revealed ripples in space-time caused by black holes colliding — the first-ever detection of the phenomenon known as gravitational waves.
There was even a ripple of applause when the 14-times major champion entered, a definite breach of protocol on behalf of the press.
Last week, palaeontologists felt the shock waves from that impact ripple through their small community.
As news of the college-admissions scandal broke, ripples of chatter emanated from wealthy enclaves of the United States.

definition: capital raised by a corporation through the issue of shares
details: Stock is collective noun for the stuff a store or a company has to sell, be it toilet paper, automobiles or clothing. Many stores close once a year for a few days to do an inventory of their stock.
examples: Professional investors won’t touch stocks with a pole, worried earnings are about to collapse.
The second — and potentially more lucrative — part of the annual payout is based on Axos’ stock performance relative to an index of more than 300 community and regional banks.
It was the same drive he demonstrated in transferring to Colorado after spending his first three seasons playing for Division II Colorado-Colorado Springs to improve his draft stock.

definition: mixed feelings or emotions
details: Someone who shows ambivalence about a person or thing has conflicting feelings. If you love your mom but find her totally embarrassing, you might feel ambivalent about having her give a presentation at your school.
examples: The ambivalence toward Anti-Semitism is surprising especially when considering the traditional support of Jewish voters for the Democratic Party.
Sports betting measures introduced in Arizona and Washington state are also considered longshots, mostly because of tribal ambivalence or opposition.

Jones is especially good at illuminating the ambivalence that activates an enticing mystery in this production: Laurey seems repulsed by the slightly creepy Jud, and yet also intrigued by his off-kilter intensity.
But this latest incarnation goes much further in digging to a core of fraught ambivalence.

definition: making or willing to make concessions
details: If you're in a fight with a friend and you want to end it, you should make a conciliatory gesture, such as inviting her to a party you're having. Conciliatory describes things that make other people less angry.
examples: On Wednesday, as criticism mounted, Bonucci posted a photo on an Instagram story of him and Kean embracing with a conciliatory message.
"He said that George was a great president, and he admired us both. He said Jeb was strong and a great man. He is trying . . . at this moment . . . to be conciliatory," she wrote.
“There is a better than even chance that the Democratic candidate in 2020, in speaking about foreign policy, will criticize Trump for being too conciliatory toward China,” he said.
Her tone in a subsequent interview with The New Yorker is far less conciliatory.

definition: cause or allow to flow or run out or over
details: There's really no way to put this delicately. Disgorge is just a fancy word for "throw up." Usually, this somewhat icky word is applied to birds or animals rather than people.
examples: Soon after 7am, the train pulls into Bulawayo’s grand but dilapidated station and disgorges about 2,000 workers, uniformed schoolchildren and other travellers into the city centre, ready for the day ahead.
An army jeep swerves into the square, disgorging its own Sergeant.
The agency wants Arsenault and his companies to disgorge ill-gotten gains and pay unspecified penalties.

BNY Mellon agreed to disgorge $29.3 million in alleged ill-gotten gains, as well as pay prejudgment interest and a penalty, without admitting or denying the findings, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

definition: praise, glorify, or honor
details: You might like your manager, but if you exalt her, it means you really put her on a pedestal and treat her like royalty.
examples: Mapplethorpe both exalted and debased the black models who posed for him, an artistic relationship that should invite reassessment for its uneven power dynamic.
A day after Mr. Trump made the choice of Mr. Cain official, Senate Republicans expressed quiet anxiety over the prospect of another #MeToo minefield even as the White House exalted the decision.

The innovations tend to be of degree — they exalt Finland’s limited but superlative produce and eschew luxury ingredients like shellfish and beef in favor of wild plants and offcuts of proteins — rather than kind.
Chandler was exalted by fans when he first took the floor for the Lakers — not just because the Compton native was a local.

definition: suggest in an indirect or covert way; give to understand
details: Insinuate means you imply or suggest something that may or may not be true. If you say things seemed to go wrong about the time your brother took over, you insinuate that he had something to do with the decline.
examples: It was insinuated into our vocabulary by Trump's television lawyer, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, after a successful but deceptive word game campaign.
While introducing Cronin, Guerrero tried to defend the train wreck of the coaching search by insinuating events didn’t unfold as reported.
But like many other first-generation African women of similar age, she referred to her bleaching routine as “toning”, insinuating benign dark spot removal, and only on her face.
He also insinuated that Milano's activism is being driven by some external force, such as backing by a political group.

definition: a verbal or written attack, especially of a belief or dogma
details: A polemic is something that stirs up controversy by having a negative opinion, usually aimed at a particular group. A piece of writing can be a polemic, as long as it gets someone's goat.
examples: Her polemic demonstrates that it isn’t just Trump who is politicizing the judiciary; judges like Clement are perfectly capable of doing so on their own.
It contains prose and verse; polemic and introspection; remixed pop lyrics and pellucid memoir; straightforward narration and constellated word games.
It is an eccentric as well as deadly serious book, a mixture of journalism, memoir and polemic.
But this is a measured, careful work, not a “People’s History” polemic.

definition: having excessive asymmetrical ornamentation
details: Rococo describes a very ornate style originating in Europe. If you love tons of decoration and fancy details, then you'll love the rococo style of architecture and music.
examples: Light from a fireplace spilled onto the Tuscan columns and dark-wood-paneled walls of a rococo den, while a likeness of her father grinned inside the frame of a nearby oil painting.
Baroque and rococo artists embraced the childlike Cupid by combining him with the biblical figure of the cherub.
The place was all red velvet, chandeliers, and rococo flourishes.
In one scene, Trump ushered contestants through his rococo Trump Tower aerie, and said, “I show this apartment to very few people. Presidents. Kings.”

definition: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
details: A stolid person can’t be moved to smile or show much sign of life, in much the same way as something solid, like a giant boulder, is immovable. Both are expressionless.
examples: Now imagine that everyone is good-humored and patient, or at the very least stolid: a political scientist might be able to extrapolate something about why Nordic socialism works.
Other notes are from longtime ES owners who, while loving their cars, would be interested in something a little less stolid, a little less of a bürgermeisterwagen.
Both arguments effectively demolish the same stolid strawman.
Grafters are stolid and conventional, lining their pockets and then quietly retreating to one of their several homes.

definition: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow
details: If you can't decide how you feel about something, declare yourself ambivalent about it.
examples: Biden was anti-abortion before he was pro-choice; his record shows that he is still highly ambivalent and unreliable in his support for a woman’s right to choose.
Or that the “Harry Potter” films would do better, but they would not be important movies, like the inevitable litter of Oscar-season biopics and broody dramas about ambivalent men.
“She spoke of being relatively ambivalent about her fame and her acting career. She loved it, but when she found activism, it really made sense of her passion.”

But the report received by Attorney General William Barr was highly ambivalent, neither indicting nor exonerating the President, and left the crucial question of obstruction of justice for the A.G. to decide.

definition: any foodstuff made by combining different ingredients
details: A concoction is a curious mixture of things, like a bunch of liquids stirred in a cup, or the elaborate and unbelievable story you make up to explain not finishing your homework.
examples: Encouraged, Mahdyar finally released these ideas on his critically acclaimed debut album Seized: a dazzling concoction of abstract hip-hop beats, classical instrumentation and manipulated vocals.
Kuijper’s whimsical list of ingredients doesn’t list animal horns, but her concoctions do incorporate found objects.
Of herbs and barks, of concoctions brewed from berries and leaves.
It was the exact opposite: a slender, transparent concoction of black plastic and odd protuberances and mesh that looked like the exoskeleton of a giant prehistoric insect.

definition: not straightforward or candid
details: Use the adjective disingenuous to describe behavior that's not totally honest or sincere. It's disingenuous when people pretend to know less about something than they really do.
examples: Dickerson, a medical doctor, said some of the statements from law enforcement against the bill were inflammatory, misleading and disingenuous.
This is not for any bona fide legislative purposes unless you lump the Democrats’ disingenuous longing for impeachment into that category.
“This is reckless, it’s irresponsible and it’s disingenuous,” Collins said.
“I expected a little more nuance, and I expected a little more ‘concern trolling’,” meaning expressions of disingenuous concern.

definition: irritate
details: To exasperate someone is to annoy him or her to the point of impatience, frustration and irritation, like when you exasperate a busy waiter by asking questions like "what are all the ingredients in the salad dressing?" and making him repeat the specials five times.
examples: The European leaders, talking Brexit for at least the 18th time and exasperated by Brexit “emergency summits,” wanted to free themselves from the chaos of British politics.
At its core, however, it’s a clumsy con and an exasperating attempt at gaslighting.
It began in July on a turbulent night at Audi Field when, after an exasperating defeat to the New York Red Bulls, D.C.
The people described mounting frustrations on both sides, with Trump exasperated at the situation at the border and Nielsen frustrated by White House actions she felt were counterproductive.

definition: lacking interest or significance or impact
details: Something insipid is lacking in flavor or interest. You'll probably find the generic poems inside of greeting cards insipid.
examples: This narrative form without style invites and even rewards a mode of bad viewing, a fusion of academic detail-hunting and political sound-biting that masks the insipid and laborious simplicity of the experience at large.
The gallop-style theme of the finale moved progressively from insipid to threatening, making for a satisfying conclusion.
Their successors adapted the formula by adding salt, garlic and herbs to the tomatoes, probably to compensate for the insipid tomatoes they found here.
But she is the daughter of the mayor, who is busy arranging her marriage to a rich but insipid young man.

definition: of or involving dispute or controversy
details: The adjective polemical describes something related to an argument or controversy. To keep the peace, avoid discussing politics at Thanksgiving, which usually deteriorates into a polemical argument with Uncle Bob. Better stick to football or apple versus pumpkin pie.
examples: This is no thin polemical screed, although the tone is often impassioned.
It’s an issue movie that wants to be thought-provoking rather than polemical.
But Leigh does not see it as a polemical work: in contrast to his contemporary Ken Loach, whom he admires, Leigh said he does not worry about making his own beliefs clear to an audience.
Two of the stories in the book, “The Good Mothers in the Parking Lot” and “Mrs. America,” address politics head-on, but neither story is polemical.

definition: be agitated
details: To roil means to stir up or churn. A stormy ocean might roil, or even a restless crowd.
examples: As a result, Trump’s tariff threats will continue to roil global markets and international relations.

While the direct impact would be more modest outside Europe, concerns about the ramifications of such an unprecedented situation would likely roil financial markets and weigh on an already weakening global economy.
It is the latest in a series of incidents over the past year with the potential of further roiling U.S.-China relations.
What if you can’t connect to most of the epochal issues roiling this country and animating so much of its current art?

definition: successive, without a break
details: Arrows, sides of a rectangle, well-organized lines of people waiting to get into the theater or the ladies' room, and anything else free from curves can be described as straight. The word can also mean honest, uninterrupted, undiluted, or heterosexual.
examples: The Reds entered the series with eight straight losses and the worst record in the NL.
Independent Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont – who’s running a second straight time for the Democratic nomination – was second at 16 percent.
The ‘patrons,’ poured in through the gates as soon as they opened—most of them, or so it seemed—heading straight to the souvenir pavilion as soon as Nicklaus and Player’s tee shots were airborne.
The team announced the decision Thursday, one day after finishing its 13th straight losing season - the NBA’s longest active playoff drought.

definition: the food and drink of the gods
details: In Greek mythology, ambrosia was the food of the gods. At a picnic, ambrosia is a dessert made with oranges and shredded coconut. While the former bestowed immortality on all who ate it, the latter tastes very refreshing after fried chicken and potato salad.
examples: Imagine my bewilderment when, years later, I entered the world of cocktails and discovered that this ambrosia is seen by many bartenders as the fruta non grata of the citrus world.
Use Pink Lady apples for a more vibrant colour and tangy flavour, or ambrosia for a more custardy result.
On “Water’s Rising,” the experimental producer Djrum creates a swirling ambrosia of clinking beats and dreamy piano while Lola Empire sings of infatuation in a distant but declarative tone.
So for ambrosia beetles, the smell of ethanol isn’t just a sign that a tree is stressed or dying.

definition: an event or situation that happens at the same time
details: Concomitant means accompanying. If you run into someone that you have a crush on, you might feel nervousness with a concomitant forgetfulness.
examples: Mr. Arison’s life was similarly driven by the lure of an American education and the concomitant career possibilities.
Near universal adoption of the vaccine in the developing world meant that measles infections and concomitant deaths became rare.
Some of Mr. Wunderman’s techniques presaged the targeted advertisements of the Internet era and their concomitant concerns about privacy, a value he insisted that companies must respect.
The concomitant challenge to preventing retirements is convincing those lawmakers who lost to run for their old seats.

definition: unaffected by concern for one's own welfare
details: If you can't decide whether to purchase the shirt with orange polka dots or the purple paisley-patterned one, you might seek input from a disinterested, or unbiased, party (who will probably tell you not to buy either one).
examples: The report claims Trump was allegedly disinterested in the history of the first president during the 45-minute tour and described it to associates as “truly bizarre.”
A lot of that support probably reflected partisanship rather than disinterested hopes for fact-finding.
Many Americans are still largely apolitical, but even disinterested citizens now recognize party differences on policy, ideology and group coalitions and pick the side consistent with their views.
But Chicago seemed disinterested right from the start.

definition: a feeling of annoyance
details: If you've ever become so frustrated with someone or something that you feel like you're at the end of your rope, you have experienced exasperation. You are fed up!
examples: It will be quickly followed by frustration, exasperation, we’re still here.
In European capitals there was weariness and exasperation with Britain’s tortuous Brexit divorce after 46 years of membership.
As he rose from the dais, Beal flashed a hint of exasperation about the question and mumbled under his breath that “y’all trying to get me in trouble.”

Her story moved quickly from social media to the press and television, where sympathy for the problems that street cleaners faced over the severe winter was mixed with exasperation at their employer's glib responses.

definition: be emphatic or resolute and refuse to budge
details: To insist on something is to demand or swear to it. You can insist that you didn't eat the last piece of cake, and then insist that your brother show your mom the bits of frosting on his fingers.
examples: The chancellor will insist that global guidelines for tacking climate change need to be backed by urgent actions.
And many of them are still at it, insisting that it must surely be possible to pluck the benefits of E.U. membership that they like, while discarding the obligations that they don’t.
They insisted that the traditional method of getting warrants was too slow for the urgent threats posed by international terrorism.
“It’s not racist to say if you’re going to be here then you should learn the language of the country you just arrived at,” he insisted.

definition: a plan of action adopted by an individual or social group
details: Did you just come up with a plan for reducing the number of paper clips your department uses at work each month? Then you’ve created a policy, a plan of action.
examples: “The administration suffers from a lack of coherence in its policy toward North Korea,” said Suzanne DiMaggio, a North Korea expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a nonpartisan think tank.
He was waived after serving a two-game suspension to start last season for violating the league’s policy on performance enhancers.

The two Democrats are Rep. Elijah Cummings of Maryland, chairman of the House oversight and reform committee, and Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi of Illinois, chairman of the subcommittee on economic and consumer policy.

definition: of something having a dusty purplish pink color
details: As its sound might suggest, roseate has to do with "rosy." Anything that's roseate is rose colored or pinkish. It's often used in the term "roseate glow," typically to describe a sunset.
examples: For instance, the roseate spoonbill is worth six points at the end of the game.
Over a few hours I saw cypress swamps, mangrove forests, osprey, bald eagles, roseate spoonbills and sandhill cranes.
Viewed from this perspective, the behaviour of the digital giants looks rather different from the roseate hallucinations of Wired magazine.
Birds change with habitat: roseate spoonbills and great egrets feed in the bayous of Saint Denis.

definition: people having the same social or economic status
details: A stratum is a layer of something, whether abstract, like a social stratum composed of only billionaires, or physical, like the different strata (that’s the plural version) of clouds that an airplane passes through.
examples: Unfortunately, too many recipes for strata are soggy and laden with excessive custard and filling ingredients.
The strata of Europe were assumed to be well-mapped, the fossil record adequately sampled, whatever was found on their home turf to be much the same elsewhere in the world.
Perhaps such a powerful symbolic move by the most rewarded stratum in a university is unlikely in a capitalist marketplace.
In strata about 75 million years old, there seems to be a riot of dinosaur species.

definition: make better
details: To ameliorate is to step in and make a bad situation better. You could try introducing a second lollipop to ameliorate a battle between two toddlers over a single lollipop.
examples: “This is yet another instance of the government refusing to ameliorate the harm done by their unconstitutional and cruel family separation policy.”
The generous funding helps to ameliorate one of the traditional weaknesses of the German research system — its comparative lack of permanent positions.

Her campaign noted that the prison incarceration rate for African Americans in the county declined during her tenure, though experts said that did little to ameliorate a dramatic disparity between black and white prison rates.
It is time for politicians to “consider either reversing or ameliorating this national act of self harm”, he says.

definition: characteristic of those who treat others with arrogance
details: If you are being condescending, you are looking down on someone. A 10-year-old who says to his sibling, "What do you know? You're only a 6-year-old!" is being condescending.
examples: Because although it’s condescending to treat sports contemptuously, the tire fire currently raging in most other fields of human endeavor deserves nothing better.
“Millennials are filling their homes — and the voids in their hearts — with houseplants,” the Washington Post declared in a beautifully condescending article about the fertile phenomenon.
The teacher, Ginsberg said, was “rude and condescending.”
“Elisabeth, calm down dear,” Walters cut in again, offering a condescending primer on civilized debate.

definition: taken apart at the points of connection
details: Disjointed isn’t when you can bend your thumb all the way backwards — that’s double-jointed. Disjointed means "unorganized" or "disconnected."
examples: Realizing my skin wasn’t desirable in the UK or in the US, or in west Africa, I felt disjointed, as if I didn’t belong anywhere.
Reading the Wikipedia page is far more moving than anything in the disjointed film.
As disjointed as Mr. Holtzman’s script is, Ms. Burns, who created the part in the play’s 2014 premiere, holds the production together.
There was good reason for the disjointed play on both sides.

definition: remove by cutting
details: An excise tax is a special tax levied on specific products sold within a country. To excise something can also mean to get rid of it. Say, wouldn't it be nice if they would excise the excise taxes?
examples: The state levies the transient accommodations and general excise taxes that the short-term rental operators must pay.
The state levies the transient accommodations and general excise taxes the short-term rental operators must pay.

With permission from Wright’s literary estate, Parks’s vision diverges largely from the original plot, excising the long trial scene at the end in which Max, a white Communist lawyer unsuccessfully defends Bigger.
Even as Hinds excised some battles for length and clarity, it’s a bloodbath.

definition: serve as the inciting cause of
details: The Olympics often inspire people to take up a sport, but they can also inspire patriotism. Inspire means to excite, encourage, or breathe life into.
examples: Sentimentally, she dished that she was inspired to conceive the lush floral design by her mom, who pushed her to embrace the process of making her own gown in the first place.
I hope his memory inspires more good work in Crenshaw and communities like it.
When Variety posted a video in which Sarandon said Trump inspired more women and people of color to run for office, Messing pulled no punches in her response.
Their newness and my own fresh start in Los Angeles inspired the first recipe for this, my first “Home for Dinner” column.

definition: a governmentally organized unit
details: The noun polity refers to a political group of any size or shape — it can be a government, a state, a country, or even a social group.
examples: So in many ways, the winner on Sunday was the image of Turkey’s polity, both at home and abroad.
“The polity of the United Methodist Church presumes trust,” she said.

“What Fukuyama laments as ‘fracturing’ is in reality the result of marginalized groups finally overcoming centuries-long efforts to erase them from the American polity — activism that will strengthen democratic rule, not threaten it,” Abrams wrote.
Without a public sphere dominated by agreed-upon-facts, many say, a healthy society—and wise polity—become impossible to sustain.

definition: an overwhelming defeat
details: When you think about the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat, associate a rout with the agonizing defeat. A rout is the kind of humiliating loss that makes you wish you would have been injured in the first quarter so you could have avoided the outcome.
examples: “If there was ever a deserved victory, then that was it. Congratulations to Bayern,” Watzke said Sunday, a day after the rout.
Lewandowski put further gloss on the rout with Bayern’s fifth in the final minute and the German champions are now in pole position to retain the title.
Orlando set an offensive season high in a rout of Atlanta in its final home game of the regular season, getting a key victory for playoff positioning.
After stifling Colorado on Wednesday night in a quarterfinal rout, the Longhorns were in shutdown mode again against their in-state rivals.

definition: marked with stripes
details: If a field is plowed into furrows, it's striated––or, technically, it's marked with striae, which are stripes or grooves.
examples: Their striated depth, like that of an archeological site, suggests the accretions of civilizations.
The clay is built up layer by layer, producing striated patterns and surfaces resembling knitting, complete with knots and loops.
The Mountains, their exposed striated flanks speak of time.
He also used lamps and spotlights to produce a dramatic view of a worker beneath a towering cliff of salt, so denuded and striated it appears almost like a lunar landscape.

definition: disposed or willing to comply
details: If your friends want to try sky diving and you're amenable to the idea, sounds like you're going to be jumping out of a plane. If a person or thing is amenable to something, they are ready, willing, or responsive.
examples: Beyond France, Austria was among a few EU states more amenable to a shorter Brexit lag.
Perhaps it was inevitable that Generation Hankey, those teens of the late-1990s who are now parents, would be amenable to their own kids playing a game like Flushin’ Frenzy.
While Senate Republicans seemed largely amenable to Moore’s nomination, the prospect of Cain’s nomination unsettled some in the party.

The University of Southern California says it’s amenable to accepting the wishes of veterans and modifying a name change for Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum as long as corporate sponsor United Airlines agrees.

definition: imposing or depending on or containing an assumption
details: Something conditional is dependent on other factors. You might receive a conditional offer of acceptance from a college, depending on your high school graduation and your maintaining passing grades.
examples: The Indiana Economic Development Corp. offered Decatur Plastics Products up to $475,000 in conditional tax credits based on the company’s job creation plans.
However it would be conditional on the UK granting the same rights to EU citizens in return.
The Indiana Economic Development Corp. offered up to $2.6 million in conditional tax credits based on the company’s job creation plans.
The story unfolds in late 1775 and the first half of 1776, and one of the unexpected pleasures of digging into this story is learning just how conditional and feeble the early revolution was.

definition: causing dejection
details: Dismal is a dreary, depressing sort of bad. "With the cold rain and their team behind by six field goals, the mood in the stands was so dismal even the cheerleaders had lost their 'Rah.'"
examples: West Ham shake things up after last week’s dismal showing against Everton.
This dismal view of my gender pervades the novel, and in all objectivity, I’d say it is a flaw.
Why would the city consider building this slug in the first place, much less expand it despite dismal ridership and soaring costs?
Public Accounts Committee Chair Meg Hillier complained about the “dismal lack of progress,” by the ministry to address the issue.

definition: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
details: To exculpate means to find someone not guilty of criminal charges. If you've been wrongly accused of robbery, you'd better hope a judge will exculpate you, unless you want to go to jail because you've heard prison food is amazing.
examples: One Trump confidant argues that anything less than an overt criminal conspiracy will exculpate Trump in the public eye.
Does her more recent message exculpate me, or am I still indicted by the first?
In an interview, Alexis Botto said she did not intend her words to exculpate Sorensen or be used in his defense.
A spokesman for Virginia Tech, the university which traditionally tends to the turkeys post-pardon, said both birds Trump exculpated in 2017 are dead.

definition: an occurrence of something
details: An instance is a specific example or case of something. One instance of being chased by a growling dog can make a person spend his whole life being afraid of animals.
examples: For instance, when identical résumés are submitted for a position, with the only difference being gendered first names of applicants, “Brian” is twice as likely as “Karen” to get the offer.
Following her fundraising announcement, for instance, Warren unveiled an ambitious new plan Thursday to hike taxes on the largest, most profitable U.S. companies.
Legal experts said that each instance of spying without a warrant was a serious crime, and that there appeared to be hundreds of thousands of infractions.
There is only one known instance of the technique being applied clinically, in which a family from Jordan were treated by US doctors at a Mexican clinic, prompting controversy.

definition: cheap or pretentious or vain display
details: Pomp is a ceremonial display, such as you'd find at the Independence Day parade in your town, where brass bands and men and women in full military dress march to patriotic songs, while citizens wave flags and cheer.
examples: In his pomp, Woods was deliberately distant from virtually all of his opponents.
The match is announced at a ceremony full of pomp and tradition.
It is the predecessor to the chiselled punk cuts of the late 70s, before the pomp and fluff of an 80s perm.
In embracing the opportunity to deploy the constitutional power of the veto for the first time, he treated the occasion with all the traditional pomp of a bill-signing.

definition: category name
details: A rubric is a heading or a category in a chart, or a rule of conduct. A teacher's grading rubrics may include participation, homework completion, tests, quizzes, and papers.
examples: The gun laws in New Zealand are more layered, and do not fit easily into a pro or anti-gun rubric.
Not that the world isn’t teeming with work that might fit under that rubric, but, most often, its creators aren’t self-aware enough to think to describe it as such.

Instead, it says, programmes should use a holistic evaluation rubric, which includes specific criteria for admission and clear definitions of what high, medium and low scores look like for those criteria.

definition: severe criticism
details: One meaning of stricture is a nasty criticism, while the other is a sharp contraction of a tube or canal in the body. Either meaning can mean great pain to the person experiencing the stricture.
examples: There are no strictures against vaccines in the Jewish religion, and the overwhelming majority of American Jews are vaccinated.
Style guides for romance-novel writers offered similar strictures - and usually demanded happy endings.
That narrative spotlights only embarrassingly bad student protests and administrative strictures against “unsafety” and offensive behavior, real and imagined.
Debra Shigley, a mom of five children under age 8, realized somewhere around child number four that the perfectionist strictures imposed on many moms no longer applied to her.

definition: diffusing warmth and friendliness
details: A friendly, pleasant person could be described as amiable. Airline flight attendants tend to be amiable. The people monitoring the school's cafeteria? Maybe not.
examples: No one is sure why Calvin took his own life, but other parents told Krok that he seemed to be an amiable, well-adjusted child.
It started with amiable small talk, and eventually evolved into a friendship.
Another is a caper about two amiable numbskulls who work at a restaurant called the Sushi Shack.
A 1986 Washington Post summation of his administration said Mr. Hughes “set modest goals without apology” and created an image that never went beyond that of an “honest and amiable caretaker.”

definition: excuse, overlook, or make allowances for
details: If you condone something, you allow it, approve of it, or at least can live with it. Some teachers condone chewing gum, and some don't.
examples: For example, he encouraged cops to handle suspects roughly when they’re arrested — essentially condoning police brutality.
“I don’t condone what the boys did” qualified with a but and judgements of Jane Doe’s decisions.
“We do not condone that behavior,” read a message apparently from the Skylar account, though it was not immediately clear which photograph or influencer were being referred to.
I do not believe that the president of the United States condones that kind of behavior.

definition: stop associating with
details: At the end of a lesson period, your teacher says, "class dismissed." This means that you and the rest of the students are free to go.
examples: Kilmeade later added, "She should use this opportunity as a Muslim leader not to dismiss a Muslim attack — a Muslim extremist attack."
The Russian Embassy in London dismissed the report at the time as “disinformation and fake news.”
District Judge Brian Morris scheduled a June 5 hearing on the Justice Department’s motion to dismiss the lawsuit.
The Daily Camera reported court records showed that a Michigan Circuit Court judge dismissed the lawsuit filed by Burke in December 2016.

definition: unequivocally detestable
details: If something's execrable it's really and truly, unbelievably, absolutely the worst.
examples: There was human misery, too: the animals’ mahouts, doing this for lack of alternative employment, were – and generally still are – execrably paid and housed by the attraction owners.
He might want to be familiar with the term “execrable” - that’s a good one for this movie.
Meanwhile, Trump's execrable immigration policies continue to be enacted, with the courts only shutting down some of the very worst excesses.
All over Winter, even in frozen barbarian Perunter, it is considered execrably vulgar to talk business while eating.

definition: set up or lay the groundwork for
details: An institute is an organization or association designed to study or promote something. If you're interested in politics, you might want to do an internship at one of Washington D.C.'s many political research institutes.
examples: About 40 minutes after Trump’s tweet, Mo Elleithee, director of the institute at Georgetown, went on Twitter to correct the record.
She says that she expected the proportion of institutes explicitly using the impact factor in these documents to be higher, but warns that their results might only be the “tip of the iceberg”.
An institute official said many of the owls were found emaciated in odd places like backyards, parking lots and driveways.
He proceed to keep his promise and institute prohibition in the state.

definition: denoting or governed by or relating to a bishop or bishops
details: If you ever listen to talk radio you'll hear some fairly pontifical talk going on — that is, puffed up, vain, overblown speech from someone convinced he alone is right.
examples: The changes were issued under the form of an Apostolic Letter, a 12-article law, and a set of detailed guidelines affecting personnel in the Vatican and its related institutions such as pontifical institutes and embassies.
Such is the case with this pontifical made for a bishop in Ferrara, Italy.
Such a step would require the church to reconsider its use of pontifical secrecy codes.
A Catholic who served on two pontifical commissions, Dr. Sanneh also worked to explore connections between Christianity and Islam, tracing their spread across West Africa.

definition: the elementary stage of any subject
details: Rudiment, usually used in the plural, means the basics. If you know the alphabet, you have the rudiments of reading at your disposal.
examples: The two met in 2015, and soon began running workshops for eight-to-twelve-year-olds—James teaching the rudiments of design, tailoring, and styling—before photographing them in the mostly deprived districts where the children live.

definition: walk with a lofty proud gait
details: When you strut, you walk with a proud swagger that has a little arrogance thrown in, like the prance of a running back who has just flown past the 250-pound linebackers and planted the ball in the end zone.
examples: Each morning I was awoken by the calls of strutting peacocks, resounding gongs, and tractors blaring Bollywood hits as they made their way to the surrounding fields.

definition: characterized by friendship and good will
details: The adjective amicable means "friendly" — but in particular, use it when describing relations one might otherwise expect to be unfriendly. The end of a romantic relationship that's less than amicable might involve broken dishes or broken bones.
examples: A source also told the outlet that everything is amicable between Sanchez and Whitesell, who married in 2005 and reportedly separated last fall.

definition: direct the course of; manage or control
details: Conduct is about how you behave––"conduct unbecoming"––and also about carrying something through––"the survey was conducted in May and June."
examples: American Media’s board conducted a review of its tabloid business, including the Globe and National Examiner brands, and decided to explore strategic options.

definition: express a negative opinion of
details: If you haven't got anything nice to say, then it's time to disparage someone. It means to belittle or degrade a person or idea.
examples: The British woman who faced up to two years in a Dubai prison for a disparaging Facebook post about her ex-husband’s new wife will be released, the group representing her said Thursday.
