definition: curse or declare to be evil or anathema
details: Just when you thought you knew every word in the book for hate, here's a new one: execrate. The word means to despise or also to curse.
examples: Though the Democrats’ advantage over the GOP in voter identification is not particularly large — eight points, according to Gallup — 24 percent of Americans now accept the no-longer execrated label “liberal,” up seven points since 1992.
Americans execrate “outsourcing,” which supposedly involves sending “American jobs” overseas.

definition: the state of being isolated or detached
details: The noun insularity refers to the quality of being isolated or detached. In fact, the word is based on the Latin word insula, for "island." The phrase "no man is an island" means that no one can be completely separate from others.
examples: A parable about the insularity of the moneyed class?
He also concedes the potential risks of local, voluntary organizations, including their insularity.

It is also a revealing lesson on the insularity and posturing of the conservative intellectual community.

definition: full of holes
details: If something is full of tiny holes or openings, you can describe it as porous. A sponge is porous, and if the border between countries is open for anyone to cross easily, it too can be called porous.
examples: Queen Elizabeth National Park, which is located near the porous border with Congo, is Uganda's most popular safari destination.
Florida plans on being super-aggressive on July 1 to find free agents who will immediately shore up a porous defense.
“Populist” or “civic nationalist” groups provide forums for those with more radical beliefs to proselytise and organise, and the barrier between such groups tends to be extremely porous.
They were ambushed by four gunmen in Queen Elizabeth National Park, a protected area near the porous border with Congo, according to Ugandan police and a government spokesman.

definition: a deceptive maneuver, especially to avoid capture
details: Movie bank robbers always seem to pull some kind of ruse, a deceptive trick or tactic like hiding the money underneath the bank while they drive off in the getaway car to avoid capture by the police.
examples: “The shaved head’s just a ruse,” she adds.
When one doorman caught on to my ruse, I started bribing them to keep the arrangement going.
To their credit, it appears that some Office Depot employees complained about the ruse, the FTC lawsuit said.
When the jihadists tried to force him to fight, she dressed him as a woman and fled, but Kurdish forces arrested him when they discovered the ruse, she said.

definition: deprive of strength or efficiency; make useless or worthless
details: When something stultifies you, it drains you of your energy, enthusiasm, or pleasure. A well-acted Shakespeare play can be a thrill. A poorly acted one can stultify like nothing else.
examples: The 22-year-olds met at Pacific Union College, a small Adventist school in Napa Valley that, while isolating and often stultifying to them, was a crucible for finding and asserting themselves through music.
It helps us move past the stultifying stereotypes that stifle the meaningful exchange of ideas and limit our growth as a society.
But unless we are faced with a steady diet of stultifying boredom, we never learn how.
And they offer a stultifying choice that doesn’t change 365 days of the year, which kills the urge to cook.

definition: a warrant granting release from punishment for an offense
details: Amnesty can mean a pardon for a wrongdoing, or it can also signal a government's willingness to overlook something.
examples: The weapons will be illegal starting at midnight, but police said an amnesty will be in effect until details of the buyback are announced.
The weapons will be illegal starting at midnight, but police said a brief amnesty program will be in effect until details of the buyback are announced.
The legislation would apply to illegal immigrant “Dreamers,” some of whom are already here under the Obama-era administrative deportation amnesty program known as DACA.
He was released early in 1998 as part of a general amnesty.

definition: have a meeting in order to talk something over
details: If you gab, chat, and talk it up with someone, you have conversation, but if you're looking for input from each other as you talk, you confer, or consult, together. They had a family meeting to confer about a schedule for sharing the new laptop.
examples: Arizona’s legislation creates a new frontier because it doesn’t require any other state to confer the same benefits on people licensed in Arizona.

It reminded me of the research suggesting a disproportionate number of female politicians are breast cancer survivors because it confers respect on a level equivalent to a war wound.
The courtroom was silent for a few moments as Musk conferred with his lawyers, seemingly trying not to gloat.

definition: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
details: The trunk of some people's cars may contain items as disparate as old clothes, rotting food, and possibly a missing relative. Disparate things are very different from each other.
examples: The bill’s reintroduction promises to shine a light on Democratic presidential candidates’ disparate visions for the long term future of American health care.
The move reopens the debate over his call to eliminate private health insurance and highlights Democratic presidential candidates' disparate visions for the long-term future of health care.
The bill’s reintroduction promises to shine a bright light on Democratic presidential candidates’ disparate visions for the long-term future of American health care.
Mr Salvini's new alliance hopes to rally all these disparate political forces into a single united front.

definition: an explanation or critical interpretation
details: If your teacher gives an explanation of a difficult text you are reading, she is giving you an exegesis on it. An exegesis is a critical look at a text.
examples: “It is a false exegesis to use the Word of God to promote migration. God never wanted these rifts,” Cardinal Robert Sarah said in a new interview with French publication Valeurs Actuelles.
The notes are not neutral exegesis but richly explanatory and argumentative.

Built on a shaky foundation of tweet exegesis, movie references and celebrity trivia, Wolff’s theory posited that West’s recent embrace of conservative politics was actually an elaborate piece of performance art.

The final “Silent Night” was arranged by the group’s young director and founder, Matthew Robertson, in a veritably baroque exegesis that piled up voices in a pulsing superstructure around the familiar tune.

definition: in opposition to a civil authority or government
details: An insurgent is a rebel or a revolutionary, someone who takes up arms against the authorities.
examples: An Interior Ministry statement Thursday says security forces exchanged fire with the Islamic militants, but no casualties were reported among the police as they stormed the insurgent hideout in the Mediterranean coastal city of el-Arish.
His grandfather, the Mexican insurgent Emiliano Zapata, rallied poor campesinos under the battle cry “land and liberty” a century ago – only to be double-crossed by a former ally and murdered.

The Press Trust of India reports that the attack occurred Tuesday in the Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh, an insurgent stronghold, just two days before a multi-phase general election begin in India.

definition: maintain or assert
details: Assume something or present it as a fact and you postulate it. Physicists postulate the existence of parallel universes, which is a little mind-blowing.
examples: Countless 1950s science fiction stories postulated galactic empires with Eisenhower-era social arrangements, complete with heroes still puffing away on cigarettes.
We then try to find the solidity and concreteness of the perceived world in that postulated underlying reality.

Most controversially, as postulated by the prominent Harvard University astrophysicist Avi Loeb, perhaps it was an alien artifact—a gossamer-thin sheet-like spacecraft engineered to coast on starlight through the interstellar depths.
The task of writing fiction in line with Winters’s postulates became his lifelong mission.

definition: cause to be perplexed or confounded
details: There are three ways to stump: you can ask someone a question they can't answer, you can travel making political speeches, or you can stomp.
examples: In his stump speech, he does not raise legitimate issues related to immigration.
On the stump, Warren frequently mentions her ethics legislation, calling it “the biggest anti-corruption bill since Watergate.”

Then, for the rest of the weekend and into this week, Parr’s story became part of the presidential candidate’s stump speech.

definition: having no definite form or distinct shape
details: Amorphous means without a clearly defined form, like the moon's amorphous reflection in a lake. Figuratively, something amorphous lacks focus, be it a work of art, a political movement, or even someone's life plans.
examples: Drumbeats lurch and sputter amid eerie, amorphous electronic sounds; instruments like guitars or pianos are relegated to the far distance.
I always banked on suddenly waking up one day and needing a child – as if broodiness were an amorphous thing that would abruptly materialise at some point.
Was that amorphous mask of white ahead showing swaths of pale pink?
“In the age of Trump, when you want to be something for everybody, you’re going to end up being amorphous for a lot of people.”

definition: a flowing together
details: Confluence means a flowing together. In a literal sense, it's about rivers. But it's more often used to talk about the coming together of factors or ideas, or of cultures in a diverse city.
examples: When dotted with the patrons, most dressed in Easter pastels, it's a confluence of color so spectacular they can't be replicated on a palette.

I paddled past the historic hangars at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling and up to the National War College at the confluence of the Anacostia and Potomac.
Sometimes the confluence of unrelated events provides a moment of clarity in politics.

definition: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
details: Dispassionate describes someone who is not getting carried away by—or maybe not even having—feelings. It's something you'd want to see in a surgeon, who keeps cool under pressure, but not in a romantic partner.
examples: A mostly dispassionate recounting of events, the essay revealed little about why he took part in the televised deception.
Although Burke’s treatment of her four subjects is deliberately dispassionate, she does seem to empathize with Salsbury, insecure about her abilities and desperate for respect as an artist.
“Nobody’s starting in on you, buddy,” Zooey said, in the same dispassionate tone.

The ABA evaluators reviewing Grasz’s record and writings expressed concern that his “passionately-held social agenda appeared to overwhelm and obscure the ability to exercise dispassionate and unbiased judgment.”

definition: worthy of imitation
details: Exemplary people excel at what they do and are excellent examples to others. Something exemplary is so good that it is an example for others to follow.
examples: Monika Grütters, the German cultural minister, described the case as an “exemplary resolution” to one of many second world war restitution cases, most of which are far less straightforward.
But he was also an exemplary craftsman, a hardheaded liberal and a playwright who valued the power of conflict.
The sheriff’s office describes the recently married, 29-year-old as an exemplary deputy who served with distinction and honor.
And in an exemplary display of public-private-sector cooperation, the Cocoa and Forests Initiative in Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana and Colombia aims to end deforestation from cocoa cultivation.

definition: have in mind as a purpose
details: If you intend to do something, you mean to do it or have it in mind as a goal. Do you plan on getting your holiday cards in the mail before February this year? Then you intend on getting them out early.
examples: Trump spawned confusion last month when he appeared to lift sanctions imposed by his own administration that were intended to further isolate North Korea.
The final extended episode will be musical, a decision Soloway claims was integral to the intended message.
"We intend to fully address the issues raised at today's court conference."
Assemblyman Tyrone Thompson presented the legislation to lawmakers earlier this month, saying the bill is not intended to displace or remove children from their current charter school.

definition: existing in possibility
details: If you can describe something as possible but not yet actual, choose the adjective potential. Companies try to reach potential customers through advertising.
examples: They hope to provoke a legal challenge with the potential to overturn the U.S.
They asked for documents on potential acquisition and operation of the regional networks plus MLB’s strategies.
Everyone else in the large field of declared or potential Democratic 2020 contenders registered at less than 1 percent.

definition: so great in size, force, or extent as to elicit awe
details: Stupendous means amazing or awesome. You just won a million dollars and are donating it to charity? That’s stupendous!
examples: She only wants you to understand how stupendous creation is, as well as all the works of human ingenuity and passion.
He quickly took his Kodak into that stupendous valley and was so moved by the experience that it changed his life.
For a young composer, this is a stupendous achievement.

The implications of this stupendous new efficiency are the production of much fancier and brighter wireless mice and keyboards — where the previous battery power limitation is greatly loosened — as well as prettier and faster RAM.

definition: more than enough in size or scope or capacity
details: Ample describes an abundance of something. An ample supply of apple muffins at the bake sale is a good thing, as is ample legroom in your new van, but you probably don't want your ample waistline spilling over the top of your jeans.
examples: President Reuven Rivlin said he would wait until next week to gather recommendations from party leaders on whom they want to lead the next government, leaving ample time for political jockeying.

“Donald Trump is all things to all people,” he told me in his Greenwich Village apartment recently, under the gaze of his ample collection of European church statues from the medieval to the Baroque periods.
Since the Fed controls rates by paying interest on reserves it needs ample reserves in the system.
Breakfast was an ample buffet spanning not just bread and jam and fruit, but also cheese, olives, poached eggs, guacamole and grilled tomatoes.

definition: someone who follows established standards of conduct
details: A conformist is a person who follows traditional standards of conduct. If you're a conformist, it's unlikely you'll join a revolution to overthrow your government; instead you'll argue that it's best to keep things the way they are.
examples: Birth order, according to conventional wisdom, molds personality: Firstborn children, secure with their place in the family and expected to be the mature ones, grow up to be intellectual, responsible and conformist.
As Inglehart notes, societies eventually reach a tipping point at which “conformist pressures” reverse polarity and begin to support changes they previously opposed.
In Scandinavia, the dominant conformist zeitgeist is called the Law of Jante, a reference to a fictional Danish town that enforces being ordinary in every possible way.
Italian politicians still whisper that they hope that the wild populists governing the country will be Romanized by the conformist establishment.

definition: send away towards a designated goal
details: Anything that needs to be mailed, sent off, or quickly shipped needs to be dispatched. Letters, official reports, teams of police — if it has somewhere to be, you can dispatch it to get there.
examples: The Springfield News-Leader reports that the shooting happened Tuesday afternoon after officers were dispatched to check on the man who was sitting in the van and was unresponsive.
The Texas International Produce Association asked McAleenan to dispatch officers and agents from the northern U.S. border and seaports to reduce delays.
Police also informed dispatch that an attorney for Jacobs arrived at the home.
He also expressed willingness during the interview to dispatch federal forces to states losing control of their prisons.

definition: make a great effort at a mental or physical task
details: Exert basically means to put forth effort to do something. For example, when you exert yourself in a workout, you can really feel the burn in your muscles.
examples: Given the massive control exerted by social media and Internet companies over the information Americans use every day, such broadmindedness is essential.
In doing so, Mr. Trump took broad aim at a pillar of the Iranian state, which exerts enormous influence in politics and the economy as well as in Iran’s internal and external military policies.
The success of Haftar’s gamble may depend on the degree of private pressure exerted by his allies including Egypt, the United Arab Emirates and France.
However, it is worrying that a guy like William, a man who is proud of his lack of medical background, exerts so much influence over people’s health choices.

definition: command against
details: Interdict means to forbid, to nix, to veto. If your parents find out you're planning a party for a time when they're away , they will interdict it.
examples: We are not effectively interdicting the transfer of cartel dollars heading south from the U.S. because we do not inspect traffic leaving the U.S.
We think we catch about one-third of the illegal aliens and interdict maybe 15 percent of the drugs.
One of the ways in which they want to deal with Haitians is to interdict them at sea, to prevent them from even entering the country.
Those transactions were meticulously recorded, in Excel spreadsheets and intercepted phone calls, interdicted shipments and internecine debt feuds.

definition: a customary way of operation or behavior
details: Practice can be a noun or a verb, but either way it's about how things are done on a regular basis. You can practice shotput every day because your town has a practice of supporting track-and-field events.
examples: Watch one of Washington’s spring practices, and it’s easy to see why.
He was signed to Washington’s practice squad in December and waived days later.
Gray limped around the mound, threw a few practice pitches, and stayed in the game for two more innings before leaving.
He says the initiative will help provide evidence-based information on best court practices to support treatment of drug addiction.

definition: the quality of being charming and gracious in manner
details: Suavity is the art of making people like and want to be around you, like the celebrity whose suavity helped him land great movie roles — even though he wasn't the most talented actor to audition.
examples: Fontana seized upon that note of insolent suavity at a time in Italy of economic boom and cultural éclat—most brilliantly evident, of course, in film.
The focus of these writers isn’t on the suavity of the actors, the glamorousness of the costumes or the grandeur of the sets.
With all that inside of them shapes an outward suavity waiting for a touch to.
We felt that we hadn’t exploited our limited stay with maximum suavity.

definition: locating something at a time when it couldn't have existed
details: An anachronism is something that doesn't fit its time period, like if you say you'll "dial" your smartphone.
examples: To some extent, the room is an anachronism.
There is a serious anachronism at work: the coverage that speaks to Schneidermann on an emotional level now was largely ineffective at the time it was printed.
Does the popularity of racist souvenirs in Cuba’s tourism sector mean that Canadians are re-animating racist anachronisms in their consumption of tourist Cuba?
That this “Company” is set, the program says, “in modern day New York” only occasionally begets anachronisms.

definition: be confusing or perplexing to
details: If you have an identical twin, you've probably tried dressing alike so that people confound you with, or mistake you for, one another. You've also probably learned that, unfortunately, this trick doesn’t work on your mom.
examples: He called the way PBMs do business “one of the most confounding, gnarled riddles in American health care.’
Whatever the strengths and weaknesses of this “Master and Margarita,” Bulgakov’s beguiling, confounding story shines through it.
Former local newspaper editor Bob Hammel moderated the event and sat beside Knight, covering for the coach when he appeared confounded, according to the Indianapolis Star.
For Denis, baffling the audience early on is an efficient, confounding statement of purpose.

definition: force to go away
details: To dispel is to get rid of something that's bothering or threatening you, regardless of whether that's warts, worries, or wild dogs.
examples: Any thought that the PM might be treated to a pre-summit monstering from Brexiteer backbenchers, to demonstrate that she might not be able to deliver whatever she promised EU leaders, was soon dispelled.
While Couples dispelled the rumors on Monday of an imminent Masters retirement, he also acknowledged that time is not on his side.
Saunders’s eyes narrow at talk of Dixon’s mulling a comeback campaign, chatter that the former mayor did little to dispel in recent days.
The March jobs gain probably won’t be enough to dispel all the pessimism, though.

definition: use of physical or mental energy; hard work
details: Exertion is effort. Exercise requires physical exertion. Listening to great jazz requires mental exertion. What kind of exertion does jazzercise require? Perhaps too much.
examples: This will be possible only if we anchor the exertion not simply in abstract ethics but also in respect for existing international human rights law and fundamental freedoms — and that is the key point.
Here is a masculinity not of muscular exertion but baleful inaction.

For that matter, Zahler’s taut, restrained style is a part of that exertion of force—it’s an artistic force that, with its centripetal pressure, prevents the centrifugal force of emotionalism, sentimentality, Pollyanna-ish liberalism from prevailing.
His four daily hours in the pool were a ritual of solitude, discipline, exertion.

definition: tiresomely long; seemingly without end
details: Use interminable to describe something that has or seems to have no end. Your math class. Your sister's violin recital. A babysitting job where five kids are going through your purse and the parents didn't leave a number.
examples: That leaves Congress only one route: a possibly interminable civil litigation.
The interminable loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks made a deep outing from Maeda more crucial than usual for the Dodgers.
It wasn’t quite enough to lift them to the playoffs, but they should return this year after a three-year absence — an interminable gap for their regal brand.
Inside the Commons, MPs are preparing for a third consecutive night of voting on Brexit as they try to break the interminable deadlock.

definition: someone who carries out a learned profession
details: A practitioner is an expert who uses that knowledge as part of a profession. Every yoga practitioner started by attending an introductory class.
examples: Talk of prejudice in medicine runs the risk of sparking a backlash from practitioners.
A day earlier, the Texas Senate approved imprisoning medical practitioners for up to 10 years if they don’t treat infants who survive abortions.
Last Congress, we added nurse practitioners and physicians assistants to the same reporting mechanism.
I worked with Kirstjen for decades as part of the community of scholars and practitioners who advocated for effective homeland security policies.

definition: inferior in rank or status
details: A subaltern is someone with a low ranking in a social, political, or other hierarchy. It can also mean someone who has been marginalized or oppressed.
examples: Bearded men of 50 were among them and subalterns of 18 as well.
We were interrupted by a subaltern, who scolded us and told us to leave the body lie.

The islands, which fell under Danish rule in the fourteenth century, became self-governing in 1948, but the relationship between the two countries remains that of a resentful subaltern state and a condescending colonial power.

Latest Project Her next media venture, Joojoo Journal, which she describes as a “multilingual, multimedia publication where diasporic, marginalized and ‘subaltern’ voices are uplifted,” goes live in April.

definition: chronologically misplaced
details: Something that's old-fashioned and maybe a little out of place is anachronistic, like a clunky black rotary-dial telephone sitting on a desk beside a sleek new smart-phone (or whatever the new technology is when you read this).
examples: The vision of Mr. Mendes with his bulky old camera and flashbulbs seemed anachronistic, if not absurd.
Media narratives coalesced around words like “quirky,” “anachronistic,” “effusive,” “undisciplined,” “garrulous,” and “folksy.”
But when there’s no such thing as the middle, a show styled to float there will play to some as anachronistic.
Things sound louder without really sounding fuller, anachronistic touches abound, and the stereo mixing is a bit too busy and impressed with itself.

definition: solidify, thicken, or come together
details: Congeal means to jell — to solidify or become gelatinous. Sounds gross? But wiggly Jell-O is actually congealed liquid, so it can't be that bad, right?
examples: Their greatness, it seems, is largely a product of how many unknowns congeal around them, as well as the intensity, specificity and profundity of those unknowns.
Such collectives congeal around their political leaders’ rhetoric that provides righteous justification of suppressing these defiled minorities by all means necessary.
By morning they will be pale and green and their blood congealed and black.
In one circle, an infant lay on her mother’s lap, sucking hungrily on a bottle empty but for a layer of congealed milk inside.

definition: occupy in an agreeable, entertaining or pleasant fashion
details: Visitors to an elementary school during recess may be surprised by the way the kids disport themselves. Disport means to play in a carefree way or to amuse yourself in a lighthearted fashion.
examples: He showed me works he was making: visions of exploding buildings and fantastical beasts disporting themselves in temples and gardens.
While elsewhere in town, van loads of tourists are being carted around to view houses once inhabited by movie stars gone and long forgotten, at San Vicente Bungalows the live ones disport themselves.
The luxurious genre descends from the celebrated French tradition of young men and women shown disporting themselves amorously in parkland settings.
Neither is it a crapshoot, with random particulates disporting themselves until something works.

definition: fill with sublime emotion
details: Exciting or thrilling things might exhilarate you. If you love acting, just the thought of being on stage might exhilarate you, giving you a feeling of giddy excitement.
examples: It’s both exhilarating and infuriating to watch as “Fosse/Verdon” drags us through these recurring spats, in the style of “A Star Is Born” and a hundred other celebrity rise-and-fall tales.
But sport is at its most exhilarating when it showcases the emergence of youth.
It’s less exhilarating, however, for those who read our most enthused festival reviews, only to learn that it may be months or even years before they get to see the gem in question.

How on the turbulent Earth did the fourth son of immigrants from a giant country long discouraging toward female athleticism end up as the exhilarated play-by-play voice of the very American women’s Final Four?

definition: insert words into texts, often falsifying it thereby
details: When you interpolate words into a text, you alter the text by adding words in. If you’re describing your favorite novelist's work, you might interpolate a few examples of her writing into your description.
examples: In both cases, the devices interpolate between the planes to allow users to determine how out-of-focus the blurred parts of their shots should appear.
At a few key moments in “Call Me Madam,” he interpolates the melody of “God Bless America,” which he’d written more than 30 years earlier.

There’s certainly no shortage of bopping—by the old-school definition—in the music video for “7 Rings,” the Rodgers and Hammerstein–interpolating song that last week debuted at No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100.
On “King’s Dead,” Future freaks it and interpolates Three Six Mafia at the same time.

definition: concerned with practical matters
details: To describe a person or a solution that takes a realistic approach, consider the adjective pragmatic. The four-year-old who wants a unicorn for her birthday isn't being very pragmatic.
examples: The strongest traditional liberal candidates, despite their pragmatic streak, speak with hopeful idealism, stemming from their relatively optimistic view of the country’s capacity to compromise, reform and change.
But this pragmatic thinking was undone by an accident: At the worst possible moment, Ogunbowale couldn’t miss.
The rationale was pragmatic: to secure the line of inheritance that kept property in male hands.
“Hollings was a much more pragmatic legislator who cared about details and programs.”

definition: make subservient; force to submit or subdue
details: If you say you won't be kept down by the man, you are saying that you won't let the man subjugate you. To subjugate is to repress someone, or to make them subservient to you.
examples: Throughout the novel he goes on and on about how women want to be subjugated, in life in general and in the bedroom in particular.
The series’ juxtaposition of the supernatural and mundane is the perfect setting for a pack of underachieving vampires who’d rather stay home and bicker than subjugate mankind.

Tarrant fulminated about hordes at the gate from Australia, where white settlers first established a colony in 1788, and, over the next century, proceeded to murder, kidnap, and subjugate the Aboriginal population.
Tyrannical regimes seek to control what their populations read, see and hear, lest the people obtain information that might encourage them to question the power that subjugates them.

definition: similar or equivalent in some respects
details: Use the adjective analogous to describe something that is similar to something else and can be compared to another.
examples: Using the “Whites” moniker for the team because of their white uniforms is roughly analogous to calling Stanford University’s sports teams the Cardinal, Kotler argued.
Jan achieved an analogous stylistic rigor in the coordination of his production’s scenic elements.
Understanding the analogous control parameters that govern the transition inside teams and companies helps us engineer more innovative organizations.
He uses the classifications “Europeans, Africans and Asians” as analogous to biological populations — which they’re not.

definition: relating to the relationship between a wife and husband
details: The adjective conjugal describes all husband-and-wife matters, so if someone who is married says, "Single people don't understand how I feel," you can be sure it's a conjugal situation.
examples: So finally, in 2009, Anna — a career federal government worker who specialized in federal government work — suddenly decided, in some type of crazy karmic conjugal kickback, to start watching hockey games.
Berlinger shared there were two women who did not participate in the documentary — his ex-wife Carole Anne Boone and their daughter Rose, who was conceived after an alleged conjugal visit.
His cry his perfect word pitched against The baffled contradictions of the heart Wrestling them embracing them Strangling them with a jealous conjugal desperation.
The far-right candidate used a term that describes conjugal visits by partners to male inmates.

definition: your usual mood
details: Someone's disposition is their mood or general attitude about life. If your friend woke up on the wrong side of the bed, tell her that she might need a disposition makeover.
examples: “We reiterated our disposition to establish cooperation mechanisms for international aid and assistance,” Mr. Maduro wrote Tuesday on Twitter.
The prosecutor’s office said, in a statement, that it considered it a “just disposition and appropriate resolution to this case.”
“A bit more temperate than Dorne, in both weather and human disposition.”
The impression is offset by the wire rim glasses he wears and by the bookish disposition of a person who, as a teenager, once asked for a copy of the German Constitution as a present.

definition: a pressing or urgent situation
details: Think of a mix of excitement and emergency, and you have exigency, a sudden, urgent crisis. The very word conjures up danger and intrigue that demand a cool head and an immediate effort at a solution.
examples: If that violates the exigencies of franchise filmmaking, so be it.
It will continue to operate under a declaration of financial exigency.
“To the extent that there are any plausible exigencies, they are of Muthana’s own creation.”

More bittersweet and less triumphal than its predecessors, and directed by a returning Dean DeBlois, “The Hidden World” concerns the exigencies that Hiccup faces as a leader, both politically and personally.

definition: marked by close acquaintance, association, or familiarity
details: Intimate means being close. A small restaurant is called intimate because you're sitting close to the other people, and your best friends are considered your intimate friends.
examples: From the moment she first hears him preach, the two seem held by a rapport that is both entirely platonic, it must be noted, and stirringly intimate.
Deeper tones lend a sense of drama and mystery and form a perfect backdrop for candlelit dinners and intimate gatherings.
“It’s all part of my fabric,” she said of including such intimate details.
“The studio was an intimate space at the heart of the community, which helped calm people’s nerves in front of the camera,” McKay said.

definition: speak about unimportant matters rapidly and incessantly
details: If your little sister won't stop talking about her latest crush and you don't want to hear it, you might say, "Stop prattling on about that loser!" To prattle is go on and on about something unimportant.
examples: Asked how the police officer responded, he said he was sworn at and told to "shut my... prattle'."
Peter prattles on about the old days, recalling a Nashville where, as he describes it, everyone looked effeminate.
She prattled on, and contentedly he half listened.
While she prattles away, we see cartoon Trump reach below the viewers’ line of sight to grab Meg inappropriately.

definition: direct energy or urges into useful activities
details: When you're at a lecture and you feel restless, you've got to sublimate the desire to move around. That means you force the desire to be more subtle so you can continue listening — even if you don't want to.
examples: A few other things interest her, including desire, sublimated and unleashed.
Or Anthony Davis, the No. 1 pick in 2012, whom Calipari convinced to so sublimate himself that he took fewer shots than three teammates on their championship team that season.

But maybe most of all, the explanation for Morant’s remarkable improvement between two seasons was the changing team dynamics around him, and his willingness last season to sublimate his own numbers for the team’s sake.
Some of them seem to sublimate that guilt and restlessness into feats of extreme athleticism.

definition: a state of lawlessness and disorder
details: Use the noun anarchy to describe a complete lack of government — or the chaotic state of affairs created by such an absence. A substitute teacher might worry that an unruly classroom will descend into anarchy.
examples: Instead there is anarchy, and when everything meshes, it sounds like newly invented harmonic wonder.
A community that indulges thoughts of anarchy was wary of adding any guardrails to the programs and products it produced.
The possible outcomes include anarchy, totalitarianism and outright dictatorship.
Put simply, the U.S. imports drugs and exports anarchy.

definition: summon into action or bring into existence
details: If your mom can magically conjure up the most delicious meals from the most random ingredients in the kitchen, she might just be the best cook in the neighborhood.
examples: That is the idea, to conjure these open, wild spaces.

VAR intervened successfully, overruling a duff offside flag, and leaving Suárez dancing around on his own, taunting the crowd, leaping about weirdly as the referee suddenly conjured a goal from his earpiece.

Donald Trump and Republicans are already hard at work attempting to portray Democrats as radical socialists, demonise freshmen members of Congress such as Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and conjure images of a new Venezuela.
Mr. Fischer steered toward each new horror with an ingenuity capable of conjuring all the narrative’s gothic scenery — no strobing, blood-red light shows necessary.

definition: an elaborate analytical or explanatory essay or discussion
details: Disquisition is a long and elaborate word to describe a long and elaborate analysis of a given topic. If you launch into a disquisition about toe jam at a party, you'll soon be talking to a wall.
examples: Still, wherever Lopez goes, he is never far from a disquisition on humanity’s merciless ways.
He offers grisly disquisitions on the death squads, on the disappeared, on body parts washing up on the beach.
A section on the opiate crisis includes a speculative and persuasive disquisition on the possible links between chronic pain and the authoritarian promise of control.
But neither was it strong for French President Emmanuel Macron to offer a disquisition on the difference between nationalism and patriotism in his remarks.

definition: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
details: Use the adjective exorbitant when you want to describe something that is really just too much! You'll often hear people griping about exorbitant bank fees or exorbitant interest rates.
examples: Two years ago, when I was reporting on the opioid epidemic in one West Virginia county, the exorbitant cost of it—both socially and financially—perpetually astonished me.
Law school is an exorbitant racket that condemns countless students to years, even decades, of crushing student debt.
“The private school options aren’t that attractive. They also utilize a Eurocentric curriculum and add to the exorbitant cost of living in Seattle.”

Ward said he felt it was important for there to be some interest rate available because there are inflationary costs associated with lingering debts, but he said the 12 percent was just too exorbitant.

definition: difficult to manage or mold
details: Can't manage your stubborn little brother who won't do what anyone says? You could call him intractable, or you could call your mother. Problems are intractable when they can't be solved.
examples: But on a subject as intractable as illegal immigration, that doesn't necessarily change the outcome.
By the weekend, she was facing one of Chicago’s most intractable problems, when 31 people were shot, three fatally.
McAleenan knows the problem well, and he knows how intractable it is, as well as the momentum it gathers as more and more families leave Central America.
If the offended person is so intractable +they won’t listen, then the fault is theirs.

definition: a preliminary introduction, as to a statute or constitution
details: A preamble is a brief introduction to a speech, like the Preamble to the Constitution that starts out "We the People of the United States, in Order to form a more perfect Union...do ordain and establish this Constitution."
examples: Events of the following month added to an excitable Masters preamble as Tiger Woods won the Tour Championship at East Lake.
The preamble to the bill notes that Quebec “attaches importance to the equality of women and men.”

The preamble to the treaty commits members to “safeguard the freedom, common heritage and civilisation of their peoples, founded on the principles of democracy, individual liberty and the rule of law”.
A preamble said the D.E.A. and the inspector general worked together on redactions, and press officers for both declined to comment on the inadvertent disclosure.

definition: of high moral or intellectual value
details: In common use, sublime is an adjective meaning "awe-inspiringly grand, excellent, or impressive," like the best chocolate fudge sundae you've ever had.
examples: It must be sublime to be unencumbered by conscience, weightlessly bloviating to the cheers of admirers without the burden of truth.
Abstract painters such as Barnett Newman and Mark Rothko painted sublime slabs that were praised in hushed voices.
In this sublime hoax, Mills argued, the designer was central.
The filling may be chopped by hand, but it’s easier to achieve the sublime texture with either a high-speed blender or full-size food processor, not a mini-processor.

definition: short account of an incident
details: A short, amusing true story is an anecdote. You might come back from a crazy spring break with a lot of anecdotes to tell.
examples: For nearly three hours, their eyes barely left their screens as they attempted to verify candidates’ comments in real time: allegations about corruption, statistics on the country’s Muslim population, boasts, and even personal anecdotes.
Since the term “cloaking” doesn’t appear to exist prior to Thompson’s experience — at least in terms of dating — anecdotes of being #cloaked are not as widely available online.
The anecdote is shared by their daughter to explain the couple’s latest establishment: Mama Chang in Fairfax, “a celebration of women in the family,” says Lydia Chang, chief of business development.
In the wake of McIntyre’s death, anecdotes are surfacing which reveal more and more shining facets of the gem she was.

definition: an expert able to appreciate a field
details: A connoisseur is a person who, through study and interest, has a fine appreciation for something, like the connoisseur who can identify the clarinet player on a jazz recording by the sound of his inhalations alone.
examples: Showing a nicely judged sense of humor, the annotated catalogue of Pistner’s collection of Lilliputian-sized books is a gorgeous, Brobdingnagian tome — and sure to become a standard reference for connoisseurs of miniature bindings and texts.
A moment of great enjoyment for connoisseurs of schadenfreude, and karma.
In just those two, he offered one treat for the connoisseur and one for those who stop by basketball every now and then for a spectacle.
The lusty foods and intense wines of southern Italy provide inspiration to spare for cooks and connoisseurs.

definition: behave unnaturally or affectedly
details: To dissemble is to hide under a false appearance, to deceive. "When confronted about their human rights record, the Chinese government typically dissembles."
examples: He stonewalled, he dodged and he dissembled with an acuity developed from decades of practice concealing Republican malfeasance.
Having conflated a political crisis with a national one, Mr. Trump chooses to dodge, dissemble and lie.
In French discussions of integration, there is a tendency to dissemble questions of race, class and social discrimination beneath the fig leaf of religion.
As Burnett dissembled, Stern kept prying, and the exchange became excruciating.

definition: add details, as to an account or idea
details: The verb expatiate means "to add details to in order to clear up." If your story is confusing to everyone who hears it, certain key parts must be missing. Better expatiate so that people can understand it.
examples: When the baron expatiated upon the superior practices of Europe, the Indians were baffled.
When the question is general enough, they move quickly from answering it to expatiating on general themes.
Groucho expatiated on Lear’s relationship to his daughters.
The emotional temperature in the room changes when this imposing paterfamilias begins expatiating with contempt on Aaron’s plan.

definition: stubborn refusal to compromise or change
details: If you refuse to compromise with your sister about whose turn it is to do the dishes, your mother might accuse you both of intransigence. Intransigence is a stubborn refusal to change your views.
examples: It was Taylor who pushed for John Gielgud as the butler in “Arthur” in the face of studio intransigence.
An AP investigation finds that the war-torn country’s massive cholera epidemic was aggravated by official intransigence and potential corruption.
It is feeding partisanship’s rancor and intransigence, as voters organize around opposing the other side.
The sadly predictable response is equal and opposite intransigence.

definition: not secure; beset with difficulties
details: Grab for the adjective precarious when something is unstable, dangerous or difficult and likely to get worse. Are you totally broke and the people you owe money to keep calling? You're in a precarious financial situation!
examples: She spends the duration of the film either melting down or on the precarious verge of melting down, while assorted acolytes mostly scramble to accommodate her.

IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde says that while her agency is forecasting a rebound in growth next year that forecast is “precarious and subject to downside risks” with rising trade tensions a top threat.
It said it hoped to see a rebound in global growth later this year but admitted that was "precarious".
Shallow graves were precarious, too, vulnerable to animals and further floods, the possible scattering of bones.

definition: inclined or willing to give in to orders or wishes of others
details: When animals live in packs, one animal is usually the dominant leader, while the others fall into more submissive roles. To be submissive is to obey or yield to someone else.
examples: Sadly, the most submissive figure in this story is President Trump.
We showed women with desires who were not submissive and men who acted appropriately.
“This is an explicitly submissive position. Nothing compares to this.”
The business relied on a group of submissive men for the women to practice with.

definition: a feeling of ill will arousing active hostility
details: Animosity is hatred. If your (supposed) best buddy embarrasses you in front of a big crowd, your friendship could turn into animosity.
examples: The tension and “animosity” between the justices was “palpable and unpleasant,” and it bled over into an acidic, acrimonious set of opinions.
When they are marching, there is always this feeling of animosity on the streets, and some of my colleagues do not like going into the city.

A review of the research on rising animosity among Democrats and Republicans finds a lot of important and well-studied trends: Negative views of the out-party are rising and they are increasingly manifesting in nonpolitical interactions.
It quickly escalated, and the animosity between the two men exploded.

definition: an idea that is implied or suggested
details: When you're talking about the implied subtext of words rather than their literal meaning, reach for the noun connotation. A political boss might not want to be called "boss" because of the negative connotations.
examples: But a DMV official rejected the request, writing that the configuration “carries connotations offensive to good taste and decency,” according to a letter included as an exhibit in the suit.
It’s another example of fears and connotations — what wine signifies — triumphing over honest expressions of tastes.
“Our concern was with the connotation of the statement to the Black Lives Matter movement,” the new post read.
But Kaminsky also mines puppetry’s negative connotations too; when villagers are kidnapped and killed, puppets are hung on their doors.

definition: cause to become widely known
details: Disseminate means to spread information, knowledge, opinions widely. Semin- derives from the Latin word for seed; the idea with disseminate is that information travels like seeds sown by a farmer.
examples: The Han officials I met during my fieldwork referred to this rise in technologically disseminated religious piety as the “Talibanisation” of the Uighur population.
Conceived by Clément Chéroux, the museum’s senior curator of photography, the exhibition connects our current moment with a longer, more complicated history of disseminating images.
One difference with previous waves of unrest is the role of social media in organising and disseminating images of the protests.
But it is now being disseminated to the whole force.

definition: make amends for
details: In the fairy tale, the baker must expiate his father’s sins by bringing the witch three ingredients for a magic potion: a cow, a cape and a slipper. Expiate means to make amends or atone for a wrong you or someone else has committed.
examples: Most outgoing employers expiate their guilt with reference letters so lavish that they qualify as fiction.
As the two sisters waited for their father’s return, in the care of an aunt, they were forced to expiate the sins of their deceased mother.
The past sins of a ruthless aristocratic class are inherited, but not expiated, by the present-day upholders of law and order.
The appropriation of natural goodness by corporate brands allows us to expiate our guilt for participating in the system.

definition: invulnerable to fear or intimidation
details: Intrepid is just a fancy word for describing a person or action that is bold and brave. Super heroes are intrepid in their struggle for truth, justice and the American way.
examples: Everyday objects are repurposed as building blocks of the fantastical worlds encountered by Jason and his intrepid adventurers.
His explorations put him and his less intrepid companions in danger, but his concern was always for his instruments.
Waters ran the final possession to perfection, punctuating an intrepid dribble drive with the winning scoop shot.

The mailers, in particular, painted a vivid picture of a scrappy band of intrepid attorneys and hate-group monitors, working under constant threat of death to fight hatred and injustice in the deepest heart of Dixie.

definition: a rule of personal conduct
details: A precept is a rule or direction, often with some religious basis, dictating a way you should act or behave.
examples: But in court documents, CorePower’s lawyers dismissed karma as a meaningless “metaphysical precept,” on par with words like “authentic,” “World Class Yoga Experience” and, yes, “soul-rocking.”
Thus, against what the New York Times is implying, Christians, following the precepts of the Bible, are not dangerous or subversive.

definition: an actively expressed feeling of dislike and hostility
details: Antagonism means hostility. You might feel antagonism toward your annoying little sister, particularly if she's always borrowing your stuff without asking.
examples: The way I see it, pushing Mexico and other nations to do America’s bidding on highly complex problems like drug control and migration simply produces more antagonism while failing to achieve the desired results.

definition: the body of voters who elect a representative for their area
details: If you're an elected official, your constituency is the group of people whose interests you were elected to represent.
examples: “I certainly won’t be going on holiday next week. I will be getting back to the constituency and doing the day job.”

definition: move or draw apart
details: When two roads diverge, they split and go in different directions. If your opinion diverges from mine, we do not agree. To diverge means to move apart or be separate.
examples: The inspector general’s office says Chicago police are committed to improvements but that some police proposals “substantially diverge” from report recommendations.

definition: praise, glorify, or honor
details: If you have a crush on a guy who likes your best friend, it can be very depressing to listen to him extol your friend's virtues, while you just nod and smile. If you extol something, you praise it very highly.
examples: Mr. Trump frequently extolled WikiLeaks during his campaign, as it posted unflattering emails about his opponent, Hillary Clinton, that were hacked from the Democratic National Committee and Mrs. Clinton’s campaign manager, John Podesta.

definition: the act of appealing for help
details: An invocation is an appeal to a higher power for help, such as a prayer for serenity or a plea to the rain gods during a drought.
examples: But in that same decision it also acknowledged that there was such a thing as executive privilege, an imprimatur that encouraged its invocation by Nixon’s successors.

definition: dress or groom with elaborate care
details: When a bird or a cat preens, it smooths its feathers or cleans its fur. When you preen, you primp and pay careful attention to how you're dressed and groomed, as if you're inviting the whole world to watch you.
examples: Otherwise, “his only thought was to get rid of you,” as he strutted around, predatory and preening: the “epitome of the normal male.”

definition: make dirty or spotty
details: To sully is to attack someone's good name and to try to ruin his reputation. If you spread false rumors that there's chicken stock in the vegetarian entree at Joe's Diner, you would sully Joe's good reputation.
examples: Returning that money just because the donor’s reputation is now sullied may get the charity in trouble with state regulators.

definition: someone from whom you are descended
details: An antecedent is a thing that comes before something else. You might think rap music has no historical antecedent, but earlier forms of African-American spoken verse go back for centuries.
examples: The first antecedents of the modern Republicans were the Federalists, led by Alexander Hamilton.

definition: compose or represent
details: To constitute is to make up a whole from smaller parts, or "constituents." "What constitutes a family?" means "What makes up a family?"
examples: As I grew up, the list of what constituted comfort food for me grew.

definition: tending to move apart in different directions

definition: obtain by coercion or intimidation
details: To extort is to use information or the threat of violence to acquire cash or something else. Extortion is a classic shakedown, a gouge, a squeeze.

definition: quickly aroused to anger

definition: a statement that is held to be true
details: A premise is what forms the basis of a theory or a plot. When you called 911 on the guy in your back yard, it was on the premise that he was a thief and not the meter-reader.

definition: characterized by oppressive heat and humidity
details: Stifling, humid and downright oppressive, sultry is an adjective that has everything to do with sweltering heat and a definite need for a tall glass of iced tea.

definition: suggesting human features for animals or inanimate things

definition: having variety of character or form or components

definition: an inference about the future based on known facts

definition: too old to be useful

definition: take away possessions from someone
details: It could be your wine portfolio, your stake in a mining company, or even the extra coats that are taking up space in your closet. Whatever it is, when you divest something, you get rid of it.

definition: recklessly wasteful

definition: uncertain how to act or proceed

definition: creating an appearance of importance or distinction

definition: having or showing arrogant disdain or haughtiness

definition: a feeling of intense dislike

definition: some situation or event that is thought about

definition: surpassing the ordinary or normal

definition: of, affecting, or being on or near the surface
details: Anything superficial has to do with the surface of something. If you're judging a book by its cover, you're being superficial. People who worry too much about their clothes and hair may also be considered superficial.

definition: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
details: Something is antithetical when it is in complete and utter opposition to the character of something. If you’re a vegetarian, eating giant T-bone steaks is antithetical to your beliefs.

definition: compete for something
details: To defend a belief or keep affirming that it's true is to contend. People used to contend that the earth was flat, but eventually, when no one dropped off the edge no matter how far they traveled, the "round" theory won.

definition: easily handled or managed

definition: an established line of travel or access

definition: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
details: When you prevaricate, you lie or mislead. Now, go ahead and tell me whether you already knew that meaning, and don’t prevaricate about it — give me the story straight!
examples: If the prime minister continued to prevaricate and attempt changes to the backstop, Cooper said, she and others would attempt to force a new process.

definition: more than is needed, desired, or required
details: When something is so unnecessary that it could easily be done away with, like a fifth wheel on a car or a fifth person on a double date, call it superfluous.

definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
details: Use the noun apathy when someone isn't interested in the important things that are happening. You might feel apathy for the political process after watching candidates bicker tediously with one another.

definition: the act of competing as for profit or a prize
details: There is nothing "content," or satisfying, about being in contention, and that's probably because the word contention means being in a competition that ends with one side, usually the winning one, being content.

definition: a representation of a person's thinking with symbolic marks
details: A document is a piece of paper that contains official information. Don't you wish you had a document saying that the bank owed you $5 million?

definition: completely free from dirt or contamination
details: If something is pristine it's immaculately clean or has never been used. So please check your shoes before walking on a pristine white carpet.
examples: The company reported 18 leaks and twice spilled large quantities of drilling fluids in two pristine Ohio wetlands while constructing a $4.2 billion natural gas pipeline.

definition: take the place or move into the position of
details: If you click on the link after this description, a new screen will supersede, or replace, this one. A longer description will supplant, or supersede, by replacing this brief one.

definition: a short pithy instructive saying

definition: showing an inclination to disagree
details: A contentious issue is one that people are likely to argue about, and a contentious person is someone who likes to argue or fight.
examples: Energy policy is as contentious as any in Australia, which is the world's biggest exporter of coal and liquid natural gas.

definition: stubbornly unyielding
details: Someone who's dogged is stubbornly persistent. In the old Looney Tunes cartoons, Wile E. Coyote's pursuit of the Road Runner is dogged. He simply will not give up.

definition: humbly entreating
details: A suppliant is someone who begs or prays for something, and to be suppliant is to humbly pray or ask for forgiveness. Puppy-dog eyes can help if you’re trying to look suppliant.

definition: great coolness and composure under strain

definition: a tortuous and twisted shape or position

definition: a comic verse of irregular measure
details: We're not sure why poor dogs always seem to get used to describe something really dreadful, but it's the case with doggerel — meaning irregularly rhyming, really bad poetry, usually comic in tone and fit only for dogs.

definition: making great mental demands
details: Something problematic poses a problem or causes difficulties. Your ambitions to become the next great leader of Spain are great, but your inability to speak Spanish might prove problematic.

definition: the cognitive process of conjecturing
details: A supposition is a guess or a hypothesis. Your supposition that your kids will automatically wash their hands before dinner is probably false. You'd best remind them to do it or risk dirty hands at dinner.

definition: being of questionable authenticity
details: Urban legends — stories about phantom hitchhikers, deep-fried rats, and spider eggs in bubblegum — are classic examples of apocryphal tales. They're told as if they're true, but no one can ever verify their origins or authenticity.
examples: One guard told him a story, perhaps apocryphal, about an accused Russian assassin who was jailed in Kiev, the capital.

definition: a binding agreement that is enforceable by law
details: When you and someone else have agreed on something and that agreement is both binding and enforceable by law, you have a contract. When you rent an apartment, you and your future landlord sign a rental contract.
examples: It helped lead him to the defending champions on a one-year bargain contract.

definition: pertaining to a code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
details: To be dogmatic is to follow a set of rules no matter what. The rules might be religious, philosophical, or made-up, but dogmatic people would never waver in their beliefs so don’t even think of trying to change their minds.

definition: of or relating to processes
details: If you have to follow so many rules at work that it seems like nothing ever gets done, you could say that the procedural requirements of your job are getting you down. The adjective procedural describes something related to a required or standard course of action.

definition: unfriendly and inclined toward anger or irritation
details: Surly describes behavior nobody wants to be around. Think of the irritable old guy who lives on your street and always seems to be simmering with some sullen nasty anger, whose every utterance he spits out with a rude snarl. He's the poster boy for surly.

definition: a person who argues to defend some policy or institution

definition: artificially formal

definition: mental infirmity as a consequence of old age

definition: a natural inclination

definition: a proud stiff pompous gait

definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment
details: Apparent means obvious, but — and this is confusing — it can also mean something that seems to be true but isn't definite. "The train's arrival is apparent — it's in the station — but apparently my friend missed it because she is not getting off."

definition: an injury in which the skin is not broken

definition: shower with love; show excessive affection for
details: Who doesn't love to have someone dote on them? If you dote on someone, you shower them with love and attention. Sounds like the life!

definition: postpone doing what one should be doing
details: Procrastinate means to put off doing something until a future time. When people sit down to write term papers, they can find all kinds of clever ways to procrastinate: reorganizing the paperclips, calling everyone they know, typing "I am bored" fifty times in a row.

definition: move in large numbers
details: A swarm is a good word for a large group of bees going on the attack — not good news. Like bees, any group of people or animals can be considered a swarm if they act together and quickly — even fiercely.

definition: be attractive to
details: Appeal means "to ask, or address." If you appeal to someone's better nature, you're asking them for mercy. If a shirt doesn't appeal to you, you could also say it doesn't "speak" to you, or more simply, you don't like it.

definition: a difficult problem
details: The tricky word conundrum is used to describe a riddle or puzzle, sometimes including a play on words or pun.

definition: sediment that has settled at the bottom of a liquid
details: Those little grains of tea or coffee left at the bottom of the cup are known as the dregs. The dregs are the least wanted portion, or the residue.
examples: Southern California’s NHL teams are the dregs of their conference, and they will miss the playoffs in the same season for the first time since 2004.

definition: recklessly wasteful
details: Use the adjective prodigal to describe someone who spends too much money, or something very wasteful. Your prodigal spending on fancy coffee drinks might leave you with no money to buy lunch.
examples: In his homily, the pope spoke about the return of the prodigal son, and how the warm reception he was given upset his older brother.

definition: an erratic turn from an intended course
details: The noun swerve means a sudden turn off your path. As a verb, it means to move off your original route, possibly to avoid a collision. You can swerve either toward something or away from it.
examples: It shows the SUV stopping to let the pedestrian walk by, but then accelerating and swerving into the person, leaving the victim with a broken leg.

definition: make peace with
details: Appease means to make or preserve peace with a nation, group, or person by giving in to their demands, or to relieve a problem, as in "the cold drink appeased his thirst."
examples: But Israelis increasingly appreciate Netanyahu’s steady hand on the tiller, and his ability to avoid war without appeasing Israel’s enemies.

definition: get over an illness or shock
details: Convalesce is a soft-sounding word, and it describes something you should do in a soft bed: recover from an illness.

definition: pleasing to the ear
details: Use the adjective dulcet to describe a sound that is soothing and soft, like the dulcet harmonies in a 70s pop song or the dulcet tones of a harp.

definition: situated at or extending to great depth
details: When you need a word that's deeper than "deep," consider profound.
examples: "It’s a profound honor to continue my dad’s legacy while stepping into the shoes of a young Tony Soprano," he's previously said.

definition: a person addicted to luxury and pleasures of the senses
details: If you know someone who's totally addicted to luxurious things and all of life's pleasures, call her a sybarite. Unless she's inviting you over for champagne brunches and showering you with gifts — in which case you should keep your mouth shut.
