definition: add to the very end
details: To append means to add on, usually to the end of something. You might want to append a clause onto a contract if you feel something has been left unsaid in it.
examples: “Flay” is, at its core, just an OK indie drama about a bickering brother and sister, with some blah supernatural hooey clumsily appended.
Some of my parents’ contemporaries distinguished themselves by appending their academic qualifications to their names.

“We are being exposed to an unacceptable public discourse regarding Arab citizens,” Rivlin said in comments appended to a long-planned speech Monday marking 40 years of peace between Israel and Egypt.
The RAH’s spokesperson appended a short note: “Just to flag though, the phrase ‘definitely going ahead’ would be a misquote.”

definition: a large formal assembly
details: A convention is a meeting, usually of a particular group. Political parties, teachers, plumbers, gardeners, toymakers and computer designers all hold conventions.
examples: After Trump addressed the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention last year, he welcomed 95-year-old Allen Jones to the stage.
After years of resisting the state primary as their method of choosing delegates for their presidential nominating convention, Washington Democrats are finally switching for 2020.
The Palestinians and many countries consider the settlements illegal under the Geneva conventions that bar settling on land captured in war.

Ecuador's president, Lenin Moreno, said Thursday that his government made a "sovereign decision" to rescind Assange's political asylum due to "repeated violations to international conventions and daily life."

definition: fool or hoax
details: A dupe is a furry, ceremonial hat occasionally worn during ancient pagan rituals... or not. Dupe actually means “trick or deceive.” We’re sorry we tried to dupe you into believing the wrong definition.
examples: Uber abruptly left the state when one of its autonomous vehicle hit and killed a woman, and Theranos was accused by federal regulators of duping investors about the accuracy of its blood tests.

His face and voice radiate pain, befuddlement and anger — much of the latter directed at himself — at how he was duped into writing an article that boosted the company’s profile and probably extended its reach.
But he is trying to persuade prosecutors, and me, that he was an unwitting assassin, duped by the two mysterious handlers he met at the Vienna Cafe, men he knew only as Philipp and Maksim.
Even now, some of those who were duped do not think they were lied to, at least not exactly.

definition: make a prediction about; tell in advance
details: To prognosticate means to predict something or at least hint at what will happen in the future. When a lot of natural disasters start happening close together, you might prognosticate that the world is ending, a prediction that's actually thousands of years old.
examples: “I’m not going to prognosticate today on how distribution will look.”

Of these three current Northwest exhibitions, “Between Bodies” is the most prognosticating, combining careful research, innovative media and artistic imagining to envision new realities and new ways of interacting with the world.
It’s still difficult to prognosticate forward with four games left to play, but the three-quarters mark of the regular season is a good time to begin studying the playoff scenarios in the NFC.
Would Mr. Carone prognosticate so glibly if he were face to face with the family of pedestrian Elaine Herzberg, struck and killed in Arizona by one of the new wonders?

definition: a person who tries to please someone to gain an advantage
details: A sycophant is a person who tries to win favor from wealthy or influential people by flattering them. Also known as brown-nosers, teacher's pets or suck-ups.
examples: Maybe Trump is getting bad advice from the very sycophants he’s nominating to the Fed board.
“I mean, he is a sycophant for Donald Trump, he is all things Trump. He’s not even thoughtful about it.”
He also denies he would be a Trump “sycophant.”
It matters that he appears to be a Trump sycophant.

definition: assign a duty, responsibility, or obligation to
details: The President can appoint someone as ambassador to another county; that means to give them the job or recommend them for it.
examples: Twitter messages between WikiLeaks and Trump's eldest son, Donald Jr., showed the group lobbying him to get his father to suggest that Australia appoint its native son Assange to be its ambassador to the U.S.
He appoints himself chair of the Revolutionary Command Council for National Salvation, which rules the country, and is named defense minister.
Algeria’s newly appointed interim leader on Wednesday set the date for a presidential election as July 4, the day before the nation celebrates its independence day.
He found his way into diplomacy and politics in the early 1980s, when he was appointed deputy chief of mission to the Israeli Embassy in Washington.

definition: be adjacent or come together
details: Use the verb converge to describe something that comes together at a common point: “Thousands of Elvis fans plan to converge on the small Arkansas town where unconfirmed sightings of the deceased superstar eating at a local barbeque restaurant had been widely reported.”
examples: Over the last weekend, the protesters converged on the Ministry of Defence, the army headquarters and President Bashir's personal residence - all within the same huge compound near the airport.
Taxis in Berlin converged on the capital’s famous Brandenburg Gate, filling up the wide boulevard that leads west from the monument.
More than 100,000 supporters converged on downtown Washington a year ago for a rally that became a defining symbol of the students’ determination to upend American politics.
They called for an animal protection law as they converged on a tomb of an American woman who is seen as the founder of animal rights in Cuba.

definition: willingly obedient out of a sense of respect
details: Are you a dutiful person? If you are, then you do as you're told, out of a feeling of duty and obligation. Dutiful children know this means cleaning one's room, taking out the trash, and not talking back!
examples: Out of a dutiful sense of modesty, I’m going to say no.
It felt more dutiful and perfunctory than anything, as if Phillies fans knew the media would be listening and took it upon themselves to uphold their own reputation.
Or that she would invoke former secretary of state Hillary Clinton as a paragon of dutiful defense work.
Spicer’s dutiful narration is supplemented by musings from Hogan, the author, who serves as a kind of sub-narrator.

definition: tending to discourage, especially of prices
details: If something's so expensive you can't touch it, it's prohibitive. That Ferrari in the showroom? You may want it, but its price is prohibitive.
examples: Because the cost of the wheelchair was prohibitive, Jackson went to his former high school for help.
“When applied to insects, prohibitive conservation rules designed to protect individual animals become nonsensical and do not help anything,” he said.
Turkey’s benchmark interest rate of 24 percent barely keeps the currency stable and at the same time puts a prohibitive cost on borrowing for Turkish firms.
Hawaii enjoys legendary amounts of sunshine, but the cost of turning it into electricity by 2008 still seemed prohibitive.

definition: reasoning in which a conclusion is derived from two premises
details: A syllogism is a type of logical reasoning where the conclusion is gotten from two linked premises. Here’s an example: An apple is a fruit. All fruit is good. Therefore apples are good.
examples: Such once comfortable syllogisms, needless to say, are facing mounting skepticism.
It was like a bizarre syllogism: these clothes are in photographs, the photographs look good, ergo these clothes look good.
DHS’s proposed use of credit scores involves a similar moral syllogism, and it illustrates the problem of metric creep.
She knows her way around a syllogism, but she also knows that persuasion is not reducible to reason—that the best arguments, on their own, do not always win.

definition: being of striking appropriateness and pertinence
details: Something apposite is fitting or relevant. It is apposite that radio stations play Christmas carols on Christmas Eve, and that your tax accountant takes vacation after April 15th. It all makes sense.
examples: It is an apposite question, the answer to which changed, fundamentally, that day in December.
Did he say it all simply because he couldn’t get over how extremely apposite it was?
The reference to the second world war is apposite.
This sentiment seems apposite, perhaps especially in San Francisco.

definition: the act of coming closer
details: Convergence is when two or more things come together to form a new whole, like the convergence of plum and apricot genes in the plucot.
examples: Of late, though, an extraordinary new talent convergence is riveting the contemporary American stage.
There is also a deep convergence between conservative politics and racism in post-civil rights America.
We’ll be spending our time looking at every aspect of the convergence of music and tech.
On first blush, the new poll might seem to show a convergence between Trump’s thin skin over "SNL" jokes and general public perception.

definition: think moodily or anxiously about something
details: To dwell in a home is to live in it. To dwell on something — usually something bad, like a failed romance or terrible service in a restaurant –- is to think or speak about it at great length.
examples: And then, all of a sudden, Ridley decided he was not so keen to dwell on the past after all.
“Obviously it’s a different team and you don’t want to dwell what’s happened in the past. But it’s more just sort of past playoff experiences,” Marchand said.
In the years that followed, as his production with the Tampa Bay Rays soared and his salary stayed static, he did not dwell on the money he left on the table in arbitration.

Using found objects — in particular, vintage tennis rackets — that she largely harvests from her neighborhood in Pittsburgh, German creates “power figures” and other objects that dwell on the nature of black female strength and identity.

definition: a planned undertaking
details: A project is a piece of work that is planned or intended. Plan a little extra time for your gingerbread house project — gluing the walls and roof can take a while.
examples: All those projects are on hold under the U.S. sanctions.

The rest of the project was mostly funded by two big investors: a South Africa-born Israeli entrepreneur named Morris Kahn and the Adelson Family Foundation, a charity based in Los Angeles that supports Israel.
Tyrion’s rise on the show fit that project; he wasn’t morally conflicted enough to be an antihero, but he certainly validated, if not glamorized, beta-male softness.
Van Wagenen also periodically worked for the church as a producer and director for many years on a variety of projects, church spokesman Eric Hawkins said.

definition: balance among the parts of something
details: Things that have symmetry are balanced, with each side reflecting the other. A human body has such complex symmetry, from eyes, ears, and nostrils to arms, legs, and feet, that even a minor injury can make a body look unbalanced.
examples: Because of the centrality of the table, dining rooms lend themselves to symmetry.
But from time to time an atom ends up in the wrong place, disrupting the beautiful symmetry of the crystal arrangement.
“The symmetry of the patterns is very important for the behavior of the droplet,” said Dr. Song.
In the end there was a strange sense of symmetry about it all.

definition: in fear or dread of possible evil or harm
details: If you're apprehensive, you're anxious or fearful. If you live near a busy intersection with no stop signs, you might be a bit apprehensive about crossing the street.
examples: But local farmers, holiday firms and politicians are apprehensive.
Germany is particularly apprehensive of possible U.S. tariffs on car imports.
The Wall Street Journal report said that senior Pentagon officials were apprehensive about the move, fearing it provoke a backlash against US troops in the region.
But both he and the art director Steven Defendini were a bit apprehensive, given the intricacies of the sets and costumes.

definition: make realize the truth or validity of something
details: "How again was it that you convinced me to do this?" the boy said to his friend before they jumped out of the plane on their first sky dive. Convince means to talk someone into something, or win someone over.
examples: “I guess we need some convincing that there is a necessity for a sixth branch” of the U.S. military, Sen. Joni Ernst, Iowa Republican, said.
"I guess we need some convincing that there is a necessity for a sixth branch without our armed forces," she said.
But the leaders were also not in fact greatly convinced May’s new plan would work.
Brenner tried to convince him of the role of genetic mutation.

definition: irritable as if suffering from indigestion
details: Dyspeptic is an old-fashioned word not often used anymore. It describes someone who is irritable due to depression or indigestion.
examples: Basically a compendium of sexist jokes, the dyspeptic work was aimed at an audience of “the ordinary set of giddy-headed young men,” and it was very popular.
Private Life is certainly very good at shivving its characters at close range and gutting these dyspeptic, privileged white people when they deserve it.
This dyspeptic side was occasionally aimed at reporters.
He is a dyspeptic chatterbox, prone to a gallows sensibility even in sunny times, and these were not.

definition: a prediction made by extrapolating from past observations
details: When you push something away from a central structure, that's called projection. If you predict that the Jets will win tomorrow's game, that's a projection, too — you're pushing your mind away from the present and into the future.
examples: A proposed amendment to the bill would require the State Public Charter School Authority to establish a five-year plan that includes the growth projection of charter schools.
Bernstein & Co. media analyst Todd Juenger does not expect Disney to reveal pricing or provide projections for subscriber growth.
AUGUSTA, Ga. — We’re almost done with all our Masters projections now that real golf is rapidly approaching.
The long projections, or axons, of those cells form the optic nerve, along which signals from the retina are carried to the brain’s visual cortex, where they are interpreted as images.

definition: inform somebody of something
details: To apprise someone about something is to fill them in, to give them the scoop. If someone in your immediate family wins the mega-bucks lottery, you want to be the first one to be apprised of that event!
examples: Cameras will detect road signs, and a display will keep the driver apprised of what was posted even if the driver missed them.
“The government is still investigating the circumstances surrounding this discrepancy, but wanted to apprise the court of it as expeditiously as possible,” Goodhand told Morin.
Under Stern’s watch, when apprised of the problem, the NBA did next to nothing.
GOP leaders were apprised of the strategy to discredit Cohen as untrustworthy.

definition: highly complex or intricate
details: If something is convoluted, it's intricate and hard to understand. You'll need to read over your brother's convoluted investment scheme a few times before deciding whether or not to go in on it.
examples: This convoluted and unworkable plan continues to devolve as bill sponsors now try to appease business-lobby critics who will likely never sign onto any kind of family leave legislation.
Toby soon finds himself doubting what he sees, as the line between reality and the imaginary becomes increasingly convoluted.
But the efforts to avoid tax, in the case of Schaeffler and his lenders, took a particularly convoluted form.
Authorities allege the students pulled off a convoluted scheme in order to wring Apple of the cash by using counterfeit devices and exploiting Apple’s return policy.

definition: a member of the working class
details: Working class, blue collar, plebeian and certainly not aristocratic — that's what the adjective proletarian means.
examples: Leslie Fiedler used the occasion of the novel’s publication to dismiss Algren himself as “a museum piece—the last of the proletarian writers.”
When your tantrum ended, you left us one of your funkiest Final Fours: the gritty kingdom of Michigan State plus three programs from the vast proletarian division — Texas Tech, Virginia and Auburn.
In the decades after World War II, the Italian earth produced a lot of cinematic salt, and local stories of peasant and proletarian hardship proved to be a popular global export.
Yet she was no less determined to shed the skin of her middle-class background, to reinvent herself as a kind of Pan-European proletarian.

definition: move towards
details: To approach is to get near something. An airplane is cleared for a final approach just as the wheels approach the landing strip.
examples: President Donald Trump agreed in talks in Washington that a top-down approach led by leaders is essential to facilitate further progress in nuclear talks, Chung Eui-yong, the South Korean national security adviser, told reporters.
The Roosevelt Institute report is an effort to provide a unified analytical approach and coherent policy agenda for this progressive moment in the Democratic Party.
About 7,000 of them are in detention centers - mostly in Tripoli - where conditions were awful even before they began hearing gunfire and shells as eastern forces approached a week ago.
"Stockpiling is just one part of our multi-layered approach to minimise any supply disruption, which includes alternative transport routes," a spokesman said.

definition: excessively fat
details: Corpulent is a formal word that describes someone who is very overweight. You might describe Santa Claus as a corpulent man with a ruddy complexion and a jolly grin.
examples: As corpulent and as unwieldy as the film’s vision of London is — sluggish, lumbering and clumsy — the movie isn’t something you savor so much as swallow whole, without tasting it.
But Sister Lucia, an elderly, corpulent nun, is less trusting than the others.
James’s corpulent face, with its still-sensuous lips and coolly — wearily? regretfully? arrogantly? — appraising eyes, radiates a modern ambiguity.
Pictures of him show a corpulent replica of Nikita Khrushchev.

definition: grow rapidly
details: When something proliferates, it's growing, spreading or multiplying really quickly. Bunny rabbits have a habit of proliferating, as do dandelions in untended gardens and funny YouTube videos on the internet.
examples: Rundquist also notes this will be especially valuable as CAFOs continue to rapidly proliferate, creating a moving target for environmental groups’ monitoring efforts.
But the industry’s continued struggles became apparent last month, when videos from the shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, proliferated for days on social media.
The issues proliferate: from the private takeover of public space, through basic questions of local democracy, to issues around work and pay.
As electric, self-driving cars proliferate, cities might be just swapping one form of congestion with another.

definition: official acceptance or agreement
details: Approbation is a formal word for approval or praise. Approbation is like getting the nod in a big way. Politicians rely on the public’s approbation to get elected.
examples: The term “lyric” fuels the approbation “lyrical,” meaning music that is attractive, melodic, and grateful on the ear.
His blogpost, published on the neutral Medium website under the title “No thank you, Mr Pecker”, flipped the script and earned widespread approbation.
On the left of the party, that is attracting rising approbation.
The leftist Mr. Ruffin brushed off any suggestion that he would profit politically from Yellow Vest approbation, or even that he wants to.

definition: speak in response
details: A counter is a surface used for making transactions in a store or in a home kitchen for preparing food. In a store, you pay for items at the counter.
examples: Newsom is in the Central American nation in an attempt to counter the Trump administration’s harsh immigration stance and recent moves to cut millions of dollars in U.S. aid to the country.
The group was founded by physicists in 1960 to help counter the growing threat of the Soviet Union, and much of its work still focuses on national security.
“Jet lag is real,” he says, perched at a rail counter toward the back of the coffee house.

Fairfax County is considering creating a taxpayer-funded legal defense fund for immigrants caught in deportation proceedings, part of a growing effort by local governments to counter the Trump administration’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants.

definition: not selective of a single class or person
details: The adjective promiscuous is often used pejoratively to refer to someone who has many romantic partners. However, the word can also be used in a general sense to mean "not limited, restrained, or restricted." If you're a promiscuous reader, you'll read just about anything — from biographies to science fiction to the back of the cereal box.
examples: What Nutt now knows is that there are 15 different Gaba receptor subtypes in multiple brain regions, “and alcohol is very promiscuous. It will bind to them all.”
Think of her as one of the great novelist Jean Rhys’s lost, promiscuous heroines transplanted to the 21st century, but with a devouring sense of humor that goes far beyond irony.
The film was 8½, the tale of a fecklessly promiscuous director abandoned by his muse.
“Outside thee Epiphany church, on G street, a very promiscuous and very silly looking assemblage was gathered.”

definition: suitable for a particular person, place, or situation
details: Something appropriate is correct and fits the situation. A sweater-vest with reindeer on it is appropriate holiday apparel, even if it's totally embarrassing.
examples: The New York State Taxation authority released a statement in October 2018, saying it was “reviewing the allegations in the New York Times article" and "vigorously pursuing all appropriate avenues of investigation.”

“So, it’s not really science. I think it’s somewhat appropriate that somebody with a pseudoscience degree is here pushing pseudoscience in front of our committee,” Massie said before Kerry fired back.
Baumann said Sotheby’s always sought to clarify the provenance of objects it was asked to sell, and to facilitate their return where appropriate.
He was at the forefront of the 1975 Asilomar meeting to discuss the appropriate use of emerging abilities to alter DNA, was a key proponent of the Human Genome Project, and much more.

definition: cancel officially
details: When an officer in the military shouts, “Belay that order, Private!” that is a countermand. A countermand is an order that cancels or reverses an earlier command. Countermand is also used as a verb meaning “to cancel or revoke.”
examples: The software countermanded the pilots’ instructions 26 times in a row, and finally took 189 people into the sea.
In December, he surprised many on his foreign policy team by countermanding it in a tweet: “It’s time to bring our great young people home!”
The countermanding of Lola’s casting decision, and the laughter in the boys it provoked, made for a shift in the balance of power.
In one instance, a devastating strike that killed 155 people in a funeral hall was ordered by a junior officer who countermanded an order from a more senior officer, a State Department official said.

definition: a natural inclination
details: A propensity is a natural tendency to behave in a certain way. We all have propensities — things we tend to do. Dogs have a propensity to bark, and many people have a propensity for getting annoyed by it.
examples: He said that "creates the appearance of bias and an understandable willingness, desire and propensity to rush to judgment in prosecuting."
Given that his game is predicated more on craft than raw athleticism, they worry about his propensity for committing turnovers.
“I don’t see it as luck,” freshman forward Emmitt Williams said of his team’s propensity to find a way to win late in games.
That’s because “decacorns tend to share two characteristics: plenty of money and a propensity to spend it in a race to build up share.”

definition: a supplementary component that improves capability
details: Something that is an accessory to something but not an integral part of it is an appurtenance. If you buy a car, you may want to purchase a few appurtenances for it, like an ice scraper and fuzzy dice to hang from your rear view mirror.
examples: Yes, dear fathers and others born with the appurtenances generally designated male.

One of the most unaccountable recent additions to the shopping-mall audio loop is Joni Mitchell’s “River,” which advocates skating away from all the holiday’s appurtenances, including cut-down trees, reindeer and “songs of joy and peace.”
In fact, it is the whole package — the dress, the background, the appurtenances of wealth and power — that matters.
There were, of course, millions of men with toothbrush mustaches, but the choice by a performer or politician to keep or to discard a symbolic appurtenance is never accidental.

definition: an assembly to conduct judicial business
details: A court is a room where justice is administered. Many popular television shows feature scenes in court, although it’s debatable whether these depictions are realistic.
examples: His license was suspended last month after he failed to pay or protest a speeding ticket, court records show.
When that court finally turned him down, Assange dyed his hair, popped in colored contacts and skipped bail, fleeing to the Ecuadorian Embassy.

Pending court approval, the companies would be liable to a $9.75 million settlement for the class action that began in April 2017, which may result in payments of up to $400 for participating plaintiffs.
He faces up to five years in jail — which is a serious threat, but only a fraction of Manning’s commuted 35-year sentence, and courts rarely apply a crime’s maximum penalty.

definition: a basic or essential attribute shared by members of a class
details: What you own or have, like a car or clothes, is your property. The qualities that a thing has are its properties. Aloe is a plant with medicinal properties — it soothes burns.
examples: It shifted ownership of more than 200,000 base family housing units to private real estate developers and property managers under confidential 50-year contracts, which the military now says must be renegotiated.
These techniques craft films into a single crystal without the breaks or defects that would disrupt their electronic and optical properties.
Barry also benefited from the “gross undervaluation of her father’s properties,” a scheme that saved the family tens of millions of dollars in taxes, the Times reported.
To Wilcox, the women on her list are victims of an epidemic unseen or ignored, the result of societal attitudes that see women’s lives as the property of men.

definition: of a suitable, fitting, or pertinent nature
details: Apropos means regarding or appropriate to, as in: Apropos of your interest in fishing, your grandfather gave you his set of championship lures, rods, reels and lucky tackle box.
examples: And better yet, apropos: Na is 12th in approaches from 50 to 125 yards.
Early yesterday morning, apropos of nothing, Donald Trump suggested on Twitter that he’s thinking about closing the U.S./Mexico border.
A week later, the Republican huddled with reporters ahead of his State of the Union address, and apropos of nothing, mocked McCain’s book sales.
There is that creamy O’Hara coloratura, too, to sing us all into happy submission and apply to this revival an apropos adjective: unmissable.

definition: crouch or curl up
details: To cower is to shrink in fear. Whether they live in the country or city, any mouse will cower when a huge, hungry cat approaches.
examples: “No security. No peace,” this ad says furiously, over images of blazing farmland and cowering children.
Whether cowering at a new height or finding astonishment as he, with a sneeze, is sent airborne, the digitally rendered Dumbo is one precious pachyderm.
Meanwhile, us wusses are cowering under our sheets.
Only a few metres before the cliff walk, there's another piece of a child cowering.

definition: make peace with
details: If you forgot flowers on your Mom's birthday, you can still propitiate her by sending a bouquet the next day. Propitiate means to appease someone or make them happy by doing a particular thing. Handy strategy for lovers, too.
examples: The films feature a recurring archetype: the arrival of a stranger, the discovery of a secret cult, then a vicious murder, perhaps a sacrifice, designed to propitiate pagan gods.
Nationalist groups such as the IRA and PLO were somewhat propitiated by negotiated territorial compromises.
I suspect that Oskar probably still believes that it was just something in my nature: that somebody needed to be sacrificed on the altar on the way to propitiate whatever, and that that was him.
She was famously jealous and violent, and Hawaiians tried to propitiate her with offerings of pork, fish, liquor.

definition: naturally disposed toward
details: Something apt is perfectly appropriate, clever and well-suited to the matter at hand. A "Cinderella story" might be an apt metaphor for an underdog team that makes it to the championships.
examples: Defendants facing probation were probably more apt to choose a plea deal, he said, while those staring down possible jail time are more apt to try to fight back, he said.
“Calabria, the ‘toe’ of Italy’s boot, is the most apt real-world comparison.
Back in season 1, “game of thrones” was an apt description of the action.
Texas Tech’s Norense Odiase referred to assistant Mark Adams as sort of the team’s “defensive coordinator,” thereby introducing apt football terminology.

definition: showing marked and often playful evasiveness or reluctance
details: Take the adjective coy for a person who pretends to be shy but really isn't, or someone who could give a definite answer but won't. Coy behavior can be playful or just plain annoying.
examples: Now, with Mr. Trump in his sights, Mr. Serrano is playing it coy.
For someone so interested in the power of others, Caro seems coy about his own power to shape legacies.
Manager Brad Ausmus dodged an inquiry on the date of the next scheduled checkup on Ohtani’s surgically repaired right elbow on Wednesday at Angel Stadium by playing coy.
Tiger played it coy when asked about the logo by the media, confirming it was Frank but offering few details on how he went from his golf bag to his shirt.

definition: presenting favorable circumstances
details: When the timing of something is propitious, it's likely to turn out well. A propitious time for taking a big test is when you've studied hard and had a good night's sleep.
examples: Now is a propitious time to debate the efficacy of forward-deploying U.S. military in the Middle East.
For Mexico, the timing of the caravan quandary is hardly propitious.
For those athletes wanting to do so but fearful of the consequences, there may never be a more propitious moment to act with conscience and conviction.
My timing was propitious, and I biked up just as “Wonder Woman,” I mean “Magic Hour,” was rehearsing a scene.

definition: inherent ability
details: An aptitude is something you're good at. A rock star might have an aptitude for energizing an audience, or for trashing his hotel room.
examples: Her devotion to the Dark Lord and her aptitude for magic itself are both put to the test when she confronts the inherent misogyny of the witch world.
Besides their signature plume, tuft cells share with their forebears details of their internal structure and an aptitude for detection.
We’d taken a personality and aptitude test, and after I looked up the P words in the dictionary, I realized that yes, I am precocious, but examining fossils didn’t interest me whatsoever.
The “more meritocracy” argument against both legacies and racial quotas implicitly assumes that aptitude — some elixir of I.Q. and work ethic — is what our elite primarily lacks.

definition: cheat or trick
details: To cozen is to mislead, defraud, or fool someone through lies. Cozen rhymes with dozen, and if you say you had two wrong answers on your math test, but you really had a dozen, you might be trying to cozen your parents.
examples: The point, however, is not to entertain the driver/employee but to cozen the owner.
The knowledge and guile of their managers enabled them to corrupt and cozen all too many of the region’s elected public officials and to thwart the legitimate aspirations of the people.”
“A few, mayhaps. Most are simply cautious. Some think to cozen him. He is not a man easily cozened, however.”
And the beauty of the pearl, winking and glimmering in the light of the little candle, cozened his brain with its beauty.

definition: correct behavior
details: Propriety is following what is socially acceptable in speech and behavior. If you are someone who cares about always doing the right and proper thing, your friends might accuse you of being obsessed with propriety and beg you to loosen up.
examples: Now he is turning his attention to the propriety of the investigation itself as it began.
They are of a nature which may with peculiar propriety be denominated political, as they relate chiefly to injuries done immediately to the society itself.
Neither shudder—hers or mine—was supposed to be part of the propriety calculus; it lived in the domain of flinches and squirms and private preferences it’s impolite to mention.
“The failure of the District Court to consider the evidence of grand jury abuse, let alone require any assurances of propriety by the government, is reversible error,” the appeal lawyers argued.

definition: curved down like an eagle's beak
details: Aquiline means like an eagle, so if someone tells you you have an aquiline nose, it means your nose looks like an eagle’s beak. Believe it or not, this is a compliment.
examples: There I met a group of hyper-realistic anime characters with exaggerated eyes, slim, aquiline noses and jaws who were to be my new “friends”.

A young man with very dark skin, African features, and an obviously African-American name suffers vastly -- vastly! -- greater effects from racism than a pale-skinned woman with an aquiline nose and a name like Meghan Markle.
“We’ve got the long aquiline noses. And we are so old.”
She studied his face: the wrinkles, the aquiline nose, the mumbling mouth.

definition: annoyed and irritable
details: If your friend fell out of bed, spilled hot tea on his socks, and tripped in the snow, you might expect him to be crabbed. Crabbed describes someone who is grumpy, or irritable, or has a generally crotchety attitude.
examples: I recognized Dad’s crabbed scrawl on a small brown cardboard box.
Zhou gestured to an open hallway, then crabbed along in his usual way.
With a crabbed, pre-New Deal understanding of administrative power, the court appears unwilling to grant agencies the discretionary authority to address our greatest problems, such as climate change.
No solid contour was certain, but all devolved with the evening into one crabbed mass, gnarled and dark beneath the moon.

definition: lacking wit or imagination
details: Prosaic means ordinary or dull. Most of us lead a prosaic everyday life, sometimes interrupted by some drama or crisis.

definition: based on or subject to individual discretion or preference
details: Something that's arbitrary seems like it's chosen at random instead of following a consistent rule. Team members would dislike their coach using a totally arbitrary method to pick starting players.
examples: A finding by a UN panel in 2016 that Assange’s continued confinement in the embassy amounted to “arbitrary detention” was dismissed by the UK Foreign Office, which maintained that his presence there is voluntary.

definition: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
details: A craven man is no Superman or Spiderman, nor is he a firefighter or a soldier. A craven man is the opposite of those guys: he has not an ounce of courage.

definition: command against
details: To proscribe something is to forbid or prohibit it, as a school principal might proscribe the use of cell phones in class.

definition: act between parties with a view to reconciling differences
details: If your two best friends are fighting over the last piece of gum in the pack, you might arbitrate by telling them to split the last piece. Arbitrate is when a neutral third party helps end a conflict.
examples: On Tuesday, the Nationals filed a lawsuit in New York state court attempting to block the Orioles’ attempt to arbitrate a new dispute by an independent arbitrator with no ties to baseball.

definition: the mental attitude that something is believable

definition: of or concerned with or related to the future

definition: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge

definition: the condition of having good fortune

definition: a long narrow opening

definition: powerful

definition: with suspicion or disapproval
details: You may have trouble watching a gory horror movie, but you also won't be able to look away. Find a happy medium by looking askance, or subtly out of the corner of your eye.
examples: She looks at me askance, trying to tell if I’m trying to get away with something or if I’m for real.
These are American men and women at whom many a compatriot looks askance.
Many investors looked askance at talking to the press.
“The police will look very askance at you if you want four or five of them,” Mr. Alpers said.

definition: supply with provisions
details: Use the verb purvey to describe the activities of businesses that supply things like food, like the bakery that purveys the best bread in the city.
examples: That frazzled mom leaning over her toddler, identifying characters and purveying snacks during a “Captain Marvel” showing in Torrance on Friday night?
Others said if you were to purvey that, people might enjoy that.”
Imperialism for the masses, the movie culture of the 1920s, purveyed romantic fantasies of an imaginary East.
The avant-garde, at least as purveyed here, is way too old hat to capture it.

definition: harshness of manner
details: Asperity is the harsh tone or behavior people exhibit when they’re angry, impatient, or just miserable. When your supervisor’s “Late again!” greeting causes your entire future to pass before your eyes, he is speaking with asperity.
examples: “Now where,” he answered with asperity, “where except in the great tea shop on the main street of the town?”
The veteran actress, she continued, "brings a certain asperity to the screen and the set" and insisted on a bottle of Prosecco at the end of each day's shooting.
He is not humorless, but he does often wear an expression of some asperity, which I took as his signature combination of German restraint and Japanese restraint.
In 1787, delegates to the Constitutional Convention agreed “to argue without asperity, and to endeavor to convince the judgment without hurting the feelings of each other.”

definition: lacking in courage, strength, and resolution
details: You can describe someone who lacks courage as pusillanimous, such as a pusillanimous student who is too afraid to speak out against someone who is bullying others.
examples: It’s basically everyone: the breathless news media, the credulous citizenry, the polarizing — and pusillanimous — elected officials in Washington.
Even pusillanimous fund managers in the UK may resist something similar here.
Perhaps this poll was an outlier, possibly its findings reflected a temporary response to Trump’s pusillanimous performance in Helsinki with Vladimir Putin.
The pusillanimous, corporate-speak testimony of several corporate executives is quoted at length — perhaps at too great a length.

definition: a disparaging remark
details: An aspersion is a disparaging remark. It almost invariably appears as a plural, following the word "cast" — when you cast aspersions on someone, you are questioning their abilities or doubting them.
examples: The clip is one of a number where Sanders is seen extolling the supposed benefits of Marxist and socialist governments, while casting aspersions on the U.S. government.
The judge stressed that he was not “casting aspersions on any elected officials,” and said that he was encouraging increased security because there was too much suspicion of the process.
Schumer instead tempered the aspersion directed at his Senate counterpart as a “blatant falsehood.”
I am not casting aspersions upon Glaser, understand.

definition: have an ambitious plan or a lofty goal
details: Does your life goal include world domination? Have an ambitious plan that involves gold medals and international fame? Then you definitely know what it means to aspire toward something big.
examples: “He was what every man should aspire to be…He put the maximum effort in everything he did.”
It’s also possible that someone who aspires to face the most me-oriented politician of all in the general election needs a certain oomph.
It’s actually a carryover from an earlier period in American history, when all aspiring lawyers “read law” rather than attend school, then took an exam to gain admission to the bar.
But the best ambient music is carefully and artfully composed; it aspires to spark personal catharsis or deep release in a listener.

definition: attack someone physically or emotionally
details: To assail is to attack or assault — with throwing stars, fists, words or, less tangibly but just as violently, with troubles or doubts.
examples: Still, other parents are fighting on, questioning the strength of the cases and assailing the credibility of the prosecution’s star witnesses and the scheme’s mastermind, William “Rick” Singer.
Many Republicans in Congress were happy to assail Medicare for all but not enthusiastic about ditching Mr. Obama’s program without a ready replacement.
In Paris, Sophie Fontanel was assailed with constant comments – I get tumbleweed.
Groups that support tougher immigration enforcement assailed the appeals court’s decision.

definition: make an effort or attempt
details: An assay is a breakdown of a material, examining the individual parts that make up the whole. When you assay a situation, you look at all the elements that created the problem in order to come up with a solution.
examples: Because molecular assays provide a limited window in which to diagnose infection, the authors opted to use serological assays to measure antibody levels at different time points.
While there is room for polishing, it looks more finished than the Washington Ballet’s earlier assays of the full-length ballets “Giselle” and “Romeo and Juliet.”
Writing in Nature, Baek et al.2 provide an example of the power of such strategies, using a combination of state-of-the-art neuroscience techniques and a creative behavioural assay in mice.
Many of these were found to be pharmacologically active in assays.

definition: agree or express agreement
details: Assent means agreement. If you nod your head in assent, you agree to something or you assent to it.
examples: It must now receive royal assent from the governor general before it becomes law.
It is expected to become law within the next few days after receiving royal assent from the governor general.
"It just felt like a blessing. It was almost as though we got royal assent for my mother's dhal," she says.
"The thing is, it should be independently reproducible — otherwise it's not science," Cox later replied, shortly before broaching a compromise that appeared to win Frampton's assent.

definition: declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true
details: Asserting is all about standing up for what you believe. You might assert an opinion, your innocence, or even your authority over someone else.
examples: Mnuchin wrote, “The Committee’s request raises serious issues concerning the constitutional scope of congressional investigative authority, the legitimacy of the asserted legislative purpose, and the constitutional rights of American citizens.”

“The committee’s request raises serious issues concerning the constitutional investigative authority, the legitimacy of the asserted legislative purpose and the constitutional rights of American citizens,” Mr. Mnuchin wrote.

Mnuchin said Neal’s request raised important questions of “constitutional scope of congressional investigative authority, the legitimacy of the asserted legislative purpose, and the constitutional rights of American citizens.”
Mr. Mnuchin said in his letter he wanted to ponder whether the “asserted legislative purpose” is valid.

definition: marked by care and persistent effort
details: If you call someone assiduous, it's a compliment. It means they're careful, methodical and very persistent. Good detectives are classically assiduous types.
examples: Butina wore many hats, presenting as a gun advocate, reporter, “daredevil” working undercover, and assiduous graduate student–depending on whom she was speaking to.
Mukasonga is a master of subtle shifts in register — a skill inherited, perhaps, from the Rwandan traditions of intricate courtesy and assiduous privacy that Stefania maintained.
Stiller was assiduous about using real people and places whenever possible.

The tone grows bitter, dismissing Justice Antonin Scalia’s opinion on the Second Amendment as “a prolonged exercise in legalistic legerdemain, or perhaps a tortured display of verbal ingenuity by an overly assiduous Scrabble player.”

definition: the process of absorbing one cultural group into another
details: Whether you’re talking about ideas or nutrients, assimilation describes the act of taking something in and absorbing it fully.
examples: Obama’s concerns over security, assimilation, and fairness fall on deaf ears among Democrats today.
In February, the spokesman for Turkey’s foreign ministry, Hami Aksoy, called the “systematic assimilation” of the Uighurs a “great shame for humanity” and urged China to close the camps.
The characters from the other world struggle with assimilation.
Many black students felt pulled in two directions — assimilation or resistance.

definition: provide physical relief, as from pain
details: If you assuage an unpleasant feeling, you make it go away. Assuaging your hunger by eating a bag of marshmallows may cause you other unpleasant feelings.
examples: But his assurance hasn’t assuaged the concerns of consumer groups.
To assuage concerns, Bridenstine held a town hall Monday and took questions from employees.
And the Church’s use of external, worldly arbiters is meant to assuage suspicions of self-protection.
“Fears of soft growth are assuaged. On the upside, the wage data does not point to further acceleration that would threaten inflation.”

definition: sour or bitter in taste
details: You know that vinegar-like liquid teens put on their faces in order to tighten their pores and dry up their pimples? That's astringent. An astringent personality, on the other hand, is perceived as bitter and perhaps even a bit toxic.
examples: If this is a melodrama — and it is, in all the obvious ways — it’s a particularly eccentric, dry-eyed and astringent one.
Well, Trump continues to be a powerful political astringent, as I like to say, and the face of politics as usual is feeling the sting, especially the ones we saw Tuesday night.
Wines are rotating, oddball and only four in number — extend your trust, and end up with something like a deeply colored Calabrian rosé that’s both fruity and astringent.
The most recent season of FXX’s astringent comedy “You’re the Worst” ended, if not with a proposal, at least with a panicked surrender to the idea of marriage.

definition: into parts or pieces
details: Asunder is an adverb that means “into separate pieces.” So if you’ve torn your ex's love letter asunder, you’ve forcefully ripped it into separate pieces — and rightly so.
examples: So when Mr. Sabraw issued his reunification ruling last June, his order covered only those families torn asunder during the six weeks in which the separations were public.
Their main desire is to complicate the Brexit debate, split their political party asunder and grossly downplay the formidable difficulties that a blunt Brexit will do to the British economy.
But let’s hope that in the end, perhaps the 11th hour, these two sides realize that it’s simply too mutually beneficial to allow this relationship to get torn asunder.
When the president was forced to choose between tearing the Senate asunder over his war with the Justice Department or pushing economic stimulus, he chose stimulus.

definition: a shelter from danger or hardship
details: When someone needs a refuge from a difficult or dangerous situation, they need asylum. If a government offers to protect people who have fled war or hardship in their own country, it gives them asylum.
examples: Sustaining Canadians’ confidence in the country’s asylum system means ensuring those who enter Canada do so according to the law, he said.
WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange was arrested today after Ecuador’s UK embassy revoked his asylum status, ending a stay of more than six years.
It is not known whether the termination of his asylum and his eviction were deliberately timed to coincide with the unsealing of the indictment.
"The asylum process is being completely taken advantage of," Crenshaw told Fox News Thursday.

definition: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic
details: Atavism is a return to a previous way of doing, saying, or seeing things. It can be casual, like wearing retro clothing and listening to vinyl records, or committed, like living in a straw hut without electricity.
examples: European unification was conceived in fear — Europeans’ fear of themselves, a residue of wars produced by various atavisms, including unhinged nationalism.
In movies, food is rarely just food — it is a way of signaling obsession and atavism, consumption and desire.
Today they are more likely to identify nationalism with xenophobia and atavism—leaving this elemental force to be captured by right-wing populists.
The result is civilization, art, music, scientific reasoning and philosophy, which often attempt to mitigate and improve on our genetic atavism.

definition: make amends for
details: To atone is to do something "right" to make up for doing something wrong. Religious believers are known to atone for their sins, but even students can atone for a past failure by acing a quiz or two.
examples: Democrats running for president in 2020 are on an “apology tour”, seeking to atone for past political sins.
Later, he took steps to atone for his misdeeds, designing a synagogue at no charge, doing work for the state of Israel and promoting the work of Jewish architects.
Numerous other Democratic candidates are atoning for their past personal and political sins with effusive apologies on a host of fronts, but Biden is striking an altogether different posture.
He somewhat atoned for his defensive mistake — and strikeouts in his three previous at-bats — with a solo home run in the seventh inning off John Means.

definition: taking heed
details: Use the adjective attentive to describe someone who is alert and paying attention: “Attentive observers of the play used clues given in the first scenes of the play to guess the identity of the murderer.”
examples: The players took ownership of the problems and became more attentive to the “habit reminders” the coaches like to drill into them, like finishing their checks.
They are well-informed, attentive, reserved, respectful, stemming from Bobby Jones' standing mandate on behavior at the Masters.
He writes that the church must be attentive to women’s “legitimate claims” for equality and must better train men and women with leadership potential.
I think journalism and fiction are both ways of being differently attentive to what’s around you.

definition: become weaker, in strength, value, or magnitude
details: Attenuate is a verb that means to make or become weaker. The effects of aging may be attenuated by exercise (or by drinking from the fountain of youth).
examples: Essentially it’s a precinct-level gathering of party faithful that serves as the first step in a long, attenuated process that eventually results in the awarding of Iowa’s presidential delegates.
The immune system’s enemies list was attenuated, largely for the good.
Sports bras may attenuate this jostling but rarely eliminate it, even in women with small breasts.
But as beats, electronics, and the like began to dominate the form, the connection between root and branch, between blues and hip-hop, became more attenuated.

definition: provide evidence for
details: To attest is to prove or declare to be true. For example: the fact that you aced the SAT attests to the strength of your vocabulary.
examples: As many of his friends and former law clerks attest, my father inspired and sometimes even helped convert by example, through what one of his former clerks, A.J.
As the intricate mosaics and monumental socialist architecture across Ukraine still attest, the country, with its engineering prowess and fertile soil, used to be a jewel in the Soviet empire.
But documents from the 18th and 19th centuries attest to thousands upon thousands of items pouring into Europe.
Dean, who recently detailed her own uncomfortable encounters with Ailes in her recent memoir “Mostly Sunny,” attested to an improved atmosphere under Scott.

definition: clothing of a distinctive style or for a particular occasion
details: The noun attire is just a formal way to say "outfit." And if you’re going outside in the middle of a blizzard, your attire should include more than a bathing suit and flip-flops.
examples: Broward Sheriff Gregory Tony says the deputy was following procedure and that properly vetting an inmate’s attire is not done in a courtroom.
Brown was typically attired in all black and typically erudite when we met last week in his apartment with sweeping views of San Francisco.
His skimpy beach attire was welcomed online by adoring fans.

Then, last fall, the diocese issued a warning to the faithful, posted online and published in the diocesan newspaper, the Tablet, declaring that Coleman was still acting as a priest and wearing clerical attire.

definition: a complex mental state involving beliefs and feelings
details: An attitude is somewhere between a belief, a stance, a mood, and a pose. If you've got an attitude about something, it can be hard to change it because you think you're right.
examples: To Wilcox, the women on her list are victims of an epidemic unseen or ignored, the result of societal attitudes that see women’s lives as the property of men.
In this paradigm, there is little room for family commitments, yet this antiquated attitude still forms the context in which modern scientist-moms must operate.
“I wasn’t aware of his attitude about those young men,” he said.
The lessons weren’t about aperture settings but attitude.

definition: a quality belonging to or characteristic of an entity
details: An attribute is a quality or characteristic given to a person, group, or some other thing. Your best attribute might be your willingness to help others, like when you stopped traffic so the duck family could cross the street.
examples: The study authors caution that given the extremely small sample size, it is “impossible to attribute causality.”
It was attributed to Tom Ferrall, who is the chairman of the Ohio Federation of College Republicans.

As Binney imagined it, ThinThread would correlate data from financial transactions, travel records, Web searches, G.P.S. equipment, and any other “attributes” that an analyst might find useful in pinpointing “the bad guys.”
The Tanzanian government attributes the outbreak to heavy rainfall.

definition: assigning to a cause or source
details: "A wise man once said..." Ever wonder who said that famous quotation? Then you're curious about its attribution. An attribution identifies a source or cause of something — in this case, the person who first said the quote.
examples: Its new attribution to Leonardo won the painting a spot in a retrospective of his work at the National Gallery in London in 2011.

In the Obama administration, female White House aides who were tired of being verbally trampled in meetings made a point of amplifying each other — immediately repeating each other’s ideas with attribution.
The question to be answered by attribution science, he said, is, “How was it affected by climate change?”
The researchers found that the average Republican and the average Democrat today suffer from a level of motive attribution asymmetry that is comparable with that of Palestinians and Israelis.

definition: disposed to venture or take risks
details: This adjective is very bold — if you are audacious, you are daring and unconventional!
examples: Mayor Pete is measured and intentional and that is currently beating audacious attempts to claim headlines.
It’s both terrible and amazing, thematically bludgeoning but audacious and emotional.
Cancer cells do not exhibit “carelessness” and are not “audacious”; there are no “choices by a cell not to perform its regular housekeeping chores” or to use T cells as “human shields”.
Of those 11 six were won by Wilfried Zaha and his ability to use his audacious dribbling skills to provoke fouls.

definition: heard or perceptible by the ear
details: Something audible can be heard. Sometimes things that people don't want others to hear become audible, such as a growling stomach during a quiet moment at the movies.
examples: Some of these sounds are audible for hundreds of kilometres.
The assistant referee spotted a fractional offside, however, and VAR backed him up to the audible disappointment of the Kop.
As with the flick of a switch, a barely audible lullaby is transformed into arresting dance music.
The checks and audibles and interviews and autographs?

definition: enlarge or increase
details: Do you need to make something bigger, better, or stronger? Then you need to augment it. To augment is to increase the amount or strength of something.
examples: One approach is to augment or bypass damaged eyes with functional prostheses.
The exhibit also features augmented reality moon walks and a “Tranquility Base” family playground with a full-scale command module and other spaceflight activities.
There is always someone saying that augmented reality is going to be the thing that is going to change everything, right?
In 1989, advertising firm Young & Rubicam submitted a plan to J&J to “initiate a high level of usage” among young women to “augment the weakening baby link.”

definition: predict from an omen
details: To augur is to predict or indicate. A black cat passing in front of you is said to augur bad luck, but if you love cats you can choose to believe that it augurs good luck instead.
examples: Another, aimed at politicians including - somewhat audaciously - his rival opposition leader Rahul Gandhi and West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, talked about how a "high turnout augurs well for our democratic fabric".
The Ravens held on for the 34-31 win, but the ingenue’s finishing kick augured a future of limitless promise.
And global aviation’s current gangbusters business environment augurs continued fast-paced growth, providing lots of wiggle room to exceed Wall Street’s cash-flow expectations.
The first month of the Gregorian calendar may augur well, too.

definition: an event indicating important things to come
details: Is your team losing 15-0? Has your girlfriend just slapped your face? Dude, these are auguries — signs of how things are going to work out in the future. And these two examples don't look good.
examples: The action is imbued with augury: the movie opens with a richly colorful sequence, of a tabletop filled with tarot cards that a fortune-teller is reading for Cleo, leaving her in despair.
Orwell adds, “I don’t think it a good augury for the future of the English language that ‘marigold’ should be dropped in favour of ‘calendula.’
As such, it is using its powers of augury to tell us to beware, to be afraid.
Their emergence was an augury of an even more dangerous development: a breakdown in international law and the slow collapse of the global order.

definition: profoundly honored
details: August is not just the eighth month of the year; it also describes something esteemed or regal. The 200-year-old newspaper covering the royal wedding might be called an august institution.
examples: “The accused is not above the law, and his prosecution and this trial should serve as precedents for all future holders of this august office,” Mr. Thomas said.
He's decided that in his august and seasoned opinion as a celebrated newsman, CNN did a remarkable job.
An innovative Seattle classic gets the august James Beard Foundation's new honor for outstanding design.
Totems, shaman figures and staffs fill the gallery like an august congregation.

definition: kindly endorsement and guidance
details: If an organization authorizes you to do a specific task, even if you don't work for them directly, you are working under their auspices. Auspices means endorsement.
examples: In a statement on Friday the UCI said it was “surprised and disappointed” by the move, insisting E-bikes are one of the disciplines under its auspices, along with road, track and BMX.

Secretary General António Guterres to spearhead efforts to declare a complex humanitarian emergency, an official designation that would trigger a major, comprehensive effort under U.N. auspices and unlock the mobilization of international resources.
In Balanchine’s case, there are a number of former dancers who, under the auspices of the Balanchine Trust, teach his ballets around the globe.
Aug 7, 2016: A national referendum approves a new constitution drafted under the auspices of the ruling junta, along with new rules governing how the prime minister is chosen.

definition: indicating favorable circumstances and good luck
details: Use the adjective auspicious for a favorable situation or set of conditions. If you start a marathon by falling flat on your face, that's not an auspicious start.
examples: Naruhito’s reign will be called Reiwa, a term with multiple meanings, including “order and peace,” “auspicious harmony” and “joyful harmony,” according to scholars quoted in the local news media.
He planned to consult a fortune teller to pick an auspicious moment to end life support.
The work was an auspicious success at its 1938 premiere in Prague.
Superstition is ubiquitous in Vietnam, and any sightings of the giant turtles are deemed auspicious.

definition: severely simple
details: The adjective austere is used to describe something or someone stern or without any decoration. You wouldn't want someone to describe you or your home as austere.
examples: There will be no adoring fans seeing her as innocent Aunt Becky from Full House, and no handlers, agents or red carpets to placate her in that austere courtroom.
Yet despite his austere reputation, he was always after a box office hit, and after the disappointing results for Barry Lyndon, Stephen King’s chiller got the nod.
This is churrasco, Brazilian barbecue, opulent and austere at once, the meat scarcely adorned and tasting only of itself, salt and fire.
“Retraining our forces to fight in an austere environment - living from your tank, from your rucksack - and readying our combat commanders is so important.”

definition: conforming to fact and therefore worthy of belief
details: The adjective authentic describes something that is real or genuine and not counterfeit. Be careful when you are buying jewelry or watches. If you are going to buy a diamond ring, you want an authentic diamond and not glass. That would be authentic glass but a fake diamond!
examples: “Who’s to say our American experience is not as authentic as an American person’s from the South? We’re sharing the culmination of everything we’ve experienced and that we define as American.”
Michael Gerson added last week that Trump’s position “reflects an authentic and alarming ignorance.”
His play only works if the party’s nativism is broad and authentic.
Rather, he let this quality emerge while emphasizing other unfamiliar but deeply authentic elements.

definition: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule
details: If your teacher orders you to detention every time you show up to class with a dull pencil, you could probably describe her as an authoritarian — a ruler who prefers order to freedom.
examples: Assange, who used to oppose authoritarian governments, instead became a stooge for Vladimir Putin's efforts to influence or distort the 2016 presidential election.

Indonesia, the world’s third-biggest democracy after India and the U.S. and a stronghold of democracy in a neighborhood of authoritarian nations, holds elections for president, Senate, and national, provincial and district legislatures on April 17.
Its targets are not foreigners but domestic minority populations who appear to threaten the Chinese Communist party’s authoritarian rule.
He sought to differentiate between “tyrants” and “authoritarian” leaders, while praising Sissi’s counterterrorism efforts in Sinai and “the way he held up religious freedom.”

definition: of recognized power or excellence
details: Speak with an authoritative tone, or no one will listen to you. Why would they, if you sound like you don't even believe in yourself? Authoritative means sure or definitive.
examples: Maybe it will teach them how dumb it is to consider Facebook more authoritative than the CDC or The New York Times.
Mr. Brill is a refreshingly unmannered Ali Hakim, and Ms. Testa is a splendid, wryly authoritative Aunt Eller.
Reporters deem him “authoritative and logical and very young,” noting that he’s “at the forefront of a new crop of political leaders.”
Abel says the websites sparking her initial fears of inflammatory breast cancer appeared authoritative.

definition: operate or make run by machines rather than human action
details: When you design a machine to complete a process once done by a human, you automate the process. Standardized tests once had to be graded by hand, now they're automated, i.e. done by computers.
examples: Twitter told Fox News Thursday that the page was not directly targeted but was erroneously caught in its automated system.
Some Alexa reviewers are tasked with transcribing users’ commands, comparing the recordings to Alexa’s automated transcript, or annotating the interaction between user and machine.

"To hold algorithms to a higher standard than human decisions implies that automated decisions are inherently less trustworthy or more dangerous than human ones, which is not the case," he said in a statement.
The company also developed programmes for automating the transcription and translation of Uighur voice messaging.

definition: existing as an independent entity
details: Autonomous describes things that function separately or independently. Once you move out of your parents' house and get your own job, you will be an autonomous member of the family.
examples: Uber abruptly left the state when one of its autonomous vehicle hit and killed a woman, and Theranos was accused by federal regulators of duping investors about the accuracy of its blood tests.
“You need to be able to explain what your algorithm does if you want it to be autonomous.”
Many of the up to 100,000 Tibetans living in India fear their fight for a genuinely autonomous homeland would end with the Dalai Lama.
Or is it an expression of autonomous will, a right that must be accepted – even aided?

definition: reprehensible acquisitiveness; insatiable desire for wealth
details: Avarice is a fancy word for good old-fashioned greed. It's one of what some call "the seven deadly sins."
examples: “I felt this to be an unfortunate case of simple avarice,” said Levin.
Along the way, “Hummingbird” offers cogent commentary on the way unbridled avarice drives the search for even the smallest advantage in the cutthroat world of high finance.
And then Santiago appeals to their avarice, souring things.
Some people’s avarice extends to hoarding the food for later, ignoring that it’s generally only intended to feed you while you’re at work:

definition: take action in return for a perceived wrong
details: If you avenge your father's death by killing his murderer (thereby taking revenge for the crime), there is a good chance you'll end up in jail, if you're caught.
examples: Karen presents herself to the reader as an avenging angel on behalf of the truth, armed to the teeth with weaponized, therapy-derived insight.
On the other side, lone-wolf Islamist killers in the West say they are avenging invasions of their homelands and preventing the extermination of their fellow Muslims.
Virginia avenged last year’s first-round humiliation, but, to truly finish the redemption story, the Cavaliers must contend with yet another underdog in Auburn.
In advancing, the Huskies avenged a regular-season loss to the Cardinals.

definition: declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true
details: To aver is to state something or declare something is true. This verb has a serious tone, so you might aver something on a witness stand or you might aver that you won't back down to a challenge.
examples: “Let’s say I was acquainted with a lot of different ladies at that time of my life,” the smarmy Nick avers.
All of these subjects, Schiff averred, were fair game for investigation by the committee that he will soon chair.
Furyk wouldn’t tip his hand as to whether the four will see action in afternoon foursomes, but it seems likely when he avers that all 12 of his players are rounding into form.
“People want to talk about what is going on in the world in a non-ironic way,” Paul avers.

definition: a feeling of intense dislike
details: If you have an aversion to something, you have an intense dislike for it. Commonly it's food, but you could have an aversion to black and white movies, driving with the windows open, or taking calls from salespeople.
examples: “They were the most horrendous films: concentration camps, bodies stacked up. He was thinking of using them in the treatment sequence, where Alex is given aversion therapy.”
“Pound trading is characterised by turmoil and risk aversion resulting in wide ranges and largely directionless markets proving to be generally unprofitable for systematic strategies,” Scott said.
Two hallmarks of American economic policy under President Trump are a reflexive aversion for regulation and go-it-alone nationalism.
He was thinking of using them in the treatment sequence, where Alex is given aversion therapy.

definition: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
details: Avid usually means very eager or enthusiastic. If you're an avid reader, it means you read as much as you can, whenever you can.
examples: The homeowners are avid birdwatchers, and the gilded paper reflects a variety of flora and fauna that are indigenous to the region.
My advice: Become an avid reader of ingredients.
That means a smaller contingent of the most avid wine lovers are posting the majority of reviews and ratings.
Rose Marie Bentley was an avid swimmer, raised five children, helped her husband run a feed store and lived to 99.

definition: an auxiliary activity
details: An avocation is an activity that you pursue when you're not at work — a hobby. Pretty much anything can be an avocation: tennis, sudoku, writing poetry. If you're the journalist Clark Kent, your avocation is changing into a skintight red and blue jumpsuit and fighting crime.
examples: This predilection for early decisions applied to avocations as well.
Birdwatchers, generally quiet by avocation, thrive on the specifics of avian habit.
“I tell people this, and believe this, my vocation and avocation are the same thing. Both are sports broadcasting,” he said.
Paul keeps other avocations in his sights, including his younger pursuits of painting and film editing.

definition: resembling an uncle in kindness or indulgence
details: Everyone likes an avuncular guy, that is someone who is kind and patient and generally indulgent with people younger than he is. The Dalai Lama is an avuncular fellow. So is Santa Claus. Unless you haven't been good.
examples: For millions he remains that avuncular figure who accompanied a dignified President Obama through eight years.
Libraries bare Gabo’s name, and his avuncular, mustachioed face features on the country’s 50,000 peso banknote, as well as works by Bogotá’s myriad graffiti artists.
But Mr. Xi, 65, appears to be dispensing with vanity as he presents himself as a relatable and avuncular leader, part of his efforts to soften his hard-line policies.
Mr. Lee remained an avuncular and beloved advocate of comic books and his own business ventures well into his 90s, attending fan conventions until recently even as his health appeared to decline.

definition: an overwhelming feeling of wonder or admiration
details: Awe is a feeling of fear that is mixed with respect and wonder. You might gaze at the Grand Canyon with awe, marveling at its beauty and fearing its depth.
examples: During those last 15 months, I was awed by his courage.
It needs a smart, inventive basketball mind not awed by the history of the place and is not beholden to anyone living there.
Atlas conveys the awe and admiration he felt for Roth, “the most charismatic person I’ve ever known, the largest presence, the funniest, the most brilliant, the most profound.”
There I found myself looking with awe at the fossilized bones of an ancient paddlefish.

definition: a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof
details: An axiom is a statement that everyone believes is true, such as "supply equals demand" or "the only constant is change." Mathematicians use axiom to refer to established proofs.
examples: He is a believer in the axiom that you use the first 60 or so games to assess your ballclub and react accordingly.
But, for N.B.A. players, that postmodern axiom is much more real than it is for most of us.
He goes against the ol’ axiom of “don’t equate more with better.”
The old axiom of former House Speaker Tip O’Neill that “all politics is local” no longer applies.
